abstract: Mackey, A. G.; Reception at Newark, N. J.
snippet: Mackey, A. G.; Reception at Newark, N. J.
lead_paragraph: Maj.-Gen. SHERMAN yesterday bade farewell to the gallant armies that have followed him from victory to victory over a field almost as wide as our country. In plain, blunt, soldier-like words he briefly alludes to the leading features of their career, rejoices over the glorious termination of their work; hopes and believes that as they have been good soldiers they will be equally good citizens; warns them against filibustering temptations, and closes by saying that if the day should come when war should once more be inevitable, "SHERMAN's army" would be the first to reassume the arms they are now laying down, and stand foremost in defence of the government of their country.

abstract: The steamship Persia arrived last evening from Liverpool, with advices to the 21st via Queenstown. Her continental news is unimportant; but she brings some strange rumors concerning the relations between the United States and the government of JUAREZ. According to one report, Senor ROMERO had made arrangements with contractors in New-York and California for a loan of $25,000,000; another rumor was that JUAREZ was to be allowed to recruit from Gen. SHERMAN's army of veterans, which had been marched up to Washington for that purpose! These absurd rumors, among others of the same character, created much disturbance in the markets. It was reported that the Emperor NAPOLEON had been hastily recalled from Algeria, in consequence of apprehended trouble between France and the United States; that MAXIMILIAN had been shot, &c. The offer of a reward for the apprehension of JEFF. DAVIS caused a great excitement, and awakened the special wrath of the rebel sympathizing press of France and England, by which the act is denounced as infamous.

abstract: Morse, Calvin S.; Particulars
snippet: Morse, Calvin S.; Particulars
lead_paragraph: THE SUICIDE ON BOARD THE NORTH CAROLINA. -- An inquest was held yesterday with the view of inquiring into the death of CALVIN S. MORSE, who committed suicide on board the United States receiving-ship North Carolina on Saturday night last. A number of witnesses were examined, from which it appears that deceased had formerly kept a saloon in a questionable neighborhood in Washington, D.C., and becoming tired of his associations there, both male and female, and especially the latter, he sold out and came to New-York. He subsequently shipped in the navy as a landsman, and, in consequence of his intelligence, was assigned to a position in the Paymaster's office, which position he filled with satisfaction to his superior officer. For some days previous to the fatal deed, it was noticed that he was troubled in mind, and from some expressions it was understood that he believed himself implicated in the assassination of ABRAHAM LINCOLN. On the day previous to putting an end to his existence he asked several to feel the region of his heart, and one or two accommodated him, and by that means he evidently ascertained the exact location of that organ. After retiring to his room he shot himself through the heart with a pistol. No one on board appears to have heard the report and his dead body was not discovered till morning. Among his effects were letters from Senator FOSTER of Connecticut, and Senator HARRIS of New-York, urgently recommending him to an appointment on the Government detective force. Also, several letters from a female named LOUISE M. WESTON, of Washington, D.C. After the evidence had concluded the jury retired. The majority brought in a verdict that deceased came to his death by deliberately shooting himself with a pistol while laboring under temporary abberation of mind. The verdict of the minority of the jury was to the effect that deceased came to his death by a pistol-shot wound, but for what motive unknown to them. Coroner LYMAN accepted the majority verdict, and the jury was discharged.

abstract: The steamship Eagle, Capt. LAURENCE, arrived yesterday afternoon, bringing dates of 27th, and correspondence to 1 P.M. of that day. Mr. R.W. ALBERT, the purser of the ship, extends to us the usual facilities and the following memoranda: The United States steamer Sunflower, Commodore LORING, arrived on the 24th from Key West. The Powhattan arrived the same day and left on the 26th on a cruise. The United States steamer Wyanda, with Chief Justice CHASE and party on board, arrived on the 25th, and would leave on the 27th for Matanzaz. The steamer Ella Morse, from Key West, arrived on the morning of the 27th, and would leave the same day to join Secretary CHASE and party. The steamship Havana, GREEN, from New-York, arrived on the 26th, to leave June 1. The steamship Corsica, LE MESSURIER, arrived the same day, to leave June 4.

lead_paragraph: The New-York Conference of the African M.E. Church reassembled at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. A large number of reports on the progress of the churches embraced by the conference, and the Sunday-Schools attached to them, were read and approved. A communication in relation to the education of colored children in the ward and other schools of the city was read, asking that the conference will exert its influence, through its ministers, in having the schools filled to their utmost capacity. The communication was approved. A report of the Committee on Education was presented, recommending the conference to use all its influence to promote the cause of education among old and young. The report was approved, and it was then announced that to-day being appointed as a day of humiliation, the conference would adjourn over to Friday.

It would, however, have possessed more value as a historical record, and, we venture to think, would have done more justice to Gen. abstract: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- Few of the old comedies possess more interest than the "Heir at Low," by GEORGE COLEMAN, and this, too, despite the utter impossibility of the plot, and the extravagance of the dialogue. The wit of the latter is always forced, but it is, fortunately, still wit -- clear, genuine and decisive. The piece was selected for performance last evening somewhat precipitately, but the actors were all excellent, and they were fortunate in having and audience that could fully appreciate their efforts. LESTER WALLACK, we are sorry say, is still exceedingly sick. He has been peremptorily prohibited by his physician from appearing on the stage.
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- Few of the old comedies possess more interest than the "Heir at Low," by GEORGE COLEMAN, and this, too, despite the utter impossibility of the plot, and the extravagance of the dialogue. abstract: Fast; the Calamity and the Blessing
snippet: Fast; the Calamity and the Blessing
lead_paragraph: The President's proclamation calling for the devotion of this day to national humiliation, in view of the great national affiction, will be everywhere responded to with heartfelt solemnity. It is true that the people have already mourned, as no people ever mourned before for the loss of a leader. It is true that the hand of Providence, in permitting the dreadful blow, has everywhere been recognized. Yet all that has been expressed hitherto has been the natural prompting of each individual heart. The manifestation of feeling has been purely popular -- the same, differing in degree only, as that which has so widely displayed itself in other lands. The nation, in its national capacity, has yet to signalize its sense of the bereavement, and to bow itself humbly before high Heaven. Nothing could be more appropriate than this supplementing all the varied expressions of popular grief with such a national act of confession and homage as this day will present.

abstract: And the War; the Untrodden Domain of the South; Changes of North and South; Stonewall, Pirate; French Builder Claims Compensation; To Retain their Muskets; Financial Excitement in Europe about
snippet: And the War; the Untrodden Domain of the South; Changes of North and South; Stonewall, Pirate; French Builder Claims Compensation; To Retain their Muskets; Financial Excitement in Europe about
lead_paragraph: Of all the States of the Southern Confederacy, the State of Texas has suffered the least -- immeasurably the least -- by the war. The whole State of Virginia, from the seaboard to the mountains, has been fought over and trampled by contending armies, until all its material and moral interests were completely prostrated. In North Carolina, the line of the seaboard has been a battle-line for over three years, the central parts of the State have been traversed by SHERMAN's army, and the western parts have been raided over by our cavalry. South Carolina, seacoast and centre, has been utterly blasted by the war. Georgia has been fought over, from Ringgold to Savannah. Florida and Alabama have been visited in nearly all their parts by our forces, and their limited strength has been used up. Mississippi fell under the power of GRANT and SHERMAN. Tennessee has been one vast battle-field, from Memphis to Knoxville, from Fort Donelson and Nashville to Chattanooga. Louisiana, in all its parts, has been scoured by our armies, and Arkansas has suffered all it could bear. The Border States of Missouri, Kentucky, Western Virginia and Maryland, have all also experienced profoundly the horrors of war.
headline: {'main': 'Texas and the War The Untrodden Domain of the South.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Texas and the War The Untrodden Domain of the South.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: London Saturday Review on the NEW-YORK TIMES and Jeff. Davis; London Saturday Review on the N. Y. TIMES
snippet: London Saturday Review on the NEW-YORK TIMES and Jeff. Davis; London Saturday Review on the N. Y. TIMES
lead_paragraph: The London Saturday Review is seriously out of temper with the New-York TIMES. It gives it credit for being the representative journal of the United States. It regards its exposition of political questions as "orthodox"and "authoritative." It holds the TIMES to be both a "responsible" and a "respectable" journal. But it complains that such a journal should offer insults to Gen. LEE; that it should propose the hanging of DAVIS; and that it should be "malignant in its bearing both to foreign Powers and to domestic enemies." The charge is thus laid:

abstract: Vinton, Rev. Dr., Sermon on Day of Humiliation
snippet: Vinton, Rev. Dr., Sermon on Day of Humiliation
lead_paragraph: Trinity Church was filled with an attentive and appreciative audience. The solemn and impressive services of the Episcopal Church were rendered more so by the occasion that called them forth, and also by reason of the change which Bishop POTTER had directed should be made in them. Instead of the Anthem, "Venite Exultemus Domino," Psalm exxx., "De Profundis Clamavi," was chanted in the most solemn manner. At the end of the Litany, and immediately before the General Thanksgiving, the Prayer for a Person under Affliction was said, the phrase "sorrows of thy servants," being altered to "sorrows of the people of this land." At the conclusion of the preliminary service Dr. VINTON preached from the following text:

abstract: In pursuance to orders lately issued by the Adjutant-General of the State, injections of the various militia regiments are being held nearly every every evening. On Monday the Eleventh and Eight Regiments were inspected. The Eighth has always ranked high for its proficiency in drill and admirable appearance. The number turned out was 377 muskets and 39 officers -- absent, neatly 160 men -- and thus the aggregate strength of the regiment cannot be far from 600 rank and file. Maj. HARRIOTT, Brigade Inspector, performed the important duty of inspection.

abstract: No national day of fasting, we believe, has ever been more generally, or more solemnly, or more discreetly observed than yesterday. There were in this city -- as there naturally would be in other great cities -- large numbers of holiday-makers, who neglected to join the multitude of worshipers. But there wire no boisterous merry-makings. All the churches and places of worship, Protestant, Roman Catholic and Jewish, were well attended. And the prevailing tone of the public exercises was generally in excellent harmony with the saddening events of which the fast was a recognition. An incident in the solemnities of the day deserves emphatic mention. The rebel prisoners (rank and file) on Hart's Island made special interest with the military authorities to be permitted the privilege of joining in the religious observances. And -- the request being granted -- the poor delinquents mustered to the number of twenty-five hundred, and reverently took part in the solemnities of the appointed worship. The act may well help to obliterate the record of many public misdeeds.

abstract: Duke de Persigny on
snippet: Duke de Persigny on
lead_paragraph: The most supple and convenient instrument of French Imperialism since the death of the Duke DE MORNY is the Duke DE PERSIGNY. At the head of the police his services were often invaluable whenever the freedom of opinion or of election had to be curbed. It seems, however, from the latest Paris news that PERSIGNY is to appear in a new role -- one altogether outside of his old official character. He has, in short, turned author, like his imperial master; modern instead of ancient Home being his theme. He predicts the perfect liberation and unity of Italy, as the certain result of French intervention. If he could predict as much for the country that supports him as the result of imperialism, he would do more to earn his wages. PERSIGNY's plan for Italy is to perfect the reconciliation between the Papacy and VICTOR EMMANUEL, and then set on foot a scheme for the purchase of Venetia. France, of course, would take stock, as she has done in Mexico. And to France, of course, would belong the glory, besides a few mortgages, probably, on convenient provinces. The Napoleonic ideas are too valuable to be distributed gratis.

I thank you very kindly indeed. Good night."

abstract: JOHN HECKER, late a soldier in GRANT's army, made oath that on Wednesday evening he was sitting at the entrance of the Sailors' Home, in Cherry-street, when ROBERT ROGERS and PATRICK MACK invited him to enter; that he took a room in the house, and in the morning was unable to find either his money or his clothing; and that he heard ROGERS and MACK tell the landlord, THOMAS CASSIDY, that they had "been through him and found nothing." Upon this complaint MACK and ROGERS were apprehended by Policeman KAISER, of the Seventh Ward, and committed by Justice SHANDLEY.

abstract: The attendance at the Seventh-street M.E. Church, yesterday, was quite large, the pastor of the church, Rev. F. BOTTOME, acting as chairman.
lead_paragraph: Rev. Dr. CROOKS, on being introduced, repeated part of Mr. LINCOLN's farewell address, delivered at the time of leaving his homo in 1861, and part of his last, inaugural, and then said, that between those two extremes, separated from one another by four brief years, there was condensed a career, probably the most remarkable of any occurring during our entire history; one whose closing calamity was so touching as to be felt to the very verge of civilization. We were assembled to express, as well as we could, our conception of that calamity, and to draw some lessons from the mysterious providence which has befallen our nation. There was, evidently, a function to be performed by our great men in society; so great that we regard it as an inexpressible calamity when God takes from the nation the man by whom it was to be performed. A new theory had arisen, and it might be designated as Caesarism. It assumes that great men are the representatives of Providence, and have a divine right to rule; that they are the Messiahs of the human race, and men rejecting their counsels are as criminal as were the Jews who rejected the Divine Son of God. It followed, as a corrollary of this theory, that a great man was a law to himself, and he was bound to obey nothing but his own impulses. Were constitutions in the way of his destiny, then must they fall and be trampled under foot. To such men institutions were but fictions, and to them God had given the promise of restoration, and the duty of the world was to submit to their will. It was a singular coincidence, that just the hour which had given us a clear exposition of Caesarism was the hour which completed the career of the lowly ABRAHAM LINCOLN, whose life was a refutation of this monstrous error, whose whole career was a demonstration of its falsity, and a typical manifestation of human character. While the Emperor NAPOLEON, under the guise of national history, was teaching the world its error in rejecting his predecessor -- his great model, while, at the same time, one of England's greatest historians was presenting to us the career of FREDERICK the Great, the king who rejected the vain babblings of men because he was infinitely raised above them, the lowly, the loving, the upright, the conscientious ABRAHAM LINCOLN, who was a refutation of this fake syllogism, appears and passes over the stage of human history, drawing to him all the eyes of mankind and followed to his grave by the tears of the whole world. No Caesar ever received such triumphal honors; no Caesar was ever so bewailed; none ever drew such tributes from mankind as civilization hastened to place upon the lowly tomb of ABRAHAM LINCOLN. We, then, had an opposite, a contradictory theory of the functions of great men. It was that great men are the exponents of the people -- the guardians of the trust reposed in them by a people concious of its destiny and able to attain it. Under the former theory the Caesar represented only the man; under the latter one the leader represented the people from whose bosom he came. A Caesar would acknowledge no law but his own impulses; a true leader would recognize the people as the source from which he sprang, that all just government is of the people, and by the people and for the people. Mr. LINCOLN had some principles which we did not then appreciate. His first axiom was, "The American people must save themselves." The second was a fitting complement of the first, "The American people can and will save themselves." He had not the vanity or ambition of a great deliverer, and no act of his suggested any attempt in that direction. He only wanted to know the duty of the hour, and was fully resolved to know it. Believing that with the people the solution of this great problem rested, knowing that they would at last decide the course which was wise to be chosen, listening ever to their voices, he was, consequently, slow, but he was slow because it was his province; nay, it was his principle ever to keep step with the people. He would never move forward until they were ready to move with him, and when he did advance there were millions to meet him, and as their footsteps rose and fell the very earth was shaken. It was that that gave our President his wondrous power. The heart-throbs of ABRAHAM LINCOLN were those of the whole American people; the feet of ABRAHAM LINCOLN were those that moved forward twenty millions of loyal citizens. His was not the power of a Caesar, not the power that gives, from the recesses of the heart, plans which none can know, but the power which drank in its inspiration from the hearts of the common masses, and this inspiration seemed next to that which came from Heaven for all them in the way of duty and of truth. In some respects he cast aside all the time-honored precedents of his position; not merely a few chosen political guides, but the every-day men were intimate with him. He was not above being counseled and he was counseled. Whenever before did ministers have such an audience as the President of the United States? The merchant, the farmer and the plain laboring man, all had access to that lowly mind. He debated questions with the nation and was the only President who ever fairly and frankly did so; and showed most clearly that while receiving impressions he was likewise giving them. A philosopher has told us that if every man had a window in his breast the world would see strange things, but God did make one man thus, and every man [???] the lines, yet only one lesson: "Duty to God, duty to the people, with malice toward none, with charity for all, with firmness in the right as God give us to see it." Like all great men, Mr. LINCOLN had a large humanity and was the finest [???] character. Though marshaling armies to decide the destiny of the nation, he never forgot the under humanities of life. In one corner of his desk he kept somehow works tending to show the humorous side of the struggle through which was were passing, and when worn out by toil he would indulge in a genial laugh. It was never heard that JEFF. DAVIS ever burst out in a wholesome genial laugh. When appealed to on the tender side of his nature, the appeal never came in vain. His head was now among the stars, and

abstract: Cry of Negro Suffrage or Repudiation
snippet: Cry of Negro Suffrage or Repudiation
lead_paragraph: speech in Boston, in which he says that if the negro is not allowed to vote in the Southern States, the war will be proved to have been a gigantic robbery of property and life, and that a "party which would go for a repudiation of the entire war debt would have his voice and vote until God called him home." His cry, last December, was "negro suffrage or no Union;" now it is "negro suffrage or repudiation." He changes his cry, we suppose, because disunion is no longer a possibility, and therefore can no longer be made an alternative.

abstract: THE PATERSON, N.J., SPRING MEETING.  The Spring meeting of the Passaic Country Agricultural Society commences at their private grounds, at Paterson, N.J., on Tuesday next, and will be continued on the two following days, in accordance with their programme published in another column, which is affluent in sport of the most varied and first-class description there being no possibility of ...
lead_paragraph: postponement on account of the weather, hence there can be no disappointment. The Paterson association in composed entirely of high-toned gentlemen, intent only on the improvement of the breed of the race-horse, and with whom financial success is quite a secondary consideration. We all remember the intense satisfaction the Spring and Fall meetings of last year gave both to the sporting world and the general public, who, for the first time saw a race-course conducted on the same scale of liberality, even-handed justice, strict determination to preserve decorum and exclude all improper characters, as in England, where racing is supported as a legitimate pastime by the best and noblest in the land. The result was that racing received a tone and impetus it had never previously enjoyed in our midst, and that impetus made itself felt subsequently at Saratoga, whilst it resulted in truly mammoth entries for the various stakes, of the best racing stock in the land, from every section of the United States. The Paterson management this year is identical with that of last and the same admirable management will prevail; while, from the public experience of the past, the attendance cannot fail to be proportionately increased. The delightful drive by the Paterson Plank-road will tempt thousands who possess or who can engage vehicles, while the excellent railroad arrangements enable pedestrians to reach the course in a few minutes with ease and comfort.

abstract: At Hart's Island yesterday, the day was observed in the prison camp by the suspension of the rules requiring marching for exercise, and by religious services in the forenoon, conducted by Rev. ROBERT LOWRY, Chaplain U.S.A. He was invited by Gen. WESSELLS at the suggestion of the prisoners themselves, who had seen the President's proclamation for a day of humiliation and prayer, and wished to observe it. Nearly 2,000 of them were gathered in the centre of the grounds, which cover four and a half acres, and gave good attention to the preaching and prayers, and joined in the singing. After the exercises several pressed forward to shake hands with the Chaplain, who had known him when they were prisoners in David's Island Hospital. Several of the squads also held prayer meetings at S.A.M. and in the evening. The papers, hymn books, tracts and testaments, of which a liberal supply have been placed in their bands by the agents of the American Tract Society and New-York Bible Society, are very much prized, and will mostly be preserved and taken home with them. Whether sitting within their comfortable barracks or outside, or walking around the ground, many are constantly reading these. They hope soon to be sent home. The hospital is located in a fine airy position outside the camp.

abstract: Prospects, the Great Question of
snippet: Prospects, the Great Question of
lead_paragraph: There are two main questions of immediate interest: First, as to the amount of marketable cotton now in the Southern States; second, as to the facilities for getting it from the interior to the seaports and thence to the markets of the world. There are other points of importance, such as the probable price it will command, the amount of the staple that can be immediately absorbed by Europe, the influence of the export on commercial exchanges, on our finances and industries, the effect of slavery-abolition on the future growth of cotton, etc. But these latter are speculative questions, and their solution must be left to the future.

abstract: the Elephant, Death of
snippet: the Elephant, Death of
lead_paragraph: A numerous audience was assembled at Irving Hall last evening to hear the lecture of Rev. W.H. MILBURN on "The Future of the Republic." The lecturer began with long and elaborate references to the observance of the day, to the character of Mr. LINCOLN and to his public career; from which ho drew the lesson that our national policy should continue to be marked by such kind-heartedness and reluctance to inflict pain as Mr. LINCOLN's. This was followed by a sketch of the origin of the Federal Constitution, and of the two political doctrines of Federal Unionism and State Sovereignty, and of the effects of slavery in determining the character of Southern political belief, and in causing the rebellion itself; and there then followed some brief characterization of the features of the struggle, and of its effects upon our national character.

abstract: Peter R. Strong vs. Mary E. Strong. -- A motion was made in this action, yesterday morning, before Justice GARVIN, at Special Term, to resettle the issues involved herein, and to set aside the order settling such issues, made in October last; these are the issues raised by the pleading previous to the putting in of the supplemental answer by the defendant. After hearing counsel for both parties, the motion was denial, and the cause ordered to be placed on the day calendar for next Monday, before Chief Justice Robertson, for trial.

abstract: Gen. W.T. SHERMAN arrived in this city yesterday morning, at 7 o'clock, and immediately proceeded to the residence of his entertainer, JAMES SCOTT, Esq., No. 64 East Twenty-third-street. The General kept himself quite secluded and quiet the better part of the day, but rode in a carriage to the Central Park during the afternoon, and his presence created considerable excitement among the thousands congregated there. Gen. SHERMAN was accompanied by members of Mr. SCOTT'S family.
lead_paragraph: In the vicinity of Mr. SCOTT's residence in Twenty-third-street, small knots of eager people could be seen all day and evening, perforce content to satisfy their curiosity by a view of the outside of the dwelling. Last night the house was brilliantly lighted up, and many visitors passed in and out.

abstract: ROBBERY BY HOUSEKEEPER. -- A woman named MARY CANNON, employed as a housekeeper by Mrs. MARY BROGAN, No. 91 Gold-street, was arrested on Wednesday evening, on the charge of stealing $151 in greenbacks. The accused had been left in charge of the house for a short time, and on the return of Mrs. BROGAN she found that the money had been abstracted from her trunk. An officer was summoned, and the bills were found pinned in the shawl worn by the accused. She was committed for a hearing.

abstract: That unfortunate old man. FOOTE, of Tennessee, fails utterly to find that repose in some "sequestered spot" which he set out from Richmond, six months ago, to search for. From Richmond to Washington, thence beyond the seas to London and Paris, thence back across the stormy main to New-York, thence northward to Montreal over half a world has the "old...
lead_paragraph: man rampant" wearily pursued his purpose, but only, at each successive place, to discover its vanity. In Montreal, he had hardly got himself located in a "private boardinghouse, a mile from either of the great hotels," where he desired to "live in the greatest seclusion," and "devote his hours exclusively to meditation and literary pursuits," before he felt compelled to publish a long and painfully rhetorical defence against the assaults of his enemies. These enemies had circulated that FOOTE was "shunned alike by Southerner and Yankee," had published him as the "Benedict Arnold of the South," and had not scrupled to designate him as "Hangman FOOTE." As to his being a shunned man, he was not aware of it; as to his being an Arnold, he denies it; but as to the infliction of the epithet "Hangman," he woefully confesses the justice and terrible character of the punishment. These are his words:

abstract: A STREET FIGHT -- THOMAS MAHON, a willow-ware ware manufacturer in Montgomery-street, Jersey City, was taken before Recorder MARTINDALE, yesterday, charged with having, late on the night previously engaged in a rough and tumble light in the street and committing an assault and battery on Officer MANNING. The officer was pitched down a stairway head first, and narrowly escaped serious injury; and also had his coat torn off. MAHON was fined $2, and was required to make a deposit for the purchase of new coat.

abstract: O'Brien, Consignment of Coal Case
snippet: O'Brien, Consignment of Coal Case
lead_paragraph: lying in Port Carbon, and bound for Fifth-street, East River, New-York, agreed to carry the coal and deliver it at the said port of New-York to F. Wagner, or his assigns. Wagner having declined to receive the shipment, the shipper's agent sold the bill of lading to the claimant, Bonnell, who sent word to the Captain of the boat at New-Brunswick, before her arrival in New-York; that he was to deliver the coal at Crose' Dock, Brooklyn, to Mr. Husted. The Captain went accordingly to Cross' Dock, and notified Husted of his readiness to receive the coal, but Husted said he had not ordered the coal. This was on Saturday. On Monday morning, the Captain saw the agent of the shippers, who referred him to Bonnell. On his going to see Bonnell, the latter told him that Husted would receive the coal, and that he was to discharge it at Cross' Dock. The Captain made no objection to Bonnell; but at 1:30 P.M. on Monday, without notifying Bonnell, he took his boat from Cross' Dock to Fifth-street, East River, and tendered the coal to Wagner, who refused to receive it. He then libeled the coal while yet on board of his vessel without giving any notice to Bonnell, who knew nothing of these proceedings till about a week after, when he found his coal where it had been stored by the Marshal, and was compelled to pay $145 expenses of landing and storing the coal in order to get possession of it.

abstract: The last of the light-draught, monitors at this port, the Cohocs, was successfully launched on Wednesday, at 2:30 o'clock P.M., at Greenpoint. A considerable number of citizens, with their ladies, were present. Among the celebrities we noticed Commodore RINGOLD, Engineer HALL, Engineer CUNNINGHAM; the eminent shipbuilder, Mr. UNDERHILL; Engineer THOMAS, Inspector C.T. BETTS and Mr. ROWLAND. Mr. M.F. MERRITT was the contractor for the vessel, Mr. ROWLAND doing the iron-work, and Mr. WHITELOCK the wood-work. The engines were built by HEWS & PHILIPS, Newark, N.J. Her capacity is registered at 614 tons, having one turret, with two lari[???] guns. Length of vessel, 225, feet; breadth, 45 feet; and depth of Lold, 11 feet. She has been raised 22 inches so as to present more side surface above the water-line. Like all the light-draught monitors, she has the enter hull of five inches of iron, separated bywater-tight compartments from the inner wooden hull, which is about four feet thick. Upon being launched she was towed up alongside of the ocean member Puritan, which has remained in statu quo for nearly a year, owing to the dilatory action of Congress. It will be remembered that the Cohocs was one of a class of twenty vessels, whose original design the Navy Department was compelled to alter. Five were altered into torpedo-boats, having no turret, and the remaining fifteen, of which the Cohocs is one, had their decks raised twenty-two inches, besides minor alterations. The cost of alteration into the five torpedo-vessels was cost $50,000 to $60,000 each; while the [???] of the nation in raising decks, &c., of the remaining fifteen, was from $[???]0,000 to $10[???],000 each.

abstract: Day of Humiliation, Observances of; Storrs, Rev. Dr., Oration on Day of Humiliation; Stranahan, J. S. T., Address on Day of Humiliation
snippet: Day of Humiliation, Observances of; Storrs, Rev. Dr., Oration on Day of Humiliation; Stranahan, J. S. T., Address on Day of Humiliation
lead_paragraph: quiet settled upon these great centres of life and commercial activity, proving that the events which six weeks since, almost paralyzed the hearts of our citizens, caused no ephemeral sorrow, but a deep and poignant grief, which time, perhaps, has softened, but has obliterated. Regardless of sectarianism, all the churches, Protestant, Catholic and Jewish opened wide their doors, and thousands of devout worshipers assembled to listen to the suggestions of counsel and words of comfort naturally growing out of a contemplation of the public and private character of the good man now sleeping quietly at Springfield, whose mourners are numbered by millions in both the New World and the Old. We surrender a great deal of space this morning to sketches of some of the discourses delivered by the clergy, which, we trust, may be read with interest and profit.

abstract: HOME MISSIONS. On Tuesday evening the City Mission held a meeting in the Cannon-street Baptist Church, Mr. A.R. WETMORE in the chair. Missionaries from the Third, Fifth, Sixth, Eleventh, Fourteen and Seventeenth Wards were called upon, who spoke briefly of their experiences and observations.
lead_paragraph: giving touching accounts of poverty, ignorance and wretchedness, and showing the success of efforts made to enlighten, reclaim, relieve and elevate. The value of tenement-house services, mission meetings, and the other instrumentalities employed, was frequently illustrated. The pastor of the church, Rev. Mr. FULLER, in a few earnest words, commended the cause as an undispensable agency for the welfare of the poor, and encouraged the laborers to persevere. In the tabled results we find the following figures; 3,513 missionary visits; 328 meetings; 13 temperance pledges; 240 persons to church; 229 children and oaths to day and Sabbath schools; 92 Bibles and Testaments and 76,210 [???]cts distributed.

abstract: The calendar was unusually large yesterday morning, embracing sixty defendants, and sixty-four complainants and witnesses, the design of the Commissioners being to clear everything up before fastday. Among the witnesses who appeared by request were His Honor Justice WILLIAM DODGE and GEORGE W. DILKS, Esq., Inspector of Police; and among the visitors was Mr. FARRON, of Detroit.
lead_paragraph: ANN MARIA EDELMAN, of No. 541 Pearl-street, stated her grievances briefly by charging that Patrolman THOMAS HARTY, of the City Hall Police, struck her in the face with a switch, while she was walking with her child in the Park on Sunday, the 20th ult. The testimony of the officer was, that he bade the child desist from plucking shrubs near the fountain, and that he merely ordered the mother and child to keep off the grass, but did not use the switch. Policeman MCWATERS deposed that he witnessed the entire transaction, and that if the officer had indulged in any violence,it could not have escaped his attention; he made oath positively that the accused did not make use of a switch. The complaint was thereupon dismissed.

abstract: Debt, and Mr. B. Noyes' Letter; on Paying the National Debt
snippet: Debt, and Mr. B. Noyes' Letter; on Paying the National Debt
lead_paragraph: Mr. BENJAMIN NOYES of New Haven writes us a letter which we publish in another column, in favor of paying off the National Debt by subscription Mr. NOYES misapprehends our position on the subject. He thinks we are opposed to it;--on the contrary, quite the reverse. We are decidedly in favor of it. The debt amounts to three thousand millions of dollars and about thirty millions of people are bound to pay it; if 150,000 out of this 30,000,000 will volunteer to pay it themselves, they will do a very handsome thing -- something, as Mr. NOYES says, which no nation on the face of the earth ever did before. We hope they will; we advise them -- we urge them to step forward and do it. We have not the slightest wish to "chill the patriotism of the people," in this or any other matter. And if anybody who was disposed to help pay off the debt by subscription, has been checked in the execution of such a purpose by anything we have said, we respectfully request him to consider it unsaid and to subscribe at once, and as liberally as possible.

abstract: Central Park, 1st Concert of Season
snippet: Central Park, 1st Concert of Season
lead_paragraph: The Central Park Commissioners announce that their first promenade concert of the season will take place this afternoon at 4 o'clock. The music will be furnished, as usual, by the Central Park Band, under the leadership of HARVEY B. DODWORTH. Should the weather prove unpropitious, the concert will, of course, be postponed. Now that the sunny skies of June are upon us, much gratification and enjoyment can be found in a visit to the Park.

abstract: -- On the 29th of April Gen. NEGRETE (Juarist) was reported within a few miles of Matamoras. His force was said to be considerable, and the prospects of the republican cause were alleged to be exceedingly bright. This news came by Havana. That which comes to-day by way of New-Orleans changes the aspect of affairs materially. The reports, however, are Gallo-Mexican entirely. If we accept them, the conclusion is unavoidable that Gen. NEGRETE has been whipped very decidedly. The dates of this last report are to the 11th of May. It is clear that nothing like authentic history can be written upon the present condition of affairs in Mexico, until the embargo now laid upon the transmission of credible intelligence, is removed. One thing, however, must be entirely apparent even to the stipendiaries of the invading power -- the country is no nearer to a state of peace than it was two years ago. The reiterated reports of French "victories" alone are sufficient to show this. If the republic army has been so completely vanquished as the touters for the invader represent, what is it that the French soldiers are still assailing with such pluck and ardor and success? Either JUAREZ has a considerable organized force still left, or these victories of the Gallo-Mexican army are the merest moonshine.

lead_paragraph: A portion of the naval and military expedition of Texas, under command of Gen. WEITZEL, has sailed from Hampton Roads, where it had been fitting out for some weeks past. The vessels comprising the flect will rendezvous in Mobile Bay, in order to coal the steamers, and to clean them thoroughly before proceeding further southward. The steamers composing the expedition are among the largest and best adapted to a long sea voyage, of any in the service. It is thought that the vessels will reach their destination in about seven days from the time of sailing.

abstract: OUTRAGE.--The chief officer of the ship Belle Wood recently arrived from Liverpool, was set upon yesterday, and dreadfully beaten by a number of sailor runners. After he became insensible they continued their brutality by jumping on and kicking him until they thought they had killed him.
lead_paragraph: OUTRAGE. -- The chief officer of the ship Belle Wood recently arrived from Liverpool, was set upon yesterday, and dreadfully beaten by a number of sailor runners. After he became insensible they continued their brutality by jumping on and kicking him until they thought they had killed him. The Captain and others succeeded, after getting the injured man on board, in restoring him to consciousness. The cause of the assault was the officer's refusing the runners admission on board the ship while she lay at anchor in the river.

abstract: Confiscation Act, the, and President Johnson's Amnesty Proclamation; Amnesty Proclamation and the Confiscation Act
snippet: Confiscation Act, the, and President Johnson's Amnesty Proclamation; Amnesty Proclamation and the Confiscation Act
lead_paragraph: The law of July, 1862, and President LINCOLN'S proclamation consequent thereupon, imposed the penalty of forfeiture of the entire property, real and personal, upon every man who should continue, after sixty days, to participate in, or in any manner abet, the rebellion. It was a trenchant measure, of much the same character as the enactment of the Confederate Congress, ten months previous, which smote all sorts and descriptions of property belonging to "alien enemies;" that is to say, to friends of the Union. Were this law now to be carried out, it would make nearly every Southern man and woman houseless, landless, penniless; for nearly every Southern man and woman has in some way participated in the rebellion since that time.

abstract: -- TheBrooklyn Board of Education has recently reduced the salaries of all the female teachers in the public schools of our sister city $75 per annum, without making a corresponding reduction in the stipends of their male employes. Such manifest injustice is the more to be remarked, as it is a notorious fact that female teachers in the Brooklyn schools, although as high a grade of competency is required of them as is demanded in New-York for similar service, are barely paid sufficient to keep soul and body together. With the prevailing rates for board and wearing apparel, it seems little short of mockery to ask this deserving class of young women to spend their time and energy for a pittance which does not average $4 per week. The respectable citizens of Brooklyn should, in justice to themselves, protest against this niggardliness on the part of their school authorities. Teachers are seldom compensated properly for their work, but we are not aware of any city comparing with Brooklyn in wealth and other elements of municipal greatness, where such an illiberal spirit has been exhibited toward them.
lead_paragraph: -- TheBrooklyn Board of Education has recently reduced the salaries of all the female teachers in the public schools of our sister city $75 per annum, without making a corresponding reduction in the stipends of their male employes. Such manifest injustice is the more to be remarked, as it is a notorious fact that female teachers in the Brooklyn schools, although as high a grade of competency is required of them as is demanded in New-York for similar service, are barely paid sufficient to keep soul and body together. With the prevailing rates for board and wearing apparel, it seems little short of mockery to ask this deserving class of young women to spend their time and energy for a pittance which does not average $4 per week. The respectable citizens of Brooklyn should, in justice to themselves, protest against this niggardliness on the part of their school authorities. Teachers are seldom compensated properly for their work, but we are not aware of any city comparing with Brooklyn in wealth and other elements of municipal greatness, where such an illiberal spirit has been exhibited toward them.

abstract: -- DR. HARTLEY generously offers to attend all persons suffering from affections of the ear at his consultation rooms, No. 1,166 Broadway, without charge, until cured, thereby proving his success unequaled, and protecting the deaf from being swindled by paying self-styled aurists exorbitant fees in advance, and the infliction of still more serious evils, by permitting the application of dangerous remedies by inexperienced and unskillful hands. Dr. H. may here state that he has no connection whatever with any person advertising to cure deafness, neither has he given permission for the publication of a certificate purporting to emanate from him, and cannot, therefore, be responsible for any alarming consequences resulting from rashness and desperation. The loss of money may not be material to some persons, but the deprivation of one of the most important of the senses ought to be regarded and treated with more than ordinary solicitude. Deafness, noise in the head, and all disagreeable discharges from the ear, speedily and permanently removed, without causing the least pain or inconvenience. A cure in all cases guaranteed where malformation does not exist. Seventeen years' close and almost undivided attention to this branch of special practice, has enabled him to reduce his treatment to such a degree of success, as to find the most, confirmed and obstinate cases yield by a steady attention to the means prescribed.

abstract: Sumner, Senator, and Wendell Phillips on Negro Suffrage; Suffrage in the South
snippet: Sumner, Senator, and Wendell Phillips on Negro Suffrage; Suffrage in the South
lead_paragraph: Senator SUMNER, WENDELL PHILLIPS and others declare that unless the negroes in the Southern States are at once allowed to vote, the war will have been waged in vain--and all tho blood and treaure it has consumed will have been lavished to no purpose whatever. It is not easy to see how sane men, professing to be patriots, can permit themselves to use such language as this. That Mr. PHILLIPS should declare such sentiments is not perhaps surprising. He is not an American citizen -- disclaims all political allegiance to the fundamental law of the land -- and has said publicly within a month that he would sooner lose his right hand than swear to support the Constitution of the United States. To him the maintenance of that constitution and the preservation of the Union are nothing. They are not objects for which he would contend a moment. If he sustained the war at all, he did it from other motives, and sought by it to attain other results. But Mr. SUMNER is not in that category. He is an American citizen, and claims to value the Union and to stand by and defend the Constitution. The war has preserved the Union -- has crushed rebellion against the constitution, and has extinguished slavery forever. How can Mr. SUMNER believe or say that it has been waged "in vain," even if some other desirable results are not at once attained ?

abstract: Yesterday the first of the returning regiments reached this city en route for their more eastern homes, where they will be greeted with the hearty and cordial welcome which has been so nobly won by the heroes of GRANT's and SHERMAN's armies. The men were in good health, good natured and orderly. Their uniforms testified to the hard service they had seen, and their bronzed faces also bore silent testimony of their exposure and hardships.

abstract: His Rank Offence
snippet: His Rank Offence
lead_paragraph: HOWELL COBB has fallen into our hands, but, it is said, he has been paroled. There is, with the exception of JEFFERSON DAVIS himself, not one of the Southern politicians who is more deserving of attention at the hands of the officers of the law than this Georgian worthy. He was Secretary of the Treasury in 1861, and was one of the original plotters of the rebellion. So far from resigning his office, however, when he determined to take part in it, he deliberately remained in it, and used the powers it bestowed on him for the destruction of the government, thus committing double perjury. With ample funds in his hands, he deliberately failed to pay the interest on the public debt, and the credit of the United States was only saved from receiving a disastrous and disgraceful shock, by some merchants of this city coming forward and voluntarily advancing the required amount. We believe there is not to be found in the political history of any country an example of greater baseness and perfidy than this of COBB's; and what makes it all the worse is, that he had the audacity, after perpetrating it, to come to New-York, and brag of it openly, in the faces of the people whom he had swindled and outraged, announcing that "the whole thing" -- meaning the national government -- "was gone up."

abstract: Honors to, in New-York
snippet: Honors to, in New-York
lead_paragraph: Gen. SHERMAN, during the early hours of yesterday, visited the most prominent places in the city, and wherever he appeared his presence occasioned a great crowd. While inside the Metropolitan Bank the crowd became so large that the aid of the police had to be evoked to enable the General to emerge therefrom. No matter where he went, the same eager and jostling crush attended his footsteps. Finding it difficult to go about town, he took refuge in the residence of Gen. VAN VLIET, remaining there until dark, when he returned to the residence of his cousin, Mr. SCOTT, in Twenty-third-street.

abstract: on the Fast and State Rights
snippet: on the Fast and State Rights
lead_paragraph: The expression in Mayor GUNTHER'S proclamation respecting the observance of the fast on Thursday, in this city, "being assured that the same was approved by the Governor of the State," suggests very naturally the question what would Mr. GUNTHER have done about it if he had not been assured that it was "approved by the Governor of the State?" We do not like "forced constructions," but we cannot help seeing, in this little interpolation, a small and rather trivial offering on the altar of State sovereignty. Our worthy Mayor evidently wishes it to be distinctly understood, that he at least is keeping watch over local independence, and that people shall not even fast and sit in sackcloth at the bidding of the central power, without his sanction and approval.

abstract: On Thursday night, two burglars entered the dwelling of Mr. HENRY F. VAIL, Cashier of the Bank of Commerce, at No. 7 W[???] Thirty-first-street, and had packed and prepared to take away wearing apparel, la[???] window-curtains, opera-glasses, jewelry, wines, etc., of the value of $1,[???], when Patrolmen JOHN B. DAVIS and WILLIAM FICHENGER, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, entered and captured them with the stolen property in their possession. It is assulted that the burglars must have been interment by confederates that Mr. VAIL's family had packed up and gone to the country, since they entered the house on the next night after the family's, departure, and when captured were found to have entered upon the undertaking with a full assortment of burglars' tools and other things necessary to the successful prosecution of a burglary. Entrance to the dwelling was gained by cutting away the iron ring which held the grating on the sidewalk, and then descending to the cellar and forcing a door on the first floor; but, unluckily for the outlaws, a citizen saw them as they descended through the coal-hole, and when they had reached the parlors and were reveling in a house-full of palatial furnishings, all of which temptingly lay before them, the officers entered, and the game was up. Like experienced and skillful burglars the outlaws, seeing no avenue of escape, quietly surrendered, acknowledged defeat, and accompanied the officers with seeming nonchalance until Jefferson Market hove in view, when an effort at escape was made. The prisoners were, however, overpowered and taken to court, where, the magistrate declining to accept bail, they were committed as GEORGE BRADY, 26 years of age, native of Ireland, resident in Hoboken, boat-builder, and HENRY WILSON, 36 years of age, born in New-York, resident in Hoboken, carpenter.

abstract: Davis, Jeff.; British Pleas for; British Pleas for
snippet: Davis, Jeff.; British Pleas for; British Pleas for
lead_paragraph: The English admirers of JEFF DAVIS profess to be terribly shocked that such a "high-toned and gallant gentlemen" should be accused of complicity in the assassination of President LINCOLN. Apart from all other considerations, they lay great stress upon the assumed fact that he knew the "rough but kindly rail-splitter" would be succeeded by the representative of a "party whose sole ideas of the conflict were identified with confiscation and extermination." They are careful not to let their readers know that the assassination plot was intended to include not only President LINCOLN, but Mr. JOHNSON, Mr. SEWARD, Mr. STANTON and Gen. GRANT. The best answer to this special pleading are the words uttered by JEFF. DAVIS himself, at Charlotte, on receiving the news of the assassination. Instead of expressing the horror and indignation which a really "high-toned and gallant gentleman" would have felt at such a crime, he complacently remarked: "if it were to be done it were better that it were well done." Subsequently, in reply to a fear expressed by BRECKINRIDGE that the assassination might be unfortunate for the South, he said: "Well, General, I don't know; if it were to be done at all, it were better it were well done; and if the same were done to ANDY JOHNSON, the beast, and to Secretary STANTON, the job would then be complete."

abstract: Microscopist; Entertainment to Soldiers
snippet: Microscopist; Entertainment to Soldiers
lead_paragraph: Prof. STARR, the microscopist, gave a tree exhibition to a large number of Union soldiers, at the depot in Howard-street, on Wednesday evening. This is the second entertainment that the Professor has given at this place within a few weeks, entirely free of charge. The exhibition was on this occasion rendered doubly interesting by the introduction of a novel and most exciting feature, entitled the "Combat of the Water Demons," in which two of the most fearful and voracious microscopic monsters were put into the same cage, when a battle immediately ensued, surpassing in fury anything ever witnessed in the bloody arenas of ancient Greece or Rome. After a prolonged struggle, in which the wildest paroxysms of rage were manifested, the engagement was suddenly terminated by the introduction of the aquatic tiger, a most uncouth and horrible shape, which devoured both of these tiny yet terrible gladiators in the twinkling of an eye. This water tiger, the only specimen known to exist, was captured by the Professor, and has been regularly fed by him every day for years. Of all the misshapen, colossal forms exhumed by the geologists, we have yet to see anything half so curious and ugly as this tiger. Under the Professor's powerful instrument, his alimentary canal becomes transparent throughout its whole length, and the spectators can easily see him swallow pieces of food apparently as large as their heads. Prof. STARR, as is well known, has the largest and costliest oxy-hydrogen microscope in this country, and the series of microscopic acquariums which be exhibited, some of them teeming with incomputable millions of the most mercurial and beautiful of creatures, and others swarming with innumerable myriads of voracious and terrible monsters, form a collection not equaled by any other in the world. Prof. STARR is a native of this city, the son of one of her wealthiest and most esteemed merchants, and has spent his whole life and a handsome fortune in the pursuit of this favorite science. He is not only a patriotic and benevolent man, but a humorous one; and our brave boys retired to rest feeling that they were indebted to him for one of the most wonderful, instructive and laughter-provoking entertainments that they had ever witnessed.
headline: {'main': "Entertainment at the Soldiers' Depot.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Entertainment at the Soldiers' Depot.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Mayor GUNTHER has as yet made no sign in response to the resolution adopted by the Common Council, a few days since, calling upon him to convene them as a Board of Health. City Hall rumor says that His Honor will veto the resolution at the next meeting of the Common Council, when the boards will immediately readopt it by unanimous consent, and assemble as a Board of Health on the 8th inst. It is understood that the Mayor's objections to the proposed action of the Common Council are on economical grounds. It is feared that the City Inspector will be ordered to clean the filthy streets at once, regardless of expense, and that the board will direct the established of public abattoirs, and introduce other important innovations, involving great expenditures. Whatever may be the merits of this municipal snarl, it is patent that something should be done without delay toward putting some of the streets in passable condition. Complaints reach us from all quarters of the disgusting, pestilence-inviting state in which the thoroughfares are allowed to remain. The bids of the contractors for street cleaning are, however, to be opened to-day, and if the contract shall he awarded to an honest and responsible party, perhaps the fact will inaugurate the era of reform in this important particular.

abstract: Street-Cleaning; Amended Specifications
snippet: Street-Cleaning; Amended Specifications

abstract: Trade of Northern Reviving
snippet: Trade of Northern Reviving
lead_paragraph: -- A promising trade, it will be seen by the news to-day, has begun to be opened up in Northern Alabama. Cotton is being sent up the river in considerable quantities; Northern merchandise is in request, and "money is found in unexpected abundance." Here we have pacifying agencies at work, which will bring general tranquillity and reconciliation in their train faster than people have dreamed of.

abstract: At noon, yesterday, Mr. DANIEL H. BURDETT sold the following government steamers at public auction. The attendance was small and the bidding slow: Sidewheel steamer Cahawba, 1,643 tons, built in 1854, 260 feet long, 38 feet beam, 19 feet deep; sold for $16,500, to JAMES MURPHY & CO. Propeller Jersey, 222 tons, built in 1850; sold for $6,800, to WHITNEY & HATHAWAY. Propeller Detroit, built in 1861, 398 tons, 137 feet long, 25 feet beam, 11 feet deep, was withdrawn. The machinery alone of the Cahawba cost more money than the vessel sold for.

abstract: Returning, and No Welcome in New-York
snippet: Returning, and No Welcome in New-York
lead_paragraph: A large number of troops passed through the city, yesterday, on their way home to points North and East. Their advent among us was almost unheralded, and they went away by the evening boats and trains without having occasion to feel that our citizens are enthusiastically prompt in recognizing their services. During their few hours sojourn at the Battery Barracks, it is true that they partook of refreshments which had been prepared, but not in very generous quality and quantity. These brave fellows are the first installment of the disintegration of the grand armies, and to-day, perhaps, and for weeks to come, others will be arriving, every man of whom has a special claim upon our cordial welcome and ungrudging hospitality. Undoubtedly this feeling toward them in all but universal with our citizens, but there is a lack of organized method to properly make it appear.

abstract: Professor BLOT'S Cooking Academy has entered upon the third month of its existence, and daily increases in favor. So great has been the desire of the gentler portion of our community to avail themselves of the advantage of the "Academy," that the Professor...
lead_paragraph: Professor BLOT'S Cooking Academy has entered upon the third month of its existence, and daily increases in favor. So great has been the desire of the gentler portion of our community to avail themselves of the advantage of the "Academy," that the Professor has been obliged to refuse admission to three hundred applicants until Fall, when he intends removing to larger rooms. Some ladies have come from Boston to be able to attend the lessons, and have guaranteed enough pupils to the Professor in that city to induce him to take a trip there and open a school during the Summer vacation of the New-York Academy. There are classes every day in the week, and this will continue until the 4th of July at least. Professor BLOT has a man assistant in place of the woman whom he had at first, and really the change is quite refreshing, for the present assistant always looks as fresh and cool as a lily, even on the hottest days; and having no skirts, he takes up so much less room, and moves with far more case. Everything in the lesson is so plain and simple that a child might do the work; everything, too, is done without any bustle or confusion; were it not for the ocular proof, one might suppose that the food was prepared "by hands unseen." The Professor intends, when his first class is far enough advanced, to teach them to prepare bills of fare that will be entirely suited to dyspeptics, so that by confining themselves to the food so prepared, any victims of that "dread enemy of man," provided he has not been too long in the monster's clutches, may, in the course of two or three months, "forget that he has a stomach." What would not CABLYLE have given had there been "cooking academies" in England, so that he might never have discovered that he had a stomach.

abstract: "Talk Trade," said a Wealthy Virginian
snippet: "Talk Trade," said a Wealthy Virginian
lead_paragraph: -- Said a wealthy Virginian, yesterday, on being questioned as to the progress and prospects of reorganization among the people of his State: "Talk trade to them." In the City of Lynchburgh there is three million dollars' worth of good tobacco waiting to find a way to the market Lynchburgh is a great tobacco storehouse naturally. But we are assured that the accumulations of this important article of consumption in other districts extending far down into North Carolina, are immense. We have to remember that of the four millions of slaves in the South, only a few thousand have been attached to the rebel armies during these four years of war. The rest have been at work, as they were before there was war. The people of the South want their roads repaired. And in very many districts -- we speak by the card -- they are able to do their repairs without much outside help. They simply want a little time. The Virginia theory of reconciliation is practical -- "talk trade to them."
headline: {'main': 'TALK TRADE TO THEM."', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'TALK TRADE TO THEM."', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: At dark last night the train from Chattanooga arrived, having on board the assets of the Tennessee State Bank, said to amount to $650,000 in coin, beside State bonds. The archives of the State were also there, and the papers of the rebel Adjutant-General's office of Tennessee. The latter were obtained by means of information given by negroes. It is expected that an examination of their contents will throw considerable light on the proceedings of HARRIS and his clique, who engineered Tennessee into the hands of their brother traitors. The assets, archives, and papers were to remain at the depot during the night, in care of a guard under Capt. CRAVEN, of the Second Iowa Mounted Infantry, and to be taken to the Capitol and given up to the officials commissioned to receive them, at 9 o'clock this morning. There were also on the train HOWELL COBB, the rebel Secretary MALLORY, and Senator HILL, of Georgia. The rebel officials of Tennessee, RAY, DUNLAP and BATTLE, were also brought as prisoners, the whole being in charge of Capt. GILPIN, Third Iowa Cavalry. The State prisoners were to remain in military custody last night. -- Chattanooga Gazette, May 25.

abstract: THE DISPOSITION OF BOOTH's BODY -- THE PERFORATED SPINAL VERTEBRA IN THE ARMY MEDICAL MUSEUM. -- It is nearly four weeks since a statement was made in this correspondence as to the disposition made of the body of JOHN WILKES BOOTH, which, since then, has been widely reported throughout the country, and many times contradicted. Of the substantial truth of the main particulars there can be no doubt. It will not be very many days before the visitors to the Army Medical Museum, in this city will be granted a view of the portion of the spinal vertebra of the murderer, through which passed the avenging bullet. The relic will be esteemed a most valuable one by those skilled in medical science, exhibiting, as it does plainly, the exact nature of the wound, and demonstrating the intense agony in which BOOTH must have passed his long hours of lingering death. It is now in process of preparation at the Museum, and not yet accessible to the public. -- Boston Advertiser.

abstract: We have from Now-Orleans particulars of the sad disaster resulting from the blowing up of the main ordnance depot at Mobile. Three hundred persons are reported killed by the accident, and many more must have been terribly injured. The loss in property is estimated from five to ten millions of dollars. It is not yet determined whether the casualty was the result of carelessness or design, but Gen. GRANGER announces that he shall adopt stringent measures to fix the responsibility upon the guilty parties, and bring them to summary punishment.

abstract: The conviction of the expediency and necessity of ratifying the constitutional Amendment is, we think, everywhere gaining ground in this State. The best and most enlightened friends of Kentucky are rapidly wheeling into line and putting their shoulders to the wheel to push on the great work of ridding the State of an incubus and a nuisance. Slavery in Kentucky is now neither one thing nor another. It is neither fish, flesh now fowl. The negroes are just free enough to be of no use to their masters, but not free enough to relieve those masters of their responsibilities. The masters, therefore, have all the hardships, but none of the benefits of the system of slave labor. -- Louisville Journal, May 26.

abstract: Our readers will remember that the hotel proprietors of this city offered a reward of $5,000 for the capture and conviction of the incendiaries who fired the Museum and several of our hotels. This money has been handed to Major-Gen. DIX, who, with President ACTON and Superintendent KENNEDY, will determine what shall be done with it. Parties having suggestions or claims to make, will put themselves into communication with those gentlemen.

abstract: Gen. SHERMAN's movements yesterday, were of a very diversified character. He held an informal levee at his temporary residence in Twenty-third-street, in the morning, made a few formal calls upon his personal friends, but was compelled to return home on account of the crowds. A banquet was given him in the evening, at the Union Club-house, in Fifth-avenue, and he visited, the rooms of the Loyal League Club afterward. The proceedings were very enthusiastic and hearty. Gen. SHERMAN has good reason to be proud of his reception in New-York.

abstract: Retains Bullet in Head for Six Weeks
snippet: Retains Bullet in Head for Six Weeks
lead_paragraph: A case of unusual interest, showing extraordinary tenacity of life, has recently come under our notice. It is that of a man living for six weeks, with a minie ball, weighing one and a quarter ounces in his brain, and after the ball was removed being fully restored to consciousness, with his intellect unimpaired and his physical powers perfect. Lieut. THOS. W. CHANDLER entered the service with the First Long Island Volunteers, in the early part of the war, and served without injury until the 25th of March, 1865. After the recapture of Fort Steadman on that day, our picket line was advanced on the whole of the left. In this advance the Lieutenant received a gunshot wound in the left temple which penetrated the brain. The surgeon in charge of the Division hospital probed the wound; finding the ball had entered the brain he made no attempt to remove it, concluding that Lieut. CHANDLER was fatally wounded. After remaining in the hospital for several weeks, Lieut. C. desired a furlough, but was informed that he would die on the road. After a couple of weeks more he was allowed to return to Brooklyn. On his arrival the brain was oozing from the wound, and the depression showed a fracture of the cranium. He placed himself under the charge of Dr. J.G. JOHNSON, who opened the wound, and after elevating depressed portions of bone, found the bullet pressing in upon the brain firmly wedged by the portions of the skull which had been driven in on the brain. With considerable difficulty the ball was removed, covered with brain, on the 8th of May. The brain oozed from the wound for several days, but is now healed, and Lieut. CHANDLER is able to go around. Rev. Morgan D[???]x has visited him, and expressed great surprise to see him and the result. The case has excited great interest among the surgeons who have seen it. Lieut. CHANDLER resides at No. 65 Prospect-street, Brooklyn, where he will be happy to satisfy any incredulous that it is possible to have an ounce and a quarter minie ball in the brain for six weeks, and still survive.
headline: {'main': 'A SINGULAR CASE.; An Officer Retains a Minie Ball in his Brain Six Weeks Dr. Johnson Extracts it and the Officer returns to Duty.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A SINGULAR CASE.; An Officer Retains a Minie Ball in his Brain Six Weeks Dr. Johnson Extracts it and the Officer returns to Duty.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the hands of the Palmerston Government there is no hope whatever of any scheme of Parliamentary reform however moderate  being offered to the country. A long season of agitation must precede the introduction of any amendment to the constitution. This is made apparent by the temporizing speech of Sir GEORGE GREY speaking for the House of Commons when Mr. BIRNES'  6 franchise bill was under discussion.
lead_paragraph: In the hands of the Palmerston Government there is no hope whatever of any scheme of Parliamentary reform -- however moderate -- being offered to the country. A long season of agitation must precede the introduction of any amendment to the constitution. This is made apparent by the temporizing speech of Sir GEORGE GREY -- speaking for the House of Commons -- when Mr. BIRNES' &3163;6 franchise bill was under discussion.

abstract: The fact of four young boot-blacks from New-York having been arrested in Hoboken with about $100 worth of jewelry in their possession, was mentioned a couple of days ago. Since that time, Officer KING, who made the arrest, ascertained that the jewelry-store of Mr. DILLON, under the United States Hotel in Fulton-street, New-York, was feloniously entered on Saturday night and robbed of about $700 worth of jewelry and over $100 in money. During Saturday, some masons were at work in the jewelry-store, and in the dust and mortar on the floor was found the impression of a peculiarly-formal foot, which corrresponded with that of one of the prisoners. The manner in which they effected an entrance is not known, but it is supposed they either secreted themselves in the building before it was closed at night, or crawled through a grating. Only about $100 worth of the property has been recovered. The boys were sent to New-York for trial.

abstract: Memorial Goblet; Studio Vault Safe Company
snippet: Memorial Goblet; Studio Vault Safe Company
lead_paragraph: Yesterday being the first Saturday in June, and as that day has for some years past been signalized in Central Park annals as the opening of the promenade concert season, a large number of persons visited the Park during the afternoon, and it may now be considered to have entered upon the Summer season proper. Owing to the recent warm weather and the fastidious care bestowed upon our Metropolitan pleasure-ground, the appearance of the Park was very fine indeed. The trees are in their full wealth of foliage, and the smooth shaven lawns, and the blooming and budding vegetation delight the eye of the visitor.

abstract: Irving, Charles, of Virginia
snippet: Irving, Charles, of Virginia
lead_paragraph: The Petersburgh News announces the death, on Sunday last, of Mr. CHARLES IRVING, a gentleman widely known throughout Virginia as an editor and a writer of high literary attainments. He had, at different times, edited the Memphis Inquirer, Nashville Union, Danville Appeal, Lynchburgh Republican, and in the President canvass of 1860 conducted a Douglas organ in Petersburgh. Mr. IRVING was an active participant in the demonstration which took place in Richmond April 15, 1861, in celebration of the fall of Fort Sumter. This United States flag then floated over the Whig building, an emblem of our peace and prosperity. The crowd attempted to pull it down, but Mr. IRVING made the exertion and was instrumental in saving the Whig building from violence, and the flag remained. During the war he served as a private in one of the oldest Virginia regiments, and in one of the last battles around Petersburgh received a very severe wound in the shoulder. The operation of resection was performed, but he sank under it and never rallied, and though he received every possible attention from the surgeons and nurses of the Union army, and the sympathy and kind ministrations of many Petersburgh ladies, yet he died at the Fair Grounds Hospital May 21, 1865. -- Richmond Whig, May 25.

abstract: Honors to, in New-York
snippet: Honors to, in New-York
lead_paragraph: The temporary residence of Gen. SHERMAN at the house of JAMES SCOTT, Esq., No. 64 East Twentythird-street, was again besieged yesterday morning by our citizens, who took complete possession of the sidewalks at an early hour. Hour after hour the large concourse of eager citizens stood, patiently awaiting the General's appearance, but he did not vouchsafe even a glimpse of himself to his humble but enthusiastic admirers. They were quiet but clamorous withal, cracking many a clever joke at one another's expense, and uttering now and then some dry remark upon the apparent unwillingness of Gen. SHERMAN to exhibit himself.

abstract: Burr's Trial for Treason, by Combs
snippet: Burr's Trial for Treason, by Combs
lead_paragraph: The Trial of Aaron Burr for High Treason, by J.J. COOMBS, which made its appearance at Washington some two months since, is just now coming into notice. Besides an interesting historical sketch of BURR's Western Expedition of 1806, and a very comprehensive report of his trial for treason, the volume contains a series of extended notes on the Law of Treason, which are exceedingly interesting at the present moment. In these notes will be found a full exposition of the theory of the law upon which JEFFERSON DAVIS has been indicted for treason, in the District of Columbia. As BURR's is the greatest trial for high treason which ever occurred in this country, the case will in many respects become the precedent for the approaching trial of DAVIS.
headline: {'main': "Burr's Trial for Treason.", 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': "Burr's Trial for Treason.", 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The expected surrender of KIRBY SMITH and his army will doubtless be speedily followed by the removal of the blockade and the reopening of the great seaports of Texas. Are our people prepared for this sudden return of trade to its old channels, with the accumulated volume of the last four years damming up? If our information be correct, no State of the old Union has added more largely to its material resources and solid wealth than Texas, and yet it is probable no portion of the country is yet more destitute of the necessaries of life. There ought to be immediately supplied from our city, the natural source of supply for Texas, and in compensation we shall receive a rich return from her accumulated wealth.

If our information be correct, no State of the old Union has added more largely to its material resources and solid wealth than Texas, and yet it is probable no portion of the country is yet more destitute of the necessaries of life. There ought to be immediately supplied from our city, the natural source of supply for Texas, and in compensation we shall receive a rich return from her accumulated wealth.
