abstract: Colenso, Bishop, on African Missions
snippet: Colenso, Bishop, on African Missions
lead_paragraph: At a recent meeting of the Authropological Society in London, a paper was read by Right Rev. J. W. COLENSO, D.D. Bishop of Natal, on "The Efforts of Missionaries among Savages," and an unusual amount of interest was displayed upon the occasion in consequence of the previous discussion which took place upon the paper by Mr. WINWOOD READE. Dr. COLENSO commenced by saying that there were some observations made on that occasion which he much regretted; but he felt that the question of missionary work among the savages was one which had been very properly raised. It was, he thought, very desirable to have the question discussed from a layman's point of view; and he was too well aware, from his own observation and experience, that some of Mr. READE's strictures were far from being undeserved. Mr. READE's account of the corrupt habits of native converts -- that "every Christian negress whom he met with was a prostitute, and every Christian negro a thief" -- to whatever extent it might have been justified by the facts which fell under his observation, must be supposed, of course, to apply especially to that part at Western Africa in which he had spent five months of his life. He presumed, however, that there were some outward signs on which Mr. READE must have based his judgment, and that in certain cases which came more immediately under his eye there was great dishonesty among the men and great immodesty among the women. But admitting this, it would be only fair to suppose that this state of things might possibly be exceptional upon a coast where the slave-trade, with all its abominations, had so long prevailed, and was still notoriously more or less extensively practiced; where, consequently, whatever good instructions might he given by the missionaries, or whatever good examples might be set by the better class of white residents, laymen as well as missionaries, must have been to a great extent neutralized by the vicious conduct of others. He conceived, therefore, that Mr. READE might have been unfortunate in having had the immediate neighborhood of the slave coast as the only locality in which he had an opportunity of examining into the "Efforts of Missionaries among Savages." Having no personal acquaintance, however, with that coast, Dr. COLENSO confined his remarks chiefly to the savage tribes of Southeastern Africa, among whom his lot had been cast, and to the mission-work which was carried on among them. He refrained from making any comments on the religious views of Mr. READE, and, in like manner, claimed to be held singly responsible for any which he himself expressed on this occasion. He contended that in spite of many serious drawbacks, some inevitable, some capable of being remedied, the "Efforts of Missionaries among Savages" had been a great blessing to them, and he was not afraid or unwilling to look the truth in the face -- to have the work scrutinized and its defects pointed out from a layman's point of view. He could not, he said, sympathize with those who argued that to save one human soul was a sufficient return for spending any amount of money, and sacrificing any number of lives, because it assumed that the soul in question was in danger of being lost -- that is, as such persons mean, eternally lost -- that the Father of spirits had left it to be decided by the caprice, or zeal, or the greater or less measure of selfishness of one or more of u[???]poor mortals, whether our brother's soul could be eternally saved or eternally lost. Now, this he did not believe; and he did not think other persons really believed it, for, if they did, would they ever spend a penny on themselves which they could possibly avoid spending? The right reverend prelate quoted opinions expressed by Rev. Dr. MCNEILE and by the Record newspaper, in accordance with this view, and he assumed, by the cheers which greeted the speech of Rev. Dr. MCNEILE, that, incredible as it would seem, the sentiments were really indorsed as those of the Church Missionary Society itself, by the large meeting, including His Grace the Primate of all England. Three years ago, he said, he was ridiculed by some of his critics for supposing that any great body of educated persons in England believed in these days in the literal accuracy, nay, the Divine infallibility, of every historical or scientific statement of the Bible. Yet such ridicule had been answered by the astonishing fact that eleven thousand clergy of the Church of England had set their names to a declaration of their belief in that very doctrine, as well as in that of the endlessness of future torments, while the two Archbishops have openly declared their adherence to those views. It seemed to be equally incredible that any great body of educated men should believe that every heathen who dies without the "knowledge of Jesus Christ" must be doomed to suffer endless torments. The persons who maintained that doctrine could not possibly believe it, or they would be intensely wretched during every moment of their lives. Dr. COLENSO read the following statement of a missionary who, speaking of the heathen, said: "They would perish like those heathen; and their children, about whom they thought so much, would twine about them like creepers on a gnarled oak, and they would burn -- burn -- burn on forever. Every hour, yea, every moment, they are dying, most of them without a knowledge of the Savi[???]r. On whom, now, rests the responsibility? If you fail to do all in your power to save them, will you stand at the judgment guiltless of their blood?" A heathen child, after having embraced the gospel, said to him, "How long have they had the Gospel in New-England?" When told, she asked with great earnestness, "Why did they not come and tell us before?" And then added, "My mother died, and my father died and my brother died without the Gospel." Here, she was unable to suppress her emotions. But at length, wiping away her tears, she asked, "Where do you think they have gone?" He, too, could not refrain from weeping, and, turning to her, inquired, "Where do you think they have gone?" She hesitated a few moments, and then replied with much emotion, "I suppose they have gone down to the dark place -- the dark place. Oh, why did they not tell us before?"' It wrung his heart as she repeated the question: "Why did they not tell us before?" They had all heard, he supposed, of the old Bulgarian chief, who, when told that his father and mother and all the ancestors of his tribe were burning in hell-fire, declared that he would rather go and burn with them than live in such a gloomy heaven with so inhuman and unjust a being as this God -- a very Moloch -- whom the missionary spoke of. He had heard substantially the same uttered from the mouth of a Zulu; and did not hesitate to say that, on this particular point, the ideas of that Teuton and that Zulu were far more orthodox -- far more truly christian -- than those of such a missionary, trained, though he may have been, in schools of Christian theology. He rejected, then, utterly the employment of the argument that without our missions the heathen would be eternally lost, as a reason for not taking any account of the weight of gold and silver which was thrown into the treasury of missions. But it was said, Ex nihilo nihil fit. Multiply the work of one missionary as much as they pleased, and it would still amount to nothing, or next to nothing. The results of missionary labor among savages were infinitesimally small; and an army of 10,000 teachers, though laboring for 25 years, would do little to raise a savage race from its barbarism. But societies in England must be fed, and reports, therefore, must be sent; and accounts of little details, which nobody would think of chronicling as incidents worthy of notice in any parish in England, must be forwarded by the missionary as tokens of his own activity. Before a sweeping judgment was passed, either on such reports or on the "Efforts of Missionaries," it might be well to consider more closely some of a missionary's primary difficulties -- at least, when entering upon a comparatively new field of labor. It was a great defect in our present system of missions, that the missionaries generally were not practical men; that they had no knowledge of any practical science, such as that of medicine, or of any mechanical art, or even of agriculture. They were mostly mere theologians, interpreters of Scripture, or teachers of catechisms or creeds. This was a very serious drawback upon such missions as ours, and was not easily remedied, because so few of the English clergy were practiced in any of those arts and sciences, which, however desirable, are not absolutely needed for their ministry in England. Yet the advantage resulting from the possession by a missionary of medical science or practical skill of any kind was incalculable, still more when the two were united in one person. It might be supposed that it was enough that some subordinate should have such qualifications, and the missionary merely superintend his work and devote himself to the higher duties of his spiritual office. But this was a mistake, in such a case as that of the Zambesi mission, where the whole party was plunged into the centre of South Africa, far away from the bounds of civilization. Great evil was also caused by those who insist, in their teaching of the heathen, upon the absolute infallibility of the Scriptures -- a doctrine which happily is not held or taught by our national Church. Yet there are missionaries, and even missionary bishops, who, while holding their offices by letters patent from the Queen as Bishops of the Church of England, still violated their duty to the Church of which they were ministers, by misrepresenting its teaching on this point, and by laying down this doctrine to the ignorant heathen as the positive teaching of that Church itself, which, as we now know distinctly, it is not. The course which the great body of missionaries had taken on the question of polygamy was a very serious impediment to the progress of the work. Here, again, without any authority from the Church of which they are ministers, there are many of the missionary clergy, and even Bishops, of the Church of England, who had laid down the law that every convert admitted into the Christian Church should put away all his wives but one, if he had more than one before baptism. It would be reasonable if they said, "You need not be baptised at all; you may be good men without being formally received into the Church, as there have been good men of old who were never baptised, and who had more wives than one, yet lived faithful lives. It was writin the Bibe of the Polygamist Abraham, from the mouth of Jehovah himself, 'I know him that he will command him and his household after him, and they shall keep the way of Jehovah to do justice and judgment;' and you, with your many wives, must try to do the same. As a Christian, you cannot take more, but you must not be false to those you have already taken, and to the obligations you have already contracted lawfully, according to your own native customs. You must not, in the selfish hope of saving your own soul, commit an act of wrong to any of your wives and children." Having referred to some of the principal defects which might and ought to be remedied in the missionary proceedings of the present day, Mr. READE would probably admit, on consideration, that his censures were really valid chiefly in reference to such defects. But if so much difficulty, necessary or accidental, attended the work of missions, why engage in fact was unique in the history of the British colonies. Yet, after all, there would be room for the missionaries. Among these youths so taught and trained, there would be some whose hearts would be touched with the divine desire to be themselves the teachers and educators of their brethren, not only as regarded the things of this life, but as regards the life to come. And the native community itself, thus raised from a lower level, would desire to hear the message of life from the lips of these teachers.

abstract: New-York Citizen; Col. Halpine, Editor
snippet: New-York Citizen; Col. Halpine, Editor
lead_paragraph: The New-York Citizen, of Saturday last, appeared under the editorial charge of Col. HALPINE, late of the army, and well known under the soubriquet of "Miles O'Reilly." It will be devoted, as heretofore, to municipal and general reform, but will now give greater prominence to matters of universal interest, literature, art, public affairs, social life, and so on. The editor is a vigorous, sprightly, racy writer -- celebrated as a poet, a wit, a romancer and a critic; and, under the new auspices, the Citizen will doubtless soon become one of the most popular weeklies in the country.

abstract: The expedition which left Charleston, Kanawha Co., some ten weeks ago, for the White Sulphur Springs, has returned. It was composed of a picked body of men from the First New-York and Seventh West Virginia Regiments. The expedition was entirely successful. On the 11th inst., the Nineteenth, Twentieth and Twenty-second Virginia (rebel) Regiments surrendered, including portions of other commands. They were paroled, and allowed to return to their homes. The people are reported as very submissive, the war feeling subdued, and the country hoping for the establishment of peace. -- Wheeling (Va.) Intelligencer, May 27.

abstract: -- The Port Royal New South says: "When JEFFERSON DAVIS arrived here he had with him a bright, pretty little octoroon boy about eight years of age, named JAMES HENRY BROOKS, or as they had nick-named him on account of his remarkable agility, 'Jim Limber.' He was found in the streets of Richmond and taken to Mrs. DAVIS, who, learning that his mother was dead, adopted him, probably as a plaything for her children. On arriving in our harbor and finding a long voyage before her, with a dark, unwritten future ahead, she requested our kind Provost-Marshal-General, Maj. B.W. THOMPSON, to take the boy and to present him to Maj.-Gen. RUFUS SAXTON, with her compliments, and the request that he would take good care of him and train him into a proper manhood. We asked the little fellow who made him, and the reply was, 'God made me, but LINCOLN made me free.'"
lead_paragraph: -- The Port Royal New South says: "When JEFFERSON DAVIS arrived here he had with him a bright, pretty little octoroon boy about eight years of age, named JAMES HENRY BROOKS, or as they had nick-named him on account of his remarkable agility, 'Jim Limber.' He was found in the streets of Richmond and taken to Mrs. DAVIS, who, learning that his mother was dead, adopted him, probably as a plaything for her children. On arriving in our harbor and finding a long voyage before her, with a dark, unwritten future ahead, she requested our kind Provost-Marshal-General, Maj. B.W. THOMPSON, to take the boy and to present him to Maj.-Gen. RUFUS SAXTON, with her compliments, and the request that he would take good care of him and train him into a proper manhood. We asked the little fellow who made him, and the reply was, 'God made me, but LINCOLN made me free.'"

abstract: CAPT. BRACKETT'S MEN AMONG THE SWINDLERS.  Dr. REED, of Boston, appeared at the Mayor'e Office yesterday afternoon, and accused VAN HOUTEN, Broadway auctioneer, of cheating him in the sum of $104, the accused having charged $1.23 a yard for linen which had been knocked down to the complainant at 23 cents a yard.
lead_paragraph: CAPT. BRACKETT's MEN AMONG THE SWINDLERS. -- Dr. REED, of Boston, appeared at the Mayor'e Office yesterday afternoon, and accused VAN HOUTEN, Broadway auctioneer, of cheating him in the sum of $104, the accused having charged $1.23 a yard for linen which had been knocked down to the complainant at 23 cents a yard. Officer JOHN COWAN, of the City Hall force, was sent to the auction-store, and Dr. REED's money was recovered and restored to him . . . . The same officer accompanied private JOHN LONG, of a Michigan regiment to JAMES GRAT's den, No. 13 Chatbam-street and there recovered $67....GEORGE JACKERLAND, a soldier, having played three-card monte and been cheated out of his watch, made complaint at the City Hall, and Officer COWAN accompanied him to LEWIS WEEKS' place, at No. 103 Chatham-street, and there recovered the watch.

abstract: -ANTOINE THOMAS, of this city, was arrested on Saturday morning last, by United States Deputy-Marshal COBB, upon a bench warrant from the United States Circuit Court, Boston, and was arraigned the same day before the said Court, upon three indictments found by the Grand Jury, at the present term. The first indictment charges that THOMAS aided and abetted one ZENO KELLEY in fitting out the ship Tahmaroo, knowing that she was to go on a slave voyage; the second charges him with having enticed and persuaded witnesses to go beyond the jurisdiction of the court, and with having secreted witnesses so that they should not be forthcoming to testify; and the third charges the defendant with having paid a large sum of money to one MANUEL MACHADOS, one of the crew of the Tahmaroo, to induce him to abscond, and with having offered further sums of money to other witnesses for a like purpose. To each indictment ANTONE THOMAS pleaded guilty, and was ordered by the Court to recognize in the sum of $2,500 for his appearance before the court from day to day. -- New-Bedford Mercury, May 29.
lead_paragraph: -ANTOINE THOMAS, of this city, was arrested on Saturday morning last, by United States Deputy-Marshal COBB, upon a bench warrant from the United States Circuit Court, Boston, and was arraigned the same day before the said Court, upon three indictments found by the Grand Jury, at the present term. The first indictment charges that THOMAS aided and abetted one ZENO KELLEY in fitting out the ship Tahmaroo, knowing that she was to go on a slave voyage; the second charges him with having enticed and persuaded witnesses to go beyond the jurisdiction of the court, and with having secreted witnesses so that they should not be forthcoming to testify; and the third charges the defendant with having paid a large sum of money to one MANUEL MACHADOS, one of the crew of the Tahmaroo, to induce him to abscond, and with having offered further sums of money to other witnesses for a like purpose. To each indictment ANTONE THOMAS pleaded guilty, and was ordered by the Court to recognize in the sum of $2,500 for his appearance before the court from day to day. -- New-Bedford Mercury, May 29.

abstract: New-York, Ainslee Albert, Shot by Policeman Webber
snippet: New-York, Ainslee Albert, Shot by Policeman Webber
lead_paragraph: Last evening Patrolman GUSTAVUS WEBBER, of the Eleventh Ward, went to his dwelling, at No. 119 Columbia-street, and there, finding ALBERT AINSLEE in conversation with his wife, engaged him in a quarrel, and shot him through the breast, inflicting a mortal wound. He then fied into the Eighteenth Ward, but was hotly pursued, and, fearing capture, shooting himself through the head, fell unconscious. Policeman REYNOLDS, of the Eighteenth Ward, removed him to the Eighteenth Precinct Police Station, and thence to Bellevue Hospital; but when he reached that institution he was quite exhausted, and it was feared that he could not live until morning.

abstract: Returning; the Country's Debt to
snippet: Returning; the Country's Debt to
lead_paragraph: Among the inscriptions on the banners which were displayed on the occasion of the late great Military Review in Washington, was one in these words: "A debt the country can never pay the debt of gratitude it owes to its heroic soldiers." We may add that if this debt is one which can never be paid, it is one which should never be repudiated.

abstract: GENERAL ORDERS No. 55 -- I. The terms of surrender agreed upon by Lieut.-Gen. TAYLOR and Major-Gen. CANBY, on the 4th inst., includes all officers and soldiers of the Confederate armies serving within the limits of the Departments of Alabama, Mississippi and East Louisiana, and all such persons within the limits of this division who have not been paroled, by reason of having been absent from the appointed places of rendezvous, will report themselves to the commander of the nearest U.S. military post, surrender the arms and other public property that may be in their possession, and give their paroles. Failing to do this within the next thirty (30) days, they will be arrested and sent North as prisoners of war. Commanders of military posts, to whom these parties report themselves, will give the paroles and passes, as authorized by the terms of surrender. A register of the paroles, giving the named rank and regiment of the persons paroled, and date of the parole, will be kept, and one copy of it transmitted to the Provost-Marshal-General, at these headquarters on the last day of each month.

abstract: Homer's Iliad, Earl of Derby's Translation
snippet: Homer's Iliad, Earl of Derby's Translation
lead_paragraph: There are many books that obtain a large share of notice on account of the circumstances of their origin and the sources whence they spring. There are a few that command attention from their intrinsic merit. And there are a still smaller number that legitimately combine both classes of attraction. Among them, Lord DERBY'S Homer undoubtedly takes rank. That the Lord STANLEY of the past generation, whose Parliamentary triumphs, both as the ally and adversary of Sir ROBERT PEEL, are cherished as the choicest traditions of statesmanlike eloquence -- the conservative leader of our own day, the Lord DERBY, a power in the State, dignified, irascible, gouty and imperious, should, when approaching his seventieth year, be able to devote time and scholarship sufficient for an undertaking that cost the youthful energies of POPE seven years of anxious and absorbing labor, is of itself enough to cause his work to be estimated among the curiosities of literature. But when this arduous enterprise turned out to be satisfactorily accomplished -- when running through the long list of translators, from the days of Queen ELIZABETH to our own, Chapman, Hobbs, Pope, Cowper, Sotheby, Newman, &c., competent authorities -- nay, the universal voice of modern criticism pronounces that this new version has no equal in all that relates to a faithful presentment of the old Grecian in our modern tongue -- it must be admitted that it is scarcely possible to conceive a book putting forth greater claim to consideration than this does. The noble author's object, as stated by himself, was simply "an attempt to transfuse into an almost literal English version something of the spirit as well as the simplicity of the great original." How happily this end has been attained, a perusal of the version will show. It may be luxuriously studied in the elegant edition published by Mr. SCRIBNER -- a specimen of bookmaking as a technical art that need fear no comparison with the English original. All the history, and much of the theology of the ancient world, goes back to Homer. To offer to his countrymen a rendering of the mighty lines of Homer, faithfully reproducing the easy flow and majestic simplicity of its great original, is a service that will outlive the transitory triumph of politics, and assure the name of Lord DERBY a place among the benefactors of his age and nation.

abstract: Street-Cleaning Commission
snippet: Street-Cleaning Commission
lead_paragraph: We implore the Street-Cleaning Commission to delay no longer in awarding the contract for cleaning the city of its vast accumulation of filth. From the revelations made in a report elsewhere concerning the condition of the streets, we seem to be inviting disease and death in the Summer. On Saturday the bids for street-cleaning were opened. Seven distinct proposals to do the work were made, and the majority of the contractors offered ample securities for the proper performance of their obligations. There seems to be no good reason why the contract should not be awarded at once to the best candidate. If, for political ends, the commission shall trifle longer with this serious matter, to the destruction of the comfort and the imperilment of the health of the city, they assume a terrible responsibility.

abstract: DROWNED WHILE ATTEMPTING TO DESERT. -- Coroner LYNCH concluded an inquest, on Saturday, upon the body of CHRISTOPHER MURPHY, who was found drowned at the foot of Fifty-sixth-street, Gowanus, about a week since. He was a seaman on board the ship John Bright, recently arrived from Liverpool, and in attempting to escape from duty lost his life. A report was current that the mate had threatened to shoot some boatmen for attempting to help MURPHY out of the water, but this was disproved, and a verdict, in accordance with the facts, and exonerating the mate from all blame, was rendered.

abstract: Let none of our readers forget that the Spring meeting of the Passaic County Association commences at Paterson, N.J., to-morrow. (Tuesday) -- the first race of the day taking place precisely at 1:30 o'clock. The drive from New-York is most deliciously inviting at this season of the year, and we advise all who possess vehicles, or who can engage them, to adopt this method of transit. Otherwise the Erie Railroad, from the foot of Chambers-street, affords extraordinary facilities. Regular trains will run at 8:30 and 10 A.M., and an extra special, with ladies' cars, will leave at 11:45, making no stop between the depot and the course. The return trains will leave immediately on the conclusion of each day's racing.

abstract: Gen. SHERMAN's movements Saturday, were of a very diversified character. He held an informal levee at his temporary residence in Twenty-third-street, in the morning, made a few formal calls upon his personal friends, but was compelled to return home on account of the crowds. A banquet was given him in the evening, at the Union Club-house, in Fifth-avenue, and he visited the rooms of the Loyal League Club afterward. The proceedings were very enthusiastic and hearty. Gen. SHERMAN has good reason to be proud of his reception in New-York.

abstract: Debt and the Tariff; Revenue and the Public Debt
snippet: Debt and the Tariff; Revenue and the Public Debt
lead_paragraph: The present Funded Debt and Customs Revenue policy which took shape and may be said to have been founded in the Act of Congress, of Feb. 25, 1862, has worked successfully, and been faithfully administered by Mr. CHASE and his successors through three of the most trying and eventful Fiscal Years in the Nation's history. In the Act referred to and in all subsequent Loan Acts authorizing five or six per cent. Funded Stocks, all such stocks of the United States are recognized as gold-bearing, in the same high sense as before the War, and before the Legal-Tender Act, both as to principal and interest. The demand Treasury Notes receivable for Custom-house dues then outstanding were also recognized as gold-bearing, and have since been paid off accordingly. The old Funded Debt since then maturing has also been paid off in Gold. And the Gold Interest upon all our Funded Stocks has been uniformly paid in Gold, and frequently paid in advance by way of qualifying the large Custom-house demand for Gold in the open market. To these objects the Customs revenues, which are demanded by the Act of 1862 to be paid exclusively in Gold, were specifically pledged, and have proved for the three years not only equal to this important charge upon them in Gold, but have also borne the Currency Interest upon the temporary or non-funded Public Debt through the same years. Leaving an estimated surplus at the close of the third year, in gold in the Treasury, of full twenty-five millions of dollars, and a balance in Currency from the avails of surplus Gold sold in the market last year, of at least ten millions, to be carried to the currency interest of the succeeding Fiscal Year. And this, after paying $45,975,351 of such interest in addition to $130,729,846 in Gold.

abstract: There is a charming innocence about GARIBALDI, and everything he does. Here we have him writing a kindly letter in which he expresses his astonishment at the prevalent sympathy of Englishmen during the contest which has just closed. He fails to understand why those who began emancipation in the West Indies should have taken so readily to a political confederacy founded on slavery. Poor, innocent GARIBALDI! If he would appeal to the Lairds, the Lindsays and the high-toned British community they represent in Parliament, he would shortly learn a great deal more about actuating motives than he does now. His letter, however will repay perusal.

abstract: If a pestilence does not visit this city during the Summer, it won't be the fault of our officials; if disease does not seize upon tens of thousands, and death carry off vast populations, it won't be because disease and death are not courted and invited by the men paid to ward them off. Filth, par excellence, nastiness, per se, characterize many of our streets; dirt, stagnant water, puddles of scummy pestilential...
lead_paragraph: If a pestilence does not visit this city during the Summer, it won't be the fault of our officials; if disease does not seize upon tens of thousands, and death carry off vast populations, it won't be because disease and death are not courted and invited by the men paid to ward them off. Filth, par excellence, nastiness, per se, characterize many of our streets; dirt, stagnant water, puddles of scummy pestilential oozings may be seen in hundreds of localities, while smells strong enough to affect the heavens, and putrid enough to destroy a population, permeate the sanctities of our homes, and render uninhabitable whole blocks of our tenements.

abstract: The Massachusetts State Eclectic Medical Society holds its fifth annual meeting on Wednesday, the 7th inst., at the Parker House, Boston. A large attendance of members and practitioners from other states is expected. The calling of a national convention and the organization of a National Eclectic Medical Society will occupy the attention of the society; also, the establishment of the recently incorporated "Eclectic Medical College of the City of New-York," together with a hospital in this city, will be considered.

abstract: Dante's Celebration at Florence. Victor Hugo's Letter; Hugo, Victor, Letter on Dante Celebration at Florence
snippet: Dante's Celebration at Florence. Victor Hugo's Letter; Hugo, Victor, Letter on Dante Celebration at Florence
lead_paragraph: The inauguration of the statue of DANTE took place at Florence on Sunday, the 14th ult., in the midst of a display of patriotic feeling and enthusiasm such as have been rarely withnessed in the city of the Medicis. From a very early hour in the morning the streets were astir with eager crowds, the balconies were hung with drapery, and national flags waved out on every side. At a little before 9 o'clock the procession started from the Piazza di Santo Spirito, the cannon of the fort San Giovan Battista announcing its departure. The representatives of the Italian and foreign press led the way, followed by those of the Italian dramatic art, with their banner; then came in long line the representatives of the provinces, the communes, and the institutes of every part of Italy, and the foreigners invited to the ceremony. More than 700 banners were borne in the procession. At a little before eleven the cortege reached the Piazza di Santa Croce, where it was shortly afterward met by the King, who was received with hearty and long continued applause. The Mayor of Florence then delivered a short speech, and after another from Padre GLANBATTISTA GIULIANI in honor of DAN[???]E, the covering of the monument was removed. The enthusiasm at this point of the ceremony rose to the highest pitch, and the scene was altogether most impressive. Not the slightest disorder is reported to have occurred throughout the day. The pate, the feeling of the crowd frequently found vent in sympathetic cheers for Venice, Rome and Turin.

lead_paragraph: The innumerable bearings of the social revolution that is in progress in the South, consequent upon the abolition of slavery, will not be fully revealed for ages. Both races are being permanently influenced. Society, in all its relations, is being profoundly affected. Measures are being put in operation whose development will require centuries, and whose transforming effects upon the individual and national character no man can compute.

abstract: THE DEAD-LOCK IN THE JERSEY CITY COMMON COUNCIL. -- The proceedings of the Jersey City Common Council are becoming rather mixed and complicated, and from present appearances, some of their proceedings are likely to result in litigation. Some seventeen meetings have been held, and over 400 ballottings have been had for a President, without success. About two weeks since Alderman PANGBORN was elected President pro tem., after which the board elected a City Clerk, City Marshal, and City Treasurer, there being no opposition. At the following meeting these proceedings were ignored by the election of Alderman EARLE as President, pro tem., and a City Clerk, pro tem. An adjourned meeting of the board was held on Friday night when sixteen of the eighteen members were present. Alderman PANGBORN was called to the chair, and a motion to appoint Alderman GAFNEY clerk pro tem., was lost, but a motion to appoint JOHN E. SCOTT, clerk, was adopted. Ten ballots were then had, Alderman DECKER, (Reform,) receiving nine votes on each ballot, and Alderman EARLE seven. A motion to approve the minutes of the previous meeting led to considerable discussion, but finally the motion prevailed, by a vote of 9 to 7. RICHARD D. MCCLELLAND was then reelected Corporation Attorney, he having received ten votes -- the required number. Mr. WM. WHITLEY was elected Overseer of the Poor, and LUKE O'BRIEN was elected City Guager. An unsuccessful ballot was had for Street Commissioner. ABRAHAM VAN RIPER received nine votes and WM. MURRAY received five votes, and JOHN NOLAN, the present incumbent, received one. The board then adjourned to Tuesday evening, 6th inst.
lead_paragraph: THE DEAD-LOCK IN THE JERSEY CITY COMMON COUNCIL. -- The proceedings of the Jersey City Common Council are becoming rather mixed and complicated, and from present appearances, some of their proceedings are likely to result in litigation. abstract: THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE SOUTH -- THE PRESENT OPPORTUNITY. -- The lines of steamships and sailing vessels which in other days used to carry on the great commerce between New-York, Philadelphia, Boston, Baltimore and other Northern ports, and Richmond, Wilmington, Charleston, Savannah and other ports of the Southern seaboard, are now again resuming their old routes and their old labors. They are, moreover, carrying from the North to the South an immense number of emigrants, mostly young men of American birth -- traders, mechanics, laborers, and workers at every pursuit of every kind. Besides this great movement to the seaboard cities, large numbers of enterprising men are pushing down to the interior of the South by railroad, via Richmond and Raleigh, to see what are the opportunities now offered for trade, labor and settlement From Virginia, the Carolinas and Georgia, we already learn that there is good demand for labor, industry, for operatives and mechanics, such as carpenters, masons, painters, printers, etc.; and though money is not plenty, there is found to be some specie on hand, and a great abundance of tobacco, naval stores and cotton, which are already finding their way to market, and will soon make money abound throughout the South.
lead_paragraph: THE DEVELOPMENT OF THE SOUTH -- THE PRESENT OPPORTUNITY. -- The lines of steamships and sailing vessels which in other days used to carry on the great commerce between New-York, Philadelphia, Boston, Baltimore and other Northern ports, and Richmond, Wilmington, Charleston, Savannah and other ports of the Southern seaboard, are now again resuming their old routes and their old labors. They are, moreover, carrying from the North to the South an immense number of emigrants, mostly young men of American birth -- traders, mechanics, laborers, and workers at every pursuit of every kind. Besides this great movement to the seaboard cities, large numbers of enterprising men are pushing down to the interior of the South by railroad, via Richmond and Raleigh, to see what are the opportunities now offered for trade, labor and settlement From Virginia, the Carolinas and Georgia, we already learn that there is good demand for labor, industry, for operatives and mechanics, such as carpenters, masons, painters, printers, etc.; and though money is not plenty, there is found to be some specie on hand, and a great abundance of tobacco, naval stores and cotton, which are already finding their way to market, and will soon make money abound throughout the South.

abstract: Orders in View of Peace
snippet: Orders in View of Peace
lead_paragraph: From the temper and bearing of Gen. CANBY's recent orders, (which we published yesterday,) we take it that he fully understands the scope of his commission in view of the lapse from war to peace. He orders his subordinate commanders to extend the limits of their commands to all the sections of country east of the Mississippi within his jurisdiction. He directs them to see that the benefits of unrestricted trade, proclaimed by the President, are made available for the peaceful inhabitants. He makes the harboring of guerrillas an offence punishable by the withdrawal of the privileges of unrestricted trade. All military orders conflicting with the President's proclamation are revoked, and military taxes, except for sanitary purposes, are declared abolished. The work of the military, in short, as prescribed by Gen. CANBY, is not to overawe the people of the South, but to protect the peaceable against evil-doers. Much virtue will be found to lie in the temperate, unobtrusive, conciliatory manner in which these orders are carried into execution. Nothing is at this moment of greater practical importance to the reestablishment of loyal government in the South, than that military commanders of every grade should hold themselves under thorough self-restraint. Their mission henceforth is less one of physical coercion, than one of cooperation with the peaceably-disposed in the restoration of order, and the reorganization of a stable system of local administration.

abstract: Magazines for June
snippet: Magazines for June
lead_paragraph: -- Harper's New Monthly Magazine (New-York, HARPER & BROTHERS,) offers its usual attractions for all readers by its customary staff of contributors. ROSS BROWNE's second paper on "Washoe Revisited" is amusing, though the vein of adventure it illustrates has been rather worked out of late. "The Americans on their Travels," by Dr. ROBERT TOMES, is shrewd and sensible. VAMBERG's adventures in Central Asia are epitomized in "From Teheran to Samarcand." In the late war Gen. MCCLELLAN's "Change of Base" is illustrated by John S.C. ABBOTT, in a paper containing several clever wood cuts, and Gen. GRANT's career is pleasantly commented on in the "Recollections" of a personal friend. DICKENS' strangely constructed story, "Our Mutual Friend," and WILKIE COLLINS' romance "Armsdale," are the chief attractions from foreign sources, with the exception of Prof. GOLDWIN SMITH's "University of Oxford," here concluded, forming an article of value and interest. Altogether the number is a good one.

abstract: -The details of the fearful catastrophe at Mobile fail to exhibit anything but the most unaccountable carelessness on the part of those responsible for the disposition of the ordnance stores. Storage seems to have been sought in the very heart of the city. An in the building were two hundred tons of ammunition, consisting of musket cartridges, cannon powder, a large number of blank musket cartridges, a quantity of loaded shells, grape, cannister and solid shot. In addition there were about thirty tons of powder, brought into the city all the way from Gainesville, for what earthly purpose it would surely be ha[???]d to divine. There ought to be a thorough investigation ordered into the whole circumstances. Even if the firing of the magazine was purely acci[???] one must have blundered, and [???] after a fashion which demand [???].

abstract: -The annual examination of the West Point Cadets, which takes place this week, will be attended with circumstances of unprecedented interest. The occasion, like many previous ones, will be illustrated by the presence of Lieut.-Gen. SCOTT, the veteran soldier of America, and not by his presence only, but by that of Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, whom SCOTT himself has pronounced to be the "greatest soldier in the world." Gen. SHERMAN also will be there, and probably Gen. THOMAS, beside a large number of officers of lesser rank, but not less heroic character. The young cadets, and others who may be present, will have an opportunity of beholding a galaxy of military stars, such as have never before lent lustre to such an occasion. The graduates, who have been devoting years to the study of Strategy, Grand Tactics, Logistics and Engineering, will undergo their examination before the great soldiers, who have given practical illustration of their study of these branches in their early years. It would be well if the students were compelled to stand an examination in the campaigns of Lieut.-Gen. GRANT. These campaigns ought to be made a special branch of study in the Academy. They furnish masterly examples in every branch of the military art; and we should have greater hopes of the abilities of our future soldiers, if they were thoroughly familiar with the grand campaign of the Mississippi, which culminated at Vicksburgh; the splendid Chattanooga campaign, and the final campaign from the Rapidan to the Appomattox. The histories and the books have no lessons equal to these.

abstract: City Railroads and Hot Weather
snippet: City Railroads and Hot Weather
lead_paragraph: The delightful [???] knows of the c[???]rly morning yesterday invited large numbers of pleasure-seekers [???]. Before noon, however, the absurd thermometer go[???] high, and by 3 P.M. nearly touched 90 degrees, inflicting discomfort and threatening [???] stroke. Sensible people, blessed with comfortable homes, at once be[???]ook themselves thither in quest of shade and quiet. But to the thousands of others who dwell in tenement-houses, crowded like cattle in shambles, to whom Sunday is the one day in seven of rest and recreation, the only hope of relief from the sweltering heat was in reaching the Central Park, Staten Island and other suburbs more or less remote. And for this class, against the city railroads we have a word of protest, for the shameful lack of accommodation noticeable on all the lines. Perhaps the most striking instance of this state of things was in the management of the Third-avenue care the chief means of locomotion for that large, population who exist in that peninsular portion of the city lying between Chatham-square and Fourteenth-street. After walking half a mile or more in the scorching sun to reach the frowsy, ill-ventilated cars of the company, its patrons were compelled to pack themselves, without the least regard to decency, breathing a vile atmosphere of dust and unpleasant human exhalations.

abstract: Ordinances of Secession of Virginia and Alabama secured
snippet: Ordinances of Secession of Virginia and Alabama secured
lead_paragraph: -Government has recently obtained the original Virginia ordinance of secession. It was intrusted to a German printer then a resident of Richmond, to be lithographed. From some cause or other -- the main one being that the printer had not the material with which to do the work -- the document remained in his hands until Lieut.-Gen. GRANT captured the stronghold. The Richmond printer came North and gave the paper to a philadelphia friend, from whom it was obtained by the authorities, Mr. STANTON has also received the Alabama ordinance of secession, which was secured during WILSON's raid into that State, and forwarded to him by a newspaper correspondent. These will prove valuable souvenirs of the great slaveholders' rebellion, and furnish conclusive testimony as to the guilt of various leaders.

abstract: London Times on the Fenians
snippet: London Times on the Fenians
lead_paragraph: Now that Amarica is once more at liberty for foreign enterprises, we may be excused if we cast an anxious look at that mysterious organization of which we have been so often reminded during the last four years. It is not pleasant to be informed on respectable authority that almost every Irishman in the United States has joined a society pledged to annex Canada and to liberate Ireland at our very first difference with the government at Washington, or the slightest tiff with our imperial neighbor. Since the organization is proclaimed to be no secret, and to have proved a valuable auxiliary to the Federal cause, we might venture to ask a few questions as to a movement which boasts to be a preparation for war with this country. * * * * *

abstract: Mr. THEODORE MELENFI, of the firm of MELENFI BROTHERS, of No. 155 Eighth-avenue, entered complaint against his clerk, MARTIN V.B. EVERSON, alleging that he had frequently sold goods to his confederates, and, pretending to take payment, had returned...
lead_paragraph: Mr. THEODORE MELENFI, of the firm of MELENFI BROTHERS, of No. 155 Eighth-avenue, entered complaint against his clerk, MARTIN V.B. EVERSON, alleging that he had frequently sold goods to his confederates, and, pretending to take payment, had returned their money as change, thus defrauding his employers in the full value of the goods which he had pretended to sell; and the deponent made oath that on Saturday evening one JAMES REESE purchased groceries of the clerk EVERSON and tendered bills in payment therefor, which bills EVERSON gave back to REESE. Witnessing this transaction, Mr. MELENFI summoned Patrolman WOOD, of the Sixteenth Precinct, and caused EVERSON's arrest. The prisoner, who is a young man of good address and about twenty-five years of age, asserts his entire innocence. He was committed for examination, and REESE was held as a witness.

abstract: GEN. SHERMAN AND THE CITY COUNCILS. -Everybody who admires and loves Gen. SHERMAN, will be pleased to hear of his being likely to escape "the hospitalities" of the city, which the Common Council has for some days been threatening to bestow upon him. These inestimable privileges consist in standing for some hours in the Governor's Room, in the custody of the municipal "Committee on National Affairs," and having his arm shaken severely by everybody who can get at him during that period, followed by a visit to the city hospitals, jails, insane retreats, and perhaps we should add, the dumping-grounds and the dog-pound. Doubtless there can be nothing more interesting and instructive, either to a philanthropist or a philosopher, than an inspection of these institutions; but this is hardly a kind of entertainment that it is well to offer to a soldier who has just passed four years in the bivouac and on the march. It is, we believe, usual in all civilized communities to testify pleasure at receiving distinguished strangers in the manner most likely to be agreeable to them, and not to their hosts; and the Common Council and all other public bodies would do well to bear this in mind on such occasions as the present.

abstract: Only Fit for "Dirty Work"
snippet: Only Fit for "Dirty Work"
lead_paragraph: POOR SANDERS. -- It seems from evidence just now made public, that the pretentions and fussy nuisance known as GEORGE N. SANDERS is despised and scoffed at by even the rebel rabble led by JAKE THOMPSON. Mr. C.C. CLAY sneeringly speaks of GEORGE as a poor devil, one not fit to be trusted, but very useful "to do dirty work," because he will associate with persons that none other of the Canadian rebel plotters would be seen with. To be thus kicked out like a mangy puppy is not kind treatment to even a Sanders, and we submit that he ought to make it the occasion of a new manifesto to the people of the United States.

abstract: Davis, John
snippet: Davis, John
lead_paragraph: The Chicago Times, apparently to impugn the fairness and justice of the court before which the assassins are being tried, states that Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON has several times during the trial taken objections to the testimony admitted by the court, and "expressed his surprise at the admission of evidence by the government." The Times goes on to argue that, from the well-known character of Mr. JOHNSON for probity and professional ability, it is impossible to suppose that his surprise was "otherwise than real," and based upon good foundation. The truth is that Hon. REVERDY JOHNSON has not been present in the court since the fourth day of the trial, nor since the defence was opened.

abstract: THE NEGRO TROOPS IN THE FAR SOUTH. -It seems that the government is determined to garrison the States bordering on the Gulf of Mexico, and on the Mississippi River, in great part, by black troops. The two very strong divisions, (the First and Second,) of the Twenty-fifth Army Corps, which are now on their way to Texas, are composed entirely of negroes. They saw a good deal of active service during the campaign of last Winter against Petersburgh, and approved themselves good soldiers, brave and disciplined. Fortunately their duties in Texas will be light, as there are now no rebels for them to fight; nevertheless they will do an important duty in proclaiming the authority and supremacy of the government in these regions, where its power has been defied and denied. In other times, the highly independent people of Texas might have considered it quite unbearable to have negro soldiers garrisoning their State. But the rebellion has changed all this; and the action of the Confederate Government in the matter of negro soldiers has removed all ground for regarding the measure as invidious. It is quite possible, too, that the negro troops will soon do such service against the Indian savages of Texas and Arizona, as to make them highly popular.

lead_paragraph: HACK INSPECTION. -- Capt. BRACKETT'S men, at the City Hall, are inspecting hacks, hotel omnibuses, and other vehicles, with a view of ascertaining whether they are fit to run, and whether licenses ought to be granted their owners. The carriages are driven into the east gate of the Park, and near the Police Station, which is in the southwest corner of the basement of the City Hall. Some of the vehicles are dirty and dilapidated, others are u[???]te, and many have no numbers on them, rendering it difficult to find the owner and bring him to in the, upon the complaint of persons he may have cheated. The examination of the back is corrected with strictness and impartiality; li[???]nses are refused in about one-tenth of the cases which come before the police.

abstract: Large numbers of our German fellow-citizens celebrated Pfingst-montag (Whit Monday) at Jones' Woods yesterday. At an early hour the eastern section of the city, where our Teutonic brethren most do congregate, was alive with those determined to make the most of the day, and enjoy it from the break of morn till dewy eve. German mechanics and laborers, most of them accompanied by their wives and children, were to be seen entering the Second and Third avenue cars to be conveyed to Jones' Woods. Others congregated round the headquarters of the Turners in Orchard-street to witness the procession of those well-known gymnasts on their way to the Woods. As early as 8 o'clock, the Turners commenced to assemble at their headquarter, and were soon afterward formed in line by their Grand Marshal, Col. KLOBBER. They looked exceedingly well, and wore their neat uniform of white coats, black pants and Kossuth hats. At the appointed hour three bands and drum corps took their positions in line, and at a given signal the procession moved forward in the following order:

abstract: Suppressed Testimony; the
snippet: Suppressed Testimony; the
lead_paragraph: A mutilated copy of the " suppressed testimony," surreptitiously obtained, has been permitted to circulate for several days, in some Western country newspapers naturally without the cognizance of the military authorities, who seem to have only been apprised of the facts, when the spurious report was copied into some of the New-York papers. The imposition is rectified in the official report of the "suppressed testimony" which we publish to-day.

abstract: THE COMMON COUNCIL AND PRIVATE PROPERTY. -Columbia College owns three or four blocks between Forty-seventh and Fifty-first streets and Fifth and Sixth avenues, which it is about to lease, or has leased, for building-lots. A short time ago, in order to facilitate the leasing, it spent over $20,000 in excavating them so as to leave them all ready for building. A large proportion, we believe nearly the whole, have been let, and the lessees, we believe, are very generally about to build on them very soon, having been only prevented hitherto by the high prices and scarcity of labor -- obstacles which the close of the war is rapidly removing. Within a few days, the Common Council has actually passed a resolution declaring these sunken lots on Forty-eighth and the adjacent streets to be a nuisance, and directing them to be filled up. It only remains for the Aldermen to concur, and the Mayor to sign the ordinance, and we shall witness a more extraordinary and outrageous attack on the rights of property than has yet been perpetrated in this city. Not only would a large amount of the public money be spent in undoing the work which the college has done, but each lessee would be put to an expense of $500 or $600 in again excavating his lot.

abstract: Union Course, Dictator, >amp;c., Trot for $225
snippet: Union Course, Dictator, >amp;c., Trot for $225
lead_paragraph: Since the order issued by the Navy Department reducing the navy to the actual wants of the government, a large number of vessels have been sent home form blockading and other squadrons. These vessels immediately go out of commission, and their officers and crews not being required further are discharged. Only regular officers and seamen are retained in the service, the volunteers either resigning or being discharged....The United States steamer Nyack, 7 guns, is going soon into dry-dock; this vessel, tho Shawmut, 5 guns, and Pequot, 11 guns, will be fitted out for service on foreign stations. The Mediterranean flag-ship Colorado, 52 guns. Admiral GOLDSBOROUGH, will drop down the river this week and cast anchor off the battery. The Glaueus, 11 guns, goes out of commission to-day, and will probably be sold. The bark Pursuit will go out of commission and be sold. The Wyandotte, 5 guns, is out of commission and hauled in among the lot of vessels, which number now about a dozen, to be sold. The Sarah M. Newhall, captured in Charleston harbor at its capitulation, arrived at the yard yesterday. The Epsilon arrived June 3, Acting Ensign C.F. RUSSELL commanding; Acting Second Engineer MACK, and THOS. J. FOX Acting Third Engineer. The Winooska, 10 guns, also arrived June 3. The Unit arrived yesterday, and the Belle June 3. The Rhode Island, 12 guns, sailed Saturday for a cruise in the West Indies. The Mohongo, 10 guns, double-ender, sails soon for the Pacific squadron.

abstract: THE FRENCH IN MEXICO. -- Our advices by the City of Washington, to-day, would seem to indicate the approaching close of the French occupation of Mexico. It is stated that at a recent meeting of the French Cabinet and Privy Council, M. FOULD advocated the immediate withdrawal of the French forces in Mexico, and stated that he had felt it his duty to send a dispatch to the Emperor NAPOLEON, in which he urged the necessity of taking this step. If this report be correct, MAXIMILIAN would bettor pack his imperial traps and get ready to accompany his protectors in their homeward voyage.

abstract: on Dangers of Emancipation; Freedmen; The and the Government; Emperor, the, on Popular Education
snippet: on Dangers of Emancipation; Freedmen; The and the Government; Emperor, the, on Popular Education
lead_paragraph: The opinion has recently been expressed by Maj.-Gen. JOSEPH JOHNSTON, one of the foremost of the Southern leaders, that a social war between the whites and blacks of the South is probable. There is reason to fear that this expectation widely prevails throughout the South. It was an universally accepted axiom there, long before the rebellion, that emancipation would result in one of two things--either amalgamation or extermination. That was the feeling even two or three generations ago, when slavery was admitted to be a positive evil; and it was the standing argument against disturbing the existing order of things. In fact the North, too, had the same opinion. Four years ago there were probably not ten thoughtful men in the North who had the conviction t[???] immediate and universal emancipation would be safe for Southern society. It was this fear of the social danger that would result which constrained Mr. LINCOLN to insist so strongly as he at first did upon supplementing emancipation with some great plan of colonizing the freedmen abroad.

abstract: OUR SECURITIES ABROAD. -- The City of Washington brings news of a further advance in American securities in the London market. United States Five-Twenties were quoted on the 25th ultimo at 67 to 67 1/2, an advance of one per cent. on the rates of the day previous. It would appear that the attempt of rebel sympathizers to create a panic among foreign holders of our securities, by circulating sensation rumors of a probable rupture of friendly relations between this country and France, has altogether failed.
lead_paragraph: OUR SECURITIES ABROAD. -- The City of Washington brings news of a further advance in American securities in the London market. abstract: Germany and America
snippet: Germany and America
lead_paragraph: GERMANY AND AMERICA. -- We learn from our German files that since the announcement has been made in Europe of the close of our war, there is an immense growth of the popular desire for emigration to America. Even during the progress of the war, and while the prospects of our country looked worst, there were tens of thousands of stout, industrious, intelligent Germans, who left their native land and came over to make their homes in the United States. But for every one who emigrated last Summer, there are ten who desire and purpose emigrating this year. They have learned a great deal about America during the war -about its resources, its agricultural and mineral wealth, its commercial and business facilities, and the unequaled opportunities it offers for industry and labor. They have learned also that it has a safe and strong, as well as a free and beneficent government. The results of the war, the state of society during its progress, and the condition of affairs after its close, are final arguments in behalf of republicanism. An English paper tells us that now "Austria and Prussia are filled with the spirit of transatlantic democracy," and that "Germany is saturated with American securities."

abstract: OLD VIRGINIA AND THE NEW ERA. -- The Southern State which bids fair to attract by far the largest amount of emigration from the North this Summer is Virginia. It is better known in the North than any other of the Southern States; it has advantages for commerce equal to any, if not superior: it has a soil of the highest richness, though parts of it have deteriorated under slave labor and a miserable system of agriculture; it produces, beside tobacco, all the cereal crops in great abundance; it has a mild and healthful climate; and in every point of view it is inviting. There are large numbers of "prospectors" in the State now; but they complain that though the large land owners are anxious to sell, and find it absolutely necessary to do so, they demand preposterous prices for land, not yet having been able to realize the difference in value between greenbacks and Confederate notes, in which latter trash they have for some years been accustomed to calculate. We learn, however, that land companies are being formed, which will operate at once for the interests of old landholders and new settlers.
lead_paragraph: OLD VIRGINIA AND THE NEW ERA. -- The Southern State which bids fair to attract by far the largest amount of emigration from the North this Summer is Virginia. We learn, however, that land companies are being formed, which will operate at once for the interests of old landholders and new settlers.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number full details of Jeff. Davis' capture, with detailed reports of the Trial of the assassins. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news. European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the [???] of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and [???] and deaths of the week.

abstract: The steamship City of Washington, which arrived at this port yesterday, brings European advices to May 25. The London Owl -- perhaps not the best authority -- asserts that the question of the Alabama's depredations has reached an unpleasant point, Great Britain having refused indemnity, and the American rejoinder alludes to compulsion. American ships in French ports are no longer subject to the twenty-four hour rule, the French Government having removed that restriction. Less uneasiness appears to be felt concerning the reported armed emigration from this country to Mexico. United States Five-twenties had advanced to 67 1/2. Continental news is unimportant.

lead_paragraph: On Sunday night Mr. OTTO H. CLAWS, of No. 257 Sackett-street, Brooklyn, was accosted in Tenth-avenue by three young men of good address, who asked him to go with them to take a sick man from a corner. Mr. CLAWS complied with this novel request, accompanying them to a wreeked tenement-house, where his new-found acquaintances stole his watch and chain, and f[???]. He pursued, and signaled Officer KERNAN, of the Sexteenth Ward, and [???] JOHN M[???]NNESS, of No. 224 West Twenty-fifth-street, was apprehended; but the follow's confederates escaped. The prisoner was commanded in default of $1,300 bail.

abstract: THE CITY CAR NUISANCE. -- The miseries of those who are compelled to use the horse-cars to the upper part of the island increase to a degree beyond human endurance. It is no unusual thing for conductors on the "Eastside" to boast that they have taken in as many as eighty persons on a single trip -- that is, a trip one way, either up or down -- in cars that properly hold twenty-two persons. This abomination fructifies now. But the people will and must rebel against it. Even the filth, in the streets is a more endurable evil than this packing of men, women and children into movable furnaces -- in endless layers of human grease.

abstract: WHAT CAN WE DO ABOUT IT? -- Now that the triumph of our arms has proven not only the power of the government, but the strength and safety of the democratic principle, there are beginning to be ominous fears expressed in Europe of the influence of our republican example. One English journal says: "It is not the first time that America has revolutionized Europe. The French troops returned from helping WASHINGTON to defeat England, only to cut off their own King's head. Germany is saturated with American securities, while German emigrants have filled Austria and Prussia with the spirit of Trans-Atlantic democracy. Ireland is but an outlying settlement of Federal territory." &c.

abstract: The subscription to the new series of the great 7-30 Loan last week amounted to $6,681,600, making the daily average $1,336,320. The subscriptions were steadily increasing toward the close of the week, having reached $1,513,800 on Friday, and $2,256,100 on Saturday. It is believed that the daily average of subscriptions through the current week will exceed two million dollars. The orders for the $50 and $100 notes of the new series last week averaged 931. All the gold-bearing bonds of the government were in brisk request yesterday, at a further rise in prices.

abstract: Frederick L. Hanks vs. James M. Drake et al. -- The plaintiff had employed the defendants to buy 200 shares Michigan Southern stock, on a margin of ten per cent. The defendants sold the stock for the failure of the plaintiff to keep the margin good. They sold it at the brokers' board on the same day on which they called for the additional margin. There was testimony tending to show a ratification by the plaintiff of the sale.
lead_paragraph: Frederick L. Hanks vs. James M. Drake et al. -- The plaintiff had employed the defendants to buy 200 shares Michigan Southern stock, on a margin of ten per cent. abstract: THE MURDER OF THE ITALIAN IN BROOKLYN -- CONTINUATION OF  THE CORONER's INVESTIGATION -- A DEAD MAN ROBBED. -- The investigation into the circumstances attending the murder of ANTONIO DIODATI, who was killed in the woods near the Brooklyn City line, on the 27th ult., was continued, before Coroner LYNCH and jury, yesterday afternoon. Nothing of importance was developed by the evidence, owing, in a measure, to the lack of an interpreter, several of the witnesses summoned being Italians, who speak English very imperfectly. The testimony taken is as follows:

abstract: The Quebec News, of Saturday last, makes this curious statement: "A rather singular circumstance, and one which may possibly throw some light on the great conspiracy trial now going on at Washington, transpired yesterday. The facts are as follows: Late last Autumn, a small Canadian-registered vessel (the Marie Victoria, if we are correctly informed) was wrecked in the neighborhood of Bie or Rimouski. A portion of the cargo and effects on board the vessel were saved by parties residing in the vicinity, who instituted an action in the Admiralty for damages. Among the effects recovered by the salvers are three trunks, bearing the name of 'J. WILKES BOOTH.' An application was yesterday made to Hon. Mr. BLACK, Judge of the Vice-Admiralty Court, for a commission of inspection of the contents of the trunks, which was granted. The application was made by Mr. DUNBAR, on behalf of the American Consul at this port. It remains to be seen whether the opening of the trunks will throw any light upon the Washington murder."

abstract: Duane-street Conspiracy Case

lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, in the hall of the Court of Special Sessions, Fire-Marshal BAKER and Mr. JNO. SEDGWICK appeared as prosecuting officers, before Justice DOWLING, against JUDAH PIERCE, JOHN W. FREEMAN, LUTHER N. FULLER, and WILLIAM FINDEM, late of No. 4 Erie Buildings, merchants, who were apprehended on Friday last by Capt. GREER, of the Third Ward, for alleged arson. Gen. CHATFIELD and Messrs. COOPER, BROWN, O.L. STEWART and WM. F. HOWE appeared for the defence.

abstract: On Monday evening a lad in West Twenty-first-street, seeing a woman struggling in the North River, alarmed the neighborhood, and several men sprang into the stream and strove to save her; but on taking the body to the pier life was found to be extinct. The pier being well lighted, and it being impossible that the deceased should inadvertently have walked off, it is presumed that she committed suicide. The woman's name does not appear. She was about 40 years of age, and was respectably attired in a dark woolen sack and black hood, shawl and dress.

abstract: The annual festival of the German Society of Sharpshooters commenced yesterday at Jones Wood. This year more than ordinary interest attaches to the proceedings of the society, from the fact that the trials of skill among its members will be preparatory to, and a sort of training for, the great contest at Bremen, which they are going to cross the Atlantic to attend, next month.

abstract: At West Point
snippet: At West Point
lead_paragraph: Gen. W.T. SHERMAN left the city Monday morning at 6 o'clock precisely, in the steamer Henry Burden, en route for Cincinnati. It was the intention of Gen. SHERMAN to take the 7:30 Hudson River train, but the programme was changed by Gen. DIX offering the General the use of his headquarters boat. By this means the party avoided any annoyance from the public, and gained a delicious sail up the Hudson as far as West Point. On board the excursion steamer, accompanying Gen. SHERMAN, his wife and son, were Gen. "Baldy" SMITH, Gen. VAN VLEIT, Col. DAYTON, Dr. MCMILLAN, and other members of his staff, and Mr. SCOTT, who entertained the General during his short stay in New-York. There were also on board some twenty other ladies and gentlemen.

abstract: Surrendered to Gen. Davidson
snippet: Surrendered to Gen. Davidson
lead_paragraph: The Patterson Races commenced yesterday, under the most brilliant auspices in attendance, and the admirable arrangement of the Passaic Agricultural Association. Although the weather was lowering, the attendance was unprecedentedly great, the grand stand being filled by elegantly-costumed ladies. The first race, a premium of $250, for all ages, mile heats, was won by Arcota in two straight heats; Luertine Second in each, Monmouth third, and Nightlock fourth. Time, 1:54 1/2 and 1:54. The great Paterson Derby, which has forty-four entries, single dash of one mile and a half, had eight starters, and was won by Richmond; Julius second, Maiden third, Silkstone fourth, Alexandra fifth, Saratoga sixth Mary Howell seventh, and Slasher, colt, eighth Time, 2:54 1/4; won by two lengths, half a length between second and third, a bad fourth. The premium of $600 for all ages, two mile heats, was won easily by Kentucky in two straight heats beating Capt. Moore. Time, 3:51: 4:02 3/4. The second day's racing -- including the great English Steeple Chase -- takes place to-day, without postponement.

abstract: Sterling vs. Scott, Drs., Assault and Battery
snippet: Sterling vs. Scott, Drs., Assault and Battery
lead_paragraph: Henry H. Sterling vs. James W. Scott. -- This action was brought on to trial yesterday in the Superior Court, Part I, before Chief Justice ROBERTSON and a jury. The plaintiff seeks to recover the sum of $3,000 damages, for injuries alleged to have been inflicted upon him by the defendant, on the 7th of May 1864, under the following circumstances: The plaintiff was at the time above specified the proprietor of the invention called "The Sterling Ambrosia for the Hair." He was a Doctor of Medicine, and a graduate of one of the New-England colleges. Up to May 1, 1864, it seems that he occupied rooms in the building No. 493 Broadway. At or about that time, the defendant Scott -- who was by the way another doctor -- commenced to occupy the rooms in which Dr. Sterling had formerly done his business. The latter had left some of his effects behind him, and on the 7th of the month he went there to take them away. While doing so he was, as he alleges, and as he proved yesterday in court, violently assaulted and beaten by the defendant. He claims that he was struck on the face and on the breast and stomach, and thereby injured so severely that he was compelled to abandon a thriving business and travel for his health; that he raised blood for a long time after by reason of the blows on his chest given him by the defendant; that he is not now a well man, though previously no one was more healthy than he.

abstract: The steamship North American, from Liverpool on the 25th and Londonderry on the 26th ult., arrived yesterday off Father Point. Several of the London journals deny the rumors as to the renewal of the demands of the United States Government for the depredations of the Alabama, and say the matter rests where President LINCOLN left it. Sir J. WALSH was to question Lord PALMERSTON on the subject, on the 26th, in Parliament. The Prince of WALES visited the steamship Great Eastern on the 24th, and minutely examined the Atlantic telegraph cable and the works connected therewith. The work of placing the cable on the Great Eastern is going on actively, and it is pretty certain that she will start in the early part of July, accompanied by the British frigate Terrible, and another British war steamer. The British community of Constantinople have presented an address of sympathy to the American Minister on account of the assassination of President LINCOLN.

abstract: Montreal Royal Mail Ocean Steamship Company; Anchor Line of Steamers; Inman Line of Steamers Described; Cunard Line; North German Lloyd Steamship Company; Hamburg American Packet Company; Pawtucket, Gunboat, Officers of; General Transatlantic Steamship Company; National Steam Navigation Company; Transatlantic Steamship Companies
snippet: Montreal Royal Mail Ocean Steamship Company; Anchor Line of Steamers; Inman Line of Steamers Described; Cunard Line; North German Lloyd Steamship Company; Hamburg American Packet Company; Pawtucket, Gunboat, Officers of; General Transatlantic Stea...
lead_paragraph: Thousands of our citizens who had no heart for making pleasure trips abroad during the past four years of internecine strife, are, now that the war is happily ended, casting about for the best, the safest, the cheapest and the most expeditious means of making the Transatlantic trip. For the especial benefit of this class, we have collected a variety of information concerning the several steamship lines, now in operation between this country and Europe, and publish it to-day, confident that it will prove timely and useful, not only to those who are contemplating a voyage across the Atlantic, but also to the general reader. We give on account of the seven leading steamship lines, all of which, it will be seen, are owned entirely by foreign companies; a fact which should carry with it considerable humiliation to ourselves as a maratime people.

abstract: FRANCE FOLLOWING THE LEAD OF ENGLAND -- There is a pacific item of news from France to-day by the European steamer. The Emperor's government have decided to follow the example of England in regard to the treatment of United States vessels of war. President LINCOLN's proclamation of the 11th of April has thus come to be pretty generally understood throughout Europe.

abstract: GUNTHER ON LITERATURE. -- Mr. Mayor GUNTHER is fond of preparing pleasant little surprises for those of his constituents who may sometimes doubt that he is the embodiment and type of municipal wisdom. The Common Council job of printing twenty-five thousand copies of "the report of the committee having in charge the obsequies of the late President," Mr. GUNTHER disallows on the ground that, instead of furnishing the public with a historical memoir, the Council intended to lay out a large amount of public money on "piles of printed lumber, never to be read, seldom consulted, and destined eventually for the paper-mill." This is pointed, expressive, and truthful withal. It is clear Mr. GUNTHER meant to teach the members of the Council not only economy, but style as well -- literary style. Let us suggest, as a slight tribute to His Honor's skill and pungency as a literary critic, that he be requested to edit the proposed "historical memoir" himself.

abstract: THE WAY TO EUROPE. -- Many will find convenient reference in the detailed reports of the great North Atlantic steamship lines which we publish to-day. The Atlantic Ferry is now run at a rate which will soon give us two boats a day each way; and yet they are likely to run full even at this. The vast Westward tide of emigration is met this year, by an Eastward stream of health-and-pleasure-seekers, such as is entirely unparalleled in the history of either hemisphere. It would be a greater satisfaction to record the progress, prospects, and success of these grand enterprizes, if we could number among them even one American line. Surely the reproach of being unrepresented in this vast interest will not rest much longer upon the merchants and capitalists of New-York.

abstract: The Prince of WALES visited the steamship Great Eastern on the 24th, and minutely examined the Atlantic Telegraph cable, and the works connected therewith. A very select and influential company of gentlemen were present on the occasion, among them Lord LYONS, Sir EDWARD CUNARD, GEORGE PEABODY, and CYRUS W. FIELD. The Canadian Commissioners in England, and numerous distinguished telegraph officials, were also present. The work of placing the cable on the Great Eastern is going on actively, and it is pretty certain that she will start in the early part of July, accompanied by the British frigate Terrible, and another British war steamer.

abstract: Gen. GRANT and Staff left Washington last evening, and will probably have arrived here before these lines are read by the majority of our readers. Arrangements have been made by the committee who went to Washington to invite Gen. GRANT to visit this city, fur the reception and entertainment of the General during his sojourn. Rooms have been engaged for him, and also for Gens. THOMAS, TERRY and LOGAN, at the Astor House, where, during the day, all citizens who may desire to pay their respects to these distinguished personages, will have the opportunity. In the evening, the military magnates will attend the mass meeting at the Cooper Institute; and at 11 P.M. Gen. GRANT will be serenaded at the Astor House by the Seventh Regiment Band. On Thursday morning Gen. GRANT will take his departure for West Point to witness the examination of cadets, and will then proceed to Chicago to attend the Sanitary Fair.

abstract: Ellis vs. Lessner; Replevin
snippet: Ellis vs. Lessner; Replevin
lead_paragraph: Warren Ellis et al. vs. Emil Lessner. -- This was an action of replevin to recover the possession of a quantity of bacon valued at $5,000. From the opening of the plaintiff's counsel it appeared that the bacon had been sold for cash and not paid for. When the demand for payment was made, the answer was that the goods in question had been shipped to England, and that the proceeds had not yet been realized. About a year after the sale the plaintiff commenced the action in replevin.
