abstract: The United States steamer Susquehanna, 16 guns, arrived at Havana, May 29, with the monitors Monticello, Chippewa, Fakee and Wando. The rain Stonewall was in the harbor. Notwithstanding the flaming reports circulated as to her formidable character, the officers of the Susquehanna and our correspondent considered her a miserable failure, and that six broadsides could have finished her.
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Susquehanna, 16 guns, arrived at Havana, May 29, with the monitors Monticello, Chippewa, Fakee and Wando. The rain Stonewall was in the harbor. Notwithstanding the flaming reports circulated as to her formidable character, the officers of the Susquehanna and our correspondent considered her a miserable failure, and that six broadsides could have finished her. The Stonewall is not a formidable vessel. She is greatly cramped for room. The Spaniards are trying to clean her, as she is in a filthy condition. The officers on shore have to carry their side arms, as PAGE and his crew and a whole batch of his discontented secesh are at Havana. The greatest curiosity is manifested by the entire population at the sight of the monitors, thousands of small craft plying around them incessantly. Three or four salutes are fired daily, and any number of visitors are received on board the iron-clads who curiously examine the "cheese boxes." No visitors are allowed on board, however, without a pass from the Consul-General. It is expected the Stonewall will be brought North.

abstract: New-York vs. Brooklyn, and vs. Bronxville
snippet: New-York vs. Brooklyn, and vs. Bronxville
lead_paragraph: The Gotham ball ground at Hoboken was yesterday afternoon the scene of one of the most exciting contests which has occurred there for years past, and in one respect the game was unprecedented in the annals of base ball, no less than thirteen innings being required to decide the question of superiority between the two clubs, the players being the first nines of the Gotham and Enterprise Clubs of New-York and Brooklyn. The opening part of the game was decidedly in favor of the Brooklynites, whose score stood 14 to 8 at the close of the fifth inning, but by good play the Gotham's afterward recovered their lost ground, and the close of the ninth inning found the parties equal in regard to the runs each had obtained, the score standing 17 to 17. Four more innings were then played, and it was not until the thirteenth inning was entered upon that either party scored an additional run and then the Gotham's secured 2 to their adversary's 1, thus winning by a score of 19 to 18. The game was admirably played on both sides during the latter part of it, the fielding especially being first-class Col. FITZGERALD, the editor of the Philadelphia City Item, acted as umpire, and discharged the onerous duties of his position with thorough impartiality. We append the score of this noteworthy contest:

abstract: National Academy of Design, East Room
snippet: National Academy of Design, East Room
lead_paragraph: The division of the exhibition to which we now devote ourselves contains many pictures of merit. There are necessarily some of a different order, but the balance is on the right side. Mr. S.R. GIFFORD exhibits two paintings widely divergent in character, but both good. No. 268, called "Hampton Beach," is a bright, breezy, shining spot on the ocean, with a couple of figures sitting on the sand and looking out upon the beautiful waters -- as Mr. GIFFORD probably gazed upon them -- with, the eyes of love. We notice, by the way, that sand-benched couples are becoming decidedly popular with our painters. Mr. GIFFORD's work is pretty, thoroughly finished and completely agreeable in tone. It possesses no distinct individuality, and might have been painted just as well by half a dozen other artists. This cannot be said of No, 349, "Shuwangunk Mountains." The old and well-known style of the artist comes back to us here. A vast expanse of fretted mountain ridge, exposing to our view all the secret ways of those altitudes, stretches before us. The scene is suffused with that gorgeous sunlight which Mr. GIFFORD admires so inordinately. The perspective and general sense of space are superb, whilst the wholeness of the texture of the picture is thoroughly artistic. Few even of those who object to Mr. GIFFORD's mannerism will hesitate to give this fine work the position to which it in fairly entitled. There is one thing, too, which may be conveniently mentioned here Mr. GIFFORD's mannerism is essentially and peculiarly his own. In its worst form it is yet redeemed by solid characteristics of great and unmistakable power. The difference is very clearly marked in HENRY VON INGRU's "Farm-yard Scene," No, 272. Here we have the mannerism not of an individual, but of a nation -- an imitation of the modern Flemish school, and as pluffy and rough as tools can make it. Beyond the obvious effort referred to, there is yet some merit in the picture. It is bright and healthy.

abstract: Strong Divorce Case; Order Appealed from Reversed
snippet: Strong Divorce Case; Order Appealed from Reversed
lead_paragraph: Peter R. Strong vs. Marg E. Strong. -- This was in appeal from an order made at special term of this court in December last, requiring the plaintiff to deliver to the defendant sworn copies of two letters written by the latter to a third person, (Mrs. Bedell,) and by her delivered to the plaintiff's counsel. The motion for such order was made on the pleadings, the answers of Mrs. Bedell to interrogatories on a commission, and a petition in the defendant's name, but verified by her brother, (J.A. Stevens, Jr.,) in which verification the contents of such petition were stated to be true of his own knowledge, except as to the matters therein stated on information and belief, as to which he was informed and believed they were true. Absence of the petitioner from the City of New-York, and ignorance as to her place of residence, were assigned as reasons for not verifying such petition by her own oath. Such motion was opposed on an affidavit of the plaintiff, and also one of his counsel (Murray Hoffman, Esq.) admitting the possession of the letters. This action is brought for an absolute divorce. Mrs. Bedell, in answer to interrogatories annexed to such commission to examine her, testified to the contents of certain letters received by her from the defendant, and by her destroyed, and stated that in them such defendant confessed her criminality. The letters in question were not exhibited to such witness at such examination, nor were they or their contents proved by her; she only testified to sending them to the plaintiff's counsel. The petition in question alleges what the plaintiff's affidavit denies, namely: that Mrs. Bedell testified to the contents of the letter in question. The former also stated that the defendant has no copies of them, and, therefore, could not state with accuracy their contents. The appeal was argued in the February term, before Chief-Justice Robertson and Judges Garvin and McCunn, and decided on the 27th of February last. The General Term reversed the order appealed from, Justice McCunn dissenting, and the following opinion was delivered by Robertson, Chief-Justice:

abstract: New-York State Annual Convention
snippet: New-York State Annual Convention
lead_paragraph: The annual communication of the W.W. Grand Lodge of Free and Accepted Masons of the State of New-York, was inaugurated yesterday afternoon, at the City Assembly Rooms, in "ample" form. The attendance was very large, and the seats in the spacious hall were filled by the representatives of the different lodges throughout the States, and those accredited to this Grand Lodge from other grand bodies. The array of Masons was one of the largest and most respectable assemblages that has ever convened in this city.

abstract: On Monday evening WILLIAM O'KEEFE, black-smith, and JOHN ABRAHAMS, laborer, who has long dwelt in amity in the tenement house at No. 257 East Twelfth-street, engaged in a dispute over a matter of trivial importance, and at length resorted to blows. The neighbors, who were of course attracted to the spot, attempted to interfere, but were driven off by the combatants, and the fight went on until O'KEEFE, fearing that ABRAHAMS would overcome him, drew his pocket-knife and stabbed his antagonist in the breast. He then fled, but was pursued by the bystanders, and the alarm being given to policeman KENNEDY, of the Seventeenth Ward, that officer apprehended the fugitive and took him to the Seventeenth Ward Police Station. ABRAHAMS fell when he received O'KEEFE's blow, and was immediately taken into his dwelling, where his wound, which is believed to be mortal, was dressed by Dr. SHEPPARD. He was lying very low yesterday afternoon. Yesterday morning O'KEEFE was taken to the Essex Market Police Court, and there, after examination before Justice MANSFIELD, committed to the cells to await the result of his victim's injuries.

abstract: on Oaths of Allegiance
snippet: on Oaths of Allegiance
lead_paragraph: It is said that at the late special election for members of the Legislature in Legislature in, the oath of allegiance was taken without scruple by great numbers of disloyal men, on the strength of the opinion given by REVERDY JOHNSON, in his letter last October, concerning the popular vote to be taken on the proposed new Maryland constitution. Mr. JOHNSON then declared, in reference to the oath of allegiance required from voters, that "no moral injunction will be violated by taking the oath, because the exaction of the oath was beyond the authority of the convention, and, as a law, is, therefore, void." The rebel Virginians, we can easily understand, find no difficulty in applying this doctrine to their own case. Holding that the old laws of Virginia alone prescribe the qualifications of voting, they consider that an oath, as an additional pre-requisite, is unauthorized, and, therefore, can have no binding effect on the conscience.

abstract: SUICIDE. -- A man named JOSEPH MIDDLEMORE, residing at the corner of Union-avenue and Johnson-street, committed suicide about 10 o'clock yesterday forenoon, by cutting his throat with a butcher-knife, nearly severing his head from the body. Deceased, of late, was much depressed in mind, in consequence of disappointment in business, and on several occasions had threatened to take his life. About 10 o'clock yesterday, Mr. MIDDLEMORE went down into the wood-shed, and shortly afterward was found there by his wife, with his throat cut and life extinct. Deceased was a native of England, about 64 years of age, and a brush manufacturer. Coroner BARRETT was notified and will hold an inquest to-day.

lead_paragraph: The regular monthly meeting of the New-York Historical Society was held last evening at the hall corner of Second-avenue and Eleventh-street. A large and select audience was in attendance. Lieut.-Gen. GRANT and Major-Gen. SHERMAN were unanimously elected honorary members of the society amid loud applause.

abstract: NEW DODGE OF AN ADVENTURER. -- ON Sunday evening, a tall young man, of good address, called at Messrs. THORNTON & GERRISH's drug-store, Broadway and Forty-second-street, and gave Mr. GERRISH a note, that assumed to be from Dr. ALEXANDER PERRY, of No. 136 West Forty-fourth-street, inclosing a check for $50 on the National Shoe and Leather Bank, which seemed to have been drawn by Mr. HOMER MORGAN and made payable to Dr. PERRY. The note stated that the doctor desired to use the money at church that evening, and that he would be grateful if Mr. GARRISH would cash the check. The handwriting and everything connected with the missive appearing to be legitimate, Mr. GERRISH stepped out to borrow $50; but on his return with that sum, he was unable to find the stranger, that person, suspecting that Mr. GERRISH had gone in quest of an officer, having taken a Parisian departure. Making inquiry throughout the Twenty-second Ward, Police-Captain SLOTT ascertained, yesterday, that the genteel swindler had attempted a like trick in other drug-stores and elsewhere.

abstract: Many regiments and detachments, together with a large number of stragglers, are arriving in this city daily. Those recruited in New-York are sent to Hart's Island, preparatory to being paid off and mustered out of service. The organizations belonging to the Eastern States are furnished with transportation, and forwarded to their destinations immediately. The Battery Barracks are constantly kept in preparation for the reception of regiments, and are occupied much of the time. Many of the soldiers who become disconnected from their organizations find temporary accommodations at the New-England Rooms, in Broadway, and at the State Soldiers' Depot, in Howard-street.

abstract: Meeting in New-York in Support of
snippet: Meeting in New-York in Support of
lead_paragraph: A public meeting is called for this evening, to express confidence in the character and patriotism of President JOHNSON, and to pledge the support of the great body of our people to the measures of his administration. We cannot doubt that it will be well attended. The promised presence of Lieut.-Gen. GRANT, of Gen. LOGAN, and other noble and devoted heroes of the war will insure the attendance of thousands who might take comparatively little interest in the political aspects of the day. But the public feeling of the whole country, overriding and overruling all divisions and distinctions of party, rallies to the support of ANDREW JOHNSON. The circumstances of unparalleled difficulty and delicacy which attended his accession to office, challenger for him instantly the kindest sentiments of the nation, while his high ability, his hearty sympathy with the great mass of the people, his personal share in the labor and sacrifices of the war, and the eminent service he has rendered to the Union cause, command for him the respect and confidence of all who appreciate aright the nature of the contest from which the nation has just emerged.
headline: {'main': 'Support of President Johnson.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Support of President Johnson.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: FROM THE OLD CAPITOL PRISON. -- Provost-Marshal WALDRON and Commissioner CHESHIRE have returned home from their imprisonment in the Old Capitol in Washington. It will be remembered that these gentlemen, who belonged to the Board of Enrollment of the Second District office, were arrested on the 4th ult., and conveyed to Washington by order of Col. BAKER. Mr. CHESHIRE, who is a Supervisor of the Thirteenth Ward, was arrested in the Western District while on business, and was not permitted to acquaint his family of the fact. Capt. WALDRON's arrest was equally sudden. While the officers were taking Mr. CHESHIRE on board a Wall-street ferry-boat, the Captain was coming off, and he was there seized by them and hurried off to New-York and thence to Washington. Both officials have been confined in the Old Capitol ever since, but no charges have been preferred against them. President JOHNSON having been appealed to in their behalf, ordered their discharge, with the understanding that they should appear to answer any charges brought against them by Col. BAKER. It is understood that NATHANS, the Jew, who had been previously arrested and incarcerated at the Old Capitol, was instrumental in the arrest of the above-named parties.

abstract: Grand Reception in New-York
snippet: Grand Reception in New-York
lead_paragraph: New-York was in a blaze of excitement yesterday. All the people, good, bad and indifferent, patriotic, curious and toadyistic, were up early and out before ordinary breakfast hour. From Brooklyn, Jersey City and along the line of the out-of-town railways came hundreds of others, just as patriotic, just as curious -- one and all inspired by the absorbing determination to see the hero of the hour, Lieut.-Gen. ULYSSES S. GRANT. Baffling the efforts of the enterprising, flanking the array of reportorial vigilance, the General reached his hotel, the far-famed Astor, undetected by the myriad eyes of the people, uncaught by any one of the most zealous lion-hunters, who way-laid every path but the right one.

abstract: Napoleon's, Prince, Corsica Speech, >amp;c.

lead_paragraph: The French Emperor, it will be seen, affects severe displeasure at a speech delivered by his Imperial cousin, Prince NAPOLEON, in Corsica. The cousin has resigned some of the highest offices in consequence. There is, doubtless, a good deal of imperial stage trick in this business. We shall see anon.

abstract: THE DUANE-STREET CONSPIRACY. -- Yesterday afternoon, at the Tombs, Fire-Marshal BAKER continued the examination of witnesses in the Duane-street conspiracy case, wherein JUDAH PIERCE and JOHN W. FREEMAN are held to answer for an alleged attempt to defraud the St. Nicholas, International and other insurance companies, and Mr. ALFRED A. REEVES, Secretary of the Globe Fire Insurance Company, was cross-examined until several of the counsel fell asleep, and Mr. AMOS STELLENWERF, a clerk in the Globe office, corroborated Mr. REEVE's testimony. Defendant's counsel then moved that their clients be admitted to bail, and Justice DOWLING fixed the sum at $10,000 for each. Mr. GEO. HOFFMAN, Jr., gave bail in this amount for PIERCE, and Messrs. A. COTTON and GEO. HOFFMAN, Jr., gave joint bail in $5,000 each for FREEMAN. After which Capt. GREER, in whose custody the accused have been held several days, released them, and the further hearing was adjourned until 1 o'clock this afternoon. The four merchants who are accused of the alleged conspiracy are now under $25,000 bail.

abstract: Ovation in New-York and Johnson Meeting
snippet: Ovation in New-York and Johnson Meeting
lead_paragraph: The city may be said to have, yesterday, made a formal ending of the days of public mourning for the death of the late President. There was the twofold occasion of a reception to Lieut.-Gen. GRANT and the grand demonstration in support of President JOHNSON and his administration, to bring the masses of New-York together once more for the expression of a common gratitude and the avowal of a common national faith. The masses thereupon came together as they have seldom done before. And the honors lavished upon the great Soldier at the head of the army were fitly entwined with the patriotic resolves of the vast political assemblage convened to tender to the government a cordial vote of confidence and support from the metropolis of the Union.

abstract: The Washington correspondent of the Philadelphi Ledger writes: "The complaints from the South with reference to the cotton restrictions are numerous, and an effort will be made to have them removed. Many of the parties, it is said, have realized so little from their product, when intrusted to third parties or military agents, that they prefer the cotton shall rot rather than undergo the task of hauling it within the lines. An instance is related of where the owner only received a net return of $1 per bale for his cotton, the remainder being eaten up in taxes and expenses. In the new regulations 'twenty-five per cent.' is levied at the very outset, and the response thereto will not pay the expense of the agents. An open market, those who profess to know say, will bring out the cotton, let the current price be what it may; while to hedge the traffic about with military restrictions, will only result in the staple being withheld upon the plantations."

abstract: Emigration and French Press
snippet: Emigration and French Press
lead_paragraph: THE FREE PRESS OF FRANCE. -- The French Imperialist organ here may find a text in to-day's summary of European news. One of its Paris contemporaries, it seems, has been threatened with suspension for venturing to allude to the New-York bounty-jumpers' Mexican emigration scheme. Perhaps the Franco-Mexican organ here could tell us whether it has received any warning for alluding to the same enterprise.

abstract: An investigation in the Duane-street conspiracy, wherein JUDAH PIERCE and JOHN W. FREEMAN are held to answer for an alleged attempt to demand several insurance companies, was continued yesterday, at the Tombs, by Fire-Marshal BAKER, before Justice DOWLING. MR. ALFRED A...
lead_paragraph: An investigation in the Duane-street conspiracy, wherein JUDAH PIERCE and JOHN W. FREEMAN are held to answer for an alleged attempt to demand several insurance companies, was continued yesterday, at the Tombs, by Fire-Marshal BAKER, before Justice DOWLING. MR. ALFRED A. REEVES, Secretary of the Globe Fire Insurance Company, was cross-examined at great length; and Mr. AMOS STELLENWERF, a clerk in the office, corroborated his testimony. After which a motion was made that the defendants be admitted to bail, and Justice BOWLING required them to find bail in $10,000 each. Mr. GEORGE HOFFMAN, Jr., gave required bail for PIERCE, and Messrs. A. COTTON and GEO. HOFFMAN, Jr., became bondsmen in 85,000 each for FREEMAN. Whereupon Capt. GREER released the prisoners, and the further hearing was adjourned to 1 o'clock this afternoon.

abstract: Indian Country, Proposed Colony
snippet: Indian Country, Proposed Colony
lead_paragraph: Col. MCPHAIL, late of the Minnesota Cavalry, has established a colony of 150 persons at Red Wood, far out on the head waters of the Minnesota, 40 miles beyond New-Ulm, where he proposes to settle up the country and fight Indians, using DANIEL BOONE's instead of HARDEE's tactics. He proposes to establish two other colonies further West, and in a card says he has no less than 300 correspondents on the subject -- 200 of them in the army -- who expect a discharge soon. The colony are all armed, and are more feared by the Indians than Indians by them. The Colonel expresses the opinion that this is the best way to end the war, in which opinion he widely differs from shoddy, shoulder-straps and red tape. The friendly Indians are rendering excellent service in lighting, having killed 12 [???] Indians since their [???] [???]n our rontier.

abstract: JEFF. DAVIS' DISGUISE. -- The Boston Post says: Mrs. JEFFERSON DAVIS, on the 18th January, 1861 sent an order to a firm in that city for a black-mixed waterproof cloak, with a hood to draw over the bonnet. The cloak was cut in the form of a sack, with the pockets on the inner side. Button-holes were made all the way down the front of the garment, which had a double breast and was trimmed with dark pearl buttons. This order for an article of wearing apparel which may have formed the chief part of the disguise worn by JEFF. DAVIS in his attempt to escape, will be sent to the group Chicago Fair.

abstract: Alabama, the, and United States Claims for Losses by; Government (Palmerston) and United States Claims
snippet: Alabama, the, and United States Claims for Losses by; Government (Palmerston) and United States Claims
lead_paragraph: Lord PALMERSTON, under the pressure of parliamentary questioning, has made a sort of official confession on the subject of United States claims for the depredations of the Alabama. And if his statement of the facts is not marked by peculiar ingenuousness, it is probably as honest and straightforward as might be expected from a First Minister of the Crown under the circumstances. It is at least not difficult to gather from Lord PALMERSTON that the government of the United States has not permitted the question of claims to lie in indefinite reserve -- a ponderous piece of political ordnance to be fired off at some convenient future period. Our claims have not only been submitted -- as was known many months ago -- they have been brought specially under the notice of the British Government within the last few weeks, and urged by Mr. ADAMS with conciliatory firmness.
headline: {'main': 'The British Government and United States Claims.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The British Government and United States Claims.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: London Times; Plea for the Alabama
snippet: London Times; Plea for the Alabama
lead_paragraph: The London Times, according to the European news today, makes it part of an argument against our claims for the depredations of the Alabama, that we failed to use a sufficient number of vessels to capture her! We employed, it seems, too many of our ships of war in blockading the Southern ports, and putting needless restrictions upon the British blockade-running trade. Well, this argument has at least the advantage of being novel. We might, as the London journalist suggests, have left all the Southern ports open to the neutral British traffic in saltpetre, shells, torpedoes and Armstrong guns, or for the admission of the British-built privateers and their prizes. We should, then, doubtless, have had a larger fleet to chase the Alabama from Liverpool to Nassau; thence to Bermuda, Halifax, Melbourne, (Australia,) the Cape of Good Hope, Calcutta, Hong Kong, and generally round the world where British or British colonial ports were open to welcome her, while practically closed against war vessels of the United States. We should have also shown in this way that we were intensely eager to make any bill of claims against our neutral neighbors as light as possible. But in the end, let us suggest, we we should probably have had to see the best part of the prize snatched from some one of our lucky cruisers by a British neutral craft, just as it happened outside Cherbourg Harbor. So that we fail to see the exceeding merit of the London Times' suggestion of what we might as to what we should have done. The notion is, nevertheless, ingenious enough as a plea in favor of the pirates and against us. We venture to say, moreover, it is quite as valid a plea as any that is likely to be put forward in the case.
headline: {'main': 'A PLEA FOR THE ALABAMA.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'A PLEA FOR THE ALABAMA.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Speech at Grant's Meeting, New-York; Speech at Johnson Inauguration, New-York; Great Meeting in New-York in Support of; Speech at Johnson Meeting, New-York
snippet: Speech at Grant's Meeting, New-York; Speech at Johnson Inauguration, New-York; Great Meeting in New-York in Support of; Speech at Johnson Meeting, New-York
lead_paragraph: There have been many rows, many disturbances, many scenes of confusion in the city of New-York, but we do not remember any one or any number of them combined, which in rowdyism, disturbance, and confusion can compare with that which characterized the first hour of the monster meeting at Cooper Institute. Published in the morning papers was a call for a meeting of those who desired to extend a hearty support to the administration of President ANDREW JOHNSON. It was announced that Gen. GRANT, Gen. AUGUR, Gens. THOMAS, LOGAN, BLAIR and others would be present, while they and other well-known men would address the audience.

abstract: Question and the Monroe Doctrine
snippet: Question and the Monroe Doctrine
lead_paragraph: It is odd how much more largely "the Mexican question" figures over the water than here. The European journals are all agog concerning the designs of our government upon MAXIMILIAN. All kinds of rumors float through their news columns; all kinds of speculations inflate their editorials. Each issue is but a new kaleidoscopic arrangement of protests and threats sent to the French Emperor -- peremptory notices to MAXIMILIAN to quit -- incontinent filibusters swooping down -- secret treaties with JAUREZ, full of direful portent. Publicists are perplexed; capitalists nervous; philosophers curious; quidnuncs in a ferment. On the other hand, the American mind shows very little concern about the matter. It may occasionally glance at it, and then quietly turns away. It neither discusses nor denounces. It drops a remark or two, and passes to higher claims upon its attention. It troubles itself as little about MAXIMILIAN in Mexico as about Sancho in Barataria.

abstract: New-York Club, Annual Regatta; Brooklyn Club, Annual Regatta
snippet: New-York Club, Annual Regatta; Brooklyn Club, Annual Regatta
lead_paragraph: Our yachtsmen have been favored this year with wind and weather; the elements have conspired to do their behests, and nothing was needed to insure entire success but individual effort and combined willingness to have an enjoyable season. Americans are no Mesdames Chick. It can never be said that they are unwilling to make an effort, as the result of the racing and boating of this season abundantly proves. For years, yachting, which is yet in its infancy, or, at best, in short clothes, has struggled against prejudice, ignorance and time. Some regarded it as an amusement too exclusive in its nature, others knew nothing of its exhilarations, while to the mass, the time needed for a thorough trial of its most enjoyable experiences, was a drawback of insurmountable proportions.

abstract: Processes of
snippet: Processes of
lead_paragraph: It will be remembered that two years ago, when the war was at its height, and the prospects of the conquest of the South anything but cheerful, the country was very greatly exercised upon the question of "reconstruction." How it was to be accomplished; what were to be its modes and conditions; upon what principle it was to be effected, or on what precise system it was to be conducted, were questions that called forth volumes of Congressional eloquence; filled the newspapers; gave birth to numerous factions, and greatly agitated the whole people.

abstract: All over the World; Trade, Cotton, >amp;c.; Revival; Silence, the Virtue of, in Grant and Sherman
snippet: All over the World; Trade, Cotton, >amp;c.; Revival; Silence, the Virtue of, in Grant and Sherman
lead_paragraph: A public man, adored by the nation and the recipient of countless "ovations," who has not "the gift of the gab," and cannot put two sentences together in public, is a very novel phenomenon in this country, and yet we have had two such among us, in the persons of Gens. GRANT and SHERMAN, within the last week. No amount of pressure or persuasion has been sufficient to extract a speech from either of them, though there are, probably, no two men in the world, at this moment, who have so much to say that is worth saying, and that everybody would like to hear.

abstract: Good Policy Appointing Southern Men for Southern Offices; Men for Southern Offices
snippet: Good Policy Appointing Southern Men for Southern Offices; Men for Southern Offices
lead_paragraph: President JOHNSON consults the dictates of good policy in selecting, so far as possible, for official stations in the Southern States, loyal Southern men. In the appointment of Mr. HOLDEN to be Military Governor of North Carolina, and in selecting Southern residents for Collectors of Internal Revenue at Savannah, Charleston, Mobile and Pensacola, he has indicated the general policy to be pursued in this respect. It is much wiser than the policy which has been warmly pressed upon him, of sending Northern men to fill those offices in the rebel States. The latter course would be a distinct practical proclamation that we had achieved a conquest of the Southern people, and that we intended to hold and to treat them as a subjugated community; that we would not intrust thorn with any of the duties and powers of office, but would send men among them from other States to execute the law and represent the authority of the victorious and conquering government. Such a course could not fail to exasperate and alienate the great body of the Southern people.
headline: {'main': 'Southern Men for Southern Offices.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Southern Men for Southern Offices.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

lead_paragraph: The Duane-street conspiracy investigation was continued, yesterday, at the Tombs, by Fire-Marshal BAKER, before Justice DOWLING, and two witnesses were examined. Mr. JAMES WARREN, of No. 103 Ninth-street, clerk in the New-York Warehouse Security Company's office, testified that both prior to the second alleged incendiary fire at No. 4 Erie Buildings, and subsequently, he viewed the property upon which the Security Company had made advances, and that subsequent to the fire he ascertained that a large number of the whisky-barrels which were stored in the building, were found to be empty. Mr. EDGAR E. HOLLEY, Surveyor for the Globe Fire Insurance Company, was put on the stand, and the further hearing was adjourned to 1 o'clock this afternoon.

lead_paragraph: At about 4 o'clock on Tuesday morning, a fight occurred in the Gaieties Concert Saloon, in Broadway, near East Houston-street, and JOSEPH JOHNSTON, of No. 218 Spring-street, was stabbed in four places in the abdomen. He was taken to the New-York Hospital, and there an ante-mortem inquest was held on Wednesday, and testimony was taken as follow:

abstract: Assistant District Attorney Hutchings appeared for the people yesterday, and called as the first case that of Paul Valner, a dishonest Tenton, who was indicted for stealing a watch and chain from the person of Henry Strauss, while the said Henry was enjoying his lager at Jones' wood on a warm day in May last.  Complainant testified that the value of the watch was $20.

abstract: -The squabble between NAPOLEON and his Cousin might be looked upon as one of some dynastic as well as political significance, were it not that the same sort of farce has been played over and over again, not as between the cousins alone, but between the Emperor and his wife as well. This business of keeping up the appearance of a democratic and conservative antagonism in the family is as old as the first Empire. The present representative of Bonapartism adopts it because it is a tradition. The parvenu worships tradition, because he hasn't much of it to go upon. When the Emperor affects a political quarrel with his Imperial spouse, and sends a special warning to her newspaper organ, La France, he plays the radical or democratic role himself against the ultramontanists. When he falls out with Prince NAPOLEON, the Prince plays democrat, and the Sovereign becomes as conservative as if his family name and honors ran back in direct line to CHARLEMAGNE. If there is any political meaning in this Imperial rumpus, it is that the Emperor has thoughts of backing out of Mexico, and ordered the Cousin to break the ice on that delicate question.

abstract: FIREMENS' COURTESIES RECEPTION OF WARREN HOSE OF PHILADELPHIA There was a fine display of Brooklyn Firemen on Wednesday afternoon, for the purpose of receiving Warren Hose Company No. 29 of Philadelphia, now on a visit to this city and New-York. The announcement that the visitors would land at Montague Ferry, attracted large numbers to the...
lead_paragraph: FIREMENS' COURTESIES -- RECEPTION OF WARREN HOSE OF PHILADELPHIA. -- There was a fine display of Brooklyn Firemen on Wednesday afternoon, for the purpose of receiving Warren Hose Company No. 29 of Philadelphia, now on a visit to this city and New-York. The announcement that the visitors would land at Montague Ferry, attracted large numbers to the heights, all of whom were greatly disappointed when it was arcertained that the company, with their New-York escort, landed at South Ferry. Constitution Engine Company No. 7, whose guests they were during their brief stay, received them at the foot of Atlantic-street, and escorted them up Atlantic and through Court-street to Montague Hall, in the following order:

abstract: The concluding festivities connected with the farewell gathering of the New-York Schutzen Corps, preparatory to its departure for Bremen, took place yesterday at Jones' Woods, and very pleasant they were. Delightful weather favored the fair women and brave men who assembled to take part in the ceremonies of the occasion, and nothing occurred to mar their pleasure. It is characteristic of the Germans to be orderly and quiet on such festive occasions. During the eight or nine years that the Schutzen Corps has been in existence their gatherings have never, in a single instance, been disgraced by a row. Even minor disturbances of the peace have been entirely unknown among them.

abstract: Means of his Widow and Family; Express, Tribune, >amp;c.
snippet: Means of his Widow and Family; Express, Tribune, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: MRS. LINCOLN's MEANS. -- It is not true, says the Tribune -- far from it -- that "the late President left an ample fortune." On the countrary, we happen to know that Mr. LINCOLN'S executor and nearest friend, United States Judge DANIEL DAVIS, of Illinois, after taking an account of the estate, has notified Mrs. LINCOLN that she cannot afford to keep house on her means, but must board. -- Express.

abstract: The last of the veterans have been reviewed. The war-worn and battle-scarred Sixth Army Corps to-day marched through Washington and exhibited its tattered banners and admirable organization to thousands of spectators. The pageant was only less in interest than that of two weeks ago, because less in size, but there were many hundreds of eager eyes that gazed with satisfaction upon the battalions, ...

abstract: New-York, Wooster-street, Connor, Dennis, Robbed
snippet: New-York, Wooster-street, Connor, Dennis, Robbed
lead_paragraph: Late on Wednesday night DENNIS CONNOR, of Portland, Me., was garroted and robbed by GEORGE PETERSON, a colored waiter, and a confederate, while passing through Wooster-street. The fellow knocked him to the pavement, and thentying a handkerchief over his mouth, rifled his pockets of $115 in Treasury notes. Fortunately Policeman GRADY, of the Eighth Ward, heard the shriek which CONNOR uttered before the ruffians applied the handkerchief, and reached the spot in season to take PETERSON into custody, but the other outlaw escaped. PETERSON was committed without bail.

abstract: A sad accident, resulting in the death of a rigger, occurred at the yard yesterday morning. Mr. JOHN MORTON, while in the act of carrying the end of a cable rope across the plank from the edge of the Dry Dock, on board the United States steamer Hartford, now being repaired, fell on the hard granite pavement, about forty feet, and was picked up insensible. He was instantly attended by Drs. EVERSFIELD and LUCK, United States Navy, but his injuries were internal, and he died after half an hour's suffering. The Coroner was duly notified. Deceased leaves a wife and four children in a destitute condition. . . . . United States schooner Sam. Rotan arrived Wednesday, Acting-Ensign J.W. MILLER, commanding, and MICHAEL TOBEY, Acting Mate. The Frolic, tender of the Colorado, is in commission, and hauled in the stream; she took her crew on board at 1 o'clock P.M., yesterday. The Nyack is in commission, hauled in the stream, and has her crew on board. The Peoria is moved alongside the dock, taking in stores, and about getting ready for service. The recently captured prize Sarah M. Newhall, off Charleston, S.C., is the object of many curious questions by persons supposed to be interested in her. It appears she left Galveston, Texas, under legitimate instructions, and stopped at the port of Savannah, understanding that it was open. She was stopped and declared a prize. It is supposed she will be acquited and returned to her owners. Several seacaptains were under the impression that the port was open at the time the Newhall was captured . . . . A board of three naval officers, of which Commodore SELFRIDGE is President, is now holding sessions at the Navy-yard, and engaged in business of a private nature.

abstract: on Disposal of Rebel Leaders; Oration on Disposal of Rebel Leaders
snippet: on Disposal of Rebel Leaders; Oration on Disposal of Rebel Leaders
lead_paragraph: The announcement that GERRITT SMITH would lecture on the following subject: "That the Government has neither the legal not moral right to try the rebels, and that the way to a sure and enduring peace lies not through perfidy and vengeance, but through justice and law," attracted a large audience to Cooper Institute last evening. All of the seats were occupied by an intelligent and orderly assemblage.

abstract: Visit to West Point
snippet: Visit to West Point
lead_paragraph: Gen. GRANT, true to his great reputation as a "flanker," completely outmanoeuvred New-York, by leading the public to suppose, through the newspapers, that he had left the city at midnight of Wednesday, on his way to West Point. In reality, he slept quietly at the Astor House until 6 o'clock yesterday morning, when he proceeded up the river on his projected visit. As a piece of pure strategy this manoeuvre ought to rank high among the many similar achievements of the Lieutenant-General.

abstract: Capt. DE ROHAN, Naval A.D.C. to Gen. GARIBALDI, and Commodore of the second Garibaldi Expedition to Sicily in 1860, under the American flag, had the honor of presenting to Gen. GRANT yesterday the congratulations of Gen. GARIBALDI, who throughout the rebellion has never for a single instant wavered in the most outspoken and heartfelt expressions of sympathy for our cause. It may not be generally known that GARIBALDI is a citizen of the United States, and during his retirement to Caprera has watched with the greatest anxiety the progress of events, maintaining steadily against contrary opinions oftentimes expressed by English visitors, that the cause of liberty must and would triumph, and that if the North failed, then might he and every other soldier of freedom well despair, "For," said the General, "though I am an Italian, yet am I also a soldier of humanity."

abstract: The advent of ELIAS HOWE, Jr.'s, sewing-machine establishment in Broadway (No. 529) is an event of interest, inasmuch as he is known to the public as the original inventor of sewing-machine. His machine comes with the prestige of the maker's name, and its established excellence. He is a thoroughly educated and practical mechanic, and his long and necessary familiarity with the business peculiarly qualifies him to judge of the public wants, and how far they are supplied. His manufactory is established at Bridgeport, Conn., near that of WHEELER & WILSON, which it rivals in size, completeness of appointment and system of management. The machine itself has merited and received the highest awards at various fairs, including the World's Fair, London, in 1862, and it challenges comparison with any of its class. For leather work, tailoring and manufacturing purposes, it has no superior, and we predict for it a success second to none of its kind. -- World.

abstract: ARREST OF DEALERS IN "QUEER." -- Yesterday morning Officer COWEN, of the City Hall force, apprehended, at the Western Hotel, one LEWIS F. GARRETT, a resident of Newark, who describes himself as a farmer, of New-Ulm, Sullivan County; and Officer MCCORD, of the same force, apprehended, at the Girard House, one LEWIS SCHUESTER, of New-Ulm, farmer, both prisoners having been found passing well-executed and deceptive spurious fifty-cent fractional notes in imitation of the new fifty-cent currency. The prisoners had in their possession counterfeit currency representing upward of $100. SHUESTER, who is a German, aged 52 years, was taken before United States Commissioner OSBORN, and held to await an examination on Monday next, and GARRETT was sent to Newark under a warrant which had been issued by the authorities there.

abstract: The Sixth Army Corps was yesterday reviewed by the President. A stand for the President, the members of the Cabinet, general officers and the foreign legations, was erected on the pavement in front of the Executive Mansion, and another stand was placed on the opposite side of the street for the accommodation of members of Congress and military and naval officers, and directly east of it a third stand was located, for the occupation of sick and disabled soldiers. All of these stands were tastefully decorated. The Sixth Army Corps has participated in all the battles of the Army of the Potomac, from its organization. Maj.-Gen. MEADE, commanding the Army of the Potomac, accompanied by his staff, and Gens. SLOCUM, HUMPHRIES, HUNT and MEIGS, were among the prominent officers at the reviewing stand. Secretary SEWARD witnessed the passage of the finely drilled and war-worn troops from a window of the State Department. The head of the column reached the Treasury Department at about 10 o'clock. Maj.-Gen. H.G. WRIGHT was in the advance, with his staff, followed by his escort. The General's horse was decorated with a beautiful wreath, and his saddle was covered with flowers. Maj.-Gen. BARTLETT rode with the staff, and was followed by the corps flag and escort. The troops comprised in the Sixth Corps are from New-Jersey, Connecticut, New-York, Pennsylvania, Rhode Island, Massachusetts, Wisconsin, Vermont, Maine, Ohio and Maryland. The troops as they passed were enthusiastically cheered by the thousands of spectators, among whom were not a few soldiers supported by crutches. The veterans of the corps wore green twigs on their caps and flowers were profusely displayed by the officers. The old torn and faded battle-flags were proudly borne in the long line. A detachment of New-York Engineers brought up the rear. The spectacle was as imposing and interesting as the previous reviews, though not so extensive as to numbers.

abstract: Paterson Spring Meeting, Last Day
snippet: Paterson Spring Meeting, Last Day
lead_paragraph: The third and last day's racing of the Paterson Spring meeting came of yesterday, (Thursday.) The avidity with which the elite off New-York have taken hold of the Paterson races, and given it the weight of its affluent support, was fully manifested on Wednesday, (the steeple-chase day,) when such a throng assembled on the occasion as has never previously been seen, remarkable alike for its numbers and respectability, on any race course in the vicinity of New-York. The result of the admirable management displayed by the executives of the meeting, the earnest desire to contribute to the comfort of all present, the strict attention to decorum, and the excellent punctuality which was maintained in all the details, found its reflex in the closing day of the meeting. The last day, or "wind-up" of a racing meeting is usually a dull affair. The great events are usually exhausted, as also the vim of the visitors, and the result is generally a series of consolation scrambles among the contending stables, and defeated horses, for "hay and straw" compensation. It was not so, however, at Paterson; for in addition to the three great races previously advertised, the association, with a liberality which does it honor, threw in a fourth and extra race in the shape of a handicap hurdle race, with a premium of $400 for the winner and $100 for the second horse, for which all the steeple-chase horses of the previous day, and two other fresh horses, were entered.

abstract: Impertinent Advice from Impertinent Men; Pleas for the South
snippet: Impertinent Advice from Impertinent Men; Pleas for the South
lead_paragraph: It was unfortunate for the meeting held last night to hear Mr. GERRITT SMITH deliver himself on " reconstruction, conciliation and pacification," that the gentleman who was announced to take the chair, and, at least, two of those who signed the call, should have been persons who have been from the outset bitter opponents of the war, or in other words, warm supporters of JEFF. DAVIS' right to do as he pleased. Mr. CHARLES O'CONNOR, for instance, was just as much opposed to all measures for the restoration of the national authority in the rebellious States as JUDAH P. BENJAMIN himself, though being a sensible man, he of course never thought of displaying his feelings in anything more potent than words. Mr. O'GORMAN, too, was perfectly horrified by the whole struggle which has just ended so gloriously, and in 1862 -- 3, in the dark days of the war, when many hearts were faint and weary, did not hesitate to use what influence he possessed to aggravate the general doubt and despondency. Of Mr. S. M. BARLOW there is very little to be said. If a man's words and acts count for anything, no bitterer enemy of the government, when the government needed all the support it could get, was to be found, at least in the whole North, than himself. And he derives an additional claim to the respectful attention of the community, from the fact that he was a leading member of the famous Society for the Diffusion of Political Information, which devoted itself in the Spring of 1863 to reviling Mr. LINCOLN for meddling with slavery, and the spread of tracts proving the divine origin of that institution.

abstract: 'STAT NOMINIS UMBRA." -- The lately-sown grass in the park springs up healthily; and the foliage of the trees has a cheerful and reviving look about it, such as has not been witnessed for many years. These natural adornments, it is true, are enjoyed at the sacrifice of certain purely artistic features of the park. The Statue, a composite work, (by an unknown artist, who has embodied in one impressive figure, the popular ideal of several grand revolutionary characters,) for example -- is partially lost to view, and the worshiper of art in its rarest expression finds the favorite object for the time under an umbrageous obscurity. The artistic eye is, in a measure, disappointed. But the less sophisticated multitude find their satisfaction in the green adornments of nature. Thus, in all things, may we find compensation. "Stat nominis umbra" -- let the statue remain in the shade.

abstract: On Negro Suffrage and Repudiation
snippet: On Negro Suffrage and Repudiation
lead_paragraph: Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS was recently represented as having declared that unless universal suffrage was conceded to the enfranchised slaves, he for one would advocate the repudiation of the debt incurred by the war. As he had already declared that the war, in that event, would be proved to have been a failure and a fraud, it did not seem unnatural that he should favor the refusal to pay its costs. But the Anti-Slavery Standard publishes what it calls a "corrected report" of his remarks, which represents him as having taken a different position from that ascribed to him. He is now reported to have said that if the negro is excluded from the ballot-box, the whites of the South will send men to Congress who will, by joining the Democrats, carry the assumption of the rebel war debt; and that this debt thus assumed Mr. PHILLIPS would repudiate. We accept the amended version of Mr. PHILLIPS' remarks, as somewhat more creditable to his honesty, though much less complimentary to his judgment than the other.
headline: {'main': 'Wendell Phillips on Negro Suffrage and the War.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Wendell Phillips on Negro Suffrage and the War.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: United States vs. Thirty-five Bales Cotton, >amp;c.
snippet: United States vs. Thirty-five Bales Cotton, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The United States vs. Thirty-five Bales of Cotton and Other Goods. -- This was an action brought to forfeit the goods, which were valued at about $35,000, for an alleged violation of the non-intercourse acts, it being alleged that these goods were proceeding from the rebel States to the loyal States. The goods formed part of the cargo of the brig Elf, which arrived in this port from Matamoras in October, 1863, and the ground of forfeiture was that the cotton was purchased in Texas. The goods were claimed by Mr. Caymari.

abstract: London Herald; Mock Heroics on Davis
snippet: London Herald; Mock Heroics on Davis
lead_paragraph: -- The English press, friendly as well as unfriendly, take the capture of JEFF. DAVIS very much to heart. Like that late eminent fugitive from justice, they think that our government should have been more magnanimous than to hunt him down; and now, that he is caught, they are anxious we should "swear him, and let him go." The Star, News and Times unite in reminding us that the quality of mercy isn't strained, and that we ought to forgive and forget. But, with one exception, the English papers admit that DAVIS has no personal claims to mercy. The News holds him responsible for the last two years of the war; and the Times reminds its readers that the author of the Mississippi repudiation scheme, the calumniator of the English people, is not entitled to respect or even sympathy. The only exception is the London Herald. Unabashed by the ridiculous figure its hero cut in his endeavor to escape, that journal exclaims:

abstract: Lynch vs. Kennedy, Extraordinary Verdict
snippet: Lynch vs. Kennedy, Extraordinary Verdict
lead_paragraph: James Lynch, Receiver, &c., vs. John Kennedy. The action was brought by plaintiff, as receiver of the late firm of McClish, Lyon & Co., iron-founders of this city, to recover the sum of $578 46, for iron railings sold by that firm to the defendant, on or about the 1st day of June, 1861. There was no dispute about the sale and delivery of the goods, but the defendant in his answer set up that one Edward Kilpatrick was engaged in building some houses for him in this city, and that by agreement between the latter and Kilpatrick, he (Mr. Kilpatrick) was to furnish the iron railings, and not, the defendant. There was considerable testimony taken on the trial, at the conclusion of which the case was submitted and the jury, after a short absence, returned into court with a verdict for the defendant. After the rendition of the verdict the Court immediately said: "Gentlemen, this is the most extraordinary verdict I ever heard." The Judge -- (To counsel for plaintiff) -- "You may move at once to set aside the verdict." It is understand that a motion will be immediately made to set aside the verdict as against evidence, and thus secure a new trial. The observations of the Court in regard to the verdict produced quite a sensation in the court-room.

abstract: To-day closes the Summer examination of the naval students at Newport. The examination was attended by the following Board of Visitors, appointed by the head of the Navy Department: Vice-Adimal D.G. FARRAGUT, U.S.N., President; Rear-Admiral D.D. Porter, U.S.N., Capt. J.L. Worden, U.S.N., Hon. Jos. T. Mills of Wisconsin, Rev. C.B. Boynton, D.D., of Maryland, John Jacob Astor, Jr., of New-York, J.M. Forbes, Esq., of Massachusetts, members.
lead_paragraph: To-day closes the Summer examination of the naval students at Newport. The examination was attended by the following Board of Visitors, appointed by the head of the Navy Department: Vice-Adimal D.G. FARRAGUT, U.S.N., President; Rear-Admiral D.D. Porter, U.S.N., Capt. J.L. Worden, U.S.N., Hon. Jos. T. Mills of Wisconsin, Rev. C.B. Boynton, D.D., of Maryland, John Jacob Astor, Jr., of New-York, J.M. Forbes, Esq., of Massachusetts, members. Their duties were to attend the examination, and inquire into the state of the police, discipline and general management of the institution, the results of which were to be reported to the Secretary of the Navy. On Monday the interesting proceedings commenced by examining the first class in interternational, constitutional and maritime law, both in writing and orally. The second class was examined in naval gunnery, and the fourth in algebra. Commander J.S. BLAKE, the respected commandant of the institution, was highly complimented for the discipline manifested in every department. Over two hundred applicants for admission were examined, nearly three-fourths of whom passed. The school-ships Constitution and Santee are moored in their old places, together with the practice-ships Macedonia, Marion, Marbethead. The Atlantic-house, as well as the vessels, is filled with midshipmen. At present there are about 500 students at the academy, divided into four classes. Two examinations are held annually, the second occurring in September. Everything is provided for the comfort and welfare of the student. The daily routine begins with the reveille at 6 A.M. all the year round, when the middles turn out, stow away their hammocks and wash and dress for inspection at 6:50. Breakfast, prayer and the sick call fill the time to 7:57, when the forenoon studies and recitations commence, which lasts until 12:57, when dinner is called. Afternoon studies begin at 1:57 and continue to the retreat at 3:57. From 4 to 5:45 military drill on shore, takes place and sometimes a good deal of sky-larking. Supper and the evening parades intervene and the evening studies are called at 7:30. Hammocks are slung at 9:30; at taps (9:53) all turn in; at four bells, seven minutes after, there must be perfect silence fore and aft. The table is supplied not by rations, as in actual service, but by a commissary who is paid per week or month, as at a hotel. The cost per month for boarding a midshipman is $16 50. A middy's pay is $500 per annum, which is intended orly to cover his necessary expenses for maintenance and clothing. Of this they are not permitted to draw more than $100 a year, thus forming [???] of [???] year term, with which to procure an outfit for actual service. Liberty to go ashore is granted each Saturday, except to those who forfeit the privilege by improper conduct. While on liberty the rules of the academy must be strictly observed, the middy being required to state in writing that they have not violated the "regulations." Church parties are formed on Sunday, to go to whatever place of worship they please -- going to and returning from church without stopping at any other place. In such a large assembly of young gentlemen, there are of course a few who represent the cruder specimens of humanity, but the strict regulations have an excellent effect in forming a gentlemanly character. It is a well-known fact that our navy, during the rebellion, has greatly felt the need of accomplished officers. Our navy should prefer the flower of American youth an applicants for admission in the Academy, rather than those favored one appointed by members of Congress. High authority has suggested that the present system be done away with, and the system of competitive examinations be adopted, in which the successful contestants would obtain the appointments. The highest and lowest ranks would then be represented within the walls of the Academy. At the last examination not more than one-third of those that entered the Academy finally graduated, owing to ill-hearth, interest, and voluntary resignations. The cruise of two or three months this Summer is looked to with happy anticipations by the students. They will probably debark at Annapolis, Maryland, as the commodious buildings and grounds of that locality have been undergoing a thorough renovation.

abstract: Returning; Gratitude Forgotten in New-York
snippet: Returning; Gratitude Forgotten in New-York
lead_paragraph: -- All through the week our city has been jubilant. Every day the eager crowds of our population have thronged the busy streets as regiment after regiment of returning braves have passed through them, browned by exposure in field and camp, with garments stained and torn by war, but with high and martial step, with brightly-gleaming arms, and flags illustrious with the records of victory. As the rivers of steel wound their way between groves of welcoming banners, shouts of gladness rose from the thousand-voiced people, flowers, strewn by fair hands, carpeted the earth, and glorious strains of music and of song lifted the souls of a grateful city to a delirium of joy. Not forgotten are our heroes! The tender melody of bands which, with speaking voice, proclaimed the return of peace, or rang forth martial airs sacred to our national history, and which chronicle the deeds of our soldiers, spoke for us all. The men who sit at our Council Boards, as with all the honors at their command they welcomed the Army Come Home, spoke for us. And while that army felt that "Home, Sweet Home" was theirs once more, we, for whose hearths and firesides and liberties and honor they have fought and bled, made them feel that, while we valued all that was worth living for, we were grateful and would never _____ _____

abstract: New-York, Forty-second-street, Highway, of Mr. Golding
snippet: New-York, Forty-second-street, Highway, of Mr. Golding
lead_paragraph: Early on Thursday evening Mr. LAWRENCE G. GOLDING, of No. 26 Jefferson-street, was assaulted and robbed by two ruffians whom he encountered in Forty-second-street, near Eleventh-avenue. One of the following, who describes himself as JOSEPH LELLIS, of Canada, aged 18 years, was apprehended by Patrolman BROOKS, of the Twentieth Ward; but the stolen property, consisting of a gold watch, chain, &c., which LELLIS had passed into the hands of a confederate who escaped, was not recovered. Declining to receive bail for LELLIS, Justice LEDWITH committed him to the cells.

abstract: ADVENTURES OF CONVICTS ON A HARLEM TRAIN -- ONE RETURNED TO SING SING. -- On Thursday morning MARTIN TOOLE, a murderer, who five years ago was sentenced to serve twelve years and six months in Sing Sing Prison, escaped with a follow-convict, and the two boarded a Harlem Railroad train at Mount Kisco Station, but were suspected by the conductor, notwithstanding their sailor garb, and when they were about to go from the cars at Mount Vernon station, they were detained. Finding remonstrance useless, they morosely rode on until the train reached the tunnel at Thirty-fourth-street, when, in the darkness, one of the convicts escaped through the door of the car; not, however, until he had been once knocked down by the conductor. And TOOL attempted to leap from a window, but was caught by the leg and held until the car reached Twenty-seventh-street, when he was turned over to Officer MCCUSKER. He was sent back to Sing Sing yesterday. His confederate is still at large.

abstract: The Toronoto Leader calls attention to the fact that "bounty-jumpers" are thronging that city, which reminds one of the proverb about "curses like chickens",  It adds: "Their moneymaking pursuits having been put an end to by the stoppage of the war, they are open for all sorts of reckless and daring undertakings.
lead_paragraph: The Toronoto Leader calls attention to the fact that "bounty-jumpers" are thronging that city, which reminds one of the proverb about "curses like chickens", It adds: "Their moneymaking pursuits having been put an end to by the stoppage of the war, they are open for all sorts of reckless and daring undertakings. It has come to the knowledge of the police authorities that one of the schemes concocted by those scoundrels is the robbery of one or more of the city banks in the daytime; and it is not without good grounds for the belief that it is now made public. No harm can thus be done, while those particularly interested may be awakened to a consciousness of their danger and the possibilty of such a scheme being carried but successfully. All the bank managers and brokers should be prepared for consequences of this nature. In some of the banks, where there are only a few young men as clerks, there would be no difficulty whatever in a few bold men securing in a few minutes the large amount of money which, during office hours, is always exposed upon the desks. The managers of these institutions, warned of their danger, are understood to have made special preparation to guard against an attack which may come upon them when least expected. Indeed, it seems that, as a necessary measure of precaution, fire-arms should be always available at banks and exchange offices offices, especially during office hours."

abstract: Free Lances for
snippet: Free Lances for
lead_paragraph: The news from the Rio Grande points to the probability of a considerable military emigration from Texas to Mexico. In view of this emigration it may be well for the Imperialists not to reckon too surely on their "Confederate" friends in any fighting that may have to be done. If KIRBY SMITH has gone across the river, he has gone, first, to escape a trial for treason; second, to make money; third, to take sides with the party most likely to win. This simple theory of the case MAXIMILIAN and his French friends will and worth consulting before many more months pass over their heads. We make them a present of it for nothing.

abstract: Fellowship of London Times, New-York Tribunes, Daily News, >amp;c.
snippet: Fellowship of London Times, New-York Tribunes, Daily News, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: -- The London Times received last night, fully backs up the views of the universal forgiveness association of New-York. For once, the patriot who controls the Daily News may quote the British oracle with approval. It reasons in favor of DAVIS and his confederates from the stand-point of the last Irish rebellion -- a fact which must make its arguments of peculiar interest to one partaker, at least, of the goodly fellowship which has brought the editor of the late Richmond Inquirer, the editor of the Tribune, the editor of the London Times, Mr. RICHARD O'GORMAN, Mr. GERRIT SMITH and Mr. S.M. BARLOW into one political bed.

abstract: At police trials, on Wednesday, there were several distinguished visitors who had come to NewYork expressly to learn something of the Metropolitan Police machine among them Capts. John H. Northrup, Charles R. Squire, and James A. Cross, and Sergts. Win. E. O'Brien, Perry, and Bogardus, of the Capital Police, of Troy.
lead_paragraph: At police trials, on Wednesday, there were several distinguished visitors who had come to NewYork expressly to learn something of the Metropolitan Police machine -- among them Capts. John H. Northrup, Charles R. Squire, and James A. Cross, and Sergts. Win. E. O'Brien, Perry, and Bogardus, of the Capital Police, of Troy. Judge Strong was also among the visitors. At the opening, President ACTON's table bore seventy-two complaints; and at the close it was manifest that at least sixty-five of the number ought never to have been entertained, or that they should have, been cleared up by the Captains and other officers in their respective station-houses, without putting the commissioners to the trouble and expense of preparing formal indictments and taking more than two hundred men from active duty to spend at least half a day at Police Headquarters. Why could not Officer Cornell, who was found off post, in a stable, from 6:10 to 7:45, have, been tried by the Captain and Sergeants of his own precinct? They would then have learned that he was watching mischievous boys; and it the superior officers had done him any injustice, he could have appealed to the commissioners. These gentlemen run the Metropolitan Police machine, it is true; but if they continues to waste the police time in trials that should be conducted in the station-houses, they may expect the public to make its own comment.

abstract: Duane-street, Conspiracy; Case Closed; no Jurisdiction
snippet: Duane-street, Conspiracy; Case Closed; no Jurisdiction
lead_paragraph: Fire-Marshal Baker continued the investigation in the case of Judah Pierce, John W. Freeman, Luther N. Fuller, and William Findon, the liquor-dealers who are alleged to have attempted, by destroying their stock of liquors at No. 4 Erie Buildings, Duane-street, to defraud the St. Nicholas, International, and other insurance companies, and the New-York Warehouse and Security Company. Only two witnesses were examined Thursday, and the hearing was then adjourned to 1 o'clock on Friday afternoon. The testimony was substantially as follows:

abstract: And Neutrality; a New Plot
snippet: And Neutrality; a New Plot
lead_paragraph: -- We have news to-day from Nassau that another pirate is afloat the same that was concerned in the Chesapeake and Roanoke captures. If the story of this new scourge is honestly told, the "Confederates" in command must have belonged to the Richmond "detached service." Their mission is not that of ordinary privateering. It is entirely of a piece with the St. Albans robberies, the yellow-fever plot, and the burning of Northern hotels. A vessel, (American, of course,) boarded by the pirate off the Bahamas, was instantly fired, while the Captain and his crew were left to perish with the wreck, or make their escape as best they might in small boats. We cannot say that we are astonished at this story, horrible as it is. We shall not be surprised, indeed, if scores of our merchantmen share a similar fate before the piracy legalized by Europe has filled up the measure of its iniquity. This improved system of murdering on the high seas is the logical result of all the rebel ram-building and harboring of the pirates in the Seaports of Western Europe and the British Colonial possessions. And it is simply folly to expect that such an organized system of belligerency on the part of professed "neutrals" against the United States is to pass into history without a reckoning. At this rate of provocation, we venture to say, the reckoning must come soon.

abstract: London Times on Neutral Duties; London Times, D. News and Herald on Davis' fate
snippet: London Times on Neutral Duties; London Times, D. News and Herald on Davis' fate
lead_paragraph: The law which, according to the English view, governs cases of this kind has been so clearly explained, and will be, doubtless, so powerfully stated in answer to the American demands, that there is no need for us to say anything further on the subject. Our point is simply that nations in a state of war must protect their own interest, and cannot expect [???]trals to guard them from the operations of the enemy. It is enough for us to show that nothing was done in bad faith by this country. The Alabama was, it is true, built by British subjects, and her armament was also furnished from an English p rt; but this, though a culpable act on the part of certain Englishmen, does not compromise the government, which used reasonable means to prevent such proceedings, and would have stopped the vessel had not the Confederate agents fraudulently taken her out to sea. All that can be said is that the affair was one that is always possible in maritime war. In getting ready "No. 290" the Confederates and their agents were too quick for us and for the Federals also; they carried their vessel into the ocean before we could seize it in the Mersey, or the Federals could seize it in the narrow seas; if we were slow, the Federals were negligent. Mr. ADAMS, who inter[???]d the British Government of the character of the vessel, might have as easily communicated with the naval authorities of his own country and taken measures to capture the vessel as soon as he left our jurisdiction. A belligerent government can hardly claim to be com[???] for [???] results of an accident, when it is plain that its own agents neglected to [???] a proper wat[???] over the enemy's proceedings. The British Government, however, does not, we conceive, assert that a neutral country is not responsible [???]ly for the [???] [???] of ships or expeditions within its limits [???] one of two belligerents; on the contrary, no [???] [???] would be more ready than our own to allow that such equipments were real grounds of complaint. That there is no desire to defend the [???]ity of the fitting out of the Alabama is show by the [???] that proceedings were taken against the constructors of the [???] and that this vessel, as well as the two [???]t[???] "r[???]" were seized by the British Government in spite of the protestations and [???] legal opposition of those concerned in [???] them. This conduct of our government sufficiently shows what if con[???]s the [???] of a neutral State to be. A well-[???]nt but [???] act was passed half a century ago to forbid the very proceeding of which the Americans complain, and certainly no State in Europe or the New World has maintained the principles of neutrality and non-[???] more strictly than our own. All that we now content for is that when a vessel does a [???] [???] a [???] [???] as a neutral may be [???] to maintain a [???] has no claim to be com[???]ted, especially in a case like the present, where the vessel act[???]y went out to sea we armed, was armed in the open [???], and might have been captured without opposition if the belligerent who now complains had used the commonest in precautions.

abstract: Six Months' Retrospect
snippet: Six Months' Retrospect
lead_paragraph: Once during the issue of Lord MACAULAY's History of England, the interval of time between the publication of two contiguous volumes was actually greater than the historic space spanned by the long-expected treatise. Such had been the suffocating wealth of material disclosed to the gifted writer, so much in the realms of fact and opinion offered itself on every hand for him to examine and digest, such were the number and magnitude of events to be recorded, that he seemed, in a certain sort, to have slipped backward in his appointed task; or, as an appreciative critic said, the leaves of history turned over faster than MACAULAY could illuminate the pages.

abstract: Forrest vs. Forrest; Divorce; Injunction
snippet: Forrest vs. Forrest; Divorce; Injunction
lead_paragraph: Edwin Forrest vs. Catharine N. Forrest, The United States Trust Company, James Lynch and John Kelly. -- This was a new phase of an old and well-known litigation. The bill of complaint sets forth the marriage of the complainant with the respondent, Catharine N. Forrest, and the various proceedings which were taken in the suit in the Superior Court of this city, down to the final judgment, and that proceedings had been taken to enforce the payment of the moneys decreed to be paid to Mrs. Forrest, by executions, which were placed in the hands of the defendants, Lynch and Kelly, Sheriffs or the City of New-York, and out of funds deposited in the United States Trust Company. He therefore brings this suit, desiring, as he says, to bring the question before the Supreme Court of the United States, whether the Superior Court of the City of New-York has jurisdiction to decree a divorce of a marriage contracted in England, between parties who were both of them residents of Pennsylvania at the time the suit was brought. And alleging the total insolvency of Catharine N. Forrest, he prays for a temporary injunction pending this suit, and prays that the judgments in the cause may be declared entirely null and void.

Naturally, the result was a singular failure.

abstract: THE AFRICAN M.E. CONFERENCE. -- The 45th Annual Conference of the New-York African M.E. Church, commenced its sessions yesterday morning, in the Bridge-street African M.E. Church. Some twenty-four churches were represented. Rev. ALEXANDER WAYMAN presided, and Rev. LEONARD PATTERSON officiated as Secretary. The proceedings were opened with devotional exercises, and after an address of welcome to the brethren, it was resolved that the daily sessions commence at 9 A.M. and adjourn at 1 P.M. The annual sermon was preached in the afternoon by Rev. Mr. PATTERSON. The conference will continue for about ten days.

We have since seen and conversed with a highly respectable gentleman who was present on the occasion. He assures us that the meeting which was called under the letter of Major-Gen. THOMAS, suggesting the reorganization of civil officers in North Alabama was very large, and composed of the best citizens of Limestone County.
lead_paragraph: A brief notice of a public meeting held at Athens, Ala., on the 1st instant, appeared in the Union yesterday. We have since seen and conversed with a highly respectable gentleman who was present on the occasion. He assures us that the meeting -- which was called under the letter of Major-Gen. THOMAS, suggesting the reorganization of civil officers in North Alabama -- was very large, and composed of the best citizens of Limestone County. The Chairman. Mr. J.W.S. DONNELL, is a son of Rev. ROBT. DONNELL, whose memory is still revered in that section of the country, while the Secretary, Mr. J.W. SLOSS, is also a gentleman of high character and good lineage. The resolutions adopted were reported by a committee of which Hon. GEORGE S. HOUSTON, formerly a member of Congress from that district, was Chairman. They recommended prompt action by the people of Alabama, to give vitality to the constitution and laws of the State, and to restore it to its former relations with the General Government, and express the opinion that this could be accomplished by making use of the present State officials and organization. Rut, to avoid controversy, another plan is suggested, to wit:

abstract: Bismark, Count, on Prussian Claims in Germany; Schleswig-Holstein Question; Question, the
snippet: Bismark, Count, on Prussian Claims in Germany; Schleswig-Holstein Question; Question, the
lead_paragraph: The disagreement between Prussia and Austria on the Schleswig-Holstein question grows more entertaining as it goes on. Each of these powers entered into the war against Denmark with the full intention of cheating each other, and pocketing the lion's share of the spoils. Out of Germany this was apparent from the beginning. Even Germany, the land par excellence of philosophers and thinkers, will not go to war for an idea; and no sane man out of Germany ever believed that the crusade against the little mother kingdom was begun for the purpose of delivering the Schleswig-Holsteiners from Danish rule. Everybody knew that Prussia had an eye on Kiel, as a commodious harbor for her prospective navy. Austria wanted another ally among the small German States that support her against Prussia, and assist in checkmating the ambitious designs of King WILHELM and Herr BISMARCK. The smaller States of the confederation merely followed their leaders; and the people at large supported the war from a vague notion that it might lead to grand results in the way of German unity, _____ that unfulfilled dream of many centuries.

abstract: Commodore Morris, S. S., officers of
snippet: Commodore Morris, S. S., officers of
lead_paragraph: The U.S. steamer Commodore Morris, Acting Master H. BINGHAM, commanding, arrived here on Friday from Hampton Roads, where she left on the 7th. She was put in commission in 1862, at the Brooklyn Navy-yard, and proceeded to Hampton Roads to join the North Atlantic Squadron. She has participated in most of the engagements and expeditions in the waters of the James, Nansemond, Pamunkey, and the Chesapeake Bay. She held a pominent position in the advance of the army and navy in April, 1864, up the James and Nansemond Rivers, and was several times under a brisk fire. When the Commodore Jones was blown up by a torpedo, May 6, 1864, she rendered valuable assistance in saving most of the crew of that ill-fated vessel, being the vessel nearest to her, and had passed twice over the spot where the explosion took place. In July, 1864, had a very exciting engagement with a rebel battery of Whitworth guns, planted on Malvern Hill, one shot from the enemy passing through the magazine passage and two barrels of loose powder, and lodging in one of the shell rooms, doing no other damage than the rupture caused by the progress of the shot.
