abstract: Notwithstanding it is well known in this city that thousands upon thousands of our brave and selfsacrificing soldiers are constantly passing through New-York, on their way to their native States, or the various discharging depots throughout this State, very little enthusiasm is exhibited by the people for whom these noble men have done so much, in sustaining the brunt of the battle and restoring the Union.
lead_paragraph: Notwithstanding it is well known in this city that thousands upon thousands of our brave and selfsacrificing soldiers are constantly passing through New-York, on their way to their native States, or the various discharging depots throughout this State, very little enthusiasm is exhibited by the people for whom these noble men have done so much, in sustaining the brunt of the battle and restoring the Union. In many instances, a regiment coming home for the first time after three years of hard and painful service; after having marched many hundred miles, fought scores of battles, endured the thousand and one dangers and hardships of a campaign life -- in heat and cold, amid storms and under burning skies, hungry and footsore they come to our city, unheralded and uncared for.

abstract: Great activity appears, now that the rebellion is virtually ended, in the location and purchase of public lands, even at the most distant points of the republic. The returns from Humboldt, California, which have just reached the General Land Office, show that the cash sales at that office for the month of April, 1865, amount to $13,992 47; that in the same month the cash sales at Marysville, California, amounted to $5,089 91; that at the land office at Booneville, Missouri, there was taken up, for actual settlement, under the Homestead Law, in May, 1865, the quantity of 10,973,54 acres.
lead_paragraph: Great activity appears, now that the rebellion is virtually ended, in the location and purchase of public lands, even at the most distant points of the republic. The returns from Humboldt, California, which have just reached the General Land Office, show that the cash sales at that office for the month of April, 1865, amount to $13,992 47; that in the same month the cash sales at Marysville, California, amounted to $5,089 91; that at the land office at Booneville, Missouri, there was taken up, for actual settlement, under the Homestead Law, in May, 1865, the quantity of 10,973,54 acres.

abstract: War, the Late, and Peace
snippet: War, the Late, and Peace
lead_paragraph: The era of war has been a terrible experience for the nation. The struggle closed with such luminous splendors, and so perfect has been our triumph, that we have already almost forgotten the awful events and the fearful years through which we slowly passed. The convulsive shock that followed the initial action in Charleston harbor on the 12th of April, the wide and universal preparations for war, the appalling issue at Manassas in July, the weary winter of doubt, the great and disastrous battles on the Peninsula, the misfortunes in the West, the repeated demands for more troops, the gigantic and ill-starred battles of Fredericksburgh and Chancellorsville, the indecisive and ever-recurring campaigns in Maryland, Pennsylvania and Virginia, as well as in Kentucky, Missouri and Tennessee; the ravages of pirates on the high seas and on our own coasts -- these were events calculated to try the mettle of the nation, and imperil its existence. Faction reared its head in the North; riot and treason were rampant, and the great Powers of Europe perpetually menaced us with direct quarrel. Our losses in men were enormous; our outlay in money stupendous; our efforts after success innumerable and, ceaseless; but still, up to the opening of last year, the great armies of the enemy obstinately maintained themselves in Virginia and Tennessee, and the Southern Confederacy was powerful and defiant. No wonder that great numbers utterly despaired of success, and still greater numbers were doubtful and despondent. Last Summer, the fierce and awful straggles in the Wilderness and thence to Petersburgh, and the prolonged and bloody struggles of SHERMAN in Georgia, did not seem to the nation promising of anything like decisive success; and when Winter came with GRANT still standing before Petersburgh, SHERMAN "lost" in Georgia, and THOMAS fighting in Middle Tennessee, the final issue still seemed to thousands uncertain, and even the most hopeful continued to look for weary years of war. In a few months, victory, decisive, complete and glorious, was secured for the army and flag of the Union; and suddenly the strife which had raged over a continent gave place to universal peace.
headline: {'main': 'The Late War The Present Peace.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Late War The Present Peace.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Wheeling (Va.) Register says: "Many of the farmers along the river are plowing up and replanting their spring crops of corn, the recent freshets having destroyed the crops planted early in the season. We are informed that the wheat crops in the river bottoms are threatened with rust, in consequence of the continued rains and heavy fog."

abstract: Citizens of the Sixteenth Ward having recently made bitter complaint against a gang of young thieves who were bounty-jumpers as long as the war lasted, and who are now the terror of the West Side above Eighteenth-street, Capt. HEDDEN, of the Sixteenth Police Precinct, instructed his men to watch the fellows vigilantly, at their nest and elsewhere, and lose no opportunity to take them into custody.
lead_paragraph: Citizens of the Sixteenth Ward having recently made bitter complaint against a gang of young thieves who were bounty-jumpers as long as the war lasted, and who are now the terror of the West Side above Eighteenth-street, Capt. HEDDEN, of the Sixteenth Police Precinct, instructed his men to watch the fellows vigilantly, at their nest and elsewhere, and lose no opportunity to take them into custody. Accordingly, on Friday night, there having been a disturbance in the porter-house kept by THOMAS KAVANAGH, at No. 134 West Twentieth-street, a platoon of officers entered there and apprehended KAVANAGH, the landlord, MATTHEW SMITH, TERRENCE QUINN, PATRICK SMITH, JAMES JOHNSON, LAWRENCE CASEY, SIMON CLARK, CHARLES MUNDY, and WILLIAM DOWD. The prisoners were held at the Sixteenth Precinct Police Station until yesterday morning, and then taken before Justice LEDWICK for examination on a charge of vagrancy; but there being no sufficient evidence against KAVANAGH, MATTHEW SMITH, TERRENCE QUINN, JAMES JOHNSON, WILLIAM DOWD, and SIMON CLARK, they were released from restraint. Counsel who appeared for LAWRENCE CASEY, PATRICK SMITH, and CHARLES MUNDY, moved that the papers be amended in the case of CASEY by expunging the clause in which the accused is alleged to have made confession that he had served a term in the Penitentiary; but the magistrate declined to entertain the motion. Counsel introduced testimony showing that CASEY's father clothes the youth and given him food, and that he is not a burden on the public, and therefore cannot be committed as a vagrant. In addition to this testimony, counsel requested his client (who had been surrounded by his peculiar friends) to exhibit the contents of his pockets, and the prisoner produced $40 in Treasury notes. Thereupon counsel denied the right of the court to commit a man as a vagrant who had in his possession, or could borrow of a friend, that sum of money. But to meet this fetch the court put Captain HEDDEN on the stand, and it was shown that at the time of searching the prisoner, in the police-station, the police did not find forty cents in possession of the entire party. Here the further hearing was adjourned to this morning.

abstract: Bishop Verots' Circular to Clergy of Georgia and Florida
snippet: Bishop Verots' Circular to Clergy of Georgia and Florida
lead_paragraph: A convention of delegates representing the counties of Murray, Whitfield, Catoosa, Chatooga and Walker Counties, was held at Ringgold on the 25th ult. A.M. TURNER, of Murray, presided, and JOHN HILL, of Whitfield, acted as Secretary. Resolutions were adopted expressing gratification for the termination of the rebellion, and the prospect of soon being enabled to enjoy again the blessings of peace and liberty under the Constitution and the Union, -- pledging support to the administration of President JOHNSON and opposing the arrest and trial of leading rebels; -- promising every exertion to restore civil law and order in the State; -- and expressing the opinion that all officers in Georgia, before being installed into office, should subscribe to an oath that they have "never aided, assisted or encouraged the bringing on the late rebellion "or" advocated the doctrine of secession or disunion."

abstract: Condition; Trade; Military Insubordination
snippet: Condition; Trade; Military Insubordination
lead_paragraph: A commission from Gen. MAGRUDER, of Texas, consisting of Col. ASHBEL SMITH and W.P. BALLINGER, Esq., arrived here Sunday evening by the gunboat Antona, with full authority to surrender the Texas forces. The commission was sent upon the supposition that KIRBY SMITH proposed to continue his resistance to the national authority, and of course, the gentlemen composing it were ignorant of the subsequent action of the Commander of the Trans-Mississippi Department. Messrs. SMITH and BALLINGER had, we learn, an informal interview with Gen. CANDY Monday evening.

abstract: Alert vs. Active
snippet: Alert vs. Active
lead_paragraph: On Thursday, June 8, a match game of ball was played between the Alert Base Ball Club of Seton Hall College, and the Active Base Ball Club of Newark, upon the grounds of the former. The game was very interesting and closely contested throughout, but fortune was against the Actives, the palm of victory being won by the Alerts by a score of 21 to 11. Those who deserve especial mention for superior playing on the side of the Alert were C. TURNER, J.B. WALSH and C.H. TIERS. Of the Actives, COBA, LINES and FITZGERALD greatly distinguished themselves. The batting of the Alerts, to say the least, was very fine, as the Actives themselves admitted. Mr. MILLS, of the Eureka Base Ball Club, by the justice and promptitude of his decisions, elicited the applause of both players and spectators. Below is the score:

abstract: The first impulse on hearing of another plan for navigating the air is, to say pooh! and think no more about it. Yet the idea has long been a favorite one with scientific thinkers as well as with inventors. There is a wide-spread conviction among these classes of men, who are sanguine, but who are often far wiser than those who laugh at them, that some mode of navigating the air is possible, and will be discovered. This is just the sort of conviction that was felt about steam vessels and carriages, for a long time before any such things were successfully made.

abstract: Mr. STINSON MCIVOR, of a Twelfth Ward Grammar School, was placed at the bar, yesterday morning, and required to answer for an assault upon Mr. A.T. GALLAGHER, of Grammar School No. 31, in the Seventh Ward. It is said that there had long been bad blood between the complainant and defendant, and it appears that on the 27th ult. they met in Sweeny's Hotel, and there Mr. MCIVOR struck Mr. GALLAGHER. It is also said that one of the gentlemen was in liquor. Mr. DANIEL SWEENY, who was one of the witnesses in the case, testified that he saw the assault committed, and no rebutting evidence was put in. The Court imposed a fine of six cents.

abstract: New-York; Trott's Distillery, Cherry-street; $10,000
snippet: New-York; Trott's Distillery, Cherry-street; $10,000
lead_paragraph: DISTILLERY EXPLOSION IN THE FOURTH WARD. -- At 6:20 on Friday evening, a still exploded in Messrs. TROTT & CO's extensive distillery, at Nos. 54 and 56 Cherry-street, extending through to Batavia-street, and the buildings adjoining were set on fire; but the flames were speedily extinguished with trifling damage from fire. The still which exploded had been long in use, and was not, probably, worth more than $5,000; but it will require perhaps $5,000 to replace the shattered wallsand machinery in the distillery, and the total loss may be sot down at $10,000. A part of one of the walls fell upon the tenement house adjoining the distillery, in Batavia-street, but, happily, little damage was done. Mr. DANIEL HAYES, one of the firemen employed to the distillery, was seriously scalded, and Policeman CONNER took him to his abode, at No. 1 Batavia-street Messrs. TROTT & CO. are fully insured in the Globe, Harmony, Relief, Brevoort, Northwestern, Firemen's Fund, Adriatic and other Offices.

abstract: The dramatic critic is not permitted to enjoy a very long interval of rest. The regular season ended somewhere about Saturday, and the irregular or Summer season commences to-night. To judge from appearances, it will be more than ordinarily interesting. Indeed, it seems probable that in general variety and attractiveness it will more than rival its pretentious, but not over-satisfying predecessor. These Summer entertainments have sprung up entirely during the past few years, and they serve a doubly useful purpose. A source of pleasure to thousands of strangers who crowd our city during the warm weather, they are also the means of introducing to metropolitan notice many deserving artists whose regular occupation is in the country, but who thus materially add to their popularity and reputation, Some of the most favorite actors and actresses now before the public have made our city's acquaintance in this way.

abstract: People; Change to Loyalty Must be Gradual
snippet: People; Change to Loyalty Must be Gradual
lead_paragraph: The elder MATHEWS says that the Americans do everything and expect everything to be done in about twenty minutes." There is some foundation for the imputation thus conveyed. As a people we are somewhat impatient of results. We cannot wait. If anything is worth doing and ought to be done, we insist that it shall be done instantly. We were very peremptory in demanding that the rebellion should be crushed at once, -- that the armies of the rebellion, counting half a million of armed men, backed by five millions of resolute and frenzied people, should be swept out of the nation's path in a single campaign. And we are just as impatient and exacting now in regard to peace. We expect the Southern States, now that the war is over, to become instantly as quiet, as prosperous, as loyal and as thoroughly anti-slavery in sentiment, as Massachusetts or New-York, and every incident that proves this not as yet to be the case, carries alarm to the public heart.

abstract: A disastrous fire occurred at Nashville on Saturday last, by which the Quartermaster's depot was destroyed, and with it property valued at ten millions of dollars. The depot contained stores sufficient, to supply an army of 80,000 men for two years. The quantity of rope alone consumed was valued at upward of one million of dollars. The building was the largest in the country, being 800 feet front, and 200 feet deep.
lead_paragraph: A disastrous fire occurred at Nashville on Saturday last, by which the Quartermaster's depot was destroyed, and with it property valued at ten millions of dollars. The depot contained stores sufficient, to supply an army of 80,000 men for two years. The quantity of rope alone consumed was valued at upward of one million of dollars. The building was the largest in the country, being 800 feet front, and 200 feet deep. It was partitioned off by fire walls, which were suggested and built by Gen. J.L. DONALDSON. By this precaution a large part of the building, 500 feet front, was saved from destruction. Various rumors are afloat as to the cause of the fire, some maintaining it was the work of an incendiary, and others that it was the result of accident. A Court of Inquiry will investigate the matter. The fire spread so rapidly, that the building was almost one sheet of flame before the firemen could get to work on it.

lead_paragraph: -- If the story of reverses to MAXIMILIAN, which comes by way of Washington, be true, it is clear enough that the soldiers of the "Empire," are not so uniformly successful as has been represented. The news of the discomfiture of the Belgian janisaries was sufficiently important in the estimation of the Gallo-Mexican censor, to be suppressed for a full month. We do not know that a better indication of its significance could have been given.

abstract: Disease, Tenement Houses, Dirt, >amp;c.; Tenetuent-Houses, Condition of City, Disease, >amp;c.
snippet: Disease, Tenement Houses, Dirt, >amp;c.; Tenetuent-Houses, Condition of City, Disease, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: As the heated term of Summer approaches, with its thousand possibilities of sickness and discomfort, the thoughtful citizen may well stand appalled at the reckless disregard manifested by our authorities concerning the condition of our city, the state of our streets and the habits of the poorer and lower classes of our people. Were not the facts offensively before our very eyes it would be difficult to convince us that such physical outrages and moral impurities exist as are patent to our every sense. The civilized world, searched carefully by accomplished statisticians, cannot produce a city of equal size which parallels in filth and discomfort this metropolis of the American continent Money is poured out by the millions, our authorities are endowed with power akin to omnipotence in the premises, every inducement is offered by the tax-payers that should lead our officials to investigate, probe and remove the evil, and in the face of all this we find New-York, in the year of our Lord 1865, as dirty as ever, as crowded with fever-nests and pest-houses as the meanest seaport in Europe, and as liable to be swept by the hot flame of disease as the rottenest hamlet in South America.

abstract: At an early period of the late war, when we set store upon the sympathy and moral support of all friendly peoples, and especially of our English cousins, the press held up in its proper light the base conduct of the inhabitants of Bermuda, who were then doing their feeble uttermost to injure us, and in a hundred ways to aid the enemy. The course of the inhabitants of that island was the more remarkable as their material interests had been for years connected with the Northern States, while with the Southern they had had comparatively little intercourse. The City of New-York had furnished a field for the employment of their honest young men. Here was found a market for all their agricultural products, and from here they received, in exchange, their supplies of cattle, of breadstuffs and such other merchandise as they have never been able to produce for themselves.

abstract: Sigourney, Mrs. L. H.
snippet: Sigourney, Mrs. L. H.
lead_paragraph: This estimable lady died on Saturday, June 10, in Hartford, after a lingering illness. She was born at Norwich on the 1st of September, 1781, and was consequently in her 74th year. During the quarter of a century ending, perhaps, somewhere about 1850, her name was more widely known, in either hemisphere, than that of any other American authoress. Latterly her poetry has given place, in most libraries, to that of a more modern and varied school, though it will never be wholly superseded. She was early addicted to verse-making, possessed a temperament which, while it never marred her sound and solid health, was nevertheless keenly susceptible to the varied beauties and subtile influence of nature. She removed to this city in 1814, where she opened a select school for young ladies, and where her poetical talent and many lady-like and christian graces soon attracted the notice and engaged the personal interest of the late DANIEL WADSWORTH, a gentleman whose artistic and literary taste was fortunately equalled by his pecuniary means; and he was the means of introducing her to the public, in a volume of "Moral Pieces in Prose and Verse." In 1819, Miss HUNTLEY became the second wife of CHARLES SIGOURNEY, a well-known merchant of this city; and since that time she, while engaged in the domestic affairs of rearing a family of children, found time to contribute largely to the serious literature of the country, both in prose and verse. Her published works, in all, number nearly fifty volumes. Her prose is marked by vigor, beauty and good sense, and, like her poetry, is full of good moral precepts.

lead_paragraph: BURGLARIES. -- The house of Mr. WILLIAM EDSALL, No. 236 Washington-avenue, was feloniously entered on Saturday night last and robbed of dresses, table-cloths, napkins, &c., in all valued at $67.....The house of Mr. PURDY, NO. 27 Felix-street, was entered the same night and robbed of articles worth $40.....Some time on Saturday afternoon the house of ANGELO RUSSO, No. 174 Sands-street, was visited by a thief, during the absence of the family, and robbed of $500, which was contained in a tin box. A gold watch, and a $500 greenback remained undisturbed.

abstract: -- The Express and other assailants of the government are just now denouncing the Military Commission at Washington for protracting the trial of the conspirators. They are probably perfectly aware that the prolongation of the trial is due wholly to the defence. The same journals have hitherto complained that the conspirators were denied a fair trial -- that their testimony was excluded, their objections overruled and the trial conducted as if with a "foregone conclusion" that they were to be convicted. It is the extreme lenity of the court, and its anxiety that the prisoners should have a fair trial, with every possible opportunity to prove their innocence, that are now producing the delay of which these journals complain.

abstract: In the Times of Saturday last we reported the proceedings on trial of a suit brought by DUNSMORE et al. against CHAS. BUTTERFIELD to recover the amount of a note for $300, indorsed by the latter. In course of the report the defendant was referred to several times as "Gen. BUTTERFIELD" -- and the natural inference would be that he was the party concerned. We desire to correct this impression. Gen. BUTTERFIELD was not the person involved. His name is DANIEL instead of CHARLES, and we believe he has never refused to pay his notes when due. The report as originally published would produce an impression highly unjust to the General, whose honorable and gallant service during the late war give him more than an ordinary claim to redress for the injustice which would thus be done him.

abstract: Press, Aristocracy of the
snippet: Press, Aristocracy of the
lead_paragraph: The aristocratic members of the British Press regard it as a foregone conclusion that President JOHNSON will carry out a general scheme of confiscation at the South, because, as one of them forcibly points out, he is himself a "plebeian." The London Times prefaced an article on a cattle-show, the other day, with the high-toned observation that "no one thinks of eating fat in these days." And another of the name high-bred class, living among us here, complains loudly of the vulgarity of the American press. Since the days of Sir ROGER L'ESTRANGE, there has been nothing so entirely dainty in English newspaper history as the present style of [???] journalism. The Grub-street men who used to crawl about in the discarded livery suits of some titled patron were types of sturdy independence compared with the living fraternity of literary snobs. Ten to one, this Cockney chap, who never "thinks of eating fat," couldn't honestly say that he ever had a grandfather, or, if he could, we should doubtless trace the genealogy among the assistant beadles in the parish workhouse. This intense contempt for what is "plebeian" and "vulgar" may be inherited. If it is, we are safe, perhaps, to trace it to beadledom.

The government has shown no inclination to inflict needless and useless cruelties upon these or any other prisoners.

abstract: State of Affairs in
snippet: State of Affairs in
lead_paragraph: -- Our Mobile correspondent sends a picture of the condition of affairs in Alabama, which we would fain believe to be overdrawn. If the condition of the whites and blacks alike is such as is described; if the relations of the two classes toward each other are what our correspondent has seen or believes them to be, there is absolute social demoralization throughout the State. Labor is so despised by the whites that they actually prefer starvation or begging to work in any form whatever. And even in their penury and wretchedness they show the most virulent spirit of disaffection. If there were no political organization to be established under the auspices of the national government, the presence of a large military force would be necessary to prevent the destruction of the whole population by anarchy.

abstract: Corrected Report of Speech on Fraud
snippet: Corrected Report of Speech on Fraud
lead_paragraph: Partisans of WENDELL PHILLIPS are vehemently denouncing the press for not giving prompt credit to the "corrected report" of his speech concerning the repudiation of the National Debt. This makes it quite proper for us to say that the correction referred to was an after-thought on the part of Mr. PHILLIPS. We are informed, by persons who heard the speech, and whose authority Mr. PHILLIPS himself will not question, that he declared, distinctly and unmistakeably, that he would advocate a repudiation of the National Debt, unless the suffrage was conceded to the enfranchised slaves. The corrected version of his speech, which represented him as referring only to the rebel debt, was a fraud -- intended to convey the false impression that he had never threatened a repudiation of the debt incurred by the government in the war against rebellion. His menace was precisely like that of JEFF. DAVIS, the father of repudiation, distinct and flat-footed.

abstract: Williamsburgh, Highway, Mr. Frost Beaten and Shot
snippet: Williamsburgh, Highway, Mr. Frost Beaten and Shot
lead_paragraph: HIGHWAY ROBBERY AND ATTEMPTED MURDER. -- Between 1 and 2 A.M., yesterday, while Mr. ISAAC FROST was on his way to his residence, in Staggstreet, near Lorimer, Eastern District, he was set upon by two ruffians, who were accompanied by two women, at the corner of Stagg-street and Union-avenue, who demanded his money. Mr. FROST refused compliance to their demands, when they beat him severely with their fists and then discharged a revolver at him, the bullet from which lodged in his right thigh. The parties then decamped, and the injured man with great difficulty made his way home.

abstract: Yesterday morning Capt. THORNE, having on Saturday evening apprehended about seventy-five street-walkers, in the Fourth ward, transferred his Bedlam to the Tomps Court, and during the first morning hour, or until the Captain's prisoners had been duly heard and severally sentenced, the courtroom was a scene of uncontrollable uproar.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning Capt. THORNE, having on Saturday evening apprehended about seventy-five street-walkers, in the Fourth ward, transferred his Bedlam to the Tomps Court, and during the first morning hour, or until the Captain's prisoners had been duly heard and severally sentenced, the courtroom was a scene of uncontrollable uproar. The prisoners were girls in their teens and besotted and withered hags of 30, blear-eyed, tattered and torn, half-nude, bloated and utterly lost females, who, repulsive in their soberest and cleanliest moments, were now, after a night's carousal in the cells of the Fourth Ward police-station, as hateful in appearance as they were obscene and blasphemous in language. The elder females of the wretched gang were of the class that the police-court clerks style "revolvers," or outcasts who contrive to spend about two of every three months on Blackwell's Island; and these well knowing their fate, defied the officers of the court, and gave their loathsome tongues unchecked rein; but the younger, inexperienced bawds of the crew held their peace, hoping that good behaviour in court might mitigate the severity of their punishment No distinction, however, was made by the Justice, and the entire party were sent to the Penitentiary for a term of six months. But few of the number were of American birth, and not one had ever been taught in a New-York school.

abstract: Banking, Federal Control of; National Banking System; Federal Control of; Sen Guthrie's Proposals; Proposal on State Banks in 1856
snippet: Banking, Federal Control of; National Banking System; Federal Control of; Sen Guthrie's Proposals; Proposal on State Banks in 1856
lead_paragraph: It is now nearly ten years since we noticed in these columns the strange but oft-repeated summersaults of great men and rival parties on the tariff and currency questions. The occasion was the remarkable proposition of the then Democratic Secretary of the Treasury, (and now a Senator from Kentucky,) Mr. JAMES GUTHRIE, to do away with the State bank system, as an indirect infringement upon the Constitution of the United States, by an excise tax, to be levied by Congress upon their circulation, "and thus render the (State) authority to issue and circulate notes valueless." This suggestion, from such a source, created much surprise at the time, especially for its broad and extreme Federal doctrine, which demanded a resumption of the Federal constitutional power to regulate and control the currency, which the States -- originally forbidden to issue bills of credit themselves -- had usurped by creating corporations to do that, indirectly, which they could not, of themselves, do directly.
headline: {'main': 'Federal Control of Banking.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Federal Control of Banking.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: It is with great reluctance that the managers of the "Colored Home" come before their friends with an unusual appeal for their sympathies and aid, but we are constrained to do so by our pressing need, and the conviction that too deep an interest is felt in this institution to allow of serious embarrassment for want of the funds indispensable to its maintenance. During the last four years, the affairs of the "Home" have been conducted with the most rigid economy, and yet at the opening of another fiscal year, we find ourselves entirely out of funds, while the calls upon our treasury are the more urgent, because of the limited expenditures of the past few years and the additional burden of a debt weighs heavily upon us. It is true that there was a small balance at our credit by the Treasurer's report, but bills since presented for expenses previously incurred, leave the society in debt to the extent of nearly a thousand dollars. Our expenditures, for the year ending May 1, amounted to about $15,000, of which our friends contributed only $1,300; the balance of our receipts coming from the City Corporation and a fund which yielded nearly $2,000. In consequence of the advance in prices, our purchases, especially of clothing and bedding, have been of necessity very small, and now our supply is almost entirely exhausted and large appropriations are needed to provide what is requisite to the comfort of the inmates. We feel emboldened to urge our plea for help from the fact, that this is the only channel through which the wants of the aged, destitute and infirm colored people of the city are relieved. Of this class of city poor more than eight hundred have, during the last year, been the recipients of the care and protection of this asylum.

abstract: -- It is hardly necessary to say that our Correspondent in Mexico, in presenting a view of the political situation there, rather reflects the prevailing sentiment of the governing class at the capital, than gives expression to the liberal opinion which prevails in other quarters. His letters, which we publish to-day, however, will be found interesting from the fact, that they present something like an inside imperialist view of affairs.

abstract: Two manifestly incendiary fires were discoved in the Seventh Ward, yesterday morning  one in CHARLESS WOOD'S grocery, at No. 655 Water-street, and the other in SIMON NAGLE  SCHMIDT's shoe-store, at No. 119 Division-street. Little loss was sustainend from either fire; but if providentially the Water-street fire had not been...
lead_paragraph: Two manifestly incendiary fires were discoved in the Seventh Ward, yesterday morning -- one in CHARLESS WOOD'S grocery, at No. 655 Water-street, and the other in SIMON NAGLE SCHMIDT's shoe-store, at No. 119 Division-street. Little loss was sustainend from either fire; but if providentially the Water-street fire had not been discovered before it had gained headway, a majority of thirty-two families who reside on the second, third, fourth and fifth floors of the building, and who had only one narrow spiral staircase as an avenue of escape, must have perished. NAGLESCHMIDT and WOOD have been arrested and held to await an investigation by Fire-Marshal BAKER.

abstract: The thermometer is up to dog-day heat  nearly one hundred in the shade. We have had no rain of importance for two or three weeks, and the consequence is an uncomfortable atmospheric condition of things, as well as a bad outlook for vegetation. Farmers are already complaining of the want of rain, and that their Spring crops are suffering in consequence.

abstract: Prof. CLAPP, of Iowa College, is now in this city, soliciting contributions for the support of that institution. The college is situated in the town of Grinnell, 125 miles west of Rock Island, and has been quietly and moderately prosperous for about fifteen years. An effort was commenced about a year ago to raise $50,000 in aid of the institution, and $40,000 of that amount have already been secured. It is now desired to raise the remaining $10,000, which is necessary in order to make the previous subscriptions binding.

abstract: Foreign Appeals for Jeff. Davis; Foreign Appeals for
snippet: Foreign Appeals for Jeff. Davis; Foreign Appeals for
lead_paragraph: For the Counsel of the London Times, if the Tory journals of England, and of the imperial organs of France, that JEFF. DAVIS should be spared, we have an utter contempt. For four live-long years they did not refrain from giving us their advice respecting that man. They told us that it was useless to resist him; that the effort was costing an immense sacrifice of life to no purpose, and was disgracing us before the civilization of the age; that honor, justice and humanity required us to accept "the inevitable;" that if we were wise, or even sensible, or even sane, we would at once end the war and negotiate a treaty of amity and commerce with President DAVIS. Remembering that unvarying strain of admonition, and beholding present results, we cannot but regard the continuance, in that quarter, of lectures for our good, as preposterous impudence.

abstract: Idleness and Disorganization
snippet: Idleness and Disorganization
lead_paragraph: -- The prime source of the social disorganization in Alabama, as pictured by our Mobile correspondent, is idleness. The misery that attends upon idleness in any community cannot well be described. Along with it we find every sort of social disorder -- even among people above want. Aggravated by the state of civil commotion and revolution out of which the South can only emerge by [???] [???] [???] the [???] [???] of the pec[???] [???] [???] to [???] [???] execution in [???] [???] [???] [???] [???] tr[???] in the whole industrial life of the Southern people. The habit, too, has evidently grown upon them to an extent which nothing but the sharp teachings of necessity will correct. In Virginia and North Carolina, the relative situation of those who were formerly masters and slaves begins to be every day better understood -- as they both find that they must work to live, and work together at that. Alabama will get by degrees to this experience.

snippet: Montgomery, Richard; Townsend, C. D., Assistant Adjutant-General; Surrendered; Grant, John; Patterson, Ensign, J. P.; Sweeny, R. H.; King, Horatio; Grant, Mrs. L.
lead_paragraph: By Mr. Doester -- I reside in Warrenton, Va., on the Waterloo pike. I recognize the prisoner with the grey shirt on (pointing to Payne) as a man whom I saw in the road in front of my house, having three Union soldiers in his charge. An attempt was made to kill the prisoners, and the man Powell (meaning Payne) tried to prevent it; and I heard him say that he was a gentleman and wished to be treated as such; that if they attempted to kill the man he had captured, he would defend his prisoner at the peril of his life. One of the prisoners was killed when the party left the road, and I did not see them afterward. The affair occurred last Christmas.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE.--The WALLACK-DAVENPORT combination commenced the Summer sea  son at this house last evening, and succeeded in attracting a fine and fashionable audience. Better than this the artists one and all...
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- The WALLACK-DAVENPORT combination commenced the Summer season at this house last evening, and succeeded in attracting a fine and fashionable audience. Better than this the artists one and all satisfied the high expectations that had been formed of their abilities and the piece -- the "Iron Mask" -- achieved a pronounced and merited success. Who indeed can recall the sad story of that mysterious man whose fate and identity lay for so many years concealed behind that terrible vizor? The romance is followed with considerable fidelity by the dramatist, but of course with such amplications as the stage requires. The drama is, we believe, from the practiced pen of Mr. BAYLE BERNARD. The dialogue is clear and straight-forward, if not brilliant. The situations are remarkably good. We do not remember an act of any modern play that approaches in intensity and succession of emotional effect the fourth act of the "Iron Mask." It fairly thrilled the audience,and excited applause from the oldest theatre-g[???].

lead_paragraph: There is a growing interest in sheep raising in this State, and almost every leading farmer, whose locality seems fitted for the purpose, is turning his attention to this useful and profitable class of husbandry. In 1866 the number of sheep returned by the County Assessors was 584,430 -- aggregating in value $6[???]5,035, or an average of $1 19 each. In 1861 the number had risen to 913,021, worth $982,285, or $1 0[???] each. In 1862 the number returned was 1,206,695, worth $1,910,654, or $1 58 each. Later than 1862 we have no figures, but as the business has been very active, there were probably, at the close of the year 1[???], [???]ll three million of sheep in the State, worth at least $5,000,000. abstract: London Herald on Alabama Claims; Alabama Claims in Parliament
snippet: London Herald on Alabama Claims; Alabama Claims in Parliament
lead_paragraph: "As some misapprehension has been caused by the noble Lord at the head of Her Majesty's government, the other [???]ight, to a question put by the honorable Paronet, the member for Radnorshire, (Sir JOHN WALSH,) I wish ask whether the communication which the noble Lord said had been received from the United States Government with respect to the losses caused by the Alabama and other similar cruisers, is in any way contradictory to the tenor and spirit of the dispatch of Mr. ADAMS of October, 1863, in which he stated that in order to preserve amity and friendship between the two countries, he was instructed by his government to postpone any question which might arise to some future time, when it could be discussed calmly and candidly. I also wish to ask whether that communication was dated before or after the accession of Mr. JOHNSON."

abstract: Yesterday morning the light draft monitor Squando arrived here from Boston. She set out from Boston towed by the United States steamer Gettysburg, 5 guns, and proceeded in company till near Newport, at Fisher's Island Reef, on Friday evening last, when the consort had her bow stove in, and returned to Newport leaking badly. The Squando then came on to this port alone in safety. The following is a list of her officers: Acting Master Commanding, G.H. LEINAS; Acting Assistant Paymaster, John J. Thompson; Acting Ensigns, Con. Bartlett, J. Mitchell, A.A. Franzen, C.R. Fleming; First Assistant Engineer, A.E. McConnell; Second Assistant Engineers, John Doyle, Thomas Looby; Third Assistant Engineers, George Bertram, John J. Barrow; Surgeon's Steward in charge, Thomas Toole.

abstract: National Academy of Design, South Room
snippet: National Academy of Design, South Room
lead_paragraph: Mr. BIERSTADT, N.A., is fortunate in having a good place on the line, and we may at once frankly confess that he deserves it. We shall not perhaps feel ourselves justified in bestowing unlimited praise on his picture (No. 436) "Looking down Yo Semite Valley Ca," but its merits are sufficiently conspicuous to entitle them to honorable consideration. It certainly commands public attention in its present position. The dimensions of the canvas, the imposing character of the frame, (should we not in justice to artiste who use chisels instead of brushes seriously put ourselves to the contemplation of wood work? The tendency toward carpentry is marked. Considered esthetically it may also be significant,) -and the nature of the scene which glares upon us from every part of the room renders it impossible for any one to commence, as the catalogue directs "on the left as you enter." We prefer, therefore, to speak at once of this overhanging frame, and so, in some sort, escape its domineering influence. The subject is one of those grand landscapes which the intra-Californian country affords to the artist. Hugo masses of rock rise up on every hide, and through a notch wrought with the ceaseless waters of centuries the river passes. From this gigantic rift issues a flood of light, the fiery particles of the departing sun sinking into its prison home in those solitary and stern recesses. The distribution of the picture, we take it, is geographically correct. It does not lack the hardness of a Gradgrind fact, nor the sole merit of a photograph, But we may ask with pertinence and justice, in what way is such a picture essential to our perception of beauty; to our apprehension of the sublime? Natural scenery owes all its interest to the relation which it holds with man. The Alps are the most picturesque mountains in the world, simply because, they are the most known, and Mr. GIGNOUX's representation of them (opposite to Mr. BIERSTADT's picture) is valuable because it epitomises their general characteristics. But these distant regions, selected with so much pertinacity by Mr. BIERSTADT, are, as it were, cut off from human sympathy. They are to the average mind unverified. It must be added, too, that Mr. BIERSTADT, in this instance, is hopelessly local. He does not essay a generalization of the scenery of the "Yo Semite Valley," but contents himself with giving us, doubtlessly a correct, but still a positive survey of one particular portion of it. The sunlight effect to which we have referred is ingenious enough, but it is by no means novel. It detracts, perhaps, from the rigor of the scene, but it does not add to it human interest. The foreground, where the brimstone-dust rays of the sun fall upon it, is carefully finished, but the shaded part to the right, is hard, inelegant, cold and utterly commonplace as it generally is in all this artist's pictures. The rive seems to us to be narrow, extremely swollen, and "too forward," but Mr. BIERSTADT has doubtless is precise information on every, save the last point. The face of the rocks display all those characteristics which GIETHE describes as the natural traits of the German school; namely, dry simplicity hard strength and timid correctness. But, to bring our remarks to a close, the defect of the picture is its lack of an appreciable subject. These remote wonders are chilling. Had Mr. BIERSTADT bestowed the same amount of conscientious labor on any the[???] more [???]m [???]iate to our every-day or even every-twenty-[???]-year-experience, he would achieve [???] a [???] [???]ss.H[???]l he imparted to this canvas any deep, in[???], [???] [???]ve personal impression of the [???]e, he would to [???]i[???] extent also have made it in[???]re thus, To quote once more from GIETHE: Seek within yourself and you will find everything; and rejoice that without (as it may be always called,) there lies a nature that says yea and amen to all have discovered in yourself.

lead_paragraph: -- While the war lasted it was almost inevitable that many matters of social reform should have been neglected. Among the rest, little attention has been paid to the total-abstinence movement. Now, however, the interest in this question is reviving, at least on the part of clergymen and moral-reformers. To-night a large demonstration of temperance men will be made at the Cooper Institute.

abstract: The Attorney-General has issued a circular informing persons belonging to the classes excepted by the late Amnesty proclamation that before their applications will be considered, it must be shown that they have respectively taken...
lead_paragraph: The Attorney-General has issued a circular informing persons belonging to the classes excepted by the late Amnesty proclamation that before their applications will be considered, it must be shown that they have respectively taken and subscribed the oath or the affirmation prescribed in that proclamation. Every such person desiring a special pardon should make application in writing or in person therefor, and should transmit with such application the original oath or affirmation, as taken and subscribed before an officer authorized, under the rules and regulations promulgated by the Secretary of State, to administer the amnesty oath prescribed in the proclamation of the President.

abstract: -- But for the temporary pressure of government dispatches, we should now be able to publish daily telegrams, morning and evening, of all the important news from Charleston, Wilmington, Savannah, New-Orleans and all parts of the South -- at least, east of the Mississippi. And let us hope it will not be necessary much longer to employ, in connection with it, the ungracious mediatorship of the Censor.

abstract: Fire Department; Difficulty, the
snippet: Fire Department; Difficulty, the
lead_paragraph: -- It is stated that the Court of Appeals will pass judgment upon the constitutionality of the law creating a Paid Fire Department at an early day, probably toward the close of the present week. The Judges of appeal have given precedence to this case over all others, in consequence of the almost utter disorganization of Fire Department matters, during this interregnum of uncertainty, and the resultant danger to life and property in this city. Of course the decision of the Court will be final, and the prospect of a speedy settlement is something to be thankful for.

abstract: Government Agents and Southern Trade
snippet: Government Agents and Southern Trade
lead_paragraph: -- We had yesterday the very gratifying information from Washington that President JOHNSON, having had under consideration the question of encouraging and enlarging Southern trade, has determined to issue a general proclamation putting an end to the present system of purchasing cotton, tobacco and other Southern products, by government agents. The general opinion has been that there can be no relief, except through the action of Congress, from the system established by the law of July 2, 1864, providing that the products of insurrectionary districts shall be sold through government agents, and taxing them one-fourth of their value; but our dispatch states that the Attorney-General has given his opinion that the remedy is now with the President, who may, by proclamation, declare that there is no longer an insurrection in any of the States recently in rebellion. The law, as its language implies, applies to the "products of States declared to be in insurrection;" but the rebellion having everywhere entirely ceased, there are no longer any such States or any such products. By removing this taxation of 25 per cent., cotton, tobacco, and other Southern staples will only be taxed under the general laws, as in the case of products of other States.

abstract: Delegates in England
snippet: Delegates in England
lead_paragraph: -- The story is contradicted by the news from Europe to-day, that the Canadian delegates had come to an agreement with the Colonial Office on the subject of fortifications. The conferences, it seems, are still in progress; and we hear, privately, that the prime difficulty is, in getting an imperial indorsement for the notes on which the colony must raise the money necessary to do its part in the fortifying scheme. If the colonists had to borrow the required amount without such indorsation, the delegates reason fairly, it would overturn their credit altogether. Reasonable as this claim is, we doubt whether it is at all likely to be granted. Federation for all the provinces, then, would be us far off as ever; and the farming country of the Western Peninsular would renew the old clamor for annexation to the United States.

abstract: Early yesterday morning Mr. PATRICK CAVANAGH and JOHN DRAKE, both of Twenty-eighthstreet, met in that street near Eleventh-avenue, and there, after disputing, resorted to blows, and DRAKE, drawing a pocket-knife, stabbed CAVANAGH in the abdomen ...
lead_paragraph: Early yesterday morning Mr. PATRICK CAVANAGH and JOHN DRAKE, both of Twenty-eighthstreet, met in that street near Eleventh-avenue, and there, after disputing, resorted to blows, and DRAKE, drawing a pocket-knife, stabbed CAVANAGH in the abdomen inflicting a long, deep gash which let out his intestines. DRAKE was apprehended by Policeman THOMAS MCCORMICK, and held to await the result of CAVANAGH's injuries. The prisoner is a carpenter, aged about 30 years. It is thought that CAVANAGH's wound must prove mortal.

abstract: All Ports to be Open July 1, Pres. Proc.; Proclamation Opening all Ports July 1
snippet: All Ports to be Open July 1, Pres. Proc.; Proclamation Opening all Ports July 1
lead_paragraph: Whereas, by my proclamation of the 29th of April, 1865, all restrictions upon internal, domestic and commercial intercourse, with certain exceptions therein specified and set forth, were removed in such parts of the States of Tennessee, Virginia, North Carolina, South Carolina, Georgia, Florida, Alabama, Mississippi, and so much of Louisiana as lies cost of the Mississippi River, as shall be embraced within the lines of national military occupation; and whereas, by my proclamation of the 22d of May, 1865 for reasons therein given, it was declared that certain ports of the United States, which had been previously closed against foreign commerce, should, with certain specified exceptions, be reopened to such commerce on and after the 1st day of July next, subject to the laws of the United States, and in pursuance of such regulations as might be prescribed by the Secretary of the Treasury; and, whereas, I am satisfactorily informed that dangerous combinations against the laws of the United States, no longer exist within the State of Tennessee; that the insurrection heretofore existing within said State has been suppressed; that within the boundaries thereof the authority of the United States is undisputed and that such officers of the United States as have been duly commissioned are in the undisturbed exercise of their official functions; now, therefore, be it known, that I, ANDREW JOHNSON, President of the United Sates, do hereby declare that all restrictions upon internal, domestic and coastwise, intercourse and trade, and upon the removal of products of States heretofore declared in instruction, reserving and excepting only those relating to contraband of war, as hereinafter recited, and also these which relate to the reservation of rights of the United States to property purchased in the territory of an enemy, heretofore imposed in the territory of the United States east of the Mississippi River are annulled, and I do hereby Direct that they be forthwith removed, and that or and after the 1st day of July next all restrictions upon foreign commerce with the said ports, with the exception and reservation aforesaid. He removed, and that the commerce of said States shall be conducted under the supervision of the regularly appointed officers of customs provided by law; and such officers of the customs shall receive any captured and abandoned property that may be turned over to them under the law by the military and naval forces of the United States, and dispose of such property as shall be directed by the Secretary of the Treasury.

abstract: BOLD AND INGENIOUS BURGLARY. -- Early Sunday morning, the residence of Mr. HENRY HAPMAN, No. 66 Sixth-street, E.D., was entered by an accomplished burglar, who succeeded in making a considerable "swag." The burglar entered through the window of the front parlor, where a little boy was sleeping. He was seen by the boy coming in through the window, but adroitly managed to pass into the back parlor, where Mr. HARMAN was sleeping, and by the use of choloform succeeded in stealing a gold watch and chain, under the sleeping man's pillow valued at $280. He then returned to the front parlor, and went through Mr. HARMAN's coat, where he obtained a wallet containing $375 in bills and a bank-cheek for $285. The boy states that he saw a man coming into the parlor through the window, but he was afraid to cry.

abstract: London Times on Treason and Traitors
snippet: London Times on Treason and Traitors
lead_paragraph: The London Tones Presumes that no Christian, civilized administration will put to death men who were called by millions of their countrymen to exercise the functions of a regularly established government. One cannot help asking, on reading this, what number of persons must take part in a revolution to render its leaders liable to the punishment of treason? If there is anything in this argument of the Times, it must mean that it is only when a man rises at the head of a small force against the government, that the pains and penalties attached by the law to his offence can be fairly visited on him.

abstract: New-York Club, Review Kept from Plebeian Eyes
snippet: New-York Club, Review Kept from Plebeian Eyes
lead_paragraph: The review of the New-York Yacht Club yesterday, appears to have been quite an exclusives affair. The steamer Sylvan Grace, which was advertised to sail for the rendezvous at 10 A.M. touching at several landing places in the North and East Rivers, found not more than thirty passengers awaiting her. Large numbers had congregated at the piers the boat was advertised to touch at, but some mischievous person or persons circulated the report that the review had been postponed, and consequently the parties went away. Thus the club had the review entirely to themselves, and it is to be hoped enjoyed it all the more that it was not looked on by plebian eyes.

abstract: Hale vs. Brimelow; Slander on Doubtful $5 Bill; Philadelphia vs. New-York
snippet: Hale vs. Brimelow; Slander on Doubtful $5 Bill; Philadelphia vs. New-York
lead_paragraph: The grand match between the Athletic Club of Philadelphia and the Eagle Club of New-York, which took place yesterday afternoon, on the splendid new ball ground of the Gotham Club, resulted in another triumph for the Philadelphia players, they winning the game by a score of 24 to 14 in a contest occupying about two and a half hours. An immense assemblage of spectators was gathered on the grounds on the occasion, considerable interest being taken in the contest, as it was anticipated that the Athletics would meet with tough adversaries in this encounter; but though the Eagles had out nearly their best team, their play, as a general thing, was not up to the mark of their recent contest with the Stars. The Athletics played very creditably in a majority of the innings, but they, [???], were not up to their high standard. At the close of the fifth innings, which was played in an hour and ten minutes, the totals stood 14 to 7 in favor of the Philadelphians, a ratio of two to one; but in the last four innings, the Eagles gained ground, scoring 7 to their adversaries 10. The contest was played in a very manly and gentlemanly spirit, and as a whole was quite an interesting game. At the close of the match the Eagles entertained their guests, and in fact since the Athletes have been in their hands they have done their utmost to make their visit a pleasant one. The following is the score of the game:

abstract: The Comptroller of the Currency has decided that the engraving or printing of the signatures of the officers of National Banks on National Currency Notes is not sanctioned by law.
lead_paragraph: The Comptroller of the Currency has decided that the engraving or printing of the signatures of the officers of National Banks on National Currency Notes is not sanctioned by law. The engraved signatures of the Treasurer and Register are attested by the imprint of the seal of the Treasury, while the engraved signatures of the officers of the bank are unattested, unauthorized and dangerous. Though the bank committing the wrong cannot take advantage of it to repudiate its own issues, other National Banks would not be obliged to receive the notes. The issues of National Banks are receivable for all dues to the government except duties on imports, yet the government, through any of its depositaries or officers, may demand a legal attestation to these engraved signatures before receiving the notes.

abstract: Sanitary Condition of New-York, and Official Neglect; Mortality and Official Neglect
snippet: Sanitary Condition of New-York, and Official Neglect; Mortality and Official Neglect
lead_paragraph: We have just devoted four closely-printed columns to a tour of inspection, by one of our reporters, through somo of the fever districts in our city. We doubt whether many of our readers mastered their disgust sufficiently to get through the faithful description. It would be far pleasanter for a journalist to take no note of such aspects of our metropolitan life. But it is impossible to ignore them; for they have to do with the death, the needless death, of thousands. It is the duty of every resident of this city to know the extent of its evils, and to contribute to that irresistible public sentiment without which they will never be removed or ameliorated.

abstract: Lincoln Medal Subscription Seizure
snippet: Lincoln Medal Subscription Seizure
lead_paragraph: -- The notion of sundry liberal-minded Frenchmen to get up a testimonial in memory of the late President of the United States has been summarily batoned out of existence by the stout and timely intervention of the Imperial police. The subscription lists (two sous) have been bravely seized; the money appropriated to the reward of those who most distinguished themselves in the seizure, and henceforth there is an end to one revolutionary movement, at least. This must be a consoling thought for the Imperial mind, scarcely less so than the recent triumphant victory of the police over the students of the Latin quarter, when resolutions on the subject of Mr. LINCOLN's death were on the tapis. How satisfying it must be for a people to find themselves so minutely governed!

abstract: -- We have already urged that the approaching Fourth of July should be specially observed throughout the country as a day of rejoicing for the salvation of the national life, and of public acknowledgment to the soldiers of the Republic for their services on the field of battle. Gov. PARKER, of New Jersey, wisely following the example of Gov. CURTIN, of Pennsylvania, has issued a proclamation recommending that the day shall be thus observed by the people of his State, and we trust that New-York will not be far behind in this eminently proper course. The assassination of Mr. LINCOLN just about the time that the armies of the rebellion were dispersed, put all feeling of joy far away from the public heart. But the period has come when a national jubilee and public expression of thankfulness might be indulged in with profit.

abstract: Tax Commissioners; Appointment Declared Illegal; Tax Commissioners; Decision Reinstating Former Commissioners
snippet: Tax Commissioners; Appointment Declared Illegal; Tax Commissioners; Decision Reinstating Former Commissioners
lead_paragraph: -- IMPORTANT DECISION. -- The Court of Appeals, yesterday, reversed the decision of the Supreme Court in the case of the County Tax Commissioners. Messrs. WOODRUFF and PURSER, who have been in the office about a year past, under appointment of Comptroller BRENNAN, are declared to be usurpers, and ordered to be ousted. Messrs. BROWN and WILLIAMSON, who were displaced when the present officers went in, are decided to be the rightful incumbents. The court likewise decrees that all the fees and emoluments of the office received during the tenure of the defendants in the suit belong to the relators, makes provision for ascertaining the amount, and mulets the defendants in the costs of the action.
headline: {'main': 'THE TAX COMMISSIONERS', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'THE TAX COMMISSIONERS', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Government Contract for
snippet: Government Contract for
lead_paragraph: -- For the information of butchers, who are apt to be quite ignorant on such matters, we make a note of the contract just concluded for supplying the government with beef for the army and navy for the ensuing three months. The cattle are to be delivered in or near New-York, at such times and in such quantities as may be directed by the Commissary of Subsistence; to be of first quality, and free from all blemishes or imperfections; to be not less than three years old; each lot to average not less than 1,300 lbs. per animal, and no bullock to be taken weighing less than 1,250 lbs. on the scales. The cattle arc all to be thoroughly inspected. The price is $9 35 per 100 lbs. live weight. The price for the previous three months was $13 49 -- a decline of $4 44 per cwt., or nearly thirty-one per cent.

abstract: Cabinet; Benjamin, >amp;c., in Bermuda
snippet: Cabinet; Benjamin, >amp;c., in Bermuda
lead_paragraph: -- The report comes from Washington that JUDAH P. BENJAMIN, formerly Secretary of State of the exploded C.S.A., has found a sanctuary in Bermuda. BRECKINRIDGE and TRENHOLM are also said to have effected their exit from the country, and probably will soon be heard of at the same place. This fugacious trio might have stuck to J.D., their late Chief, and MALLORY and REAGAN, their imprisoned colleagues. But conscience made cowards of them, and nobody need regret their flight. Let us warn the unsophisticated people of Bermuda, who have a weakness for lionizing persons of this class, to look out that they are not swindled in the same manner that the pirate BRAINE got the best of them last year. These runaways do not visit Bermuda to make holiday with their stealings.

abstract: Appointed Provisional Governor of Mississippi; Proclamation Appointing Provisional Governor of Mississippi; Prov. Gov. Appointed (W. L. Sharkey) by President
snippet: Appointed Provisional Governor of Mississippi; Proclamation Appointing Provisional Governor of Mississippi; Prov. Gov. Appointed (W. L. Sharkey) by President
lead_paragraph: Whereas, the fourth section of the fourth article of the Constitution of the United States declares that the United States shall guarantee to every State in the Union a republican form of government, and shall protect each of them against invasion and domestic violence; and whereas, the President of the United States is, by the constitution, made Commander-in-Chief of the army and navy, as well as chief civil executive officer of the United States, and is bound by solemn oath faithfully to execute the office of President of the United States, and to take care that the laws be faithfully executed; and whereas, the rebellion which has been waged by a portion of the people of the United States against the properly constituted authorities of the government thereof, in the most violent and revolting form, and whose organized and armed forces have now been almost entirely overcome, has, in its revolutionary progress, deprived the people of the State of Mississippi of all civil government; and whereas, it becomes necessary and proper to carry out and enforce the obligations of the United States to the people of Mississippi in securing them in the enjoyment of a republican form of government; now, therefore, in obedience to the high and solemn duties imposed upon me by the Constitution of the United States, and for the purpose of enabling the loyal people of said State to organize a State Government, whereby justice may be established, domestic tranquility restored and loyal citizens protected in all their rights of life, liberty and property: I, ANDREW JOHNSON, President of the United States and Commander-in-Chief of the army and navy of the United States, do hereby appoint WILLIAM L. abstract: Mexican Affairs, Alarm on, in; Affairs; Alarm in France on
snippet: Mexican Affairs, Alarm on, in; Affairs; Alarm in France on
lead_paragraph: Those who may have lent themselves to the vain belief that the Emperor of the French was building up a stable throne in Mexico, may prepare to go through the painful process of disillusion as fast as possible. The news from France, to-day, would be sufficiently alarming to all of us, if we had any interest in the stability of imperialism in Mexico. But we have no interest at all. The story, moreover, which M. ELOIN has carried direct from Mexico to Europe -- a story which, even in the disguised form in which it creeps into print through the official and other Paris journals, speaks of disappointment and disaster to the imperial cause -- is not now to us. It agitates financial and political circles in Europe because it is new to them; and, peradventure, because they believe the backward turn of affairs is due to the secret intervention of the United States.

abstract: Trial of, at Hartford
snippet: Trial of, at Hartford
lead_paragraph: The Hartford Post of Wednesday says: "Last evening, at ten minutes past seven, Mr. FAY'S torpedo exploded under the raft which was built for the purpose of testing its explosive powers. The torpedo was charged with one hundred and fifty pounds of gunpowder, and the explosion was grand in its effect, though the report was not so loud as many anticipated. It sent up a volume of water to a height of between eighty and ninety feet, and of proportionate circumference. Following the water came a dense mass of steam, smoke and flame, the whole forming a magnificent sight and well repaying the disappointment of the spectators on Thursday last. The raft was utterly demolished, being blown into fragments, which were quickly picked up by a squad of small boats which were waiting for the chance. This invention of Mr. FAY's will eventually prove of wonderful importance, as the clockwork of the machine, which it is designed to manufacture, combined with the shell containing the powder, can be adjusted so as to explode at any time, from one minute to one month. The explosion was witnessed by a large crowd of spectators, who cheered loudly as the waters subsided.

abstract: We have heard of quite a number of instances, within the past three months, of Southern business men, who, having come North to resume their former business relations, have honorably liquidated their indebtedness outstanding since before the rebellion. Others, unable to do this at present, have promised an equitable settlement before the close of the year. It is true, their creditors could now sue them in any part of the South in regular courts; and it is also true that, had they taken an opposite course, they would have found it impossible to resume their old and favorable business relations here. But, nevertheless, their voluntary promptitude is highly creditable.

abstract: LAUNCH OF A PILOT BOAT.--The new pilot boat Charlotte Webb will be launched from the ship-yard of her builders, Messrs. WEBB  BELL, at Greenpoint, on Thursday afternoon, at 2 o'clock.
lead_paragraph: LAUNCH OF A PILOT BOAT.--The new pilot boat Charlotte Webb will be launched from the ship-yard of her builders, Messrs. WEBB BELL, at Greenpoint, on Thursday afternoon, at 2 o'clock. This beautiful vessel is in part the result of a subscription of our underwriters, merchants and others, which originated with and was carried to a successful termination by Messrs. WEBB & BELL, and she is intended to replace the James Funck, No. 22, which was captured and destroyed by the rebel pirate Tallahassee last August. She is named after the wife of ECKFORD WEBB, Esq., is of beautiful model, has been constructed in the most perfect manner, and of the choicest materials. Her dimensions are -- length of deck 80 feet, breadth of beam 22 1/2 feet, depth of hold 8 feet. It is intended that she shall accompany the yachts on Monday next in the ocean race.

abstract: Sir GEORGE GREY, the other day, announced in Parliament, on behalf of the government, that it was not the intention of Ministers to put forward any programme of parliamentary reform in view of the General Election. To this the large and liberal constituency of Halifax (Yorkshire) has responded by quietly selecting a radical Reformer as one of the candidates for the borough, in room of Sir CHARLES WOOD. The significance of this consists thus: Sir CHARLES WOOD is a model Whig; he got into Parliament on the back of Lord JOHN RUSSELL's Reform Act, in 1832. Sir CHARLES has thus been over thirty years in Parliament; he has been nearly half that time in Office with the Whigs. He is now Secretary of State for India. All this is forgotten by his constituents, in presence of the announcement of Sir GEORGE GREY that the policy of the government is to remain what it has been -- "a masterly inactivity." Hints come to Lord PALMERSTON from other quarters. Mr. JOHN STUART MILL is almost sure to win in Westminster, and Mr. THOMAS HUGHES, ("Tom Brown,") one of the best friends of the United States in Europe, is safe for another metropolitan constituency.

The ease with which Dester defeated Butler in the previous contest has included the Hiram Woodruff stable to imagine that it can readily cut down the contraband with either Lady Emma or the victor of the previous contest; but it has to be borne in mind that Butler always cuts up ugly in harness, and that to wagon in his favorite gait, as has been proven many a time and oft. He has never gone as well as during the paid week, and we are strangely mistaken if he does not make it tight progress with his opponents from WOODBUFF's stable. abstract: The most impudent case of garroting that the police have reported since the time of the Burdell murder, when the garroting craft inaugurated this species of crime, occurred in Broadway, near Fifteenth-street, at about 5 o'clock yesterday morning. Who the garroters' victim was does not appear; but they, having been seen by Policeman SAMUEL THORNE, have been arrested and held to await the appearance of the complainant. The prisoners, who render their names as JAMES MORRISON and CHARLES GAY, pursued a citizen up Broadway until they thought themselves at least two blocks distant from any Metropolitan officer, seized him by the throat, threw snuff in his eyes, and gagged him, and then, searching his pockets and taking therefrom everything of value that they could find, gave him a murderous blow on the head and fled. The unknown, however, not having been stunned, sprung to his feet and ran for his life down a side street, and was not again seen by the police. Officer THORNE rapped for aid and ran toward the outlaws when they first attacked their victim, and when they had completed the outrage and were flying from the spot Patrolman GEORGE W. NIBLO joined Officer THORNE in the pursuit, and the fellows were, apprehended, During the flight one of the accused threw into the gutter a wallet containing $50 and a bank-check for $200, which belonged to the unknown, and it was supposed that this check might give the officers a clue to him; but after taking their prisoners to court and securing their commitment until they could find a complainant, they sought him in vain. The prisoners, whose villainous visages would convict them of any crime on the calendar, are about 20 years of age.

The unknown, however, not having been stunned, sprung to his feet and ran for his life down a side street, and was not again seen by the police. Officer THORNE rapped for aid and ran toward the outlaws when they first attacked their victim, and when they had completed the outrage and were flying from the spot Patrolman GEORGE W. NIBLO joined Officer THORNE in the pursuit, and the fellows were, apprehended, During the flight one of the accused threw into the gutter a wallet containing $50 and a bank-check for $200, which belonged to the unknown, and it was supposed that this check might give the officers a clue to him; but after taking their prisoners to court and securing their commitment until they could find a complainant, they sought him in vain. The prisoners, whose villainous visages would convict them of any crime on the calendar, are about 20 years of age.

abstract: -- The dreary agonies of "Camille" happily came to an end on Saturday evening Miss HOSMER, who sustained the role of the heroine, was then and there released from the powerful necessity of dying a slow death in an exceedingly healthy and robust condition of body. During the present week the lady will have an opportunity of showing her real strenght in a variety of dramas infinitely more elevated in tone, and opportune in sterling situation, than the piece we have named. Her first essay in the new programme was made last night, when she fairly electrified the audience as E[???]ad[???]e, in SHIEL's tragedy of that name. The role is rather wordy, but the situations, as our readers know, are impressive. The exact feeling was happily seized by Miss HOSMER, whose voice is, certainly, one of the most pleasible and delicious on the stage. Her perception of the character was eminently clear and feminine, rising at times to the highest attitudes of passion. We were unprepared for a performance so generally excellent. The lady will, we are convinced, receive her best reward in New-York. Her style is refined and poetic. It was a shame that she should be spoilt in the long weariness and sore temptation of provincial theatres.

abstract: Romping-ground for Children Needed
snippet: Romping-ground for Children Needed
lead_paragraph: Doubtless, nine-tenths of those who visit Central Park regard this great work as nearly perfect in all its parts; and so it is in many respects. The business men who there seek recreation after the labors of the day, the thousands who throng it at the close of the week to enjoy the music which harmonizes so exactly with the spirit of the place, would rather see a dozen or two blocks of buildings cut off from the lower part of the island and sunk in the bay, than that their favorite place of resort should in any way be diverted from its proper use; and well they might. Every year, to these classes alone, the park will more than pay interest on the money which it has cost.

abstract: Arrested in New-York
snippet: Arrested in New-York
lead_paragraph: Mr. JOHN MITCHEL, one of the Editors of the New-York Daily News, and recently of one of the Richmond papers, was arrested yesterday at his ofsice and sent to Fortress Monroe. The public, were first informed of the fact by two large placards in front of the News office, on which was printed the announcement that JOHN MITCHEL had been arrested by military power and carried off. Naturally among his friends this summary proceeding caused considerable surprise and more alarm. Neither surprise nor alarm were, however, of the least avail. Mr. MITCHEL's career was suddenly ended, and the world moves on.

abstract: Brooklyn, East Baltic-street; $700; Brooklyn, Thirty-sixth-street
snippet: Brooklyn, East Baltic-street; $700; Brooklyn, Thirty-sixth-street
lead_paragraph: RIOT. -- A party of females and boys made an attack yesterday morning upon a house in Tillary-street, near Canton-street, occupied, it is said, by lewd women, who, by their conduct, have become objectionable to the neighborhood. Those residing in the vicinity concluded to take the law in their own hands and proceeding to the place, forced their way through the doors and commenced demolishing everything within reach. The crowd having increased to several hundred, the building was soon rendered untonable. The occupants, having fled, escaped injury. A policeman arrived when the damage had all been done and the crowd dispersed. No arrests were made.

abstract: -- Mr. ROBERT HOWARTH, residing corner of Norman-avenue and Second-street, Greenpoint, was yesterday arrested by Officer REED, of the Forty-seventh Precinct, on a charge of assaulting a young man named JAMES BROWN. It is alleged by HOWARTH that BROWN seduced Miss SUSAN HOWARTH, his sister, under promise of marriage, and then boasted of his triumph over his victim in the public streets, pointing her out to his companions in an insulting manner. On Monday evening last, Mr. HOWARTH met the alleged seducer of his sister in the street, and appealed to him to save her reputation by fulfilling his promise of marriage. This appeal BROWN treated with contempt HOWARTH thereupon administered to him a severe castigation, from the, effects of which he is now confined to his house. The case will come before Justice DAILEY as soon as the complainant is able to appear in court.

abstract: The Proclamation of the President abolishing all restrictions upon Southern trade, gave great encouragement and activity to business men yesterday.
lead_paragraph: The Proclamation of the President abolishing all restrictions upon Southern trade, gave great encouragement and activity to business men yesterday. For the first time they felt that as regards this matter, they had sure ground to stand upon. They felt that they could make definite calculations, and that they could take into account all the modifying elements, which are now no other than such as affect the ordinary courses of trade and commerce in all business communities.
