abstract: The order of the Navy Department, giving preference to the applications of maimed soldiers and seamen for labor on the public works, is as beneficent in its intentions as it is economical.
lead_paragraph: The order of the Navy Department, giving preference to the applications of maimed soldiers and seamen for labor on the public works, is as beneficent in its intentions as it is economical. Although, since the close of the rebellion, hundreds of government employes have been discharged under the system of retrenchment, and only first-class and able-bodied mechanics retained, yet all those who have been dissabled in battle, and who could possibly be retained to my advantage, still remain. Economy, of course, required that the government should not employ disabled men to perform duties which able-bodied men alone can do, as in the ship-carpenter's department. This has led to much bitter feeling among the men who have been discharged because they were maimed and no longer able to compete with the strong and skilled workmen; it has also induced some of the public journals to take up the cudgel and belabor certain heads of departments at the Brooklyn Navy-yard (Mr. DELANO, the Naval Constructor, in particular) because they did what common justice required.
headline: {'main': 'Naval Movements.; EMPLOYMENT FOR DISABLED SOLDIERS AND SEAMEN.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Naval Movements.; EMPLOYMENT FOR DISABLED SOLDIERS AND SEAMEN.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Athletic of Philadelphia, vs. Union
snippet: Athletic of Philadelphia, vs. Union
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, Mr. HERRING, the President of the Union Club, of Morrisania, and Mr. CAULDWELL, of the Sunday Mercury, the reception Committee of the Union Club, visited the Lafarge House and escorted the Philadelphians to Melrose Station, Morrisania, near which place the Union ball grounds are located, and at 3:30 P.M., the Athletic and Union Clubs began play together. The weather was extremely favorable, and a large crowd of spectators was gathered around the ball field, the attendance of the fair sex being decidedly the most numerous and brilliant seen at any match, this season; carriages occupied by the fair visitors to the grounds arriving from the villages of Westchester up to P.M., the greatest interest being manifested in the contest, it being the first of the season in that vicinity.

abstract: a Visit to
snippet: a Visit to
lead_paragraph: Very few of our citizens are aware of the changes which some of the islands which stud the East River, and other parts of our harbor, have, undergone since the commencement of the war. The continual pressure for space for hospital accommodation, consequent upon the protracted and gigantic proportions which the rebellion assumed, compelled the government to turn their eyes to the healthfully situated islands in the harbor, and several of them were at once taken possession of, and immediate operations commenced to render them available for the proposed purposed, viz., rendevouz for the mustering in of the troops supplied by the draft, hospital stations for the care and recovery of the wounded, and for the recuperation of the thousands whom the privations and vicissitudes of service in the field rendered temporarily hors de combat; rendezvous for expeditionary troops, &c. David's Island, Hart's Island, Riker's Island, Willet's Point, &c., have long been changed from their previously solitary state to busy marts and warlike posts, whence the sound of the drum and fife, and the high-floating Stars, and Stripes, are heard and seen by the steamboat travelers on the Sound.

abstract: New-Jersey vs. New-York, at Normal Grounds
snippet: New-Jersey vs. New-York, at Normal Grounds
lead_paragraph: A most interesting and well-contested game at quoits was played at the Normal Grounds, corner of Astor-place and Broadway, yesterday afternoon, the contestants being selected from the best players in the State of New-Jersey, opposed to six chosen from the best players in the New-York City clubs. A large and most respectable company was present to witness the play. At 3 o'clock the game was called; the players paired off, and judges and scorers were appointed, when a commencement took place, Messrs. GIBSON and KELLOCK, for New-York, being opposed to Messrs. MCGREGOR and GRIMSHAW for New-Jersey. The New-Yorkers won by a score of 41 shots to 29. The second game was with Messrs. LYONS and MCLAREN for Jersey, against Messrs. HUDSON and FERGUSON. Jersey won this game, the score marking 41 to 14. The most even game of the day, however, was that between Messrs. SMITH and REED, on behalf of Jersey, their antagonists being the veteran GEO. DUNNING and Mr. CRITTENDON, which was won by the Jerseyites by a score of 41 to 40. On drawing a balance of the three games, it was shown that the Jersey players had exceeded the total score of their opponents by 14 shots.

abstract: This well-known hotel, located on the Canada side of the Falls, and in full view of the great Horseshoe Fall, will be open for the reception of guests on the 24th instant. The Clifton is a first-class house, and is undergoing extensive improvements. The proprietors are Messrs. D.H. BROMLEY & Co., the firm comprising Capt. D. BROMLEY, A. CHUCK and SAMUEL SHEARS. Capt. BROMLEY has been for twelve years connected with the Central Railroad, and is well-known to the traveling public as a polite and attentive gentleman. His associates will add to the popularity of the hotel, which has ever been a favorite resort of visitors to Niagera. Passenger for the Clifton House should check their baggage and leave the cars at Suspension Bridge, where conveyances will be in waiting. Greenbacks are taken at p[???]r, and the prices are the same as at the hotels on this side.

abstract: The last hours of the unfortunate man WAL  TER, who in a moment of passion killed his best friend, are rapidly passing. The facts in this case, ...
lead_paragraph: The last hours of the unfortunate man WAL TER, who in a moment of passion killed his best friend, are rapidly passing. The facts in this case, now probably forgotten by the public, excited universal attention at the time. He was committed on the 30th of November, 1863, for the murder of a woman with whom he was living as his wife. WALTER is a very intelligent man, of perhaps thirty-five years of age. He says that he was living in St. Louis as a house-joiner; that he there met this woman, with whom he came to New-York. He was not very well, and they took rooms together at a house of prostitution, in Centre-street, opposite the Tombs. They lived as happily together as people of that class can, finding their enjoyment in matters purely physical, drinking, carousing, and all that. When the hospitals were opened on David's Island, he went there, and was employed in some subordinate capacity, doing very well, and giving general satisfaction. He occasionally came down to the city on furlough, and always spent the time with his paramour. On this occasion they left the house at which she was lodging, and went to another, where they remained several days, drinking all the time excessively, and on the last day, becoming noisy and quarrelsome, they were taken to the station-house. The next morning they were discharged; she went back to her old home, and he continued his spree. In the evening he called at the house, and went directly to the landlady's room, where he found the girl. He fell upon her and stabbed her eighteen times, in different parts of the body, when one of the other girls struck him over the head with a hair-oil bottle, and he left the place. The girl died, WALTER was arrested, tried and convicted, and sentenced to be hanged on the 23d of this month. The Court of Appeals has affirmed this sentence, and there is no reasonable doubt that on that day the sentence will be carried out.

abstract: Weehawken, Highway, Vetter Robbed of Horse and Wagon
snippet: Weehawken, Highway, Vetter Robbed of Horse and Wagon
lead_paragraph: -- FOURTH OF JULY CELEBRATION. -- A regular meeting of the Board of Aldermen of Jersey City was held at the City Hall on Tuesday evening. Alderman PANGBORN was elected Chairman pro tem. The sum of $1,000 was appropriated for the celebration of the Fourth of July, and a committee, consisting of a committee of one Alderman from each ward, was appointed to make the necessary arrangements. The board then proceeded to the election of a President, and 17 ballots were had without a choice. The candidates were Alderman EARLE, supported by the regular Democrats, and Alderman DECKER, supported by the Reform party. Alderman DECKER then arose and said the board had been endeavoring to effect an organization for nearly two months past. He thanked the members for their devotion toward him. and after withdrawing his name, nominated for President, Alderman HORATIO N. EGE. The ballots wore had with the same result as heretofore, after which the board adjourned. Up to the present time over 450 ballotings for President have been had, during which the board have been equally divided, nine each, while ten votes are required for a choice. The board have transacted some business, but there is a question as to its legality.

abstract: SERIOUS ACCIDENT TO A CHILD. -- MARY IDA GISE, a child of 4 years, was run over last evening at the Tenth-street crossing of Avenue A, by a coach which was driven by HUCH NORTON. The wheels passed over both of her legs, mangling them shockingly. Bystanders took the child to her parents' abode, at No. 226 Avenue A, and a Seventeenth Ward officer apprehended the coachman and took him to the Police Station.

abstract: Private commercial letters received here say that in the best informed political circles of Europe, the belief is general that MAXIMILIAN has expressed to his father-in-law, King LEOPOLD, and also to his brother of Austria, the strongest possible desire to abdicate the rickety throne of Mexico. The intimation of this wish at the Tuileries, through these intermediary parties, is at the bottom of much of the excitement in Paris in regard to Mexican affairs generally. It is a much more serious business for Imperialism, than the defeat of a few Belgian troops at Tacambaro, to find the newly-installed Emperor already eager to get out of the concern, and out of the country at the same time.

abstract: Oath of Allegiance for Members of Congress; Reconstruction Proclamations in Mississippi and North Carolina; Progress of and its Safeguards
snippet: Oath of Allegiance for Members of Congress; Reconstruction Proclamations in Mississippi and North Carolina; Progress of and its Safeguards
lead_paragraph: The President has issued the same Enabling Proclamation for Mississippi as for North Carolina. He will, doubtless, very soon do the same for Georgia, Alabama, Florida, Soul Carolina and Texas -- the only remaining States of the "Confederacy" whose governments have not been reorganized by other methods. Great pains have thus far been taken, and will continue to be taken, to secure the most competent and trustworthy men for Provisional Governors, District-Judges, District-Attorneys, and the other officers necessary to clear the way for the new order of things. Special care will be exercised also in the selection of the military commanders of the various Southern departments, since a conciliatory spirit and discreet cooperation on their part may do much to smooth the way. Ample earnest has already been given that whatever devolves upon the President to do in this momentous work, will be done wisely and well.
headline: {'main': 'The Progress of Reconstruction and its Safeguards.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Progress of Reconstruction and its Safeguards.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Debt, Schemes and Possibilities of Payment
snippet: Debt, Schemes and Possibilities of Payment
lead_paragraph: In reply to the inquiry of a correspondent, we beg to say, for his information, that the national debt is not yet paid. The Herald subscription for that purpose proved to be inadequate. The excellent gentlemen who forwarded for publication their willingness to take shares in the scheme, payable when all the stock was taken, got what they sought -- a little cheap notoriety but tiny have paid no money, and the debt is just as large as it was before they subscribed. Evidently the benevolence of our wealthy men had been overrated. It would require only about one-fifth of all the property in the United States, real and personal, to pay the national debt, and it seems to have been supposed that two hundred thousand persons might be tempted to pay it themselves. This proves to have been a mistake. The scheme has collapsed. Even the Herald has dropped it, and when that journal drops one of its pet sensations, it must be very dead indeed.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, Private MORRIS MILLER, a German-soldier, who had recently returned from the ar[???], entered Mr. JOSEPH COLSTEIN's shop, at No. 28 Greenwich-street, and after a pleasant chat upon war t[???]s, a pistol of curious workmanship was produced by COLSTEIN. The weapon, which was loaded, was handled freely by both men, and Mr. COLSTEIN was about to put it aside, when cue of the barrels was accidentally discharged, and the soldier received a serious bullet-wound in the neck. Coroner GOVER took MILLER's ante-mortem deposition, and it appearing that neither of the men had ever previously seen the other, and that there had been no quarrel, the jury found a verdict under which the Coroner will be enabled to admit COLSTEIN to bail to-day. COLSTEIN is a shoemaker.

abstract: on the Returning Soldiers
snippet: on the Returning Soldiers
lead_paragraph: We have another State Paper this morning from the Mayor, to which we invite public attention. It is in His Honors most agreeable style: and those who do not entirely accept the highly philosophic retrospect of the war and its contingents, which is therein presented, may, at least, have the satisfaction of agreeing with Mr. GUNTHER in the sensible recommendation which he offers on the participation of our returned veterans in the National Anniversary. His Honor is not yet satisfied that the war for the Union was entirely legitimate. But that it is a matter of not the least consequence to anybody that we have the pleasure of knowing. Enough for us all to learn that the M[???]y[???]r will be [???] lend his influence and cooperation in [???] honor to the returned soldiers on the [???]hing Fourth of July.

abstract: (Brown,) New-York, Clever Escape of
snippet: (Brown,) New-York, Clever Escape of
lead_paragraph: On the 3d Of May, MARY BROWN, an expert shoplifter, who is otherwise known as FRANCES STANLEY, having pleaded guilty of grand larceny, in stealing from Messrs. A.T. STEWART & CO's, was remanded by Recorder HOFFMAN. A day or two thereafter she was taken to court to receive sentence, but was again remanded. On the way back to the Tombs, the officer in whose custody she was walking was pushed by one GEORGE P. HALE, at the Chambers-street crossing of Centre-street, and as the officer turned to see who had pushed him, a female, vailed and attired in close resemblance of MARY BROWN, slipped into the prisoner's place by the officer's side, and the Tombs gang passed on until they had reached Worth-street. Here the female representing MARY BROWN stepped aside toward Broadway, and the officer requested her to give him no occasion to resort to force, but to go quietly to prison. The female retorted by warning him not to insult her, lest she report him to his superiors, and, raising her vail, disclosed a face which he never had seen. In his confusion, the officer permitted her to escape, and, until recently, nothing further was heard of either the real or the putative MARY BROWN; but last week District-Attorney HALL ascertained that the fugitive was in Yonkers. He informed Capt. JOHN JOURDAN of the fact, and instructed him to exercise the utmost vigilance in capturing her. Policemen WOOLDRIDGE and MCDONALD, of the Sixth Ward, accordingly went to Yonkers, and after diligent search, found and apprehended the prisoner, and she was committed to the Tombs yesterday afternoon, to be sentenced this morning. The prisoner, who has already served four years and six months in State prison for grand larceny, and whose term had but just expired when she committed the offence for which she is new to suffer imprisonment, had secured passage in today's steamer, and resolved to add one to the cosmopolitan population of California. The spurious MARY BROWN is said to be an experienced pickpocket from Rochester, and GERARD P. HALE, who is supposed to have concocted the liberation scheme, is an old convict, and was recently convicted of burglariously entering the dwelling of Mr. HENRY F. VAIL, Cashier of the Bank of Commerce.

abstract: It is decreed that the negro shall occupy the attention of the American people. For thirty years he has been the great topic of discussion.
lead_paragraph: It is decreed that the negro shall occupy the attention of the American people. For thirty years he has been the great topic of discussion. His rights as a man; his wrongs as a slave; his status among the races; his intellectual calibre; his moral possibilities; his physiological peculiarities; his hair and his heels; his color and his odor; his history and his future have been questions concerning which every man and all women wore supposed to be thoroughly posted and ceaselessly excited. Nay, his body, soul and earthly relations were not enough for the speculators, sweeping beyond this world and into the next, they argued as to whether, when he got to Heaven, he would occupy the same quarters as the white man, and be permitted to sit on the same bench.

abstract: Anxiety of a Native American Paper
snippet: Anxiety of a Native American Paper
lead_paragraph: -A daily newspaper, which but a few years since furiously rode the hobby of nativism, and advocated the refusal of suffrage to everybody born outside the limits of the country, is now painfully unhappy because there is a possibility that some half million thorough native Americans, may possibly be allowed to vote. By direct opposition, by indirect insinuation, by open sneers and perpetually varying misrepresentation, the editor endeavors to cast ridicule upon the extension of the franchise to a class of men who have, to a certain extent, enjoyed the right ever since the foundation of the government; a class whose few votes in this State have been importuned for this same editor, and who have by him been taught that the "dirty foreigner" was their greatest enemy. Now, when the question is imperative whether five hundred or five hundred thousand of these men shall vote, his pen reeks with abuse of them; he complains that neither women, nor paupers, nor lunatics, nor idiots can vote; ergo, this new class of citizens must not vote. Of course we do not look for strict consistency in these revolutionary times; particularly among those whose partisan gymnastics have left them to inquire in the words of a famous statesman, "Where shall I go?" but, surely, a sense of decency -- if that idea be comprehensible in such a quarter -- ought to induce some care in the squandering of false logic and impotent spite upon a matter that has become of great and controlling importance to the welfare of the nation.

abstract: H. Y.; Coogan, Michael, Shot by Gorman in Self-defence
snippet: H. Y.; Coogan, Michael, Shot by Gorman in Self-defence
lead_paragraph: MICHAEL COOGAN was shot and instantly killed, at about 9 o'clock last evening, at his dwelling, in the rear of No. 99 Cannon-street, near Stanton, by MICHAEL GORMAN. The circumstances, as related by Police Captain ULMAN, of the Eleventh Ward, are as follows: GORMAN, who has served three years or more in the army and navy, and who was honorably discharged from the United States ship Savannah on the 4th of May, returned to this city only to find his mother, BRIDGET GORMAN, living with MICHAEL COOGAN, and calling him husband. This annoyed young GORMAN, and he made no secret of the fact, but expressed his opinion with so much plainness that COOGAN forbade him the house. He went thither last evening, to see his mother, and COOGAN being at home, after ordering him to depart, seized him by the throat and attempted to thrust him from a second-story window. In the struggle between the two COOGAN struck young GORMAN a stunning blow, knocking his head into a looking-glass, and severely wounding him, and then GORMAN drew a small four-barreled Sharpe's pistol and discharged two barrels into COOGAN's breast. COOGAN still struggled a moment, and then fell to the floor and expired without uttering a word. GORMAN now instinctively fled, but on hearing that COOGAN's wound had proved mortal, he went to the Eleventh Ward Police Station and surrendered to Capt. ULMAN. The officers, on going to Mrs. COOGAN's apartments, found her in a condition which unfitted her for communicating intelligence; yet she retained sufficient reason to attempt to hide the weapon with which the deed had been committed. She was taken to the Eleventh Ward Police Station, and held for the night. Mrs. COOGAN is perhaps 50 years of age; COOGAN, who was a laborer, was about 45; and young GORMAN, who is a printer, is but 21.

abstract: Thousands of discharged soldiers are now in this city seeking employment. Their [???]s upon the community for the opportunity to [???]rn a respectable livelihood are patent. Their services are, at least, tacitly acknowledge on all sidas. But employers should make it a matter of conscience to engage them in preference to others in all cases where their labor can be made available. At the offices of the Soldiers' Protective Employment Bureau, in Chambers-street, and the Metropolitan Employment and Relief Agency for Soldiers and Sailors, No. 186 Canal-street, hundreds of these brave follows, adepts in the art of campaigning, and well-killed, likewise, in the pursuits of peace, apply daily for work. It is a matter of necessity that it should be promptly given given them. There are also large numbers of disabled veterans -- brave men, who have lost limbs in the preservation of the country -- who are homeless. The various "depots" and "Soldiers' Rests" are organized only for affording temporary relief to this class. Each of there institutions is now taxed to its very u[???], and they are altogether inadequate to th[???][???] [???]ities of the occasion. At least 1,000 disable soldiers, deserving recipients of aid, are to-day wandering in our streets, without a suitable habitation, receiving the uncertain support of private charity, or seeking, as a last re[???]rt, the county poorhouse. These facts are simply shocking. The late Legislature passed a law incorporating a "homo" for there gallant men. We call upon the gentlemen named in the bill as corporators, to take prompt action in the matter i[???]d to them. There is no time to be wasted. If ever there was urgent need for beneficent and generous action, it if presented in the case of these unfortunate and heroic men, who appeal alike to our gratefulness and our justice.

abstract: REUNION AT WARD SCHOOL No. 14. -- Highly interesting exercises were held yesterday at Ward School No. 14, in Twenty-seventh-street, the occasion being the thirtieth anniversary of the connection of the Principal, Miss WHITING, with the female department. The guests were principally teachers and graduates of the school. After introductory remarks by Mr. BANKS, one of the Trustees, the reading of Scripture by Rev. Dr. OSGOOD, and a prayer by Rev. Dr. LEAMAN, the following programme was rendered to the delight and interest of the large audience: Hymn -- "America," boy graduates; Introductory Remarks, John Stephenson; Welcome, to Graduates, Miss F.J. Burke; Chorus -- Reunion Song, by graduates; Essay, Miss Ball, of Class No. 62; Song -- "Blow Gentle Gales," Mr. Nash and Ladies; Poem -- Class Reunion, Miss Tompkins; Sale -- "Childhood's Days," Miss Leader; Address, James W. Gerard; Piano Solo, Miss Markstein; Solo -- James "Wake, Sweetest Melody," Miss Case; Address, Jas. L. Miller; D[???]et -- "Children Pray this Love to Cherish." Mr. Nash and Miss Case; Presentation, Mr. At[???]ry; Adress, Dr. Osgood. After the singing of a reunion s[???], composed for the occasion. Miss WHITING was presented with an elegant writing-desk and [???] by the graduates and teachers, through Mr. ATT[???]BURY, a well-known citizen of the Twenty-first Ward. On behalf of the recipient a reply was made by Rev. Dr. OSGOOD, who made an eloquent address, in the course of which he paid a proper tribute to Miss WHITING's worth as a faithful teacher.

abstract: It is fair to suppose that professional fire-eaters can swallow their own blood-and-thunder speeches, and, therefore, we shall not be surprised to find nine-tenths of the rank and file of the Texan rebel troops, quietly subsiding into obedience to "Yankee dominion," in spite of their late assertions to the contrary. They declared that "come weal or woe, they would never submit." But that was before the judicious dispositions made by CANBY, or the advent of SHERIDAN with his cavalry, and the approach of WEITZEL with his infantry. The prominent leaders in that region, however, have so absolutely committed themselves "never to consent to reunion," that we shall expect some of them to keep their words. The most feasible way of doing this is by a removal to Mexico. There is still a career open to enterprising spirits in that region. The climate of the uplands of Mexico is quite salubrions -- more so at all events than that of Houston or Galveston. These champions of independence should emigrate by all means.

abstract: and President Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation
snippet: and President Lincoln's Emancipation Proclamation
lead_paragraph: The following item of polital history, we assume to be entirely authentic. It appears in a Paper by Mr. F.R. CARPENTER, on "Recollections of Mr. Lincoln," which we publish in full in other columns. The force of the argument used by Mr. SEWARD against issuing the Emancipation Proclamation in the hour of defeat, had a pointed illustration in the case of the rebels, two years later, when they "stretched forth their hands to Ethiopia," in the moment of their supreme despair. Ethiopia simply answered by laughing at their calamity. And even the "sympathizing" outside world could barely restrain its sneers. Had we rushed from the second Bull Run in similar despair, to a similar refuge, how would the glorious lustre of the succeeding victories of Antietam, Gettysburgh, Vicksburgh, and the crowning, triumph of Richmond, have been dimmed! Yet the judgment, forecast and sagacity to which the nation owes its escape from that discredit and disgrace, were held of such account by the radical faction that for many months treachery to the cause of freedom was openly and shamelessly laid at the door of the Secretary of State, by the holder and honester of the Rouge organs, and insinuated by the more cowardly and pretentious.

abstract: It was delicately intimated, a few days ago in the Court Journal, that the accounchement of the Princess of WALES might be expected in August. Some learned authorities predicted that the event would come off in July.

abstract: Bull's Head Bank, Fraud on by J. E. Hodgson; New-York, Union-square, of Mr. Wing
snippet: Bull's Head Bank, Fraud on by J. E. Hodgson; New-York, Union-square, of Mr. Wing
lead_paragraph: On Wednesday morning Policemen SAMUEL M. THORNE and GEORGE W. NIBLO captured two out aws -- JAMES MORRISON and CHARLES GAY by name -- who had garroted and robbed a stranger in Broadway, between Fifteenth and Sixteenth streets; but the garroters' victim having fled, the officers, on reaching court, were able only to make their own affidavits that their prisoners had been seen to garrote and rob a man whose name they did not know, and that while flying from the scene of the outrage one of the thieves threw into a gutter the wallet containing $10, and a check drawn by Mr. A.C. MOORE, and payable to the order of bearer. Upon these affidavits Justice DODGE held the prisoners to await the appearance of the unknown, and, yesterday morning, the particulars of the case were published in the TIMES, with an intimation that the court would be glad to take his deposition. Seeing which, Mr. WM.R.B. WING, of Morris, Otsego County, now of the Metropolitan Hotel, went to court and made oath against the ruffians, saying that, being a stranger in town, and excessively frightened, he had not known to whom to appeal, but had thought that if a man could be robbed in Union-square at 5 o'clock in the morning, he had been singularly fortunate in escaping with his life. The banditti, who are depraved youths of 20 years, were committed without bail, and are speedily to be tried at the Court of General Sessions.

abstract: Rumored Subscription for in New-York
snippet: Rumored Subscription for in New-York
lead_paragraph: In the TIMES of yesterday there were accounts of public loyal meetings that have lately been held at various points in the States of Virginia, North Carolina and South Carolina. Their objects are, in general, commendable, and their spirit seems seems to have been good. The most noteworthy feature is, that they recognize accomplished facts -- the abolition of slavery and the necessity of a loyal submission to the provisional authorities; and they also show the popular purpose of practically participating in the great work of restoring civil government.

abstract: THE NEW-YOUR SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number detailed reports of the Trial of the assassins. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: And the Mexican Muddle
snippet: And the Mexican Muddle
lead_paragraph: The more we think of the probability of a large emigration to Mexico, the more difficult it is to predict which side, in the Mexican imbroglio, the emigrants will espouse. The Emperor can make the best payment for the present, but CORTINAS the best promise for the future. If the former offers a liberal fraction of the imperial treasury for service to be rendered, the latter can respond by pledging all that treasury -- in case he gets it.

abstract: Maury's Special Surrender; Gift of $10,000 to found Course of Lectures on Science and Religion
snippet: Maury's Special Surrender; Gift of $10,000 to found Course of Lectures on Science and Religion
lead_paragraph: Prof. S.F.B. MORSE has given $10,000 to the Union Theological Seminary of this city, to found a course of lectures on the "Relations of Science and Religion." The plan is somewhat similar to that of the Bampton lectures in England. The course will boar the name of the generous donor, but not from a wish thus to perpetuate his own name, but to pay respect to his venerated father, Rev. Dr. MORSE, of Charlestown, Mass., one of the founders of Andover, and one of the earliest friends of sacred learning in New-England, Mr. L.S. ELY has also given $10,000 to found a similar course of lectures on the "Evidences of Christianity;" while the well-known house of BROWN BROTHERS gives $10,000 more to endow the Hebrew Professorship. Other friends of the seminary have been equally liberal, Mr. WILLIAM E. DODGE, as usual, being foremost in the work, having led off with $12,[???]00 several months ago, since which time there has been subscribed in all for the seminary $150,000.

abstract: Philadelphia vs. Brooklyn
snippet: Philadelphia vs. Brooklyn
lead_paragraph: Yesterday at 1 P.M. the reception committee of the Resolute Club, with two four-horse stages, duly drove up to the Lafarge House for the Philadelphians, and took the whole party over to the Union Ball Grounds, Brooklyn, E.D., where at 3 P.M. both parties began playing in a match Athlotic vs. Resolute. The most numerous concourse of spectators gathered at a match in Brooklyn this season were present on the occasion, a bevy of the fair ones of Williamsburgh gracing the scene with their presence. The banks surrounding the grounds were lined with hundreds of people, and what with the crowd, the field of players in uniform, and the number of banners on the several flag-staffs of the grounds, the scene presented was picturesque in the extreme.

abstract: And Magruder Gone or Going to Mexico; Can it be Americanized
snippet: And Magruder Gone or Going to Mexico; Can it be Americanized
lead_paragraph: Our correspondent in the City of Mexico has been earnestly advocating peaceful emigration from the United States to Mexico, on the ground that it is the best way to prepare all that region for final annexation to the little faith in any such scheme. We recognize that Mexico is entitled to independence of all European control, but we do not yet accept the "manifest destiny" doctrine that if must some day, in its entirety, become part of the United States. The character of its eight million mongrel population -- in the worst degree indolent, ignorant, bigoted and superstitious -- sufficiently forbids it. But a sterner prohibition yet lies in the fact that all that part of Mexico, which is the most fertile and populous, all that part which forms the real substance of the country, lies south of the tropic. Mexico may eventually be the home of the freedmen of the Southern States; but its tropical character will make it impracticable for any white emigration ever to establish [???]lt there numerously enough and firmly to assimilate and identity it with car own land.
headline: {'main': 'Can Mexico be Americanized?', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Can Mexico be Americanized?', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: TROUBLE AMONG THE COLORED TROOPS A serious mutiny is reported among the colored troops at Fortess Monroe, which was [???] down without blood [???]d. Our [???] will remember that a similar story, [???]ting seriously on the good conduct of our colored soldiers, which was recently telegraphed from Memphis, subsequently proved to be a sheer fabrication; and they would do well to suspend judgment in this case until all the facts and circumstances are officially made public. We may expect to hear from the South all manner of reports prejudicial to the colored race, which must necessarily be received with many grains of allowance.

abstract: Fashion Course, General Butler, >amp;c., trot for $2,000
snippet: Fashion Course, General Butler, >amp;c., trot for $2,000
lead_paragraph: The second and long expected final contest, for which General Butler, Lady Emma, Dexter and Flora Temple were entered -- the race being mile heats, best three in five to wagons -- came off yesterday. As we stated yesterday, the little bay mare Flora Temple, having gone amiss in her training, was drawn, and HIRAM WOODRUFF having selected Lady Emma, the champion of his stable, in place of Dexter, the race was left to these two. The dull and lowering aspect of the morning precluded as large an attendance as would otherwise have been present, nevertheless, it was far larger than could have been anticipated. The held was well filled with elegantly appointed equipages, and the stand was garnished by bevies of ladies, in full Summer costumes, lending light and lustre to the scenes. The utmost order and decorum prevailed throughout. The track being placed under the supervison of Capt. DECAMP, of the Second Precinct of the New-York Police Force, who had fifty picked men, selected from ten precincts. In addition to this there was a delegation of detectives on the course, and not a solitary improper person was admitted, nor was there heard a rude jest or vulgar word throughout the day. In order and decorum under the management of Mr. CROCHERON, the Fashion Course is a thoroughly model institution.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, Detective Officers SLOWEY and NIVEN apprehended NATHAN MASS on suspicion of having stolen $180 worth of masculine attire which had been found in his possession. The prisoner said that he had purchased the clothing at a place in Twenty-second-street; but a case of surgical instruments which was found in one of the pockets disclosed the fact that it had been stolen from Messrs. MULFORD JENKINS, THOMAS KENNETT, night editor of the World, and WILLIAM L. KEYS, son of Major-Gen. KEYS, gentlemen who live at No. 112 East Fourteenth-street. On searching MASS place of abode, the detective officers found pawn-tickets representing $1,000 worth of property. The prisoner was committed for trial.

abstract: The Board of Aldermen yesterday directed the Hudson River Railroad Company to repair forthwith their rail tracks in the lower part of the city.
lead_paragraph: The Board of Aldermen yesterday directed the Hudson River Railroad Company to repair forthwith their rail tracks in the lower part of the city. They also ordered the removal of a pier at the foot, of Hubert-street, said to be constructed by permission of the Pilot Commissioners, and administered a sharp rebuke to the commissioners for granting such permission. A resolution setting apart two plots of land in Sixth-avenue for the erection by public subscription of statues of FULTON and MORSE, was referred to the Committee on Arts and sciences. The board adjourned to Monday next.

abstract: ARREST OF A BURGLAR AND RECOVERY OF STOLEN PROPERTY. -- On Thursday evening last, the residence of Mrs. MARTIN, No. 85 East Balti[???]t, was feloniously entered by forcing one of the back windows during the absence of the family, and rel[???]ed of a gold watch and chain, a gold bracelet, an enameled ring with seven diamonds and fourteen pearls, silver spoons lined with gold, and some silk dresses -- in all valued at $700. A young man named CHARLES BROWN had been s[???]n about the neighborhood, and, as his antecedents are none of the b[???], he was at once suspected, and Capt. RHODES and Special Detective DONNELLY, of the Forty-third Precinct Police, proceeded in search of him. They eventually succeeded in tracing him to New-York, and yesterday afternoon discovered him walking along Chatham -- street. As soon as he recognized the officers he took to his heels and ran down Roosevelt -- street, where he was overtaken after a brisk chase. He was brought to Brooklyn and looked up. All the property he had stolen was recovered, having not yet disposed of the most valuable portion. The accused was arrested some months since for robbing a number of houses in Herkimer-street, Ninth Ward. He was indicted by the Grand Jury, but was subsequently bailed in the sum of $1,500 by his father. Shortly before the day fixed for his trial, he escaped from the city, and his bail was forfeited. Thinking, probably, that he had no more to f[???]ar, he recently returned to the city, and remained for some days at the house of a relative, which is next door to the residence of the lady whom he robbed. He doubtless made himself acquainted with the premises, and laid his plans accordingly. At the time of the robbery in Herkimer-street he carried on the business of a butcher in that neighborhood, and was familiar with the premises he then entered in a felonious manner. His chances of escape now are very limited.

abstract: Farewell Address
snippet: Farewell Address
lead_paragraph: There are and will be limited restrictions on travel to ports on the Texas coast, but free and unrestricted travel and communication will open in five days by official orders. Only transports are at present running, but a private line of steamers will be plying in a few days. The subscriptions to-day to the Seven-Thirty Loan, as reported by JAY COOKE, were $2,011,800, including $100,000 from the Third National Bank of St. Louis; $100,000 from the Third National Bank of Cincinnati; $100,000 from the First National Bank of Cincinnati; $200,000 from the Second National Bank of Boston; $100,000 from the National Bank of the Republic, Boston; $100,000 from the Citizens' Bank of Baltimore; $100,000 from SMITH & MARTIN, New-York; $100,000 from S.T. SUIT, President National Bank, Richmond, Va.; $200,000 from National Bank of the Metropolis, Washington, D.C.; and $100,000 from the First National Bank of Indianapolis. The number of individual subscribers amounted to 1,483.

abstract: Last Sunday, the 11th inst., a boy nine years of age, named JOHN F. WHITE, was run over in Smith-street by a Coney Island car, and so dreadfully injured that he died in a day or two thereafter. It appears that deceased and another lad jumped on one of the open excursion cars. When the conductor approached them they leaped off. Ono escaped uninjured. Coroner BARRETT held an inquest, and the jury rendered a verdict exonerating the employes of the company from blame, and added: "But we are of opinion that, in default of further and sufficient precautions against accidents to passengers and others, the form of the cars should be changed to that of the close car on other reads, or that, at least, the company should be compelled to have a passageway through the centre of the cars, as well as platforms on the sides."

abstract: Brooklyn, Diodati Murder; Verdict of Jury
snippet: Brooklyn, Diodati Murder; Verdict of Jury
lead_paragraph: The investigation before Coroner LYNCH and jury in relation to the circumstances attending the death of the Italian, ANTONIO DIODATI, who was found murdered in the wood near the Brooklyn City line, on Saturday, the 27th ult., was brought to a close last evening. In consequence of an anonymous letter received, several new witnesses were summoned and examined. These were, Mr. JOSEPH CRISTADORA, of New-York, and Mr. JOSEPH MATARINO, of this city. Their evidence, however, throw no additional light upon the matter. Dr. CHARLES A. VAN ZANDT, who made the post-mortem examination of deceased, testified that he found a bullet-wound in the head, one inch behind the lower part of the right ear, passing through the temporal bone, which was broken in several parts. A leaden bullet was found in the spinal marrow, and there was an incised wound in the back of the neck, extending down between the vertebrae into the spinal cord, and two-thirds around the neck. In the back and upper part of the chest, one inch to the left of the median line, a bullet-wound was found passing through, making its exit at the junction of the first rib and sternum. The organs were in a healthy condition.

abstract: THE FERRIS FEMALE INSTITUTE. The closing exercises of the institute took place yesterday at Grace Church, the interior of which was beautifully decorated with the national colors. Quite a large number of the friends of the pupils were present.
lead_paragraph: THE FERRIS FEMALE INSTITUTE. -- The closing exercises of the institute took place yesterday at Grace Church, the interior of which was beautifully decorated with the national colors. Quite a large number of the friends of the pupils were present. The exercises were opened with the singing of an anthem by the pupils, after which an appropriate prayer was offered by the venerable President, Dr. FERRIS and the reports of the Committees on the Compositions of the Academic and Collegiate Departments were read, together with the prize compositions in each. After the distribution of the awards, an address was delivered by the President, and the exercises were closed with the benediction.

abstract: Question of Trial of; Surrender and Liability to Trial; on Duration of Parole
snippet: Question of Trial of; Surrender and Liability to Trial; on Duration of Parole
lead_paragraph: In deciding the question of trying Gen. LEE for treason -- and we believe it is not yet decided whether he will be so tried or not -- there are one or two points of great delicacy to be considered. Dr. LIEBER has discussed, with his usual acumen, the force and duration of the parole given on surrender, deciding that it lasts as long as the war lasts, and no longer, and that on its expiration, the person giving it becomes a civilian, and liable, like any other man, to any pains and penalties to which he may have rendered himself liable for violations of the laws. In other words, the parole of a prisoner binds him, and has to be respected by his captors, only so long as he would have remained in confinement had it not been given at all. Either the cessation of hostilities or a regular exchange puts an end to it, and reduces the prisoner, if an alien, to the condition of a foreign sojourner; if a rebel, to that of a simple citizen.
headline: {'main': 'The Trial of Paroled Rebel Prisoners for Treason.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Trial of Paroled Rebel Prisoners for Treason.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: -- Government is rapidly dismantling the fortifications at Richmond and Petersburgh, and shipping the cannon, etc., to the Washington and other Northern navy-yards and arsenals. The number of cannon of all kinds, siege and field, is much larger than was originally supposed. At one time four or five acres at the landing below Richmond were covered with cannon, caissons, army wagons, etc. Five vessels were at City Point and Richmond last week, loading with them, including the beautiful Whitworth battery of rifled cast-steel twelve-pounders surrendered by Gen. LEE at Barksville, Va., which was presented to the rebels at the beginning of the war, by sympathizing friends in England. Artillery officers pronounce it one of the finest batteries in the world. It will probably be sent, with other curious pieces, to West Point, as trophies. At Petersburgh just before its evacuation, many cannons were buried, and head-boards put up at each end, to resemble soldiers' graves. The negroes, always loyal to the North, immediately revealed the trick, and upward of 100 field-pieces have already been exhumed. The amount of war material now accumulated by government, both of its own manufacture and captured from the rebels, is almost incredible. Speaking of guns in a wholesale way, an artillery officer lately intimated that the cannon, caissons, ambulances, army wagons, etc., with their teams, would make a column reaching from New-York to California.
lead_paragraph: -- Government is rapidly dismantling the fortifications at Richmond and Petersburgh, and shipping the cannon, etc., to the Washington and other Northern navy-yards and arsenals. abstract: Defacement of Natural Scenery
snippet: Defacement of Natural Scenery
lead_paragraph: We regret to see that the legislative enactment against the defacement of natural scenery is likely to prove a dead letter. The vagabonds who disfigure the fairest portions of our landscapes with odious advertisements of quack medicines, patent skirts, cock-tail powders, plantation bitters, St. Domingo bitters, &c., are again busy with brush and paint, in open violation of the law. Stringent measures should be taken to put a stop to this defacement of scenery, and to bring the offenders to immediate punishment.

abstract: Coroner WILDEY held an inquest, last evening, at the Eleventh Ward Police-station, upon the  body of MICHAEL COOGAN, of No. 99 Cannon-street. The testimony of Mrs. GORMAN, the woman with whom the deceased had cohabited  three years or more, and the only person that was with COOGAN when her son, MICHALL GORMAN, shot him, was utterly worthless, and it seemed to the spectator either that the witness...
lead_paragraph: Coroner WILDEY held an inquest, last evening, at the Eleventh Ward Police-station, upon the body of MICHAEL COOGAN, of No. 99 Cannon-street. The testimony of Mrs. GORMAN, the woman with whom the deceased had cohabited three years or more, and the only person that was with COOGAN when her son, MICHALL GORMAN, shot him, was utterly worthless, and it seemed to the spectator either that the witness had resolved to disclose nothing or that she knew nothing of the north life, her brain having been muddled at the time by beer. It was shown, however, in the testimony of other witnesses, that the young man, who had but recently been [???]ol[???]ly discharged from the naval service, went to his mother's abode on business on Thursday evening; that his putative stepfather, who was in liquor, quarreled with him and threatened to thrust him from a window; that shortly thereafter a struggle was heard by the neighbors, and that young GORMAN shot him through the heart. It also appeared that GORMAN, or ascertaining that COOGAN's wound had proved mortal, voluntarily went to the police-station and surrendered, saying, "I shot the man in self-defence." The jury evidently weighed the character of the young man as compared with that of the deceased, it appearing that that of the former had ever been exemplary, while that of the latter had been bad, and they found that the shooting was in self-defence, and, under the circumstances, justifiable.

abstract: Brilliancy of; Prospects, Political, Financial and General
snippet: Brilliancy of; Prospects, Political, Financial and General
lead_paragraph: The vitality and strength exhibited by our country at this time are no less wonderful than the gigantic power it displayed during the existence of the late war. The active energies of the nation, diverted for a time to the work of war, have now returned in full force to the labor of developing our varied and incalculable resources; and the grateful change has been effected with an ease and equanimity beyond all previous hope. Our prospects for the future are as brilliant as our present position is strong.

abstract: JACOB THOMPSON's twenty-five-thousand-dollar organ here is that on which the London Times was wont mainly to rely when it wished to show that the independence of the South was an accomplished fact. Its correspondent here likewise echoed THOMPSON's organ, which accounts for the value and the timeliness of that worthy's reports of rebel victories. For this correspondent and his colaborer, "Druid," there ought to be pensions provided from what remains of THOMPSON's yellow fever fun.

abstract: Hoboken Course, Lady Thorne, >amp;c., Trot
snippet: Hoboken Course, Lady Thorne, >amp;c., Trot
lead_paragraph: Two of the Hudson County Agricultural Association purses for trotting and running races were competed for yesterday afternoon over the Secaucus track, New-Jersey. A large and most highly respectable assemblage congregated to witness the sport. As usual, the management was good, the track excellent, and everything flourishing for genuine, good sport, which certainly resulted. Two as well-contested races took place, as far as interest and amusement were concerned, as have been exhibited during the present season. The enthusiasm was immense, but not boisterous -- all pleasantry. There will be another trotting match this afternoon, for which three horses will contend. Ere long this track is destined to become one of the favorite places of resort for citizens who require three or four hours of recreation. Appended is the

abstract: Satisfactory Progress in
snippet: Satisfactory Progress in
lead_paragraph: -- The news we have to-day from North Carolina is exceedingly satisfactory. Gov. HOLDEN appears to be pursuing a cautions, conciliatory, and conservative course, in entering on the grave task of reconstruction. He is adopting precisely the course most likely to win the confidence of the people, in taking counsel informally with those who are in a position to give counsel in the matter of preparing his programme of executive action. President JOHNSON's policy gives general satisfaction, and his name is popular throughout the State.

abstract: -- Capt. JOHN JOURDAN and Patrolman WOOLDRIDGE, who had long sought SPENCER PETTIS, one of the rogues that, on the 22d of November last, forged a check for $25,000 on the Bank of Commerce, found him, on Thursday night, in bed in Fourth-street, and took him into custody. He was held until the opening of the Court of General Sessions, yesterday morning, when he was taken before Recorder HOFFMAN, and by His Honor committed to the Tombs to await trial on an indictment which was found shortly after the commission of the forgery. The prisoner, who spent the last six months among our peculiar friends in Montreal, and is supposed to have been a hale fellow well met with GEORGE N. SANDERS, JACOB THOMPSON, LAWRENCE MACDONALD, and other political gamesters, recently sickened of the companionship and resolved to risk a return to his old haunts in New-York. He came hither in disguise; but that did not avail him; the officers were on his track before he had been twenty-four hours in the city. PETTIS is a journeyman prison-bird, having served in Sing Sing and escaped imprisonment in England only by flying across the water. PETTIS, who is a native of this city, is 35 years of age.

abstract: About 11 o'clock on Thursday night a shocking accident occurred at Rahway, resulting in the death of a highly respected young lady, Miss KATE DEGRAW, daughter of Mr. JOHN DEGRAW, proprietor of the principal hotel at that place. Miss DEGRAW, together with her two sisters, had attended a pic-nic a few miles out of town, in company with a young gentleman named ENNIS. Upon their return the carriage drew up to the door, and the two sisters had alighted, and as the deceased was being assisted from the carriage, the horses took a sudden fright and dashed off at a furious speed. The young lady's crinoline became entangled in the steps of the carriage, and with her head and shoulders dragging upon the ground, the horses made the circuit of the village twice before the citizens could stop them. When they did so the young lady was found to be lifeless, and her remains presented a mutilated and ghastly appearance.

abstract: Suffrage and Threats of Revolution; Mr. Cain on
snippet: Suffrage and Threats of Revolution; Mr. Cain on
lead_paragraph: -- It is not as Evadne or as Lucretia Borgia that MISS HOSMER is seen to the best advantage. The latter character was thought would suit her presence and style better than the role in which she made her debut. We were mistaken. The opportunities offered by the large and passionate temperament of the Borgia were seized last evening with an unsteady grasp, and the evidence of injurious [???]ing in a vicious school was only too manifest. [???] advice have appeared before a New-York public with better claims to consideration [???] Miss HOSMER. Her voice is excellent, her manner impressive, and under due restraints commanding; her elocution in the suave passages that [???] become the voice of woman, is thoroughly charming. With these advantages, natural and acquired, it was not at all strange that the lady obtained an immediate success, notwithstanding a common aversion to the piece, (Camille,) in which she appeared. But these claims will surely be forgotten, and rightly, if she indulges in the "Er[???]s vein" so persistently as she did last night. We have had so many dignified types of Lucretia Borgia, both in opera and drama, that it were in vain to point out the fact that dignity is an essential element of the character. Miss HOSMER, it seems to us, is oblivious of this. The character in her hands is lowered to a level which it ought not to occupy. The haughty and erring mother becomes a mere scold, and rages furiously at everything that crosses her path. The performance throughout was uneasy -- if not violent -- in speech and in action; displaying, instead of the independence of youth, the imitative of subserviency of the old stager. There can be no humane justification, of the positive rant, the unreasonable gesticulation and incessant wails of the second act. They are mannerisms of the worst kind, and we consult Miss HOSMER's interest when we advise her to discard them at once. An audience such as she addressed will not patiently return to a school that is exploded, and the subject of general ridicule.

abstract: Applying for Pardon; Applying for Pardon
snippet: Applying for Pardon; Applying for Pardon
lead_paragraph: -- Our dispatches from Washington state that among the thousands of late rebels who are sensible enough to give up their wicked folly and apply for pardon, are ROBERT E. LEE and ALEXANDER H. STEPHENS, one the General-in-Chief of the rebellion, the other the Vice-President of the abortive nation. Perhaps no two men of note in allthe South would be received with anything like the consideration that these repentant sinners can command. In spite of his manifest treason. Gen. LEE has retained a strong hold upon Northern regard; he has held, notwithstanding his complicity in the treatment of Union prisoners, a sort of deified petition, and has been tacitly excepted from the herd of common traitors. That he should have the good sense to acknowledge his sins and ask forgiveness, is a hopeful sign. What the result may be is another matter, and one entirely within the province of President JOHNSON to determine.

abstract: Freedmen; Employers for the; Silverpen on Chivalry and the Southerners
snippet: Freedmen; Employers for the; Silverpen on Chivalry and the Southerners
lead_paragraph: The sufferings among the freedmen of the South, which the semi-rebel press of that section dilates upon with intentional exaggeration, does not, we fear, arise so much from the laziness of the negroes, or their refusal to work for themselves, as from the apathy, the obstinacy or the cruelty of their former masters. The slave-owner, having all his life wielded his whip as a sceptre, governing his black chattels with as absolute a rule as the King of Dahomey exercises over his subjects, regulating their domestics concerns and providing for their wants in the same manner and on the same plan that he adopts for his cattle, naturally enough now complains of the growing [???]ce of his late slaves. Are we to understand that the freed negro intends to insult his former master; that he is impudent, or impertinent, or intrusive? Not at all. His arrogance consists in professing to be happy without the consent of the lord of the soil whom he serves; his impudence in being an ally of the hated Yankee and a participant in the glorious results of their triumph; and the acme of impertinence is reached when the late chattel presents his bill at the end of the month and requests payment for his labor.

lead_paragraph: -- The Boston Traveller states that when a number of prisoners were released from Fort Warren, on Monday last, the crowd were very anxious to secure some of the buttons on the coats and jackets of the rebels for curiosities -- the Virginia State buttons, with the motto "Sic Semper Tyrannis" engraved upon them, being the most in demand. The rebels readily cut off a number and gave them away. Others, who were not so fortunate as to receive any, resorted to all manner of schemes to obtain a button. The man was kept in earnest conversation by two or three men, while another would operate on the buttons, and in this way several were secured. A rebel detected a person in the act, and laughed at his eagerness to get such a trifle, saying that he was willing to give away all he had on his clothes, if they would sew others on, so that he could keep his coat together. The "C.S.A." and South Carolina buttons (with the palmetto tree engraved upon the latter) were also much inquired after. They were evidently made in Manchester, England, from the mark on the back of them.

abstract: THE SEWARD FAMILY. -- The Secretary and Assistant Secretary of State are recovering, the latter slowly, however. There seems a touching fatality about this family ever since the fatal event on the 14th of April. Mrs. SEWARD, wife of the Secretary, was prostrated by anxiety and watchfulness on account of her husband and sons, and her life was despaired of. Now we hear of another accident to another branch of the family. Mrs. WHARTON, of Rensselaer County, in this State, mother-in-law of Mr. FREDERICK W. SEWARD, was riding last week, in company with Miss BOYD, her sister, to the Hudson River Railroad depot, at East Albany, to take the oars, when, on going down the hill at Bath, the horses rook fright and ran away. Both ladies were thrown out and badly injured. Mrs. WHARTON breaking her shoulder and Miss BOYD dislocating one wrist Mrs. WHARTON had set out for Washington and Miss BOYD for New-York, when they met with this accident, -- Syracuse Journal.

abstract: We had a very pleasant interview, on Saturday, with Hon. Mr. SEWARD, an old member of Congress from Georgia, who, before and during the rebellion, has been faithful to the government, the Union and the flag. He says that Georgia was forced out of the Union by the will of a few leading Secessionists; that a large portion of the inhabitants have ever been loyal; that thousands have been hiding and suffering for years; and that the surrender of LEE's army and the capture of JEFFERSON DAVIS, were events hailed with joy, especially in Southern Georgia, by a majority of the citizens.

abstract: There will be a grand Fourth-of-July Celebration, this year, at the town of West Farms, Westchester County, under the auspices of the Marion Lodge. Extensive arrangements have been made to effect a success. Supervisor S.M. PURDY, of West Farms, will preside, and SCOTT R. SHERWOOD, Esq., has accepted an invitation to officiate an orator of the day. Mr. W.G. LIVINGSTON, of West Farms, will read the Declaration. Subsequent to the speaking, there will be dancing, and other holiday exercises. The Committee of Arrangements comprise Messrs. Hugh Livingston, B. Valentine, W.L. Fisher, W.G. Livingston, John Fenn, F.K. Jessup, A. Lirchte, Charles Norton, Wm. Sherwood, Harry Cornell, Thos. Carter, Geo. Wilson, R. McChrystie.

abstract: RECOVERY OF BODIES. -- On Thursday evening the Seventh Ward Police recovered the bodies of Mrs. MATILDA WINCOOP and Misses JOANNA REARDON and MARY MCNAMARA, of No. 408 Water-street, three ladies who were drowned by the upsetting of a boat in the East River, off Pike-slip, on Sunday evening last. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest yesterday, and it was shown that the boat in which JEREMIAH O'CONNOR had taken the deceased out, capsized accidentally, as was stated in the TIMES of Monday morning. Mrs. WINCOOP's husband is in California. She was a native of England, 83 years of age. The young ladies were aged 19 and 21 years respectively.

abstract: Demands Suppression of Tribune Bulletin
snippet: Demands Suppression of Tribune Bulletin
lead_paragraph: About noon yesterday, some excitement was created in and around the Tribune office by the appearance, in angry mood, of Mr. BENJAMIN WOOD of the Daily News, who demanded the immediate suppression of a bulletin posted on the Tribune office, which reflected rather severely upon Mr. WOOD in connection with the testimony lately taken before the military commission in Washington. The attaches of the office complied with Mr. WOOD's demand and the bulletin was removed.

abstract: DEATH or GEORGE V. SACKETT. -- One of the few survivors of the pioneers of Western New-York died at Seneca Falls, in the seventy-fifth year of his age, on the 15th instant. JUDGE SACKETT was a cotemporary, at the bar, of Judge HOWEIL, of Canandaigua; Judge MILLER, of Auburn; and Gen. MATHEWS, of Rochester. He was associated in various relations with all the men of worth for more than half a century. For the last thirty years he lived a retired life, upon his farm, enjoying the society of old friends, with the circle narrowing, until, of the class referred to, he was quite alone. He was a man eminently social, with ardent and political feelings, and strong personal attachments; and, withal, a man of earnest faith and proverbial integrity.
lead_paragraph: DEATH or GEORGE V. SACKETT. -- One of the few survivors of the pioneers of Western New-York died at Seneca Falls, in the seventy-fifth year of his age, on the 15th instant. abstract: Ford's Theatre at Washington
snippet: Ford's Theatre at Washington
lead_paragraph: FORD's THEATRE IN WASHINGTON. -- Unless sundry paragraphs which are running through the papers do him great injustice, Mr. FORD, the proprietor of the theatre in Washington which was the scene of Mr. LINCOLN's assassination, is trilling outrageously with the feelings of the public. We are first told that the Lutherans propose to purchase the theatre in order to turn it into a church and next the Congregationalists have the matter under consideration; but, however these paragraphs may vary in this respect, they uniformly state that unless Mr. FORD receives one hundred thousand dollars for the property before Sept. 1, he will reopen the theatre. Possibly these statements are made without Mr. FORD's authority. If they are, he should at once contradict them in justice to himself.

abstract: SANFORD CONOVER ALIAS J. WATSON WALLACE. -- Affairs about SANFORD CONOVER, the witness whose testimony on the assassination trial caused such a sensation, seem to be in a muddle. A few days ago the Montreal Telegraph published, and we copied a series of affidavits by J. Watson Wallace, alleging that CONOVER had personated him and sworn falsely in his name. The Telegraph, of Thursday last, now says that this man WALLACE has acknowledged that he is the original CONOVER, but it adds the significant statement that he is in jail in Montreal as a "loafer," and that an accomplice of his is keeping him company. In its characteristic way, the Telegraph says further, that CONOVER "wishes to disclose how and by what means he was induced to go to Washington at the instance of federal pimps for perjury, but that Southerners here scorn to go near him to receive his disclosures."
lead_paragraph: SANFORD CONOVER ALIAS J. WATSON WALLACE. -- Affairs about SANFORD CONOVER, the witness whose testimony on the assassination trial caused such a sensation, seem to be in a muddle. abstract: Caused Military Trial of Assassins; Col. Halpine On; Conover and Wallace; Confusion of Identity; Testifying that Secretary Stanton Favored Civil Trial of Assassins
snippet: Caused Military Trial of Assassins; Col. Halpine On; Conover and Wallace; Confusion of Identity; Testifying that Secretary Stanton Favored Civil Trial of Assassins
lead_paragraph: MILITARY COURTS. -- The following statement is in regard to the establishment of a military court for the trial of the assassins. Col. HALPINE, who is responsible for the statement, doubtless, knows the facts of the case sufficiently to justify us in receiving his report as authentic. It shows that the merit, or the discredit, of instituting a military trial in this case is not Secretary STANTON's, but Judge HOLT's. It so happened that Mr. STANTON favored a civil trial. But the President and a majority of the Cabinet took Judge HOLT's view; and a military commission was thereupon named by President JOHNSON. The statement, which we take from the Citizen, is as follows:

abstract: THE REGATTA OF THE HOBOKEN YACHT CLUB.  The eighth annual regatta of the Hoboken Yacht Club will take place on Monday next. The course to be sailed will be from the club-house, Elysian Fields, to a stake-boat moored one mile east of buoy No. 15, off the West Bank. The start will take place at 11 A.M. A number of new yachts are entered, and, with a fair wind, an exciting race may be expected.

abstract: FATAL ACCIDENT AT FORTE LEE. -- On Thursday afternoon, CYRUS H. CARVER, of No. 387 East Fourth-street, who had accompanied the Second-street Methodist Episcopal Sabbath-school on an excursion to Fort Lee, missed his footing on a bluff near the pavilion on the crest of the palisades and falling to the rocks, about fifty feet below, was taken up unconscious. Dr. N.H. CH[???]SEBROUGH and other of his companions immediately placed him on board the steamer Thomas E. Hulse and brought him to this city. The young man died at 9 o'clock yesterday morning. He was 19 years of age. Coroner WILDEY held an inquest last, evening and the jury recommended that measures be taken to prevent the possible recurrence of like accidents on the cliff whence the young man fell.

abstract: Gray, Sir John, Editor Freeman's Journal, visit to N. Y
snippet: Gray, Sir John, Editor Freeman's Journal, visit to N. Y
lead_paragraph: Sir JOHN GRAY, editor and sole proprietor of the Freeman's Journal, published in the Irish metropolis, has arrived in New-York, and is at present stopping at the New-York Hotel. Sir JOHN, or Doctor GRAY formerly, has filled very high positions in the civic board of the capital of his native city. He has raised the paper of which he is owner to a position far exceeding that of any other journal in the British Isles. Such influence did he wield, that when he was elected Lord Mayor of Dublin, Earl CARLISLE, the then Viceroy, knighted him. He had, previously, on invitation, contested the representation of the County of Monoglian, against Sir ROBERT FOSTER and CHARLES POWELL LESLIE, the two conservative members, and was defeated by a small majority. He is a vivid writer, and a refined and eloquent speaker. We wish him a happy time as he wends his way through the United States.

abstract: New-York, Cavanagh Murdered by Drake in latter's Saloon
snippet: New-York, Cavanagh Murdered by Drake in latter's Saloon
lead_paragraph: Mr. PATRICK CAVANAGH, of No. 277 Tenth-avenue, died early yesterday morning, from a wound which he received at the hands of JOHN DRAKE, of No. 296 West Twenty-eighth-street, at the letter's abode, on the evening of Tuesday last. On Friday evening, the Coroner took Mr. CAVANAGH's deposition, and learned that at the time of the encounter between DRAKE and CAVANAGH, the former, who was in his own dwelling, became angry from some unknown cause, and plunged a knife into the latter's breast, inflicting a mortal wound. DRAKE has been arrested. Coroner GOVER will hold a formal inquest to-day.

abstract: Report of Peace Convention of 1861; L. E. Chittenden's Report
snippet: Report of Peace Convention of 1861; L. E. Chittenden's Report
lead_paragraph: Amongst the "memoires pour servir," on which the future historians of tho war will have to draw for their materials, there are probably none less interesting or more instructive than the "Reports of Debates and Proceedings of the Confederate Convention," held at Washington in February, 1861, for the purpose of proposing amendments to the Constitution of the United States. As the sessions were secret, and nothing was known by the public at the North, of the result which had been reached, until the close of March, when all hope of peace or compromise had passed away, and when every mind was absorbed in the contemplation of the tremendous catastrophe which was then approaching, there was but few people who paid any attention to the labors of the convention, and there are, perhaps, fewer still, who now remember that it ever sat. Neither its debates nor its resolutions have exercised the smallest influence on the course of events, or on public opinion. They never made the smallest approach to the amicable adjustment of the differences between North and South; we doubt if they over raised the smallest expectation, even in the minds of those who took part in its proceedings, that they would postpone for one hour the great collision which was then impending.

abstract: The bi-centennial anniversary of the organization of the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, on Staten Island, is to be celebrated in the church at Port Richmond, on Thursday, June 22. The exercises are to commence at 11 o'clock A.M. The address will be delivered by Rev. JAMES BROWNLEE. Rev. Dr. VERMILYE will take part in the exercises. The members of the New-York Historical Society, and others interested in the early history of New-York, are especially invited to be present.
lead_paragraph: The bi-centennial anniversary of the organization of the Reformed Protestant Dutch Church, on Staten Island, is to be celebrated in the church at Port Richmond, on Thursday, June 22. The exercises are to commence at 11 o'clock A.M. The address will be delivered by Rev. JAMES BROWNLEE. Rev. Dr. VERMILYE will take part in the exercises. The members of the New-York Historical Society, and others interested in the early history of New-York, are especially invited to be present.

abstract: THE CONSULTATION WITH GOV. PEIRPOINT. -- The distinguished citizens who have been called into council by the Governor have had very full and frank consultations with him, and have concluded their conferences. We understand that, while on a few subjects, there was a very wide difference of opinion between themselves and the Governor, yet in others there was a cordial concurrence. In those cases where these gentlemen were unable to bring the Governor to their own views, they respected the reasons which he urged as controlling him, and parted with him on the most cordial terms of confidence and mutual esteem. We understand that all these gentlemen, notwithstanding any divergence of opinion between themselves and the Governor, will give him a cordial support, and generously assist his efforts to give to Virginia the benefits of an organized civil government. -- Richmond Republic.

abstract: Ex-M. C. from Georgia
snippet: Ex-M. C. from Georgia
lead_paragraph: The President has appointed ANDREW J. HAMILTON, of Texas, to be Provisional Governor of that State, and also JAMES JOHNSON, of Georgia to be Provisional Governor of Georgia. The form of the proclamation is precisely similar to those heretofore appointing Provisional Governors for North Carolina and Mississippi, and the duties prescribed the same. They are to exercise all the powers necessary and proper to enable the loyal people to restore said States to their constitutional relations to the Federal Government, and to present such a republican form of State government as will entitle the States to the guarantee of the United States therefor, and its people to protection by the United States against insurrection, invasion, violence, &c.

abstract: Yesterday afternoon, DAVID CURTIN, a soldier who has lost a limb in the service of his country, appeared with Officer DUNN, of the City Hall force, and his prisoners, THOMAS NORTON and THOMAS HARRINGTON, backmen, and made affidavit that about ten days ago, having been discharged from a Baltimore hospital, he came hither and, on arriving at the foot of Cortlandt-street, engaged NOKTON to drive him to Roosevelt...
lead_paragraph: Yesterday afternoon, DAVID CURTIN, a soldier who has lost a limb in the service of his country, appeared with Officer DUNN, of the City Hall force, and his prisoners, THOMAS NORTON and THOMAS HARRINGTON, backmen, and made affidavit that about ten days ago, having been discharged from a Baltimore hospital, he came hither and, on arriving at the foot of Cortlandt-street, engaged NOKTON to drive him to Roosevelt street, agreeing to pay $1 for the service; that soon after he had entered the hack THOMAS HARRINGTON also entered, but departed about ten minutes thereafter and took a seat by NORTON's side on the top of the coach; that instead of taking him to Roosevelt-street they drove to Harlem, and there thrust him out in an obscure street, leaving him there, helpless, alone, and without money, as HARRINGTON had robbed him of his wallet, containing $250. Subsequently a good citizen conducted private CURTIN to the State Soldiers' Depot, in Howard-street, and Superintendent COLYER took his case in hand and sent information to Capt. BRACKETT, of the City Hall, and he caused search to be made for the accused, with the result here recorded. In default of bail the prisoners were committed. The soldier's money was not recovered.....Private JAMES B. [???]OVER, of the New-England Soldiers' Home, at No. 194 Broadway, appeared against JOHN P. THOMPSON, and alleged that while they were sleeping in the Home the accused robbed him of $180. THOMPSON, who is a Canadian, was committed for trial.

abstract: London Herald's Dismal Picture of American Affairs
snippet: London Herald's Dismal Picture of American Affairs
lead_paragraph: It has been the fond hope of every American that the collapse of the great rebellion would be succeeded by an era of profound peace, national tranquillity and renewed prosperity. To our dismay, we find that we have been miserably deluded, without suspecting it, and that we are quietly living in a terrible state of anarchy and bloodshed. For this unhappy revelation we are indebted to the London Herald. That veracious journal, in its issue of June 1, draws the following dismal picture of our present situation:

abstract: Porter, D. M., Attorney, Alleged Fraud on H. D. Stover
snippet: Porter, D. M., Attorney, Alleged Fraud on H. D. Stover
lead_paragraph: Officer HIRAM CHANDLER, of the court, apprehended DANIEL M. PORTER, of No. 4 Wall-street, attorney and counselor, on a warrant which Justice DODGE had signed upon application of Mr. HENRY D. STOVER, of No. 164 West Twenty-second street, and the prisoner, on reaching court, was required to answer a complaint alleging that he had defrauded Mr. STOVER in the amount of $25,000. PORTER, who is said not to hold a high position in the esteem of his brethren of the bar, was accused of perjury, long ago, and was to have been examined on that charge before Justice KELLY, but the Justice was called to the Yorkville Court, and the complaint fell through default. He appears for himself. Judge PIERPONT represents Mr. STOVER. Yesterday the affidavits of Messrs. STOVER and NATHANIEL WILSON, Sohertor for the Navy Department, were taken, and a subpoena has been prepared for Mr. Fox, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, whose testimony it is deemed de[???]ral [???] to have. abstract: London Theatres, Rents of
snippet: London Theatres, Rents of
lead_paragraph: -- Sir Rowland Hill has shown that the whole nation may be benefitted by a reform which at the same time benefits each of us individually. In 1839, the last year of the old system, the letters which passed through the Post-office were 70,000,000; they were 240,000,000 in 1844, rose to 410,000,000 in 1853, and will fully reach 700,000,000 in the present yeah in London alone the number of letters delivered in 1863 was 160,000,000, more than twice as many as in the whole kingdom in 1839. There are now 1100 receiving-houses and letter-pillars in the metropolis, and more than 16,000 altogether, showing that the immense number of 40,000 letters are put into each receptacle in a year, taking one with another. As there are 5,300,000 inhabited houses in the United Kingdom, this gives about 120 letters on an average to each house, Considering how few letters the humbler classes receive, the average indicates how large must be the receipt of letters by the commercial houses. Striking an average in the same way, every one of us -- men, women, boys an girls -- receives 22 letters in a year.
