abstract: CHARLES FISHER, of No. 53 Orchard-street, fell asleep in a saloon in the Bowery, corner of Hester-street, and at 3 o'clock yesterday morning GEORGE ENNIS stole his watch and passed it to a confederate, who slipped it into his boot-leg. FISHER soon awoke and was told of the transaction, and, on asking ENNIS to explain, was struck on the head with a chair by that person. Apprehending further difficulty, the landlord summoned Patrolman STAATSBERG, of the Tenth Ward, and ENNIS was taken into custody. The prisoner was committed for examination on a charge of larceny from the person. The watch was not found.

snippet: New-York Citizens' Association; Report of Sanitary Condition of City; Citizen's Association; Report on Sanitary Condition of City
lead_paragraph: At last we have a reliable report upon the social condition of New-York City; a report, moreover, that is no common one; no more compilation of statistical data, overpowering with figures and perplexing with misstatements. This is a book demanding and arresting attention; a live book; remarkable, not more for the extent of research and magnitude of labor involved in its preparation, than for the public spirit it represents and whereof it is the offspring.

lead_paragraph: The directors of the East Broadway and Dry Dock Railway, having, on Saturday evening, extended their track through Thiry-fourth-street, to connect with the Hunter's Point Ferry, President RICHARDSON, of the Fourth-avenue line, sent a force of about one thousand men to the spot last night, tore up the East Broadway and Dry Dock track, and put down rails belonging to the Fourth-avenue Company. The directors of the East Broadway and Dry Dock Railway, having, on Saturday evening, extended their track through Thirty-fourth-street, to connect with the Hunter's Point Ferry, President RICHARDSON, of the Fourth-avenue line, sent a force of about one thousand men to the spot last night, tore up the East Broadway and Dry Dock track, and put down rails belonging to the Fourth-avenue Company. The police were instructed to preserve the peace at all hazards, but not to interfere with the workmen in the work of removing or laying rails. No collision had occurred between the laborers and the police up to midnight.

abstract: Our government has taken effective precautions against any attempt of the rebels to reinstate their government. Until very recently it was not absolutely certain, even after the surrender of LEE and JOHNSTON, that some new effort might not be made to reorganize the rebel authority in Texas or elsewhere. But their President, DAVIS, is in prison at Fortress Monroe, their Vice-President STEPHENS, is in Fort Warren, the President pro tem, of their Senate, R.M.T. HUNTER is either under arrest or will be soon, and COBB, TRENHOLM, MALLORY and other members of the government are also in custody. It will not be easy to start the Confederate machine again at least without a general jail delivery in the North. The rebel magnates are nearly all caged.

But their President, DAVIS, is in prison at Fortress Monroe, their Vice-President STEPHENS, is in Fort Warren, the President pro tem, of their Senate, R.M.T. HUNTER is either under arrest or will be soon, and COBB, TRENHOLM, MALLORY and other members of the government are also in custody. It will not be easy to start the Confederate machine again at least without a general jail delivery in the North. The rebel magnates are nearly all caged.

abstract: Wells, D. A., Annual of Scientific Discovery
snippet: Wells, D. A., Annual of Scientific Discovery
lead_paragraph: This is a volume that no one can afford to do without, who would keep up with the progress of scientific discovery and the increase of knowledge among men. It is an orderly "summoning up of the books" that register the advancement of the race, disposed under appropriate heads. The laws of light and heat, the improvements in artillery and engines of war, the prehistoric traces of man on earth, and every other subject that has received advancement and attracted popular attention during the past twelve months, here finds its appropriate record.

abstract: Botts, J. M., on Northern Sympathizers
snippet: Botts, J. M., on Northern Sympathizers
lead_paragraph: -- A letter from Washington, in another column, states that JOHN MINOR BOTTS thinks that no man, in any section of the country, should be permitted to hold office until he has taken an oath that he has never done, written or said anything against the authority of the Government of the United States, or in any way given aid, comfort or encouragement to its enemies. He thinks Northern sympathizers with the rebellion more criminal and more dangerous than the rebels themselves -- inasmuch as the latter have been thoroughly whipped, and taught a lesson they will never forget.

abstract: Longfellow's Household Poems
snippet: Longfellow's Household Poems
lead_paragraph: This handsome little book is the first volume of a new series, entitled Companion Poets for the People. It is intended to include the popular works of HOLMES, BROWNING, TENNYSON, WHITTIER and others; each volume being illustrated with wood cuts, and published for 50 cents. For this small sum the reader may acquire the most favorite and select poems of LONGFELLOW in an elegant and portable shape. One of the poems -- The Dedication -- is apparently new; the rest are all firmly established in popular estimation. Low price and good quality of the article offered render the success of Messrs. TICKNOR's enterprise quite unequivocal.

abstract: Headley's Life of Gen. Sherman; Sherman, Gen., Headley's Life of
snippet: Headley's Life of Gen. Sherman; Sherman, Gen., Headley's Life of
lead_paragraph: Presents, in a compact form, the chief events in the life of one whose talents have been given unsparingly to the service of his country, and with the happiest results. As brought together by Mr. HEADLEY, the record is a glorious one, and insures the gratitude of his countrymen (in spite of the proverbial fickleness of republics) to one who has them so vigorously and intelligently as the subject of this memoir. The gigantic bubble of the rebellion was effectually pricked and its hollowness demonstrated by Gen. SHERMAN's famous campaign, emphatically "The beginning of the end" of the war.

abstract: The warm weather has not interfered materially with the prosperity of the Summer Season. To New-Yorkers it seems strange that our principal places of amusement should still continue to flourish, but those who frequent them are not of the city, and know nothing of its fastidiousness.
lead_paragraph: The warm weather has not interfered materially with the prosperity of the Summer Season. To New-Yorkers it seems strange that our principal places of amusement should still continue to flourish, but those who frequent them are not of the city, and know nothing of its fastidiousness. They are a hardy race who cheerfully accept a place in the parquet with the thermometer at ninety degrees. WALLACK's, the Winter Garden, and NIBLO's are doing exceedingly well. At the first establishment, the "Iron Mask" has achieved a positive success to which we shall again refer; at the second, Miss HOSMER is giving a round of her star impersonations; and at the third, Miss MAGGIE MITCHELL is the attraction.

abstract: LARGE HAUL OF BURGLARS, THIEVES AND CORNER LOAFERS BY THE POLICE OF THE FORTY-FIFTH PRECINCT. -- For some time past the most populous portion of the Eastern District has been kept in a state of terror by; a gang of burglars, young thieves and desperadoes, who succeeded in entering and robbing with apparent impunity a great many private residences and public stores. This state of things Capt. WOGLOM, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, resolved to end, and by his skillfully laid plans, his officers -- dressed in citizens' clothes -- succeeded, since Saturday evening, in arresting some twenty suspected parties and had them locked up. Among the number there are probably some against whom nothing can be proven, but they will have an impartial hearing before Justice DAILEY this morning. The following are the names, occupations and ages of the parties arrested: PATRICK MCLOUGHLIN aged 20, charged with feloniously entering the residence of Mrs. MURPHY, No. 116 First-street, E.D., on Friday night last and stealing three pocket-books from her boarders; John Kennedy, laborer, 22; James McCormick, 31, bartender; Joseph Slavin, 20; Patrick Kennedy, 22; Patrick Connelly, 24; James Reagan, 21, and John Dolan, 20 -- all on suspicion of burglary. The following were arrested charged with being corner loafers: John Smith, 21, tinsmith; Albert Pearsall, 17, fisherman; James Flaherty, 18, ship-carpenter; Wm. Harrison, 19, machinist; John Hoffman, 21, do.; Wm. Blake, 20, musician; John Sloate, 19, glassblower; Edward Butcher, 18, moulder; George Smith, 21, sailor; Wm. Owen, 22, painter; James Lawler, 19, laborer; James Semes, 19, do.

abstract: Officer HIRAM CHANDLER, of the court, apprehended DANIEL M. PORTER, of No. 4 Wall-street, attorney and counselor, on a warrant which Justice DODGE had signed upon application of Mr. HENRY D. STOVER, of No. 164 West Twenty-second street, and the prisoner, on reaching court, was required to answer a complaint alleging that he had defrauded Mr. STOVER of $25,000. PORTER was accused of perjury long ago, was to have been examined on that charge before Justice KELLY, but the Justice was called to the Yorkville Court, and the complaint fell through default He appears for himself. Judge PIERPONT represents Mr. STOVER. on Saturday the affidavits of Messrs. STOVER and NATHANIEL WILSON, Solicitor for the Navy Department, were taken, and a subpoena has been prepared for Mr. Fox, Assistant Secretary of the Navy, whose testimony it is deemed desirable to have. The deposition of Mr. STOVER, which was taken on Saturday, tells the entire story without uncommon legal circumlocution, and is as follows:

abstract: London Times' Indefatigable War Correspondent on Texas, >amp;c.
snippet: London Times' Indefatigable War Correspondent on Texas, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The timely arrival of the European mail last night has put us in possession of the important information, (for which we are specially indebted to the New-York correspondent of the London Times,) that the Confederate Trans-Mississippi Army, under KIRBY SMITH, numbers 85,000 effective men, including 30,000 Texan cavalry. This rather unexpected news the Correspondent procured through an enterprising and reliable Englishman, recently arrived from KIRBY SMITH's headquarters. Probably both the Correspondent and the intelligent and reliable Englishman were bound in honor not to disclose the facts here, until they had first been given to the English public, which may account for the government being, till now, uninformed as to the vast Confederate force still in the field. Let us do justice to the enterprise of the London Times and its Correspondent in procuring this important news.

abstract: Empire vs. Mystic
snippet: Empire vs. Mystic
lead_paragraph: EMPIRE VS. MYSTIC. -- The contest between these clubs, which took place on the ball-grounds on Sixty-third-street and Third-avenue, on Saturday afternoon, proved to be a signal victory for the Empire Club, and a very good practice game preliminary to the grand match which comes off at Hoboken on Wednesday between the Empire and the champion Atlantics. In the game on Saturday the Empires batted in fine style throughout, and their fielding, especially that of their catcher and second base player, was very good. Their opponents found it next to impossible to punish MARTIN's pitching to any extent, and when they did do so, they found it hard work to get round their bases. There were but about three or four players on the Mystic side at all up to the mark in play -- HARRIS being the best fielder of the party. The Mystics, too, resorted to the poor policy of changing the position of their players, when errors were committed. We give the score below:

abstract: The news from the Trans-Mississippi Department which comes to us to-day through the London Times has various points of interest. It seems that if it should, unfortunately, turn out that KIRBY SMITH has been killed or has killed himself, the command of the Trans-Mississippi Confederate army of 85,000 men is to devolve upon Gen. STERLING PRICE, "a man more formidable as a soldier and a statesman!" We have no doubt our British cousins will wait in breathless anxiety to hear more from the New-York Correspondent regarding this formidable soldier and statesman, and his vast legions. In reading these reports, one sees the advantage the London Times enjoys in having a Correspondent here, so fully alive to current events.

abstract: DROWNED. On Saturday evening FREDERICK FOSTER, a deaf mute from the Deaf and Dumb Asylum at Bloomingdale, was drowned while bathing in the Hudson off One Hundred and Sixty-third-street. abstract: Belligerent Rights; Withdrawal by England and France
snippet: Belligerent Rights; Withdrawal by England and France
lead_paragraph: Almost simultaneously with Mr. SEWARD'S announcement of the withdrawal of rebel belligerent rights by France, comes the news by the European steamer that England has followed the lead of her neighbor, and is "to refuse any longer," as the London Daily News puts it, "to recognize Confederate men-of-war in British ports." Lord RUSSELL'S official announcement of the fact we republish in other columns. In the case of France our Secretary of State finds occasion, while giving an intimation of the fact, to say that these proceedings by the Emperor's Government "have been prompted by the express desire of reviving the old sympathies between the two nations." And the whole country will readily echo the sentiment, even if it should be found difficult altogether to forget the circumstances under which the concession of belligerent rights were first accorded to the rebels, and the readiness of the Emperor's Government to give to the rebel agents, civil and naval, all the countenance possible up to the final catastrophe of their Confederacy.

abstract: Yonge, Miss, Clever Woman of the Family
snippet: Yonge, Miss, Clever Woman of the Family
lead_paragraph: Miss YONGE is an instance of the astonishing fertility of production that women of talent exemplify in their literary progeny. Her writings form almost a small library suited to all sorts and conditions of people, from her admirable school books -- Landmarks of History, &c., to her high church stories of the Reddyffe and Daisy Chain types, and her really learned and elaborate History of Christian Names. And here, after all this arduous labor, is her last book, The Clever Woman of the Family -- unquestionably the best of her novels, and a book that any writer of the day might be proud to own. In the management of a large family no one (on paper) is equal to Miss YONGE; she absolutely revels in the pranks and frolics of ten or a dozen brothers and sisters, all discriminated in character with a nicety of touch that belongs to a woman's pen alone. Her military men also in the book before us, are admirably drawn, and show evident traces of careful study from nature. The moral of this charming story is not obtrusively inculcated, but grows naturally out of its structure. The illustrations are graphic and vigorous.

abstract: a Mysterious Order; New-York; Maracini; in Central Park
snippet: a Mysterious Order; New-York; Maracini; in Central Park
lead_paragraph: At about 5 o'clock on Saturday morning, Patrolman M.C. MEANEY, of the Central Park police, while passing under the Terrace on his way to the lake, observed a man lying on one of the benches, breathing heavily and seemingly asleep and in mortal agony. Speaking to the sufferer, and receiving no reply, Park-keeper MEANEY turned him on his side and in other ways sought to rouse him, but without avail; then, suspecting something wrong, he turned the man over, and, on searching him, found in the breast-pocket of his coat a half-pint bottle containing laudanum. It was manifest that the sufferer was a suicide. The officer lost no time in summoning the two other park-keepers to aid in removing the man, and he was at once taken to St. Luke Hospital, in Fifth-avenue, corner of Fifty-fourth-street, and there left under the care of Dr. CHARLES W. PACKARD, the resident physician of the Institution; but it was too late, and notwithstanding the immediate employment of the usual antidotes and expedients the suicide steadily sank, and expired at 11 o'clock in the forenoon, four hours subsequent to his admission to the hospital.

abstract: Bodemann and Kost on Assaying
snippet: Bodemann and Kost on Assaying
lead_paragraph: Mr. GOODYEAR has rendered effectual service to many by his translation of this valuable manual. English literature is proverbially deficient in works relating to the technical processes of the sciences and arts, and what exist are mostly derived from foreign sources, like the present. It will in a great measure supersede the larger and more costly work of MITCHEL, the only book of any character that is found on the subject. It is well got up and neatly illustrated.

abstract: Farnham's, Mrs., The Ideal Attained
snippet: Farnham's, Mrs., The Ideal Attained
lead_paragraph: Many who are acquainted only by name with Mrs. FARNHAM will be surprised at meeting with a book of undeniable energy and power such as The Ideal Attained undoubtedly exhibits. The characters are vividly drawn and the sketches of the state of society in California during the early days of the gold excitement will have a future value independent of their share in the plot of the novel. The book is the work of a bold thinker and a practiced writer, who might have ranked high among our novelists had her ambition taken that direction.

abstract: Somerset, S. S., Officers of
snippet: Somerset, S. S., Officers of
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Somerset, seven guns, arrived at this port yesterday, in tow of the United States steamer Isenomia, from West Pass, St. George's Sound, Florida, which place she left on the 4th inst. She has been in commission since April, 1862, and has been attached to the East Gulf squadron, upon blockading duty, rendering good service in blockading the port of Apalachicola. She has captured several valuable prizes, one of which was the Circassian, taken off Cuba.

abstract: By the arrival of the Sidon and Bremen at this port, and the Hibernian at Father Point, we have five days later news from Europe. The only news of importance is the announcement that England and France have withdrawn their recognition of rebel belligerent rights, and now forbids rebel privateers from entering British and French ports. The French Government is reported to have sent a dispatch to Washington declaring that Mexico was under the protection of France, and would be defended against fillibusters at any coat. All England is running wild at the birth of the new Prince. King LEOPOLD, of Belgium, is worse.

abstract: On Saturday evening, Capt. THORNE and a squad of policemen made a raid upon street-walkers and other abandoned femaies whom they found soliciting from the street; from doorways, and from windows in Water, Cherry, Roosevelt and other delightful promenades in the Fourth Ward, and the reconnoissance resulted in the capture of thirty-six persons.
lead_paragraph: On Saturday evening, Capt. THORNE and a squad of policemen made a raid upon street-walkers and other abandoned femaies whom they found soliciting from the street; from doorways, and from windows in Water, Cherry, Roosevelt and other delightful promenades in the Fourth Ward, and the reconnoissance resulted in the capture of thirty-six persons. There was little sleep for the policemen of the Fourth Precinct that night or for anybody in the neighborhood of the Station-house; for the captives, having been huddled together in the diminutive prison in rear of the main building, resolved to make merry; and they accordingly diversified the exercises of the night by shouting and singing, whistling and yelling, hurrahing and screaming, and this they continued until daybreak, interlarding the whole with profanity and obscenity that might make a demon blush. Justice HOGAN committed the entire gang to the work-house, there to tarry six months or until they can contrive to procure discharge papers. Several of the prisoners are only ten years old; others say that they are forty, and might well pass for seventy. The police of several wards have recently cleansed their wards of the moral lepers who dwell therein, and the Police Justices, in carting the prisoners off to Blackwell's Island there to be kept until the dog-days are over, are, clearly engaged in a beneficent sanitary reform.

abstract: Difficulties of Reconstruction; Suffrage and Reconstruction; Difficulties of, and President Johnson
snippet: Difficulties of Reconstruction; Suffrage and Reconstruction; Difficulties of, and President Johnson
lead_paragraph: President JOHNSON is entitled to great liberality of judgment in his most arduous work of reconstruction -- more so even than was President LINCOLN in his prosecution of the war. The latter had only to push on steadfastly in a very plain way marked before him. He was shut up by the constitution to the one great necessity of suppressing the rebellion. It was a military end that he had primarily to accomplish; and his main responsibility was discharged when he raised the adequate forces, and intrusted them to the fittest commanders. President LINCOLN was a man of great discretion, and he exercised it with excellent effect when it was required. Yet the success of the war depended mainly upon the discretion of his Generals, particularly upon that of his Lieutenant-General. Though nominally Commander-in-Chief, but a comparatively small share of the military responsibility really rested upon President LINCOLN. The great quality demanded of him was constancy -- the holding on to his constitutional line of duty through the terrible military trials.

abstract: Appointment Provisional Governor of Georgia; the form of as granted
snippet: Appointment Provisional Governor of Georgia; the form of as granted
lead_paragraph: The President has appointed ANDREW J. HAMILTON, of Texas, to be Provisional Governor of that State, and also JAMES JOHNSON, of Georgia, to be Provisional Governor of Georgia. The form of the proclamation is precisely similar to those heretofore appointing Provisional Governors for North Carolina and Mississippi, and the duties prescribed the same. They are to exercise all the powers necessary and proper to enable the loyal people to restore said States to their constitutional relations to the Federal Government, and to present such a republican form of State Government as will entitle the States to the guarantee of the United States thereof, and its people to protection by the United States against insurrection, invasion, violence, &c. Provisional Governors of Florida and other States lately in insurrection will soon be appointed.

abstract: President JOHNSON continues his policy of selecting Southern Union men to fill the various posts of power and responsibility under the new order of things in the Southern States. His selection of JAMES JOHNSON to be the Provisional Governor of Georgia, and of A.J. HAMILTON to be Governor of Texas, is in strict conformity with his previous action on the same subject. There can be no doubt of the wisdom and justice of this policy. The Union men of the South are entitled to every mark of confidence and trust which the government can bestow upon them; and they are certainly much better qualified to judge of the wants, the temper, and the necessities of the Southern people, than Northern men can possibly be. The President's action in this matter commends itself to the cordial approbation of the whole country.

abstract: St. George Club, Practice Game
snippet: St. George Club, Practice Game
lead_paragraph: The leading players of this club had a practice game on their grounds on Friday afternoon, preliminary to the grand match of to-day and to-morrow at Camden, Philadelphia, in which siz of their eleven are to take part. Sides were chosen by Messrs. GIBBES and KENDALL, and a lively game of one innings played, the scores standing 58 to 54 in favor of KENDALL's party. BAMBRIDGES' 15 was the best score. GIBBES' 13 being next. The players left in the 6 A.M. train this morning.

abstract: New-York City Dry Dock and Fourth-avenue, Collision between
snippet: New-York City Dry Dock and Fourth-avenue, Collision between
lead_paragraph: On Saturday evening the directors of the East Broadway and Dry Dock Railway line extended their track to and down East Thirty-fourth-street, to connect with the Hunter's Point Ferry; and yesterday, regarding the right of way in Thirty-fourth-street as belonging exclusively to the Fourth-avenue Company, President RICHARDSON employed a force of about a thousand men to remove the East Broadway Company's track and put down rails belonging to the Fourth-avenue Company. The work was commenced last evening, and at 11 o'clock the agents of the East Broadway and Dry Dock line having appealed to the police, Capt. BURDICK, of the Twenty-first Precinct, appealed to Superintendent KENNEDY for instructions, and was ordered not to interfere except to preserve the peace, and to do that at all hazzards. At midnight there had been no collision between the workmen and the police, and the laying of the rails had been nearly completed.

abstract: During the past two days we have reached that extreme of heat to which, in the course of the year, the human pendulum oscillates from the opposite extreme of cold in this pleasant climate. The dog-days are upon us, and, consequently, we cannot too earnestly enjoin upon our readers the necessity of keeping cool. "Keep cool, with the thermometer as 90 degrees?" Most assuredly, you must do so, or your life will be forfeit.

abstract: EDWARD LEROY, of Broadway and Twenty-second-street, a pupil in the French Institute at Fort Washington Heights, was instantly killed, Saturday morning, on the Hudson River Railroad, between Carmansville and Fort Washington. One arm was run over and broken, and his head was severed from the body. It appears that the 7 o'clock train from Yonkers, coming to this city, had passed Fort Washington, and when about one-third of the distance from that station to Carmansville, the young man fell between two cars, and was run over. The train was moving at its usual speed, and was stopped a short distance from the place where the body lay, and many passengers went back to view it Only a few ligaments connected the head with the trunk. The wheels had passed directly over the neck. Capt WILSON, of the Thirty-second Precinct Police, having been summoned to the spot, took the body to the Thirtieth-street railroad station, and there on inquest was held by Coroner WILDEY.

abstract: PROBABLE SUICIDE BY DROWNING. The body of Mr. GEORGE MANN, residing at No. 130 Willow-street, was found floating in the water near Fulton Ferry yesterday morning. The Coroner was notified and on being hauled on shore it was at once identified by several persons who had been familiar with him.
lead_paragraph: PROBABLE SUICIDE BY DROWNING. -- The body of Mr. GEORGE MANN, residing at No. 130 Willow-street, was found floating in the water near Fulton Ferry yesterday morning. The Coroner was notified and on being hauled on shore it was at once identified by several persons who had been familiar with him. It appears that on Saturday Mr. MANN asked his wife to accompany him to Central Park, but for some reason she declined and he went alone. He returned about 9 o'clock P.M., and seated himself on the front stoop. Mrs. MANN asked him to come in, which he refused to do, and remarked that he was "going home," He then left and went down the street. That was the last seen of him alive. Mr. MANN was about 45 years of age and engaged in the book and stationery business in New York. An inquest will be held to-day.

abstract: A QUIET SABBATH. Complaint from various quarters having recently been made against the many lager-bier gardens on the upper part of the island, Superintendent KENNEDY instructed the captains of police to enforce an old order forbidding music or dancing at these places of popular resort on the Sabbath.
lead_paragraph: A QUIET SABBATH. -- Complaint from various quarters having recently been made against the many lager-bier gardens on the upper part of the island, Superintendent KENNEDY instructed the captains of police to enforce an old order forbidding music or dancing at these places of popular resort on the Sabbath. The recuit was that last week the Superintendent was overwhelmed with remonstrances, the keepers of the parks and lager-bier gardens up town complaining of the injustice of shutting music out of their places, and permitting the down-town saloons to continue their music as usual. Regarding the point as having been well taken, the Superintendent promulgated an order requiring every police captain of the force to prohibit music, yesterday, in every place within his precinct wherein beer or spirituous liquors were offered for sale, and the order was obeyed to the letter throughout the city. Yesterday afternoon a multitude of Germans assembled at the Bellevue Gardens, at the foot of East Seventy-ninth-street, and on ascertaining that the police had forbidden music they held an indignation meeting, passed a series of denunciatory resolutions, and departed for their respective homes. Perfect quiet reigned throughout the city last evening, even East Houston-street behaving itself like an abode of civilization. The number of arrests for drunkenness, up to 11 o'clock last evening, was reported at 42, 11 of the prisoners being females. In the Third, Eighth, Eleventh, Fourteenth, and Twenty-second Wards no arrests were made.

abstract: Resources May now be Developed
snippet: Resources May now be Developed
lead_paragraph: It cannot be said that the regular and legitimate industries of the country were prostrated during the war. The crops were duly sown and gathered, and beside supplying our own necessities, there was an abundance to supply the heavy demand for export. Ships were built for commercial purposes for our own use, and furnished to other countries for commercial uses, as well as to the navies of other governments. Foundries made engines to be employed on railroads and in all the industries. Factories of cotton goods even, were, to some extent, kept active. Every pursuit and profession that ministered to the necessities or luxuries of the people, or that was required in the economy of society or for the ends of civilization, was prosecuted to the extent required. Houses were erected, towns projected and built, and all the cities of the land enlarged. Even those pursuits which minister solely to the intellect, such as the making and publishing of books, were carried on to an extent that must be pronounced astonishing. To the same order belong the educational activity of the nation, as developed in schools, academies and colleges, and in scientific researches, which though almost totally interrupted in the Southern States, has been in regular and constant progress all over the States of the North.

abstract: We are glad to learn that Brevet Major-Gen. HENRY E. DAVIES, Jr., has been promoted to a full Maj.-General, to rank from April 6, 1865, for his bravery and gallantry in charging on that day, at Sailors' Creek, the enemy, in breast-works, and capturing the same, with three guns, two Generals and a large number of prisoners. Gen. DAVIES went into the war at the very beginning, going out with the Duryee Zouaves, (Fifth New-York Infantry,) and has risen steadily and rapidly, by his devotion to duty, and his gallantry in action, to his present high and well earned rank. Few, if any of our citizen-soldiers, have made a more worthy record.

abstract: On Sunday morning HENRY PEROUT, of No. 11 Walker-street, was robbed of $213 while asleep in his own room. One HENRY M. POUYTES, a boarder in the house, having gone out early in the morning, and at night still absented himself, was suspected and apprehended by Officer FIELD, of the Fifth Ward, not, however, without a hot pursuit and severe fight. Having been taken, POUYTES confessed that he had stolen $70. Before Acting Magistrate Alderman JONES he pleaded guilty, and was committed for trial.

abstract: A Hint to Beef-eaters
snippet: A Hint to Beef-eaters
lead_paragraph: We all remember how, once upon a time, butter-merchants made a raid upon our pockets, and how they were ingloriously driven from the field. People stopped eating butter! There is no reason (unless popular patience, amounting to folly, be a reason) why the same policy should not now be followed. Let people refuse to buy meat for one week only, and there will be such a flutter in the meat market as will prove how well the shot has told.

snippet: Desilver's Photographs of President Lincoln, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: -- PICTURE OF THE OLD HOMESTEAD. -- Mr. CHARLES DESILVER, No. 1,229 Chesnut-street, Philadelphia, publishes some interesting pictures of Mr. LINCOLN and of the Homestead at Springfield. The one entitled "Abraham Lincoln as a Father" is already familiar. The photograph of the "Old Homestead" is historically interesting it was taken two days before Mr. LINCOLN left Springfield for Washington, and at his express request, since as he himself said, he did not know when he should return.

abstract: SAILED. -- Prof. WILLIAM B. DE GARMO, of No. 59 West Fourteenth-street, sailed in the steamship Pennsylvania, for Europe, on Thursday last. He proposes to visit Paris, Vienna and other European cities for the purpose of electically gathering for the benefit of his pupils, all the attractive novelties in the saltatorial art. This method of spending his vacation is highly creditable to the Professor, who is acknowledged to be our most graceful and successful instructor of dancing. -- N.Y. Courier.

abstract: King, Robert, N. Y.; Detective Officer
snippet: King, Robert, N. Y.; Detective Officer
lead_paragraph: DEATH OF DETECTIVE POLICEMAN KING -- Mr. ROBERT KING, a well-known and highly esteemed member of the New-York Detective Police Force, died at his dwelling, No. 112 Sullivan-street, at 10 o'clock yesterday morning. Mr. KING was a veteran Policeman, having been a member of the old Municipal Police twenty-five years ago. He resigned a position onthat force to go out with Gen. SCOTT to Mexico, and he there fought creditably under that distinguished leader, and, having been wounded in the head, received an honorable discharge. Returning to this city he again accepted an appointment as Policeman, under Capt. (now Inspector) CARPENTER, of the Fifth Ward, and served under the Captain until the present organization of Metropolitan Police took the place of the effete Municipal body, in 1857, and then, linking his fortunes with Capt. CARPENTER, and going with that officer into the Metropolitan force, he was made a member of the detective squad. He was among the first that responded to the lamented LINCOLN's call for men to retake those "forts and places," and having raised a company for the One Hundred and Thirty-third (Metropolitan) New-York Volunteers, was made Captain thereof. Capt. KING passed through the sanguinary siege of Port Hudson, and followed Gen. BANKS in the disastrous expedition up Red River; but his health failing, he was compelled to resign, and when he reached home, the Board of Police Commissioners again tendered him a position on the detective force, and this he accepted. Detective KING, who had won an enviable reputation as a discreet, skillful and conscientious officer, was sent to England, last Spring, in pursuit of CHARLES WINDSOR, the Mercantile Bank defaulter; but after he had struck the fugitive's trail, British red tape stepped in between him and the accused, and he was forced to come home and report that his mission had been fruitless. A fortnight ago duty called him to the Paterson races, and while there he was prostrated by a sunstroke, from which he did not fully recover. He was able to report for duty up to Friday last, but was then forced to place himself in the hands of a physician, and yesterday morning, when the family thought he was convalescing, he suddenly expired from congestion of the brain. Detective KING, who was 43 years of age, leaves a widow and several daughters to mourn his decease. The entire body of the New-York Detective Police will attend the funeral.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number detailed reports of the Trial of the assassins. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our corresponding in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: The Richmond Republic of Saturday says: "At the time of the great conflagration on the 3d of April last, three of the warehouses in this city were filled with tobacco belonging to the French Government.
lead_paragraph: The Richmond Republic of Saturday says: "At the time of the great conflagration on the 3d of April last, three of the warehouses in this city were filled with tobacco belonging to the French Government. One of the warehouses, we believe, was destroyed by fire, but the other two, containing about 1,100 hogsheads, escaped uninjured. Monsior PAUL, the French Consul in this city, has for some days past been busily engaged in having this tobacco shipped for France. During the present week three steamers and one schooner laden with the tobacco have sailed from this port.

abstract: PATRIC CAVANAGH, of No. 227 Tenth-avenue, whom JOHN DRAKE, of No. 296 West Twenty-eighthstreet, stabbed in the breast on Monday night, the 12th inst., having died, Coronor GOVER impanneled a jury at the Twentieth Ward police station, yesterday morning, and heard conflicting testimony concerning the occurrence; but enough evidence was brought against DRAKE to convince the jury that he inflicted the mortal stab, and they so rendered their verdict.
lead_paragraph: PATRIC CAVANAGH, of No. 227 Tenth-avenue, whom JOHN DRAKE, of No. 296 West Twenty-eighthstreet, stabbed in the breast on Monday night, the 12th inst., having died, Coronor GOVER impanneled a jury at the Twentieth Ward police station, yesterday morning, and heard conflicting testimony concerning the occurrence; but enough evidence was brought against DRAKE to convince the jury that he inflicted the mortal stab, and they so rendered their verdict. Upon which the Coroner committed DRAKE, notwithstanding his counsel's written protest. CAVANAGH was a native of Ireland, aged 25 years.

abstract: At meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, a resolution was adopted granting to the City Gas Company of New-York the right to lay mains and pipes for conducting gas through the city.
lead_paragraph: At meeting of the Board of Aldermen yesterday, a resolution was adopted granting to the City Gas Company of New-York the right to lay mains and pipes for conducting gas through the city. A resolution was also adopted requesting the Committee on the Celebration of the Fourth of July to urge Gov. FENTON to designate the 3d of July as a legal holiday; and in the event of his declining to do so, then the committee are requested to recommend our citizens to observe the 3d as a general holiday. A communication was received from the Comptroller, stating that the appropriation for advertising is exhausted, and recommending that no further expenses on that, account be incurred. A resolution was presented by Alderman RYERS, asking the Comptroller whether the exhaustion of the appropriation will prevent the advertising of the proceedings of the Common Council in the regularly appointed corporation papers.

abstract: New-England Social Club
snippet: New-England Social Club
lead_paragraph: Once on a time, ere these thin hairs were gray, (meaning the writer,) a pic-nic was just about the most delightful Summer recreation possible. Then we had joyful troops of personal friends, each family with its basket of goodies, congregating in some cool and shady retreat, and mingling feed and conversation in equal parts, sandwiching with dances on the greensward and stolen strolls along the brooks, and finished off with rural sports of the most primitive and innocent sort.

abstract: London Herald on American Affairs
snippet: London Herald on American Affairs
lead_paragraph: Reading the comments of the British Tory journals on American affairs, at the present time, excites an emotion akin to that attributed to DOUGLAS JERROLD, who, on getting through a volume of BROWNING, declared that either the poet was crazy or he himself was. We are afraid the people of the United States do not comprehend what they are about, or what perils environ them. They are indulging the illusion that the golden days of peace have returned, when, according to the very latest London Herald, received by the last steamer, they are just plunging into the initial horrors of a terrible and desolating civil war.

abstract: Stone Mr. F., Argument for Herrold
snippet: Stone Mr. F., Argument for Herrold
lead_paragraph: F. STONE, Esq., counsel for HERROLD, being necessarily absent, the argument prepared by him was read by Mr. JAMES J. MURPHY, one of the official reporters of the court. It commences by saying that, at the earnest request of the widowed mother and estimable sisters of the accused, he had consented to act as his counsel. After denying the jurisdiction of the court, the counsel says, the charge in this case consists of several distinct and separate offences embodied in one charge. The parties accused are charged with a conspiracy in aid of the rebellion, with murder, with assault with intent to kill, and with lying in wait. It is extremely doubtful, from the language of the charge and the specification, under which of the following crimes the accused HERROLD is arraigned, and now on his trial, viz.: First, whether he is on trial for conspiracy to overthrow the Government of the United States, punishable by the act of Congress of the United States, passed on the 31st of July, 1861; or, second, whether he is on his trial for giving aid and comfort to the existing rebellion as punishable by the act of Congress passed the 17th of July, 1862; or, third, Whether he is on his trial for aiding and abetting the murder of ABRAHAM LINCOLN, President of the United States. His counsel will understand the legal definition of this three crimes above-mentioned, but does not understand that either to the common law or to the law of war is known any one offence comprised of the three crimes mentioned in this charge. He knows of no one crime of a conspiracy to murder and an actual murder all in aid of the rebellion, distinct and separate from the well-known and defined crimes of murder, of conspiracy in aid of the rebellion, or of giving aid and comfort to the rebellion, as defined by the act of Congress. It is extremely doubtful from the language of this charge whether the murder of the President of the United States is not referred to as the mere means by which the conspirators gave aid and comfort to the rebellion; whether it was not merely the overt act by which the crime of aiding the rebellion was complete.

abstract: China-American Trade, Steamers Engaged in
snippet: China-American Trade, Steamers Engaged in
lead_paragraph: Few of our readers are aware of the magnificent steamships constructed within the past two or three years by the ship-builders of New-York and vicinity for service in the waters of the Chinese Empire. The subject deserves special notice. Great success has attended American steamers designed for this trade, and our mechanics in consequence have won the warmest encomiums. It would seem that defence and art have extended their aid in no department of handiwork more particularly than in the construction of these vessels, and the appreciation of the fact that their models, and the skill and ingenuity manifested in their construction, are regarded as of superior order, is frequently practically shown by advices from that region, which state in effect that these vessels have banished, as it were, from those waters the old style heavy-built, lumbering English crafts, so numerous there a few years since, and which monopolized the entire trade in that region.

abstract: The steamer Constitution arrived last night from New-Orleans, with about four hundred soldiers from various regiments. She also brought the Twenty-first Connecticut, Lieut.-Col. BROWN, commanding, 350 officers and men, and the Fortieth Massachusetts. Lieut.-Col. POLLACK, commanding, 329 officers and men, (recently from Richmond,) from Fort Monroe. These regiments marched down Broadway last evening, to the battery Barracks, and were the recipients of great cheering and applause from the people who lined the sidewalks. The Twenty-first Connecticut will leave this forenoon for home, via the New-Haven Railroad.

lead_paragraph: WINTER GARDEN. -- Miss HOSMER's impersonation of the Countess in SHERMAN KNOWLES' windy play of "Love," redeems, in a great measure, the unfavorable impression which she made in "Lucretia Borgia," The lady has still a great deal to learn, and, worse yet, a great deal to unlearn, before she can rank as a first-class artist, but if she play with feminine moderation and watchful earnestness of the scene -- as she frequently did last night the step from her present position to the highest need to be great or long deferred. Mr. BARTON HILL'S Huon was exceedingly good. The play was placed upon the stage with unusual care, and the performance went off admirably.

abstract: Theories; Some will Always Adhere to; Leaders will Never Regain Power
snippet: Theories; Some will Always Adhere to; Leaders will Never Regain Power
lead_paragraph: -- Some people are afraid that the old political leaders in the South will yet again attain power. It is the last thing in the world likely to occur. They and their character were the product of a peculiar organization of Southern society and institutions, which have passed away, never again to return. It would be utterly impossible for them to exist in their old character and relationship, in the new order of things. The new era will assuredly have its new men. Even were the old leaders to try to adapt themselves to the altered state of affairs, they would fail of success; for the great body of the people in the South have completely lost confidence in them. Their theories have all been exploded, their predictions falsified, and their windy brag made ridiculous; and their false theories, promises, prophesies and brag can never be forgotten in the South, until the bones of the myriads who have fallen victims to their falsities shall have moldered. In no event will this generation see TOOMBS, WISE, WIGFALL, RHETT, BENJAMIN, & CO., controlling the South and domineering the nation.

abstract: Thiers, M., on Financial Condition of
snippet: Thiers, M., on Financial Condition of
lead_paragraph: A temperate, timely and persuasive speech has just been delivered in the French Legislature by M. THIERS. The subject chosen by the distinguished speaker was the financial condition of the country a subject which gave ample scope for M. THIERS to enlarge upon a variety of features in the imperial policy, on which the liberal and the old constitutional party in France are decidedly at issue with the Emperor. The gross national expenditure of the current year is likely to be little less than twenty-two hundred million francs, or about $440,000,000. The deficit, making the most liberal revenue estimates, is likely to exceed $36,000,000. And M. THIERS, while showing by a keen and searching analysis, the insidious way in which the disparity between the income and outlay of the empire is every year increasing, is specially careful to elaborate his picture of the costliness of the glory which France is at this moment reaping from her attempt to establish an imperial system in Mexico. The hopes of a reimbursement of the French Exchequer from the resources of that country, M. THIERS shows to have been thus far altogether fallacious. The securities based upon these resources, which had a nominal market value, last year, of 64, are, to-day, quoted at 44; and M. THIERS confesses himself so entirely skeptical of this financial record improving under a prolonged French occupation, that he urges upon the Emperor's Government the expediency of a prompt and final withdrawal from Mexico. The amour propre of the empire, he admits, might suffer, but not the glory of France. The susceptibilities of the government might be wounded, but there is safety only in retreat.
headline: {'main': 'M. Thiers on the Financial Condition of France and the Costliness of Mexican Regeneration.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'M. abstract: -- The accounts from all parts of the State represent that the growing crops never gave greater promise. The wheat and hay crops, in particular, are reported to be unusually good, and the yield is expected to be great, over the average. A gentleman from Albemarle tells us that the farmers there will make more wheat this season than they have for many years. We are glad to also hear that the negroes are generally behaving themselves well, and are remaining at home working for their former masters. In some parts of the country, remote, like Albemarle, from the seat of war, no change can be observed in the relations between master and slave, except that the negro knows full well, and the master concedes, that he is made free by the war, and that henceforth he is to receive pay for his work. The farmers are entirely reconciled to this change, and upon some plantations the work in the fields is progressing us quietly and as smoothly as before the war. In some cases again the negroes have deserted their former masters in a body, but many of them have since returned, and the others have been forced by hunger to go to work wherever they could get it. One of the Albemarle farmers, we learn, is working now twenty-five more hands than ever before. -- Richmond Bulletin.
lead_paragraph: -- The accounts from all parts of the State represent that the growing crops never gave greater promise. abstract: Moral Proscription of Rebels will be Effective; Tests of Loyalty
snippet: Moral Proscription of Rebels will be Effective; Tests of Loyalty
lead_paragraph: All the indications thus far tend to show that the Union men of the South will incorporate into their new constitutions most rigorous tests of loyalty, and very extensive disfranchisements. They have the power to do this. By the reconstruction proclamations of the President, the new constitutional conventions must be "composed of delegates to be chosen by that portion of the people of said State who are loyal to the United States, and no others;" and they are empowered to "prescribe the qualifications of electors, and the elegibility of persons to hold office under the constitution and laws of the State." It is true that all who vote for these convention delegates must have the qualifications prescribed by the constitution and laws of the State before its so-called "secession;" but thousands in each State who have these qualifications have been so identified with the rebellion that they will not be considered by the Provisional Governor, and the judges of election, his appointees, as meeting the other requirement of loyalty to the United States, and their votes will be rejected. The new conventions will represent that portion of the people who have always remained loyal at heart, and who have been made to suffer in some form or other because of it. They will take every precaution to prevent the control of the State from again passing into the hands of those who so flagitiously betrayed it. This object alone will necessitate great curtailments of the franchise. It is only to be feared that personal feeling may impel the Union men to indulge in an undue measure of proscription. The impulse will be very strong to repay persecution with persecution. All such action ought to be avoided. Broad considerations of public policy should determine the future relations of the loyal Southerners to those who have been disloyal. Private griefs should have no influence. This is a matter, however, which the loyal people of the South are entitled to settle in their own way.

abstract: The
snippet: The
lead_paragraph: The recent debate on the Irish Protestant Establishment in the House of Commons has given the subject such prominence that the question of abolishing the whole of that ecclesiastical imposition altogether is at present one of the liveliest topics under discussion in the British press. Incidental to that discussion comes out the fact that while, out of 870,401 children in attendance at the national schools, 710,270 are children of Roman Catholics, and 97,053 are children of Presbyterians, the children of persons nominally belonging to the Established Church number but 56,961. These figures need no comment.

abstract: Recriminations North and South to be Avoided
snippet: Recriminations North and South to be Avoided
lead_paragraph: We are sorry to see that there are still newspapers and people in the North which think proper to try and stir up ill-feeling against the people of the South. They still talk with a lofty contempt of its "chivalry," as if that poor, pitiful order of mortals were not now nearly all reduced to beggary. They talk of its "domineering insolence" and its "bullying," as if all that were not completely squelched by the terrible experiences of the war. They accuse it in the present of crimes which are of the past; assail it for feelings which must perish with the institutions which gave them birth; and hold it responsible for things over which it has no control.

abstract: Hoboken Club Regatta
snippet: Hoboken Club Regatta
lead_paragraph: Yesterday the eighth annual regatta of the Hoboken Yatch Club came off under auspicious circumstances. The weather was fine, but the wind was rather too light to show the dashing sailing quailities of the respective boats, entered for the contest, to advantage; nevertheless, there was no favor to either in this respect. The Hoboken Yacht Club is composed of gentlemanly amateur watermen, their laws prohibiting any bona fide members to man a boat or handle a tiller in a regatta. No "professionals" are admitted to membership. In consequence of a majority of their members having joined the navy and army during the past three years, their numbers have become somewhat disseminated. They now, however, are recruiting their strength, and the presumption is that before the close of the season they will be more prosperous in numbers and strength than heretofore. Yesterday's race was conceded by all to have been a glorious success. At 11:15 A.M. eight boats made their appearance at the starting-point. They went off in gallant style and returned in the order enumerated below:

abstract: And the Unspeakable Word--Repudiation
snippet: And the Unspeakable Word--Repudiation
lead_paragraph: -- It is evident that there is one word which henceforth no public man will dare to pronounce in America, unless he does so for the purpose of execrating that which it characterizes -- we refer to the word repudiation. Mr. WENDELL PHILLIPS was thoughtless enough to speak the word lately, and the storm of execration was at once so tremendous and universal, that even he was compelled to wriggle himself outside of what he had said.

abstract: The Coming Celebration of
snippet: The Coming Celebration of
lead_paragraph: -- The near recuring National Anniversary will be invested with vastly more than ordinary interest. The reasons for this are obvious. We have not alone to commemorate the wisdom, valor and suffering of our sires displayed in the remote past, but we are to celebrate the glories of the living present -- the stern courage, the martyr endurance, and the crowning victories of those by whose patriotism the nation has been saved. For these double blessings the public heart, with a spontaneous impulse, overflows with gratitude, and craves the opportunity to give it fitting expression.

abstract: -- On Wednesday, June 21, there are to be sold, at auction, one hundred and thirteen lots of ground in the village of Passaic, N.J. The property is pleasantly situated on the Passaic River, on the line of the New-York and Erie Railway, about eleven miles from the city, and four and a half this side of Paterson -- not more than one hour's distance from the City Hall. The lots are about one minute's walk from the Passaic Depot and in close proximity to a flourishing village, in which there are already erected churches of five different denominations, also a young ladies' seminary, and other good schools. The Passaic River flows through the rear of the property, and here there have already been built three manufactories, and nine additional ones are contemplated, four of them already in process of erection. The water power in the immediate vicinity, on the Passaic, is thought to be equal to that at Paterson. The sale will take place on the premises, at 3 o'clock on Wednesday, (to-morrow.) Trains leave at 2 o'clock from the foot of Chambers-street.

abstract: The remains of thousands of our brave soldiers lie scatterred in a wide semi-circle around Petersburgh, and mark the fields of the various operations against Richmond, from City Point, westward and northward for many miles. A great number, how many we have never yet heard, fell in the last fierce onset which burst through the enemy's lines and gave us Richmond. Their comrades entered the Capital of the Rebellion in triumph, and are even now as I write, marching through the streets of Washington -- the Capital once more of the whole nation -- but they, by whose lives the victory has been gained, were not permitted to enter Richmond, nor are they with their bothers-in-arms to receive the plandits of a grateful people. They lie sleeping where they had so long toiled and watched and fought. The number of soldiers buried around and near Petersburgh since active operations began there a year ago, must be very great. Shall these graves be given over to the plow and the wagon wheel, the trampling of animals and the feet of the passer-by? What shall be done must be done quickly. Ought there not to be a National Cemetery at Petersburgh? If the authorities or influential individuals will move in this thing, they will receive the earnest gratitude of tens of thousands whose dear ones lie buried in that region. What better name could such grounds receive than "Lincoln National Cemetery?" E.

abstract: We have noticed with much satisfaction the determination of Superintendent KENNEDY to abate some of the more glaring nuisances that abound in our city. But a short time since those dens of iniquity, the concert saloons, to Broadway, between Houston and Bleecker streets, were visited by the police, and men and women in large numbers were arrested while engaged in their immoral practices. Fast driving on the Fifth-avenue on Sunday afternoon was becoming so common and during as to defy the ordinary police force; but a squad of mounted police were directed to patrol the avenue on Sunday afternoon, and we see no more racing there. And we now see that orders have been issued to close the Sunday concert saloons and been gardens. Let the commissioners and the Superintendent execute the laws that protect, our Sundays from noisy and immoral practices, and break up the places where our young men and women are entire into licentiousness, and they will deserve the thanks of the community.

abstract: Western Emigration Scheme
snippet: Western Emigration Scheme
lead_paragraph: Thousands of the soldiers who are now returning to their homes, will find themselves without occupation, and will gladly embrace any opportunity that may offer for employment, especially if accompanied by the promise of adventure. Various projects for emigration invite the attention of all such -- some directed Westward and others to the Southern States. Capt. JAMES L. FISK, of this city, who is already familiar with the West, has issued a prospectus for a company to send an expedition to the Yellowstone country, on the eastern slope of the Rocky Mountains. The climate, soil, and agricultural and mining facilities of the country are represented as being very great. Soldiers and others wishing to join this expedition can learn all the particulars concerning it by applying to Capt. FISK, at the Astor House. It is understood that Gen. THOMAS FRANCIS MEAGHER accompanies this expedition, and that he has taken a personal interest in its organization.

abstract: The offices occupied by the City Inspector having been re-leased by the city for a term of ten years, are now undergoing a thorough cleansing and renovation, which they evidently much needed. The street-cleaning contract being about to go into operation, the City Inspector has had notices made out dismissing such of the employes of the department as formerly had charge of this matter. The notices merely state that their services will not be required after the 30th inst. The Street Inspectors will probably be retained, to see that the contractors perform their work properly. The Comptroller, it is supposed, will be prepared to discharge all indebtedness for the work of street-cleaning at the end of the month.

abstract: the Price of and City Gas Company
snippet: the Price of and City Gas Company
lead_paragraph: It seems to be a matter of utter inconsequence to the gas monopolies that the price of coal is now less than two-thirds of what it was a few weeks since. The same extortionate rates are demanded now that were fixed before the fall in the cost of the raw material. Neither has there been the slightest improvement in the quality. The gas furnished is just as execrable as it has been for a a year or two, and, if anything, grows worse. It makes darkness visible, and that is all. We catch, however, from the distance a faint glimmerof relief. A new company has been formed, entitled the City Gas Company, and the Common Council have authorized the corporators to lay their mains and pipes. Herein lies our main hope for future light, if this pipe-laying is not meant in the Pickwickian sense. But we must not be over-sanguine, either. Other now companies in other years have been authorized upon the strength of rainbow-hued promises. But their proposed healthy competition with the preexistent monopolies did little good. They soon went hand-in-glove with the monopolies in their heartless dealings with unprotected consumers.Will the City Gas Company incontinently follow their lead, or become a public benefaction?

abstract: Anniversary
snippet: Anniversary
lead_paragraph: The fifteenth anniversary of this association was celebrated yesterday at the Baptist Church, Twenty-fifth-street, near Eighth-avenue. The attendance was very large, full lay and clerical delegations from the various churches being present. Among the audience were many ladies. The object of this convention is to consult together as to the best interests of the churches in this city and in Brooklyn, and to show their respective conditions. Rev. A.H. BURLINGHAM, Moderator of last season, called the meeting to order. Various religious ceremonies were then entered into. The introductory sermon was preached by Rev. J.C.C. CLARK, from Rev. 19th Chap., and part of 10th verse. "The testimony of Jesus is the spirit of prophecy." A collection was then taken up for the Ministers' Widows' Fund.

abstract: Farewell Dinner to New-York
snippet: Farewell Dinner to New-York
lead_paragraph: FAREWELL DINNER TO SENATOR NYE. -- A very pleasant farewell dinner was given last evening, at the Astor House, to Senator NYE, previous to his departure for Nevada. Judge PIERPONT presided at the table, and, in a speech of much humor and graceful pleasantry, introduced the Senator to the assembled guests. Mr. NYE responded in his usual happy manner, the chief subject of his remarks being the new and rapidly developing State which he repeesents in Congress. He was followed by Senator MORGAN, of this State; Judge OLIN, of Washington; Mr. NICOLAY, late Private Secretary to President LINCOLN; Gen. ROSECRANS, Jude DALY and others. Secretary STANTON was expected to be present, but he was prevented by public business from leaving Washington. Senator NYE carries with him to his far Western home the best wishes of his many friends in this city.

abstract: Valley City, S. S., Officers of
snippet: Valley City, S. S., Officers of
lead_paragraph: The United States steamer Valley City, 8 guns, Acting Master Commanding JNO. A.J. BROOKS, arrived yesterday from Hatteras Inlet, She has been in the Sounds of North Carolina for the past three years. She went into commission in September, 1861, and was stationed in the Potomac until the fitting out of the Burnside expedition, which she joined and participated in the numerous actions in those waters. Her officers are: Acting Master Commanding, JNO. A.J. BROOKS; Acting Ensign and Executive Officer, W.W. Weld; Acting Ensign and Sailing Master, Leonard Denton; Acting Paymaster, J. Woodville Sands; Acting Assistant Surgeon, L.W. Loring; Acting Second Assistant Engineer, in charge, J.M. Baltin; Acting Third Assistant Engineer, John Minton; Acting Pilot, J.A. Wilson; Mates, C.F. O'Neill and W.H. Bolton.

abstract: This distinguished cavalry officer arrived here on Monday evening from North Carolina, and took rooms at the Metropolitan Hotel, where he was cordially welcomed by a host of admiring friends. Yesterday he visited New-Jersey -- his boyhood home -- and to-day he will go to West Point, there to spend a brief leave of absence. Just before leaving North Carolina, the officers of KILPATRICK's command presented him with a valuable sword as a token of their respect and esteem. It was manufactured by SCHUYLER, HARTLEY, GRAHAM & CO., New-York, at a cost, including belt and all, of about $6,000. The scabbard is made of "solid sterling silver," richly gilt. The chain on the guard is made of eighteen karat gold. On the upper band of the scabbard is the initial letter "K." in diamonds, on a scroll supported by recording angels in full relief. The lower band is richly embossed with representation of American shield -- the stars of which are made of diamonds. The blade is of the finest American steel, inlaid with gilt, and on it are engraved some of the principal battles in which the General has taken an active part. The guard is embellished with figure of a horse at full speed, and that portion protecting the wrist represents the head of a horse. On the hilt is a spread eagle poised on a globe.

abstract: While it may be possible to sympathize with the well-to-do business citizens who, this year, desire to make a double holiday, in celebration of the national anniversary, it is well not to forget that it involves a tax of a very serious kind upon that vast population whose earnings are reckoned by the day. The mechanic or laborer who earns $2 for ten hours' work finds that in giving up two consecutive clays to holiday-making, ho draws at the week's end but $8 instead of $12 from his employer. At the present enormous cost of living, is it entirely just to lay this amount of tax upon an industrious family in a single week? If the exuberant patriotism of this community fails to get all the expression it seeks in one day's celebration, let a second holiday be designated, at a reasonable interval. Three continuous days' abstinence from labor -- for it comes to that, if we begin the celebration on Monday, the 3d -- is not healthy, socially, morally or otherwise, in a community like this.

abstract: Robinson, Rev. S., Manifesto Suppressed Testimony
snippet: Robinson, Rev. S., Manifesto Suppressed Testimony
lead_paragraph: "Rev." STUART ROBINSON has issued a long manifesto, reviewing and contradicting the testimony of the witnesses who gave the testimony which was so long suppressed. The document is addressed to United States District Attorney EMMONS, of Detroit, and the only novel statement it contains is the following: "Why, what will you think Mr. EMMONS, when I tell you that I saw, myself, in intimate association here, with Messrs. THOMPSON and CLEARY, and elsewhere with Messrs. CLAY and the others, a distinguished jurist whom I understood to have come directly from Secretary STANTON himself, to consult, during the alarm about the prospective break down of the republican party in August last, and his reported fears of personal violence to the cabinet from the excited populace of the North?"

abstract: Excitement in France
snippet: Excitement in France
lead_paragraph: The news from Europe to-day shows a continuance of the excitement in the political circles of Paris, caused by M. ELOIN's report of the backward condition of Imperialism in Mexico. That gentleman, by all accounts, has had an exceedingly discouraging story to tell. It may be well, at the same time, to receive with allowance the statements of the London Times in regard to the attitude assumed by France on Mexican affairs, toward the United States. Until our government shall have departed, by some overt act, from its policy of neutrality, warnings, or quasi threats from France or any other Power would resolve themselves into something more than mere impertinence calling for rebuke. We are not accustomed to be threatened under any circumstances. It is not likely that we shall be threatened, while we are content to look on and see this experiment of Caesarism in Mexico explode, as we shall see it anon. The London Times, meanwhile, is engaged in congenial work, when it sets itself to stir up feelings of ill-will between France and the United States.

abstract: Simkins vs. Low, Salt of Bonds Agency
snippet: Simkins vs. Low, Salt of Bonds Agency
lead_paragraph: Simkins vs. Low. -- The plaintiff employed the defendant to purchase for him forty bonds, with coupons attached, of the San Francisco Water Company. The bends were for $500 each. The purchase was made in March, 1864, and the principal and last interest coupon matured in April, 1864. At par, the bonds and coupons amounted to $21,000. The defendant purchased them for $23,000, and claimed to hold them for himself. The plaintiff sued the defendant for a conversion of the bonds and for a breach of his duty as agent and claimed to recover about $40,000 as the difference between the price paid for the bonds in currency, and the value of the gold in which it was claimed the company had paid the bonds when gold was at 245 to 250. The principal question in the case, was whether the defendant was chargeable with the value of the bonds in gold or only their legal value in currency. The court instructed the jury that they must estimate the value of the bonds; that is, what they were worth on their face in currency, and not in gold in which they were said to have been paid; and on that basis they must find a verdict for only nominal damages. The jury, under this charge, rendered a verdict of six cents.

abstract: Surrender and London Tory Press
snippet: Surrender and London Tory Press
lead_paragraph: Gen. KIRBY SMITH, as appears by the European telegram this morning, has grievously disappointed the London Tory journals. By one American steamer they received the inspiriting news that this redoubtable chieftain, at the head of 85,000 veteran troops, of whom nearly one-half were cavalry, was not only prepared to bid defiance for years to any force that SHERIDAN could bring against him, but even to carry the war into the Eastern States. The next steamer brought them the unwelcome news of his quiet surrender. But, though intensely disgusted, these journals were not without comfort. We are reminded that by this surrender our troops are "brought face to face with the French outposts on the Rio Grande." This is doubtless a very dreadful circumstance, though we fail to appreciate it. And, besides, they had not then heard of the surrender of STERLING PRICE, who, according to the London Times, was likely to prove more formidable as a general and a statesman than KIRBY SMITH himself. Secessionism dies very hard in England.

abstract: Firemen's Fight at Flushing, L. I.
snippet: Firemen's Fight at Flushing, L. I.
lead_paragraph: Yesterday was set apart by the firemen of Astoria, Jamaica, Flushing and College Point, for a trial of fire aparatus at Flushing. Extensive preparations were made for a grand display, and Engine Companies Nos. 1 and 7, of the Eastern District, No. 3 of the Western District, Brooklyn, and No. 14 of New-York, were invited to be present. Consequently, early in the day, an immense number of firemen and their friends assembled in the town. In consequence of some delay, the trial did not take place until about 2 P.M., and scarcely had the machines been put in working order, when a tumult arose in Main-street, near Woolley's Hotel, which became so formidable in its proportions that all idea of a further trial was abandoned. It appears that an engineer from the Eastern District offered a bet of $40 to a member of the Astoria Company, each having been discussing the merits of the Smith and Jeffer's engine, when they quarreled over the terms of the bet -- the Astoria man first striking the Eastern District man. Their partisans then took up the quarrel, and in a few minutes the fight became general between the Jeffers men and the Smith men. As soon as the report of fire-arms was heard, the business men of the town closed up their stores, and in a few minutes afterward the wildest disorder prevailed. The reports of pistols, the clashings of bowie knives, the screams and curses of the combatants, the terrified shrieking of women and children, among whom fell showers of stones, rendered the scene one of intense horror. The house-tops were crowded with men, while the women and children sought refuge in cellars. This state of things lasted for about two hours, when the rain commenced to fall in torrents and seemed to cool the passions of the infuriated rioters, and they gradually quieted down, and collected their wounded and disabled friends. It is impossible to state the number of those injured, but it is estimated at fifty or sixty. A lady, whose name was not ascertained, received a bullet wound in the breast. Several citizens and children were wounded by stray shots, but the fighters themselves suffered the most severe injuries. The wounded brought to Williamsburgh include, PAT. MCGINNIS, _____ MCCARTHY, knife wound in neck; ED. MCHUGH, badly injured about the head; CHARLES VAN DYKE, visitor, badly; F. KELLY, head bruised. The scene of the fight presented evidences of a terrific conflict -- bricks and stones, knives and broken pistols lying about on all sides.

abstract: Jersey City Club Regatta
snippet: Jersey City Club Regatta
lead_paragraph: THE DEAD LOCK IN THE JERSEY CITY COMMON COUNCIL. -- The members of the board of Aldermen of Jersey City have been endeavoring to effect an organization for the past ten weeks, and during that time have held some twenty meetings, but so far have not been able to elect a President -- the members being divided nine and nine, while ten votes are necessary for a choice. A meeting was held last evening, when Alderman PANGBORN was elected Chairman pro tem., and JOHN E. SCOTT acted as Secretary. The minutes of the previous meeting were read, and a motion was made to approve them, to which Alderman GAFNEY raised an objection, on the ground that the proceeding would be illegal. The motion to approve was lost by a tie vote. A communication was received from Minot Engine Company No. 7, inviting the members of the board to be present on the occasion of the reception of their new engine, to-day, (Wednesday.) The bonds of the Corporation Attorney, R.C. MCCLELLAND, were presented, and a motion to lay them on the table was lost by a vote of 9 to 9. A motion to refer the bonds to a committee was also lost by a tie vote. Two veto messages were presented from His Honor Mayor CLEVELAND -- one disproving the resolution reinstating to duty Policeman SIMMONS and Chanceman DOLAN, and the other against the ordinance granting permission to the New-York and Fort Lee Railroad Company to lay down rails in certain streets in Jersey City. A motion to pass the resolution and ordinance, notwithstanding the objection of the Mayor, was lost, 9 ayes, 9 nays. A motion to go into an election for a city weigher and measurer was lost by the usual 9 vote, and the board adjourned. After the adjournment some of the members became engaged in an excited discussion, during which such choice epithets as "liar," "sucker," "two-forty nag," "a good wind would blow you on either side," &c., were freely used.

abstract: Cobden, Mrs.; Offer of Government Pension Declined
snippet: Cobden, Mrs.; Offer of Government Pension Declined
lead_paragraph: Mr. COBDEN. -- Lord PALMERSTON's offer of a government pension of fifteen hundred pounds to the widow of the late RICHARD COBDEN, was an honorable tribute to the worth and public services of one of England's greatest statesmen; but it occasions no surprise that the offer has been gracefully declined, in accordance with Mr. COBDEN's well-known opposition to the acceptance of any official emoluments. Our readers will remember that Mr. COBDEN repeatedly declined title, honors and office from his government They will also recall the circumstance that when it was proposed, some years ago, to make up Mr. COBDEN's pecuniary losses by subscription, the London Times and other Tory journals bitterly ridiculed the project, and dragged that gentleman's private affairs before the public in the most shameful and outrageous manner. Through his whole career, Mr. COBDEN never received a penny from the government treasury; and, in declining the offered pension, his widow has doubtless acted as he would have wished. It is pleasant to know that the widow and children of the deceased statesman are abundantly provided for from his private resources.

BURT, the Assistant Inspector-General, who is temporarily absent from the city.
