abstract: The engine companies of Astoria, Jamaica, College Point and Flushing met at Flushing yesterday, for the purpose of testing the power of their engines and to contend for prizes, consisting of three elaborately finished silver trumpets, manufactured expressly for the occasion. This meeting has been looked forward to with great expectancy by the firemen of Queens County, and has...
lead_paragraph: The engine companies of Astoria, Jamaica, College Point and Flushing met at Flushing yesterday, for the purpose of testing the power of their engines and to contend for prizes, consisting of three elaborately finished silver trumpets, manufactured expressly for the occasion. This meeting has been looked forward to with great expectancy by the firemen of Queens County, and has created much interest and excitement among the friends of the respective organizations in this city and Brooklyn; so much so, that delegations from the following companies of this city proceeded to the village of Flushing, to witness the contest: Engine No. 44, Peterson, No. 31; North River, No. 30; also, Franklin, No, 3; Washington, No. 1; Union, No. 5; Neptune, No. 7; Continental, No. 9; Hose No. 8, and Engine Company No. 1, of Brooklyn.

abstract: Policemen GLYNN and CROWN, of the Eighth Ward, appeared in court with ISAAC KAHN and the inmates of his house, namely: Fannie Brown, Elizabeth Matthews, Caroline Kahn, Edward E. lead_paragraph: Policemen GLYNN and CROWN, of the Eighth Ward, appeared in court with ISAAC KAHN and the inmates of his house, namely: Fannie Brown, Elizabeth Matthews, Caroline Kahn, Edward E. Tooker, Josephine West, Minnie Clark, Minnie Wilton, Jeannette Rose and Charles White, the prisoners having been arrested on a charge of grand larceny. All, however, but FANNIE BROWN and ISAAC KAHN were dismissed, and against these two M. WILLIAM CLARK, of South Amboy, made affidavit, alleging that while he was in KAHN's house one or both of them stole his gold watch and chain, valued at $350, and his wallet, containing $208 in bank and Treasury notes, and a promissory note for $600. The prisoners were committed without bail.

abstract: Proclamation on Assuming Office

lead_paragraph: Whereas, By the proclamation of ANDREW JOHNSON, President of the United States of America, dated May 29, 1865, I have been appointed Provisional Governor of the State of North Carolina, with instructions to "prescribe, at the earliest practicable period, such rules and regulations as may be necessary and proper for convening a convention, composed of delegates to and chosen by that portion of the people of said State who are loyal to the United States, and no others, for the purpose of altering or amending the constitution thereof; and with authority to exercise within the limits of said State all the power necessary land proper to enable such loyal people of the State of North Carolina to restore said State to its constitutional relations to the Federal Government, and to present such a republican form of State Government as will entitle the State to the guarantee of the United States therefor, and its people to protection by the United States against invasion, insurrection and domestic violence;" and

abstract: Retrenchment and Public Debt
snippet: Retrenchment and Public Debt
lead_paragraph: Every day now sees the expenditures of the government vastly reduced. With all possible rapidity the soldiers are being mustered out of the service and sent home. Supernumerary Generals as well as officers of other grades are being returned to civil life. Thousands of horses are being relieved from further military duty and sold. Great numbers of wagons, and most of the other paraphernalia of war, are being disposed of. Our naval force has been greatly reduced, and many of the transports and converted gunboats sold. The reduction applies to every department, and the retrenchment in expenditure is enormous.

abstract: Census, Plan of, >amp;c.
snippet: Census, Plan of, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: The taking of the State Census, which commenced on the first of June, is preceding slowly but surely. Mr. FRANKLIN B. HOUGH, who has charge of the work in this city and Brooklyn, arrived here Monday evening, and will make his headquarters at the rooms of the Geographical Society in Clinton Hall. Last evening, the enumerators of the first eight Assembly Districts met Mr. HOUGH at Clinton Hall, to receive detailed instructions in regard to their duties, and were also supplied with the necessary blanks. On Friday, the enumerators of the remaining districts will be instructed in their duties; and on Thursday, the Brooklyn canvassers will meet Mr. HOUGH in Brooklyn.

abstract: Why he Surrendered
snippet: Why he Surrendered
lead_paragraph: The farewell address of Gen. KIRBY SMITH to his soldiers, which we print this morning, shows why that redoubtable chieftain so cruelly disappointed the hopes of his Tory friends in England, and brought discredit upon the intelligence of the New-York correspondent of the London Times. It seems he was not to blame, poor follow! He was willing to sacrifice every man in his army on the altar of his country; but the perverse follows preferred not to be sacrificed. On reaching Houston, where he expected to find a Spartan band, ready to do or die, SMITH found "the T[???] troops disbanded, and hastening to their homes. They had forsaken their colors and their commanders; had abandoned the cause for which we were struggling, and appropriated the public property to their personal use."

abstract: Seward, Mrs. W. H., Wife Secretary of State
snippet: Seward, Mrs. W. H., Wife Secretary of State
lead_paragraph: The public mind was in a measure, and the family of Mr. SEWARD fully prepared, for the bereavement it becomes a painful duty to announce. Mrs. SEWARD had been sinking from the moment that her intense anxiety for the safety of her husband and son was relieved. Up to the time that hope, in both cases, came, she was wonderfully subtained. It seemed that, infirm and feeble as she had been for years, while those she loved so devotingly were in danger, disease had no power over the wife and mother. But when the strain was off, her over-taxed powers, mental and physical, gave way.

abstract: Provision Merchant, New-York, Disappeared
snippet: Provision Merchant, New-York, Disappeared
lead_paragraph: Considerable excitement was created in commercial circles yesterday morning by the announcement that the senior partner of one of the leading provision houses had been missing for some days past, and later in the day it was rumored that he had left for Europe, and was a defaulter to a very large amount. The gentleman who has been the cause of this excitement is Mr. SMITH J. EASTMAN, of the firm of EASTMAN & CO., provision dealers, Broad-street. It is stated that Mr. EASTMAN has lately been operating largely in pork, selling short, and has lost heavily. He has also been operating in stocks, but his financial difficulties are not supposed to have arisen from the latter cause, as all the losses on stock operations paid by him during the past year do not exceed $25,000. His broker, however, will be a heavy loser, as he holds Mr. EASTMAN's notes not yet matured to a large amount. A warehouse man with whom EASTMAN had extensive dealings, is also said to be missing. It is alleged that this man gave EASTMAN receipts for lard in store, knowing that many of the barrels were empty. These receipts were hypothecated to capitalists, who, of course, will be heavy losers. For some of this lard, duplicate receipts are believed to have been issued, on which money has been raised. Investigation having been made yesterday of a cellar in which some of this lard was stored, it was found that the front part of the storehouse was filled with full barrels, while the back part contained nothing but empty packages. It is supposed that EASTMAN has raised on these warehouse receipts something like $350,000, In addition to this, he is said to have drawn from the bank, the day before he left, the balance of the firm, amounting to over $100,000.

abstract: -- New that the South and its condition are opened up to our knowledge, we have learned by what a fearful system of falsehood, concerning every conceivable subject, the rebellion was maintained. The rebel leaders and the rebel press literally lied before the world about everything. They lied about the North to their own people, and lied to us about the feelings and opinions of the Southern people. They indulged in falsehoods about their armies, about their resources, about their finances, about their prospects, about their slaves, their, railroads, their cotton-burnings, their crops, etc.; and every event in current history they falsified. It is only now that their whole system of falsehood has tumbled to pieces, that we are enabled to see how baseless it was.

abstract: Ruffin, Edmund, Suicide of
snippet: Ruffin, Edmund, Suicide of
lead_paragraph: On Saturday last, Mr. EDMUND RUFFIN, who achieved and unenviable notoriety by firing the first gun at Fort Sumter, committed suicide at his residence, near Mattoax depot on the Richmond and Danville Railroad. He retired to his chamber at an early hour in the morning, and taking a seat in a chair, took a gun, loaded with shot and slugs, and placing the muzzle to his mouth, discharged the piece by pushing the trigger with a stick. The upper portion of his head was entirely blown off. In a diary of his was found a memorandum stating that he could never live under the United States Government, and took death in preference. In the same memorandum he said he would have committed the deed on the 9th of April (the day Gen. LEE surrendered) but was prevented by the presence of visitors in his house.

abstract: The person (named EDMUND RUFFIN) who happened to fire the first shot at Fort Sumter, took a shot at himself on Saturday last, near Richmond, and is dead. He seems not to have got sufficient notoriety in the Sumter business, and, by taking to suicide, he probably expected to revive his name, if only for a few days. The first strike of this man for immortality he found costly, but unavailing. The second cost but little -- only his worthless life. The result is a few days of posthumous notoriety.

abstract: Fashion Course, Commodore Vanderbilt and Black Diamond
snippet: Fashion Course, Commodore Vanderbilt and Black Diamond
lead_paragraph: Two of the most important matches of the season were down for decision at the Fashion Course yesterday -- the first of which was one of $2,000, three-mile heats, in harness, between Ella Sherwood and Toronto Chief, which, unfortunately, did not come off, Toronto Chief paying and Ella Sherwood receiving forfeit. The second match of $2,000, mile heats, between Commodore Vanderbilt, to wagon, and Black Diamond, in harness, which, as will be seen, resulted in a highly interesting race. Commodore Vanderbilt's antecedents are patent to the trotting public; not so those of Black Diamond, who has been recently brought from Canada by Mr. BECKWITH, of Hartford, who, on the faith of some fast time the block one had made on the ice, was induced to believe that he possessed a horse capable of doing great things on the Long Island Trotting Course -- with what reason the result of the race shows. The attendance, though not as large as on those great, eventful days, when miscellaneous crowds are attracted, comprised the elite of the trotting turf. The day turned out beautifully fine, after a lowering morning, and was warm enough for all trotting purposes.

abstract: Alfred Renshaw vs. Benjamin W. Freligh. The plaintiff now claims this sum. On his own evidence it appeared that eleven of the thirty-eight were drafted, for...
lead_paragraph: Alfred Renshaw vs. Benjamin W. Freligh. -- The defendant received from various persons (thirtyeight in number,) $6,000 in the aggregate, to be paid to the plaintiff when he should have furnished substitutes for each and every one of the persons so insuring themselves who should by drafted. The plaintiff now claims this sum. On his own evidence it appeared that eleven of the thirty-eight were drafted, for nine of whom he had either furnished a substitute or paid a premium so as to obtain possession of their policies of insurance, but for the two others he had not succeeded. At the close of his testimony the defendant moved for a non-suit on the ground that the contract was against the public policy and that the purpose of the arrangement had never been fulfilled. The Court gave the following decision:

abstract: As a rebel Organ; Patronage by City Authorities; Rebellion how Sustained by
snippet: As a rebel Organ; Patronage by City Authorities; Rebellion how Sustained by
lead_paragraph: JACOB THOMPSON, rebel agent, paid the Daily News of this city twenty-five thousand dollars for rebel service, if the draft drawn by him in favor of its editor is to be taken as conclusive evidence. Our municipal government at the same time illegally paid to the same print more than that sum for city advertising. The paper was, in fact, sustained -- so far as yet appears -- by joint subsidies of the rebel authorities in Richmond and the "Democratic" officials in this city. It was their joint agent. It did their joint business. They were its joint principals, and they should be held, before the moral judgment of the country, jointly responsible as partners.

abstract: Southern States, Important Order on Collection in; Important Order; Physical Training of the War
snippet: Southern States, Important Order on Collection in; Important Order; Physical Training of the War
lead_paragraph: No one who has taken the trouble to observe closely the regiments returning to our city disbandment. will deny that the men come back to civil life in fine physical condition. They look very strong, hardy, hearty and vigorous; their muscles are more tense, their vitality more energetic, and their whole organism more solid and compact. The severe duties of a soldier's life have called out what physiologists term the reserve qualities of nature -- those powers and qualities of body and soul which usually lie dormant in ordinary life, but which play so important and decisive a part in life's emergencies.

abstract: Riot of Citizens and Soldiers, 4 shot
snippet: Riot of Citizens and Soldiers, 4 shot
lead_paragraph: During the reception of the Richmond County Volunteers, of the Second Metropolitan (133d N.Y.) Regiment, at Nautilus Hall, Tompkinsville, S.I., yesterday, at about 5 P.M., two soldiers belonging to the Sixty-sixth New-York Volunteers, guarding the government cotton inside the Quarantine inclosure, came upon the green in front of the hotel, and, being intoxicated, engaged in a fight with one of the citizens but finding themselves getting worsted, they immediately retreated inside the gates of the Quarantine grounds, where, procuring muskets, they approached the green again with fixed bayonets, when a general rush was made for them, their muskets were taken from them, and in attempting to escape, they were very badly beaten. Finally, they were taken inside, when a platoon of the same regiment came up to the gates and indiscriminately fired upon the crowd, who were attempting to force the gates, and throwing missiles of all kinds at the soldiers. A number of persons were more or less injured by stones and some shot. Among the latter was Lieut. NELSON, of Company I, Sixty-sixth Regiment, shot in the breast, wound supposed mortal. Lieut. NELSON was on his way to the city, and being told of the riot at the Quarantine landing, immediately went to quell it; but on approaching the gate was shot by one of his own party. The others shot so far as known are a Mr. CAIN, (citizen,) in the left knee; will loose the leg. MORTIMER DENYSE, of the One Hundred and Thirty-third New-York, and belonging to Staten Island, shot in the left arm above the wrist. He will probably loose the arm. GEO. W. DALY, also a resident of the Island, wounded in the leg.

abstract: THE DEATH OF THE LATE GEORGE C. MANN. -- The coroner's jury in the case of Mr. GEORGE C. MANN, whose body was found in the water near Fulton ferry on Sunday morning last, (18th inst.) and who it was supposed bad committed suicide, rendered a verdict to the effect that deceased was found drowned, and added that "we," the jury "feel constrained to call the attention of the city authorities to the exposed condition of the bulkhead where the casualty is supposed to have occurred, and the absence of any proper security against similar accident. Witnesses here testified to several cases of rescue and prevention of injury, and notwithstanding other previous presentments the evil still exists; and the jury consider the bulkhead in its present condition, a mantrap and a public nuisance."

abstract: One of the chief reasons of the high price of rents and the crowded condition of the city, lies in the fact that though our population has been greatly increased during the war, there has been no corresponding increase of housebuilding.
lead_paragraph: One of the chief reasons of the high price of rents and the crowded condition of the city, lies in the fact that though our population has been greatly increased during the war, there has been no corresponding increase of housebuilding. New-York has not only grown by the natural growth of the population -- and it must be remembered that when the population of a city approaches a million, the annual natural increase is very great -- but it has grown by foreign immigration, by a large immigration from the Border States and other States of the South, and by the many thousands of people who have come from the surrounding country during the war, for purposes of business or speculation. We believe that the population of the city has increased by two hundred and fifty thousand since 1861, while we do not believe there have been houses built since then capable of accommodating twenty thousand.

abstract: An important meeting of the Board of Education was held last evening. The report of the committee recommending that the male department of Grammrr School No. 30 be discontinued, was adopted. The trustees of primary schools are authorized to close them at 2 P.M., throughout the month of July. An increase of 25 per cent. was made to the salaries of certain officers of the Free Academy.
lead_paragraph: An important meeting of the Board of Education was held last evening. The report of the committee recommending that the male department of Grammrr School No. 30 be discontinued, was adopted. The trustees of primary schools are authorized to close them at 2 P.M., throughout the month of July. An increase of 25 per cent. was made to the salaries of certain officers of the Free Academy. A majority report was adopted, in favor of appropriating $76,385 for the rebuilding of the Greenwich-avenue Schoolhouse. A minority report, in favor of delaying the making of the appropriation, was lost. The sum of $44,613 was appropriated for the erection of the new Grammer School in the Fifth Ward. An investigation was ordered to be made into certain charges against the School Trustees of the First Ward, for retaining a teacher who was unfit for his position. The Committee on By-laws reported an amendment relative to the holidays to be hereafter allowed in the public schools which was adopted, and the board adjourned.

abstract: Clara Lewis was tried, yesterday, upon an indictment charging her with grand larceny. Mr. John Perkins appeared as complainant, and related a tale of verdant simplicity and trustfulness. He first met the prisoner in Greene-street, and at her solicitation accompanied her to a room in a neighboring house.
lead_paragraph: Clara Lewis was tried, yesterday, upon an indictment charging her with grand larceny. Mr. John Perkins appeared as complainant, and related a tale of verdant simplicity and trustfulness. He first met the prisoner in Greene-street, and at her solicitation accompanied her to a room in a neighboring house. Mr. Perkins being a stranger in the city, recently from the interior of Maine, and having something over three hundred dollars in greenbacks with him, which he was afraid he might lose in his perambulations about the city, he concluded to give it to Miss Clara for safe-keeping. He accordingly deposited with her three one hundred dollar greenbacks, and went on his way rejoicing that his money was secure from thieves and sharpers. But unhappily for Perkins, his frail friend showed an exceeding unwillingness to return the money when demanded, and astonished her confiding depositor by asserting that he never gave her any money to keep. This being the whole case for the people His Honor instructed the jury that there was no larceny proven, it being simply a case of breach of trust. They acquited the prisoner without leaving their seats. Recorder HOFFMAN gave Perkins a little good advice in regard to keeping his money himself in future, and District-Attorney Hatchings also kindly suggested to him that he had better return to Maine, as he was too much of a "Daisy" to get along in New-York.

abstract: Between 8 and 9 o'clock last evening, Mrs. JOSEPHINE COHEN, having been thrust from the threshold of the Hotel Swiss, at No. 19 Jay-street, fell, head foremost, on the door-steps leading to the hotel and was instantly killed. There are, of course, two statements already abroad in the Fith Ward. That of SIMON COHEN, husband of the deceased, is that himself and wife arrived in port, yesterday, on the National Steamship Company's steamer Arion, and on leaving that vessel went directly to the Hotel Swiss and engaged board at the customary tariff of the house, $1 50 a day each. Their luggage have come up from the steamship last evening, they had ordered a porter to take it to their room; but the landlord, WERNER WERNER, objected, saying that there was too much to be taken up stairs. COHEN insisted upon having his luggage in his own room, and WERNER WERNER insisting that it should not be taken up. COHEN went out and engaged board at the Wyoming Hotel. Returning and preparing to depart from the Hotel Swiss, he had words with WERNER, concerning his bill, the landlord having demanded $3, notwithstanding, according to COHEN's story, he had had nothing. Mrs. COHEN entered into the dispute with spirit, and, it is alleged, WERNER struck both herself and her husband, and when she was about going out of his doors, gave her a push or kick, throwing her over, head foremost, to the foot of the stone steps leading to the house. When taken up, Mrs. COHEN was a corpse. Policeman COLE, of the Fifth Ward, hearing the shout which the bystanders made for the police, hastened to the spot and took WERNER into custody, and turned him over to Capt. PETTY, at the police station, and the body was taken into the Fifth Ward Hotel, where it was viewed, last evening, by Police Surgeon KENNEDY. Subsequently Capt. PETTY sent a body of policemen to apprehend the inmates of the Swiss, and the following-named boarders were taken as witnesses, and held at the Fifth Ward Police Station last night: Moritz Glaser, John Bruppacher, H. Ryf, Nicholas Bauholser, Louis Gabbiell, Joseph Stach, Anton Low, Jacob Egger, Henry William Sieb, Florin Colin, (daughter of deceased,) and Agrada Shader, Mrs. COHN, who was 34 years of age, was a native of Brussels. An inquest is to be held to-day, by Coroner WILDEY.

abstract: the New Constitution of
snippet: the New Constitution of
lead_paragraph: There seems to be no reason to doubt the success of the new constitution of this State by a very handsome majority. The latest figuring at St. Louis shows that the home vote is about equally divided, with several counties that surely have voted yea yet to be recorded; the soldiers' vote is pretty nearly unanimous in the affirmative. So, there is a prospect that this unfortunate State, which has for font years been ravaged by the worst sort of guerrilla warfare, and which was for nearly two of these years the theatre of many of the most important movements in the main conflict, will soon begin a new career, starting from first principles and on an improved basis.

abstract: Fire Department Law; Validity Sustained
snippet: Fire Department Law; Validity Sustained
lead_paragraph: The opponents of reform in the City Fire Department have had all the opportunity they desired to test the validity of the new act. The decision rendered in their favor in the lower Court has been reversed by the Court of Appeals. The Metropolitan Fire Commission is pronounced a legally constituted body, and it assumes henceforth the organization and control of a Fire Police for the city.

abstract: The One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Regiment (Veterans) arrived in this city yesterday afternoon, from Richmond, on the steamer John Brooks. They landed at the foot of Bridge-street and marched to Joralemon-street, rear of the City Hall, where they were dismissed until 2 o'clock this afternoon, when they are to proceed to Hart's Island for the purpose of being paid off.
lead_paragraph: The One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Regiment (Veterans) arrived in this city yesterday afternoon, from Richmond, on the steamer John Brooks. They landed at the foot of Bridge-street and marched to Joralemon-street, rear of the City Hall, where they were dismissed until 2 o'clock this afternoon, when they are to proceed to Hart's Island for the purpose of being paid off. The regiment was organized in the Summer of 1862, and was designated as the Second Senatorial Regiment. The men were sworn in on the 9th of September of that year, and encamped in the City Park, near the Navy-yard, from which place they embarked for the war under command of Col. ANTHONY CONK. They numbered 1,100 men, and 150 recruits were added since. With desertions, casualties and sickness their numbers have been reduced to 340 men. These have returned, and present a first-rate physical appearance. The officers are as follows:

abstract: A trial of considerable interest was commenced, yesterday in the Supreme Court, before Justice CLERKE and a jury, in which the plaintiff, who is a widow, and sues as administratrix of a deceased husband, seeks to recover the sum of $5,000 by virtue of a recent statute of this State. The defendant was the owner of premises Nos. 103 and 105 Mercer-street, upon which he was erecting buildings, and for that purpose had...
lead_paragraph: A trial of considerable interest was commenced, yesterday in the Supreme Court, before Justice CLERKE and a jury, in which the plaintiff, who is a widow, and sues as administratrix of a deceased husband, seeks to recover the sum of $5,000 by virtue of a recent statute of this State. The defendant was the owner of premises Nos. 103 and 105 Mercer-street, upon which he was erecting buildings, and for that purpose had made excavations. On the night of the 13th of July last, Mr. AMOS M. BUTLER was found in one of these excavations nearly suffocated, and survived only a few hours after being taken out. The plaintiff claims that he fell in on account of the insufficient protection of the excavation. The trial will be continued to-day.

abstract: Protection Engine Company No. 5, of Jersey City, returned home yesterday afternoon, from Boston, with their new steam fire engine, which was built by the Amoskeag Manufacturing Company, at Manchester, N.H. They were received at the ferry by Liberty Engine Company No. 1, Americus Hook and Ladder Company No. 2, Passaic Hose Company No. 4, and Jackson Engine Company No. 6. A procession was formed, and preceded by a platoon of twenty-two policemen, under command of Aid DOYLE, and accompanied by three bands of music, they paraded through the principal streets of the city, after which a trial of the engine was had, resulting satisfactorily to all concerned. It is a third-class single engine; steam cylinders, 7 3/4 inches in diameter, and 9 1/2 inch stroke; pump 4 1/4 inches in diameter, and 9 1/2 inch stroke. The boiler is cased with Princes metal, with German silver moldings. The steam cylinder is cased with German silver, with Princes metal moldings. The air chamber and signal two hand lanterns are silver-plated, and the four coach lanterns are of Princes metal. The engine, which cost $4,500, is very pretty, and is built in the most substantial manner.

abstract: -- The citizens of the town of Bergen are making extensive arrangements for the celebration of the coming Fourth in grand style. The programme will be as follows: A procession which will form on the Old Bergen-square, at 10 A.M., consisting of the Fire Department, militia and returned veterans in full dress; the various civic societies of the town; thirty-six young ladies representing the thirty-six States of the Onion, dressed in white, and drawn in cars by twelve white horses, to be followed by citizens generally, on foot and in carriages. After marching through the principal streets, an oration will be delivered by Mr. THOCKMORTON, Esq., after which a dinner will be served up and the day will close with a grand display of fireworks from the town hall. National salutes will also be fired at sunrise, noon and sundown.

abstract: On Wednesday evening a quarrel occurred in the Hotel Suisse, at No. 19 Jay-street, between WERNER WERNER, landlord, and Mrs. JOSEPHINE COHEN, wife of SIMON COHEN; and Mrs. COHEN having been either pulled, pushed or kicked from a door-step, fell to the aidewalk, was taken thence a corpse. The occurrence had every appearance of murder; and the Fifth Ward Police, regarding it as such, took the landlord and husband into custody, and subsequently arrested all the inmates of the house, and detained them as witnesses at the police station until yesterday morning, when they were examined and released by Coroner COLLIN. We print a portion of the testimony which was taken at the inquest, as follows:

abstract: Boston, or Philadelphia; Comparison with
snippet: Boston, or Philadelphia; Comparison with
lead_paragraph: We notice that the commercial papers of Boston and Philadelphia are in the habit of talking as if New-York were jealous of the prosperity and envious of the greatness of these cities. The Philadelphians are not only demonstrating continually that their city is the proper commercial centre of the continent, but they imagine that New-Yorkers busy themselves in doubting it. Boston, being even smaller than Philadelphia, swells out against New-York in proportionately greater magnitude, and fancies that the "green eyes" of the Empire City are ceaselessly fixed on its commerce, its Common, its riches, its aristocracy, its literature and its organs.
headline: {'main': 'Boston Notions and Philadelphia Fancies.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Boston Notions and Philadelphia Fancies.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The resolution of the Common Council relative to celebrating the 3d and 4th of July, now awaits the Mayor's signature. It is understood that His Honor does not regard the resolution with favor, for several reasons; among others that it casts a slight upon the Governor. By the terms of the resolution the Committee on the Celebration of the Fourth of July, are requested to ask the Governor to designate the 3d as a legal holiday, and if he refuses to comply, then the committee are desired to recommend our citizens to suspend business on that day, and observe it as a day of rejoicing. The Mayor yesterday transmitted a copy of the resolution to Gov. FENTON, and His Excellency's reply will no doubt determine the Mayor's action in the matter.

abstract: Commencement; Thirty-first Commencement
snippet: Commencement; Thirty-first Commencement
lead_paragraph: Yesterday morning the thirty-first annual commencement of the University of New-York was celebrated at Niblo's Garden. The occasion was made one of peculiar interest, both by the orations delivered by the members of the graduating class of 1865, and the manner in which they were delivered. At an early hour a constant stream of visitors poured into the spacious theatre, and it was not long before every seat was occupied, the vast auditorium presenting a scene of rare beauty and interest. The audience was mainly composed of the fairer sex, and the various lines and shades exhibited by the endless variety of costumes was almost bewildering. The greatest degree of enthusiasm was manifested by the lady friends of the graduates, who were unanimous in their applause of the orations, and overwhelming in spontaneous offerings of floral tributes to their especial favorites.
headline: {'main': 'LOCAL INTELLIGENCE.; UNIVERSITY OF THE CITY OF NEW-YORK. abstract: Building and Materials; Peace, Production and Prices; Prices and Buildings; Peace and Production; Industry, Production and Peace
snippet: Building and Materials; Peace, Production and Prices; Prices and Buildings; Peace and Production; Industry, Production and Peace
lead_paragraph: Among many of our most sagacious business men, the return of peace was looked to with gloomy forebodings, as the commencement of a period of severe industrial depression. One year ago there was no little reason for such painful apprehension. The insurrectionary States were known to be nearly desolate or on the borders of starvation; a million of men, directly in the service of the General Government, were to be discharged and thrown into the channels of our shrunken industry, at a time when the government demands which had stimulated it to an almost preternatural degree of activity, were expected to cease. At the same time, with the currency returning toward the specie standard, as was hoped, there would necessarily follow a decline in values, which would put a temporary stoppage to most kinds of manufactures required by ordinary consumers. "Who will build ships," it was asked, "when the government will have hundreds to dispose of at merely nominal prices? Who will put up houses with the prospects of a great decline in business and fall of rents? Who will spin silk or weave cotton for a falling market? Who will speculate when prices slide down day by day, like an avalanche? And what demand can arise for luxuries, in view of the struggle that is certain to follow for the necessaries of existence? In a word, will there not be, with the cessation in our industry, a panic, compared with which that of 1857 was insignificant in regard to duration, and no more extended in its sweep? In view of the troubles experienced in the British islands after the peace of 1815, before Europe had time to adjust itself to the new condition of affairs and become the customer it had been for British merchandise, what might not be apprehended here, where no much larger a proportion of our able-bodied men would be at once diverted from the pursuits of war to those of peace?" He did many thoughtful, patriotic men reason till a few months or weeks ago, and so do a few still reason with themselves.

abstract: -- A German named CHARLES SCHNAFFER, residing with the family of Mr. PETER DIBBLE, No. 416 Canal-street, New-York, was drowned on Sunday last, while bathing, off Coney Island Point. He left his clothing in one of the bathing houses, and as no one called for them, they were given in charge of Justice VOORHIES, of Gravesend. Mr. DIBBLE called upon the Justice on Wednesday, and fully identified the clothing. The body has not, however, been recovered. Deceased was about 22 years of age, and had but recently arrived in this country.

abstract: In looking to the progress of pacification at the South, the happy result will be found to be in part due to the great magnanimity of GRANT's original terms with LEE at Appomattox Court-house, repeated by SHERMAN to JOHNSTON at Durham Station, by CANBY to TAYLOR at Citronelle, and by CANBY, through BUCKNER, to KIRBY SMITH at New-Orleans. Not a little is due to the generosity of the President's amnesty; much more still, peradventure, to the liberal and fraternal spirit in which the North, less ardent, but surely steadier in its affection, has stretched wide open its arms to greet again the repentant South.

abstract: -- Complaint having been made because a body lay in Whitehall-slip from Tuesday noon until Wednesday afternoon, Coroner WILDEY desires to say that notice was received at the Coroner's office at 3 o'clock on Tuesday afternoon; he went to hold an inquest, but-could find no witnesses; he held the inquest at 8 o'clock on Wednesday morning, and delivered a certificate to Officer NESBITT, of the Harbor Police, and it was taken to No. 1 Bond-street. It should further be known that there is only one cart for the removal of the city's dead, and that it is sent out at 1 o'clock every afternoon, too late to be brought into requisition by the Coroners when they hold inquests late in the day.

abstract: N. Y., Stewart, John, in Jones Wood; Curran Acquitted
snippet: N. Y., Stewart, John, in Jones Wood; Curran Acquitted
lead_paragraph: Patrick Curran, indicted for manslaughter, was tried yesterday. Charles S. Spencer, Esq., appeared as his counsel, and Assistant District Attorney Robert C. Hutchings, for the People. Mr. Hutchings stated in his opening, that the jurors now had before them a case which involved the protection of our citizens and the sanctity of human life. The prisoner was charged with causing the death of one John Stewart, on the 23d day of May last, at Jones' Wood, by shooting him with a pistol. Mr. Hutchings said that he would not anticipate the evidence for the prosecution, but he was confident that when they had heard this testimony they would be convinced that this was manslaughter, and that it was not justifiable.

abstract: There were no troops arriving yesterday, and none reported on the way by railroad this side of Baltimore. Two steamships were telegraphed from Sandy Hook as coming up the harbor, supposed to...
lead_paragraph: There were no troops arriving yesterday, and none reported on the way by railroad this side of Baltimore. Two steamships were telegraphed from Sandy Hook as coming up the harbor, supposed to contain troops from the coast. No arrival had, however, been reported at a late hour. Several regiments are expected from the southern coast very soon. The One Hundred and Forty-fourth New-York, erroneously reported in some newspapers as having arrived here from Hilton Head, have not, according to late advices, yet left that place, but were expecting to leave every day.

abstract: THE STEAMER NEWPORT. -- This magnificent new steamer for the line between New-York and Newport, has just been completed, and will make her trial trip on the 26th and take her place in the line on the 28th inst. She is of collossal dimensions, being 350 feet in length, with 150 staterooms, 600 berths and ample accommodations for a thousand passengers. She is splendidly fitted up, the bridal and other staterooms being marvels of elegance and luxury. The curtains are of rich silk brocatel, the furniture of black walnut, covered with crimson. The carpets are of the finest English velvet. The painting, gilding and decorations, by the first artists and workmen, are exceedingly rich and chaste. The boat was built by JOHN ENGLISH & SON, the builders of the famous North River steamer St. John. It is claimed that the Newport is the finest steamer afloat, and when we remember that $600,000 have been expended in building and equipping her for service, we do not find it difficult to admit the assertion. The Newport will be commanded by Capt. BROWN, of the Metropolis, and long a favorite officer on this line. THEODORE WARREN, Esq., a gentleman equally well known, will be clerk of the boat. The addition of so superb a vessel to the well-known steamers of this route shows how liberal a patronage has been bestowed on it, and how much travel is expected in the future. Another fine new boat, the Old Colony, is to be added, we learn, before the close of the season.

abstract: Fire Department; Paid Brigade Secured for New-York; Municipal Reform and Albany Legislation; Paid Fire Brigade
snippet: Fire Department; Paid Brigade Secured for New-York; Municipal Reform and Albany Legislation; Paid Fire Brigade
lead_paragraph: Good order has received another triumph in the decision of the Court of Appeals, that the legislative enactment for a paid fire brigade in this city, to be controlled by commissioners appointed by the Governor, is not unconstitutional. The struggle against it by those interested in perpetuating the present abuses has been almost as ardent as was that against the Metropolitan Police bill. For a time, it seemed as if the wildest elements of disorder would be let loose. If we had had a FERNANDO WOOD at the head of our city affairs, as on the other occasion, probably enough we should have had another revolutionary meeting in the Park, and another high carnival of riot. But we have escaped this time without outbreak, until the highest court of the State has had opportunity to affirm the validity of the law. That decision is pronounced with even a more decided voice than in the Police case -- the court standing now seven for the law to one against, then six to two. This settles it.

abstract: Butler vs. Herter; Sewer Accident
snippet: Butler vs. Herter; Sewer Accident
lead_paragraph: Emma Butler, Administratrix of Amos M. Butler, deceased, vs. Gustave Herter. -- This action is brought to recover the sum of $5,000 damages, which it is claimed were sustained under the following circumstances. In July last the defendant was the owner of premises known as Nos. 103 and 105 Mercer-street, and was at that time engaged in building thereon. As is usual in such cases, an excavation was made under or near the sidewalk. About 1 o'clock in the morning of the 13th of July, Mr. Amos M. Butler was passing along the walk on the side of Mercer-street, where the excavation was made. So far as the testimony shows, he was alone, and it is alleged in plaintiff's complaint that owing to there having been placed there no sufficient and proper guards, be fell into the excavation, and was, by the fall, so badly injured that he died in a few hours afterward. This action is brought by his widow, as administratrix, under and by virtue of an act of the Legislature of this State, passed several years ago. The plaintiff claims that her husband's death was caused solely by the negligence of the defendant in not having placed there the usual safeguards, and that there was no negligence or want of care on the part of the deceased.

abstract: The
snippet: The
lead_paragraph: Our streets have rarely afforded a more curious sight than has been presented for several days in the hundreds of Southern soldiers, in transit homeward from the military prisons. Clad in unwholesome-looking dingy gray -- an army uniform in name, but never in color -- squalid, unkempt and forlorn, they are permitted to wander about at will, exciting some share of interest wherever they go. The dominating expression upon the faces of these men from the South is amazement at what they see. Naturally so, as they mainly belong to that class of the Southern people known as the "poor whites," who never before were favored with a chance to look upon the activities of a great city.

abstract: -- The June reception at the closing of the academic year of this institute, at Nyack, on the Hudson, took place on Wednesday evening, and was attended by the usual elegant and refining features which have characterized the reception of this school. The audience was of the largest, the entertainment of the best, consisting of vocal and instrumental music, and the reading of a racy collection of original articles by the students. The reading of Miss CROSBY was noteworthy for its excellence. Miss ROWE's instrumentalisms, Miss BRINSMAID's and Miss MANSFIELD's vocalisms charming and loudly encored. THEODORE TILTON, Esq., delivered an address at the close of the exercises, quite in his own happy vein.

abstract: Unpaid, the Hardships of
snippet: Unpaid, the Hardships of
lead_paragraph: -- We publish a letter to-day -- one out of many received on the same subject -- complaining of delay in the payment of arrears due to the soldiers. We do not know how far these complaints bear upon the general backwardness of the Paymaster General's accounts. It is probable, however, we take it, that our correspondents describe local and exceptional hardships, rather than the condition of affairs generally. Of one thing the soldiers will not have to complain a day longer than the War Department if the Secretary of the Treasury can help it. Their claims are entitled to precedence, and this they will have. But even after the money has been found the business of disbursement is so enormous, that more time is required for it, than the soldiers can well afford.

abstract: Thirty-ninth Anniversary, Excursion, >amp;c.
snippet: Thirty-ninth Anniversary, Excursion, >amp;c.
lead_paragraph: Everybody in New-York knows the Light Guard of New-York, with their white uniforms and towering shakos, their gallant deeds and hard-earned reputation. But everybody may not know that the Light Guard have outlived their cotemporary organizations, and now in 1865 see the thirty-ninth anniversary of their birth. It is difficult to write the past record of the Guard, for so many interesting events cling round the history of the corps that it is impossible to choose from among them.

abstract: The news from Mexico is interesting. If the reports that we receive from New-Orleans may be relied on, MAXIMILIAN'S tenure of authority grows more precarious every day. The Emperor, it is said, displays no latent for governing his turbulent subjects, and leaves the management of affairs almost entirely to the Empress.
lead_paragraph: The news from Mexico is interesting. If the reports that we receive from New-Orleans may be relied on, MAXIMILIAN'S tenure of authority grows more precarious every day. The Emperor, it is said, displays no latent for governing his turbulent subjects, and leaves the management of affairs almost entirely to the Empress. The foreign mercenaries are becoming disorganized, and the French troops look to Marshal BUZAINE for orders. A report comes by way of Brownsville, Texas, that Gen. NEGRETE has been defsated and taken prisoner by the Imperialists. The rebels who have sought refuge in Mexico find themselves unwelcome visitors, being treated by Liberals and Imperialists with neglect ann contempt.

abstract: Mr. PERKINS CLEVELAND, of No. 1 Irving-place, made oath that at about 1 o'clock on the morning of the 18th inst., he was accosted in Seventeenth-street, near First-avenue, by one JOSEPH COURTNEY, otherwise "Squinting Joe," and that after a brief colloquy, young COURTNEY, who is a more stripling of 17, demanded his watch, and then, Mr. CLEVELAND declining to comply with the demand, seized and wrenched it from its chain. Mr. CLEVELAND laid hands on the young robber, and during the mortal struggle that ensued a courtesan entered upon the scene, and recognizing COURTNEY, aided him in making his escape. Mr. CLEVELAND pursued the thief, and both he and his feminine acquaintance -- COYLE by name -- were arrested by Policeman WHITMORE, of the Eighteenth Ward. The Magistrate declined to act it either of the prisoners to bail, but committed them for trial.

abstract: Mr. SILAS SEYMOUR, Chief Engineer and Superintendent of the Washington Aqueduct, in a report to Secretary HARLAN, dated June 15, says: "In accordance with a request contained in your letter of the 1st inst., I have the honor to inclose herewith a 'statement of the expenditures on account of the Washington Aqueduct from July 1, 1864, to May 31, 1865, inclusive,' which embraces the last appropriation of $150,000, and also the balance ($671 37) on hand at the date of the last appropriation, together with the amounts ($15,552 35) realized from other sources, making an aggregate of $166,223 72.

abstract: The Avenger's Task Done
snippet: The Avenger's Task Done
lead_paragraph: The process of reconstructing the Union and of restoring to the national authority the same extent of sway, and the same vigor which it possessed before the war, goes bravely on. Each day signalizes, if not some movement for the reintegration of a State, at least the application for pardon of noted individuals, who seek refuge under the generous amnesty proclamation of President JOHNSON. It is thus that the rehabilitation of the disloyal States moves forward hourly with gigantic strides.

abstract: RETURN OF BATTERY C, FIRST NEW-JERSEY ARTILLERY -- GRAND TORCH-LIGHT RECEPTION IN HOBOKEN. -- The members of Battery C, First Regiment New-Jersey Artillery, under command of Br[???]vet Major WOERNER, returned home on Wednesday evening. About forty of the members being residents of Hoboken, the citizens of that place gave them a grand reception last night. The entire Fire Department turned out in torch-light procession and escorted the veterans through the principal streets of the city, and all along the line the citizens turned out and gave them a hearty welcome. After the procession the firemen together with many prominent citizens, and the members of the battery repaired to Otto Cottage Garden, where a bountiful collation was served up, Speeches of welcome were made by BENJAMIN VAN RIPER, Hon. Mr. ABBET and others. The following singing societies were present and gave some fine vocal music: The Quartette Club, Germania, Harmonia and Concordia Societies. The affair wound up with dancing, which continued until a late hour in the night. Amongst the invited guests present were Gen. HATFIELD, Col. VAN AMSRURG, Col. TRAVERS, Col. BATISLAW, and Capts. MOUNT, FOSTER and CONSMULLER. This battery was raised in Hudson County and went to the war in September, 1863, and was attached to the Second Corps. They have taken part in the following engagements: White House, June 20, 1864; Deep Bottom, Reams' Station, Aug 25; Fort Hask, March 28 and 29, and April 1 and 2. The battery arrived at Trenton about two weeks since, and were paid off and discharged on Tuesday.

abstract: Resuscitation Necessary
snippet: Resuscitation Necessary
lead_paragraph: -- We spoke a few days since of the importance of energetic action on the part of our commercial men, shippers and ship-builders, to resuscitate our mercantile marine from the low condition into which it had fallen during the war. The Boston Commercial Bulletin, which has been discussing the subject, expresses astonishment that American ship-builders are not more active, now that peace is assured. There is not only the transportation of Southern staples, which the English and French are trying to secure; there is not only the vast trans-atlantic Ocean trade by steam which is now entirely in European hands; but the carrying trade of the world, from which we have been in a great measure excluded by rebel privateers, is now open to us. When our shipbuilders have three or four hundred thousand tons of shipping afloat, we shall be able to take advantage of all markets, and shall easily replace with American ships the two hundred sail of foreign vessels that crowd the port of New-York. We have abundance of ship-building materials upon our own soil, whereas Great Britain, our principal rival upon the seas, is compelled to import most of her timber; and the Southern pine, which was so extensively used before the war, may now be obtained by the same means as easily as ever. As the Bulletin remarks, everything, so far as we can perceive, is in favor of our ship builders, and nothing against them but their own fears. Let them throw their fear to the winds, and begin at once to replace the shipping which has been sold to foreigners or destroyed by British pirates, and we have no doubt they will soon reap a golden harvest for their enterprise.

abstract: The greatest trotting match that has been witnessed for a very long period will take place at the Fashion Course on Monday next, the stakes being  $5,000, heats of three miles each, the contestants being HIRAM WOODRUFF'S famous Long Island horse Dexter, and the justly celebrated Stonewall Jackson, of Hartford. (The latter must not be confounded with his namesake who has trotted repeatedly on the Island.)
lead_paragraph: The greatest trotting match that has been witnessed for a very long period will take place at the Fashion Course on Monday next, the stakes being $5,000, heats of three miles each, the contestants being HIRAM WOODRUFF'S famous Long Island horse Dexter, and the justly celebrated Stonewall Jackson, of Hartford. (The latter must not be confounded with his namesake who has trotted repeatedly on the Island.) The high estimate WOODRUFF places on Dexter as the best trotting horse out, is well known to the trotting world, while the supporters of the Hartford horse are just as firmly convinced of his superiority. It seems to be generally admitted that Dexter and Stonewall are the two best three-mile horses we have on the trotting turf, hence an intense interest is manifested concerning the result of the contest for the long distance championship. At present the Hartford horse is the favorite, at odds of about 5 to 4 in his favor; but in all probability the Dexter party will come into the market with a rush on or before the day; if so the tables will be turned. Formerly heat races of two, three, and four miles, were common occurrences, and esteemed as better tests of the courage and lasting quanlities of a horse than mile heats, now so much in vogue -- as in the latter, a horse may and frequently does win who has a great turn of speed and but little endurance. Hence this coming match will not only be regarded as a welcome novelty, but as exhibiting a desire to return to the good old times of the trotting turf when these gallant lengthy contests were wont to attract their tens of thousands of spectators.

abstract: John Picket, alias Baker, was tried yesterday, for grand larceny, the indictment charging him with stealing a trunk, the property of Mr. William Ray, from the Putnam House, on the 17th of June instant. The only evidence against the prisoner was that the trunk was seen in the vicinity of the door of the room occupied by prisoner and an accomplice, where it had ...
lead_paragraph: John Picket, alias Baker, was tried yesterday, for grand larceny, the indictment charging him with stealing a trunk, the property of Mr. William Ray, from the Putnam House, on the 17th of June instant. The only evidence against the prisoner was that the trunk was seen in the vicinity of the door of the room occupied by prisoner and an accomplice, where it had been moved by some one unknown. The prisoner, when arrested, was coming up-stairs, and a burglar's instrument was found upon him. The jury found him guilty, and he was remanded for sentence.

abstract: PUBLIC MEETING OF FENIANS. -- A large meeting of Fenians was held last evening in Temperance Hall, corner of Grand and Seventh streets, E.D., under the auspices of the Emmett Circle. THOMAS GALLAGHER, Esq., occupied the chair. Addresses were delivered by Mr. THOMAS BRENNAN, of New-York, and Mr. GEO. J. CAMPBELL, Centre of the Shamrock Circle of Greenpoint. The speakers appealed to their countrymen and friends to aid them in carrying out the object of the Brotherhood, which was, they stated, the absolute freedom and regeneration of Ireland. At the conclusion of the address the Circle held a private meeting.

abstract: Charlier Institute Commencement
snippet: Charlier Institute Commencement
lead_paragraph: The tenth commencement of this institute was celebrated last evening at No. 126 East Twenty-fourthstreet. The spacious schoolroom was tastefully decorated with flags and bouquets. The majority of the pupils were present, as well as many of their relatives. Rev. Dr. CROSBY presided. This school has been in existence for the past ten years. It was opened in September, 1855, with seven pupils; it now numbers five hundred and forty-two.

abstract: Suffrage; Boston Demand for; Dana, Hon. R. H., on Negro Suffrage
snippet: Suffrage; Boston Demand for; Dana, Hon. R. H., on Negro Suffrage
lead_paragraph: Boston has led off in an imperative demand upon President JOHNSON, that he shall exact negro suffrage at the hands of the Southern States, as a condition of their being permitted to belong to the Union. Hon. RICHARD H. DANA made the ablest and most careful argument on this subject on that occasion. We reprint it in another part of this morning's paper. Its leading points are (1,) that, as the conquering party in the war, we have the right to impose upon the conquered party whatever laws and exactions we may deem essential to the national welfare; (2,) that negro suffrage is essential to the national welfare; and (3,) that we, therefore, have the right and are in duty bound to require the Southern States to permit negroes to vote as the condition of their sharing in the rights and privileges of the National Union. Mr. DANA elaborates each of these points with characteristic ability and care.

abstract: on Education and Voting
snippet: on Education and Voting
lead_paragraph: -- We are sorry to see that Mr. BEECHER has been assailing one of the noblest features of New-England politics. He made a speech in Boston the other day denouncing the legal requirement that every citizen should be able to read and write before he should be allowed to vote. "Citizenship," he said, "has nothing to do with reading and writing." "Talk of education being necessary to make a voter! to vote only requires good common honesty and good common sense."

abstract: Dupont, Admiral S. F.; Cor. TIMES
snippet: Dupont, Admiral S. F.; Cor. TIMES
lead_paragraph: Admiral DUPONT, the hero of one of the earliest and most brilliant naval victories of the war, died suddenly yesterday morning, at the La pierro House, in Philadelphia. He was a native of New-Jersey, but received his appointment in the navy from the State of Delaware, of which he was a citizen, in December, 1815, nearly half a century ago. Up to the time of the Port Royal expedition he had spent nearly twenty-two years in active service at sea, and about eight years in duty on shore, the balance of his time having been unemployed. Among the important positions filled by the late Admiral were the following:

abstract: -We have another fearful railroad massacre to report to-day, and the victims are in great part, as usual returning soldiers. The Ohio and Mississippi Line is the scene of the slaughter on this occasion. And the catastrophe is made peculiarly memorable, not alone by the large number (some hundreds) killed or wounded, but by the colliding of three trains.

abstract: Coercion by British Government
snippet: Coercion by British Government
lead_paragraph: -There is news direct from England, and also from the Provinces, that the British Government have determined to use influence of a resistless kind to bring the maritime colonies into the Federation scheme. Those of them that refuse to become partners in that political compact are to be henceforth denied the benefits of the protection they now get from the parent State. These refractory Provinces might do without the protection, but they would find it hard to do without the expenditure of British gold, which accrues to them from the quartering of sundry garrisons within their borders. There is where the Imperial shoe begins to pinch them. And there is how they will begin to discover and appreciate the advantages of the intercolonial union. All this, meanwhile, looks as if the colonists were being invited to cut loose from the parent State altogether, and seek an independent state of political existence, as soon as they can find it convenient.

abstract: The public and those interested in benevolent enterprises will be pleased to learn of the opening of another charity in our city, under the title of the New-York Dispensary and Hospital for Women and Children, at No. 252 West Twenty-sixth-street, near Eighth-avenue. Its Board of Managers is composed of ladies, and its specific object is the treatment of the diseases of women and children, by thoroughly qualified women physicians. The institution opens under favorable auspices, and promises a success. It is well located, and in a neighborhood wholly unprovided with any similar and wide-reaching charity. The lower part of the building is used as a dispensary, and is open daily, and those too sick to come to it are visited at their homes. Both dispensary and hospital  are under the professional care of a physician in charge, and two resident house and dispensary physicians, assisted by a staff of presiding physicians. The building is partly paid for and is mostly furnished. The maintenance of the charity beds will be by public and private contributions, in a similar manner to the plan pursued at St. Luke's Hospital.

abstract: -- Yesterdayafternoon Patrolman MURPHY, of the Thirteenth Ward, found a seaman apparently drunk on Pier No. 53 East River. The seaman was taken to the Thirteenth Ward Police-station, and in his pockets was found a pass from the United States receiving-ship Vermont, showing his name to be PETER O'MEALLY, and that his time would have expired to-day. He was sent to a cell, and there found, at 6 o'clock last evening, dead. He was 30 years of age. Coroner WILDEYheld an inquest, last evening, and the jury found that O'MEALLY died of congestion of the brain.

abstract: Decent Respect to the Opinions of Mankind
snippet: Decent Respect to the Opinions of Mankind
lead_paragraph: In a few days more, at every popular gathering in honor of the National Anniversary, we shall hear the stately utterances of our Declaration of independence. Again we shall listen to those simple but noble words which, while they record the high and solemn resolutions in which the nation had its being, avow "a decent respect to the opinions of mankind."

abstract: THE ONE HUNDRED AND THIRTY-NINTH REGIMENT. The flags of the City Hall and Court-house were displayed, yesterday, in honor of the One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Regiment, which arrived the day previous, and were dismissed to meet again at 2 o'clock P.M.
lead_paragraph: THE ONE HUNDRED AND THIRTY-NINTH REGIMENT. -- The flags of the City Hall and Court-house were displayed, yesterday, in honor of the One Hundred and Thirty-ninth Regiment, which arrived the day previous, and were dismissed to meet again at 2 o'clock P.M. At the hour named the men began to assemble in the rear of the City Hall, after which they marched in review before Mayor WOOD, Major-Gen. DURYEA, Brig.-Gens. CROOKE and SMITH, Col. ANTHONY COOK, the original commander of the regiment, and others. Congratulatory addresses were made by Mayor WOOD and Gen. SMITH, after which the regiment, escorted by the Polytechnic Cadets, under command of their military instructor, Major HORACE A. SPRAGUE, marched to the foot of Gold-street, where they embarked on a steamer for Hart's Island. It was intended to give the men an entertainment, but the time was so short that it could not be accomplished. The regiment will remain on Hart's Island until paid off.

abstract: -- Yesterday afternoon, Patrolman JOHN C. FITZGERALD found an unknown man, suffering from apoplexy, on the sidewalk in Dover-street, near Front. He was taken to the Fourth Ward Police-station, and thence to the New-York Hospital, and there the sufferer died at about 6 o'clock last evening. Nothing was found on his person to indicate his name or abode. Capt. THORNE thinks that he was a seafaring man. He was about 30 years of age, had short black hair, whiskers and moustache, and light brown eyes, and wore a dark checked cashmere shirt, gray woolen drawers, blue and brown checked pantaloons and waistcoat, and brown felt hat. His stature was about 5 feet 7 inches. The body may be seen at the New-York Hospital.

abstract: Method of Conveying to Penitentiary
snippet: Method of Conveying to Penitentiary
lead_paragraph: We respectfully call the attention of the Commissioners of Charities and Correction to an abuse of which they certainly have no knowledge, and for which they will doubtless and a remedy. It relates to the manner of conveying prisoners to the penitentiary and the reformatory institutions of the islands. This work is, we understand, performed by contract, or so much per head. Obviously it should be done as decently and privately as possible. But such is very far from being the case.

abstract: The Thirty-seventh Regiment Massachusetts Volunteers, 360 men and 20 officers, arrived in this city yesterday afternoon, from Washington, per Amboy steamer, and disembarked at Pier No. 1. The regiment was received by the Sons of Massachusetts, and escorted to the Battery Barracks for dinner. The regiment subsequently departed, per rail, for Hudson, en route for Pittsfield and Springfield, where grand receptions await the command. The Thirty-seventh will rendezvous at Galoupe Island, Boston Harbor, for final muster and payment.

abstract: A remittitur in the case of the new Fire Department Law, and also one in the case of the law relating to the Tax Commissioners, -- both of which laws have just been passed upon in the Court of Appeals, -- were presented yesterday to the Judge sitting at Special Term, Supreme Court, and were by him signed, preparatory to the entry of a final judgment on the decision in the Court of Appeals, in the case of the Tax Commissioners' Law, an order was granted to show cause on Monday next, in the Supreme Court, why a reference should not be had, as provided for in the decision of the Court of Appeals.
lead_paragraph: A remittitur in the case of the new Fire Department Law, and also one in the case of the law relating to the Tax Commissioners, -- both of which laws have just been passed upon in the Court of Appeals, -- were presented yesterday to the Judge sitting at Special Term, Supreme Court, and were by him signed, preparatory to the entry of a final judgment on the decision in the Court of Appeals, in the case of the Tax Commissioners' Law, an order was granted to show cause on Monday next, in the Supreme Court, why a reference should not be had, as provided for in the decision of the Court of Appeals.

abstract: -- At about 7 o'clock last evening a number of mischievous boys set fire to several bales of hay that lay in East-street near Broome, and twenty bales of hay, of the value of about $60, were consumed. The lads escaped. The hay belonged to Mr. SILAS T. ROBBINS. The firemen appeared on the scene as promptly as ever, and poured their streams on the buildings and shipping in the neighborhood with a will, thus preventing the flames from spreading.

abstract: New Political Organization
snippet: New Political Organization
lead_paragraph: All who are in any way conversant with the soldiers in camp and field, will remember the oft-repeated expression of "wait till we get home, and see how we'll straighten matters." During the continuance of the war, now practically closed, this feeling has reigned paramount, and no one knowing the force of the soldiers' character will be surprised that the movement so often foreshadowed, has at length found utterance and a definite shape.

abstract: WALLACK'S THEATRE. We notice, with some surprise, that the very successful drama of the "Iron  Mask" will be withdrawn after to-night's performance. Few plays have been given with more marked success. The press has been uniformly flattering in its notices, and the audiences except when kept back by the extreme heat have been large and thoroughly appreciative.
lead_paragraph: WALLACK's THEATRE. -- We notice, with some surprise, that the very successful drama of the "Iron Mask" will be withdrawn after to-night's performance. Few plays have been given with more marked success. The press has been uniformly flattering in its notices, and the audiences -- except when kept back by the extreme heat -- have been large and thoroughly appreciative. The "combination," we suppose, desires to show its strength in other fields, and have a change in the programme. On Monday "Oliver Twist" is to be produced. Mr. WALLACK's Fagin is already known to the public. In its thorough realization of the character of the wretched old "fence," the conception may be called Pre-Raffaelitic. Mr. DAVENPORT is the Bill Sykes, Miss FANNY MORANT the Nancy Sykes, and Miss IONE BURKE the Oliver.

abstract: -At the Revere House, East Houston-street and Broadway, last evening, Detective DUSENBURY apprehended one CHARLES STONE, otherwise Capt, otherwise Lieut. Charles H. Stratton, an alleged horse-thief and confidence-man. The specific charge against the prisoner is, that he hired a team at the united States Hotel stables in Boston, and sold the same for $190. He came to New-York, and, with a pay-roll which in said to have been forged, introduced himself as an officer of the regular army, now on the staff of Major-Gen. DIX, and as such sought to negotiate a loan of $150 from Mr. F.R. PAGE, a Broadway broker. The prisoner was held at Police Headquarters last night, and is to be taken to Boston to-day.
lead_paragraph: -At the Revere House, East Houston-street and Broadway, last evening, Detective DUSENBURY apprehended one CHARLES STONE, otherwise Capt, otherwise Lieut. Charles H. abstract: -- The formal surrender of Galveston, reported to-day, is only of consequence in so far as it has prepared the way for the President to extend the order removing restrictions upon trade to the Texan ports, in the same manner as to other ports of the South. The whole country is now open to foreign commerce, with nothing to bar it beyond the ordinary regulations of a state of peace.

abstract: Cruelty to Animals
snippet: Cruelty to Animals
lead_paragraph: -A correspondent very properly reminds us, when we quote illustrations of the cruelty practiced toward dumb animals in England, that it would not be amiss to look at home. It is only too true, that both poultry dealers and wholesale butchers (many of them, at least,) permit the practice of a system of needless torture, by their assistants, in bringing their live stock to the market, or in preparing it for the stalls. The preliminary process of dressing fowls, as described by our correspondent, is scarcely less horrible than the atroccous practice of vivisection; and the manner in which the smaller class of live cattle are dragged or driven to the shambles, is an outrage upon the natural feelings of any one not utterly hardened by familiarity with cruelty in its must barbarous forms.

abstract: Chicago, Funny Stafford, Tug
snippet: Chicago, Funny Stafford, Tug
lead_paragraph: A terrific explosion occurred in Chicago June 19, when the boiler of the tug Fanny Stafford exploded. The engineer was instantly killed. His body was blown out of sight, and has not been seen since. The Captain was blown from the storn of the tug to the vessel in tow, a distance of forty feet. Two wheelsmen and a deckhand were also blown into the headgear of the vessel, where they clung fast. All are uninjured. A piece of the boiler and works attached, weighing three tons, was blown into the air a distance of sixty feet, passed over a four-story building, and landed on the roof of a building across the road, a distance of nine hundred feet from the scene of the explosion. In the upper stories of the house were living two families, who, marvellous to relate, were unhurt, although the first floors are complete wrecks. The door of the boiler, weighing eixty-eight pounds, was blown a distance of four blocks, crashed through the roof of a building, cutting through the two-inch planks of the flooring, and buried itself in the cellar. The shock caused by the explosion was fearful, literally shaking the entire city. The Stafford was a new boat, having run but two seasons. She is a total wreck. Loss $10,000. The cause of the explosion is said to have been over pressure of steam.

abstract: -- An embankment in Thirty-ninth-street, between First and Second avenues, fell on PATRICK KING, yesterday afternoon, and one of his legs was broken. He was taken to the New-York Hospital... A brick fell from a scaffold in Eldridge-street, near Division, yesterday afternoon, striking POTTHAUS WEYER on the head. He was taken to the New-York Hospital, and it was ascertained that he had sustained a compound fracture of the skull. Dr. JOHNSON thinks that WEYER's injury is not necessarily mortal.

abstract: One of those surprises which Governors delight in gratified Sheriff KELLY and CHAS. H. WALTER, the murderer, yesterday morning. The execution, which was to take place at 9 o'clock on Friday, the 23d, has been postponed by order of Gov. FENTON for a fortnight. Everything was in readiness; the priests had prepared the culprit; his mind was serene, and his peace with God and man secured. The Sheriff, with his black-hatted, black-coated, black-gloved deputies, were drawn up in line, and their staves were duly tipped with crape. ISAACS, the executioner, was on hand bright and early, and had with him the dreadful habiliments of the grave. The scaffold stood gaunt and naked in the court-yard, where the pleasant breeze played idly with the fatal cord. The coffin, empty, rested on the ground, with its silver-plated cover bearing this inscription:

abstract: TERESA MESTRADO, a child of seven years, was accidentally shot and instantly killed, yesterday afternoon, by ANTOINE GAVISTA, who had been employed by the girl's father to paint his saloon, at No. 480 Broome-street, and while carelessly handling a pistol, pulled the triggers and shot the girl. He was apprehended and taken to the Eighth Ward Police Station, where Coroner WILDEY will hold an inquest at 8 o'clock this morning.

abstract: CHARGED WITH ROBBING THE MAIL. -- A young man named RICHARD TRUAX was brought before United States Commissioner JACKSON yesterday afternoon, charged with having abstracted a letter containing a check for $130 from a mail-bag on the Erie Railway, between Chesterville and Jersey City, on the 7th inst. The check was in favor of HENRY H. BAKER, of Warwick, N.Y., on the Central National Bank. It is alleged that accused attended the Paterson races, and having lost at betting, gave the check to the winner, which resulted in his arrest. He was held for examination.

abstract: Meeting in Behalf of
snippet: Meeting in Behalf of
lead_paragraph: A very slim and dyspeptic meeting was held last evening, in the amphitheatre of the Masonic Hall, in Thirteenth-street, the object of which was to express indignation against the arrest of Mr. JOHN MITCHEL, late of Richmond, and now a resident of Fortress Monroe, Va. The remarkable patriot, JOHN MULLALY, of the Metropolitan Record in this city, presided over the meeting. Judge MCCUNN was present, and letters were read from RICHARD O'GORMAN and CHAS. O'CONOR.

abstract: During yesterday the Metropolitan Fire Commissioners filed numerous applications for appointments, and met the Mayor and Comptroller as a Board of Estimates, agreed to ask (it is said) $600,000 for the rest of 1865, and $700,000 for 1866. They also requested Chief DECKER to continue in office, and he agrees to do so. The commissioners are perfectly undisturbed in office, and their administration is not opposed nor likely to be.

abstract: Accident a Hoax
snippet: Accident a Hoax
lead_paragraph: -If we are to believe a telegram from the Superintendent of the Ohio and Mississippi Railroad, the fearful accident reported in yesterday's issue of the TIMES is the invention of some maliciously-disposed reporter, no such accident having occurred. It is in possible to conjuncture the motive for trifling with the public feelings on a matter of such fearful consequences as this. Surely an investigation into the origin of such reports ought to be had at once. There are certainly, in all conscience, a sufficient number of actual disasters to record, without giving currency to imaginary horrors.

abstract: The Thirteenth New-Hampshire, Third Massachusetts Heavy Artillery, One Hundred and Sixth New-York and Tenth Vermont Regiments, arrived in the city yesterday. The Vermont boys remain at the Battery barracks until to-days, when they will depart for home. The Thirteenth NewHampshire, sailed for Boston in the State of Maine; the Third Massachusetts took steamer for Boston, and the One Hundred and Sixth NewYork, left by special steamer for Albany, yesterday.

abstract: RESOLUTE VS. ACTIVE. The first match of the season between these leading organizations of Brooklyn and New York, and the first game they have playedtogether since they became senior clubs, came off on the Union Ball Grounds, Brooklyn, Eastern District, yesterday afternoon, a large gathering of spectators being present on the occasion. Both clubs had good nines in the field but not their strongest, the Resolutes lacking the services of DAVIS and FINCH, and the Actives missing STROU[???]BERG and VANDERWERKEN. The high wind that prevailed favored pitching as regards speed in delivery, but an unusually large number of high foul balls being hit, a long game was the consequence. It was a batting game throughout, the field[???], as a general thing, being below the mark of both clubs, the batting, however, was first-class, some of the hits made winning the prize of a bottle of champagne chored for fair balls over the fence. The game f[???]t[???]ed considerably. The Actives led off with a lead of 10 to 2 in the first three innings, but when they began their fourth inning the score stood 9 to 10, and similarly when they closed their fourth inning the total stood 22 to 10 in their favor, and yet at the close of the seventh, the totals were but 26 to 21. In the eighth inning they for the third time made a brilliant dash at the bat, and finally came in the victors by a score of 37 to 26. It was dark when the eighth inning closed. We give the score below:

abstract: Now that the Southern States are open to the enterprise of Northern men, no time should be lost in availing ourselves of this chance for the employment of capital, energy and skill in returning their prosperity and developing their resources. Instead of continuing these vain and idle bickerings on questions of the past, let us begin to recognize the fact...
lead_paragraph: Now that the Southern States are open to the enterprise of Northern men, no time should be lost in availing ourselves of this chance for the employment of capital, energy and skill in returning their prosperity and developing their resources. Instead of continuing these vain and idle bickerings on questions of the past, let us begin to recognize the fact that the sooner we extend a helping hand to our brethren, and by all practicable means endeavor to stimulate them with a new vitality, the sooner they will be enabled to assist us in return.
