abstract: Appointed to Berlin Mission
snippet: Appointed to Berlin Mission
lead_paragraph: The appointment of Ex-Gov. WRIGHT, of Indiana, as Minister to Berlin, a post which he filled with distinguished ability during Mr. BUCHANAN's administration, is one that gives very general satisfaction. During his official residence abroad, Gov. WRIGHT won an enviable reputation by his open-handed hospitality and his assiduous attentions to the interests of American residents and visitors in Berlin. His house was always open to his countrymen, who were ever welcome at his frequent and informal receptions. His relations with the Court of Prussia were of the most friendly character. A plain, unpretending American gentleman, a thorough Democrat and Republican, he commanded, by his tact, his dignity of deportment and genuine simplicity of manners, the respect of the government to which he was accredited and of the foreign Ministers with whom, socially or otherwise, he came in contact. He enjoyed the warm friendship of the venerable HUMBOLDT, who was a frequent visitor at his house, and whose last appearance in public, we believe, was at a dinner given by Gov. WRIGHT, in honor of WASHINGTON's birthday.
headline: {'main': 'The Mission to Berlin Appointment of Gov. Wright.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Mission to Berlin Appointment of Gov. Wright.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The Augusta Chronicle, of the 7th inst., publishes a history of the Hampton Roads conference, between President LINCOLN and Secretary Seward, on the one side, and ALEX. H. STEPHENS, R.M.T. HUNTER and J.A. CAMPBELL, on the other. The Chronicle says its statement is based on a conversation between its editor and Mr. STEPHENS himself, immediately after his return ...
lead_paragraph: The Augusta Chronicle, of the 7th inst., publishes a history of the Hampton Roads conference, between President LINCOLN and Secretary Seward, on the one side, and ALEX. H. STEPHENS, R.M.T. HUNTER and J.A. CAMPBELL, on the other. The Chronicle says its statement is based on a conversation between its editor and Mr. STEPHENS himself, immediately after his return home to Georgia from the conference, and prefaces it with the remark that as DAVIS has no longer the power to arrest and confine persons or suppress papers, "it may be as well to let people know the truth." Mr. STEPHENS is said to have been well-disposed toward and hopeful of the result of this interview, but did not altogether like his companions in the mission. President LINCOLN and Secretary SEWARD, as is well known, informed the rebel commissioners that no terms for peace would be entertained which did not recognize "complete restoration of the authority of the constitution and laws of the United States over all places within the States of the Confederacy;" and the late President remarked that "whatever consequences may follow from the reestablishment of that authority, it must be accepted; but individuals subject to pains and penalties under the laws of the United States, might rely upon a very liberal use of the powers confided to him to remit those pains and penalties if peace be restored." Mr. LINCOLN's offers throughout were of the most generous and conciliatory character, and he urgently insisted on the return of the rebellious States and the close of the war, and offered $100,000,000 as compensation to owners of slaves for the abolition of slavery throughout the South. The result is known. Nothing was done; and the arch traitor now in Fortress Monroe, despite the report of Mr. STEPHENS -- who thought "the way open for settlement,? -- rejected the propositions with contempt, and in communicating the result to the people of the South, he prefaced the report with false statements written by himself. The Chronicle says Mr. STEPHENS returned "home with but a new cause of sorrow," and those who say he talked of making speeches denouncing the terms offered by our government, "simply lied." He spoke of Mr. LINCOLN "as an old friend, who had generally voted with him in Congress, and who had a good heart and fine mind, and was undoubtedly honest."

abstract: Dickson vs. Hussey; Breach of Promise
snippet: Dickson vs. Hussey; Breach of Promise
lead_paragraph: Dickson vs. Hussey. -- This was an action for damages. The plaintiff alleged in her complaint that she came over from Liverpool in the ship Escort, of which the defendant was master, in December, 1860; that on the way over the defendant promised to marry her, although he was then a married man; that failing to seduce her by means of this promise, her entered her room in the night, while she was lying unconscious from the effect of drugs which he had administered to her in wine which he had induced her to drink, and then and there ravished her, and carried her, still unconscious, to his own room, where he kept her for a while, and that she remained unconscious for about ten hours; and she asked damages to the amount of about $10,000.
headline: {'main': 'An Extraordinary Case with an Extraordinary Ending.; SUPERIOR COURT. By Judge McCunn.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'An Extraordinary Case with an Extraordinary Ending.; SUPERIOR COURT. By Judge McCunn.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The public are evidently awaking to the outrageous nature of the great meat extortions, and the complaints heard on all sides are loud and urgent. Those who are responsible for the continued high prices will do well to heed this state of things. Attention once earnestly given to the question of how much meat is proper for the preservation of health, and the substitutes for animal food, and the grazing farmers will suffer a blow to their prosperity from which it will be difficult to recover. The sources of supply are many, also, and the higher prices are here the greater temptation for distant competition. To graziers we would say, be warned in time; and to the public we would but reiterate the advice, buy no meat.

abstract: Russell, Earl, on Fair Play to Pirates
snippet: Russell, Earl, on Fair Play to Pirates
lead_paragraph: It was not in Lord RUSSELL'S nature to announce the withdrawal of belligerent recognition form the late insurgents in terms which would appear friendly to this country. The temporary exception made in favor of such piratical cruisers as are now in British, or Bristish Colonial ports, resolves itself into a needless act of discourtesy toward the United States, at the same time that it can be turned to no account by the pirates themselves -- unless they take to promiscuous cruising against the commerce of the world generally. What does Lord RUSSELL propose to do? The exceptional portion of his letter, textually quoted, reads thus:

abstract: The Fortress Monroe correspondent of the Philadelphia Inquirer writes: "Although no conversation is permitted with the imprisoned arch-rebel, he, like neighborhood Verges, 'will be talking.' The 'stern statesman' is becoming garrulous in his old days. A few days ago, he talked of the times when he was Secretary of War. And he told the walls, and his mute mechanical guards, and the immobile commissioned officer who bear him company, that during his administration of the war bureau, he was struck by the large number of bills pouring in for some deposited on the Rip Rap Shoals. He also examined the raid bills of his predecessor in office, and found among them many portly bundles, all authorizing the payment of moneys for stones to fill up or raise Rip Rap Shoals. Secretary JEFF.'s suspicious were aroused; he procured him a boat, and had himself conveyed to the Rip Raps, to see for himself what became of all the stones for which Uncle Sam paid. DAVIS' suspicions were well founded. The slippery Captains of the schooners who were employed to carry stone and throw it on the shoals, threw it in the deepest water of Hampton Roads, where, if JEFF. speaks truly, there must be several submarine cairus erected at the government expense.

abstract: Question; the
snippet: Question; the
lead_paragraph: We are crowded with letters full of complaint, questions and suggestions about the price of meat. The whole matter lies within a very narrow compass. The butcher has meat to sell; are you forced to buy? If not, do not. The butcher will be forced to throw his meat away within a very short time, and will be able to buy no more. Then who will suffer? Not the public, who can well afford to cool off a little on vegetables this hot weather.
headline: {'main': 'The Meal Question.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Meal Question.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: In the eleven divorce suits below entitled, Justice INGRAHAM yesterday confirmed the reports of the referees, and granted the judgments of divorce prayed for by the plintiffs. In five of the suits the wives are plaintiffs, and in six the husbands appear as such:
lead_paragraph: In the eleven divorce suits below entitled, Justice INGRAHAM yesterday confirmed the reports of the referees, and granted the judgments of divorce prayed for by the plintiffs. In five of the suits the wives are plaintiffs, and in six the husbands appear as such: Maria L. Jenks vs. Russell E. Jenks; Mary E. Parker vs. Timothy Parker; Mary L. Field vs. Geo. H. Field; Jenny Hales vs. George Hales; Mary A. Devine vs. Chas. M. Devine; Michael Smith vs. Mary Smith; Philip Schulhofs vs. Harriet E. Schulhofs; David Weil vs. Florence Weil; Henry Tarreyn vs. Henrietta Tarreyn; Samuel C. Hinman vs. Sarah E. Hinman, and Francis Salley vs. Catharine Salley.

abstract: BARBARA DIEDERICH, an interesting miss of 13, preferred a charge against NICHOLAS CHRIST, of No. 309 Seventh-avenue, her stepfather, alleging that on the 4th inst., while her mother was at the Central Park, having left her alone in the house, he committed a hideous assault. CHRIST, who is a German shoemaker, aged 45 years, was apprehended by Roundsman GUNNER, of the Twenty-ninth Precinct, and committed for examination. Mrs. CHRIST says that her husband has been committed on a trumped-up charge.

abstract: Williamsburgh, Highway, of Mr. Merrick
snippet: Williamsburgh, Highway, of Mr. Merrick
lead_paragraph: HIGHWAY ROBBERY. -- An old gentleman named TITUS MERRICK, residing in North Sixth-street, E.D., was attacked early yesterday morning, at the corner of North Seventh and Sixth streets, by a gang of ruffians, who beat him unmercifully and robbed him of what little money he had in his possession. On his reporting these facts at the Forty-fifth Precinct station-house, Sergt. MADDOX, accompanied by officers LEE and COLAHAN, started in pursuit of the offenders, and succeeded in arresting a man named BERNARD DOYLE, and a companion of his who gave his name as JOHN SIMPSON. Mr. TITUS recognized DOYLE as the man who searched his pockets. They will be taken before Judge DAILEY this morning.

abstract: Insubordination in Mexico, Gen. Wool's Denial of the Story
snippet: Insubordination in Mexico, Gen. Wool's Denial of the Story
lead_paragraph: Our eight Police Magistrates hold court on alternate weeks, and each disposes of his own prisoners, usually on the last day of his week's labor. This day being the Sabbath, the Sunday morning session is often quite theatrical in its visible features. Yesterday morning was one of the most interesting of these occasions, at the Third District Police Court, popularly known as Essex Market -- the court before which the officers of the Metropolitan Police are required to take all offenders that they may capture in the five densely populous, cosmopolitan Wards of the, great East Side. The week's calendars had been corpulent, and there was consequently a vast array of offenders that Justice MANSFIELD had committed to prison is await his pleasure -- many of them persons whom he had held merely to purge them of poisonous gin, others old offenders, that had been detained to enable the police to find evidence upon which to convict them of crimes of high grade, and yet others who had been imprisoned for a day or two, by way of reprimand. These were summoned from the cells in gangs. The first gang was composed of the "revolvers," or those unhappy beings of both sexes whose master is the battle, and who come down from Blackwell's Island once in three months or six, only to return within a week of their release. These were summarily consigned to the "Black Maria," that gaudily-painted vehicular contrivance which takes its name from the color it once bore, and wherein both sexes and all classes of criminals are huddled like untamed beasts in a cage. The second gang appearing, we see young men who, having been abroad on festive tours, have fallen into the bands of the meddlesome police and rendered themselves liable to the $10 fine or ten days imprisonment, which is the prescribed penalty for intoxication. These are ordinarily dismissed with a mild reprimand; but where it is shown that an inebriated man has given an officer offence, he is punished by imprisonment, as was the case, yesterday morning, with a dashing youth who had defied the policeman who had ordered him to go home. The magistrate thought that this prisoner was able to contribute ten dollars toward the support of the county's paupers, and he was accordingly given the option of doing this or of serving ten days on "the Island." A boy with a letter in the Post-office, having stolen a ball, was told that if he turned to look back on the way home his fate shall be that of Lot's wife, and, moreover, if he is again arrested for petty larceny he shall go to the House of Refuge. The third gang comprises thethieves of higher grade; the fourth, the burglars; the fifth, the highwaymen, and so forth, but let us to the, business of the day. The first noteworthy case is brought by Policeman MCCARE, of the court, and the complaint is for.

abstract: Jerked Beef and the Price of Meat
snippet: Jerked Beef and the Price of Meat
lead_paragraph: In view of the persistent attempts by our graziers and butchers to force us to pay exorbitantly for meat, the experiment successfully made in England to use South American jerked beef as a chief article of food, becomes of great importance. The most distinguished scientific men have carefully investigated the subject, and report that the meat is perfectly good and as nutritious as when fresh. The price is so low -- it can be shipped from Buenos Ayres at three cents a pound -- that there is no reason why a handsome profit should not be realized on arrival here, though sales be made at one-quarter the present price of beef in this city. The truth is that we can afford to be at the mercy of no one interest in regard to the prime necessities of life; and even if the meat salesman at once lower their prices, the importation of jerked beef is needed as a check upon future operations such as we now suffer from. Commercial men will no doubt see to this. The extortions of one class of tradesmen invariably end in its own discomfiture, and in the enrichment of another class. In short, the fable of the silly person who killed the goose that laid the golden eggs, is just as true an exposition of the consequence of greediness as it ever was, as certain people will surely find out before very long.

abstract: A dispatch from Fort Smith says that EX-GOV. WADE, of the Choctaw Nation, has arrived at that post from Dooksville to confer with Gen. BUSSY, commanding the District of the Frontier, for the return to their homes of all Choctaw Indians who have been engaged in the Confederate army. A temporary treaty of peace was effected with the Choctaw Indians at Dooksville on the 18th inst. by Col. MATHEWS, of the Ninety-ninth Illinois Infantry, who was sent as commissioner on the part of the United States. The Indians agree to cease at once all hostilities against the United States, and return to their homes and resume their former occupations. The Indians appear very friendly to the United States, and are anxious to resume friendly relations. Gen. BUSSY has issued an order inviting all Indians to return to their homes, and assuring them they will not be molested by the United States authorities so long as they keep the temporary treaty of peace entered into.

abstract: The Thirteenth New-Hampshire, Third Massachusetts Heavy Artillery, One Hundred and Sixth New-York and Tenth Vermont Regiments, arrived in the city Saturday. The Vermont boys remain at the Battery barracks until to-day, when they will depart for home. The Thirteenth New-Hampshire, sailed for Boston in the State of Maine; the Third Massachusetts took steamer for Boston, and the One Hundred and Sixth New-York, left by special steamer for Albany, Saturday night. Several detachments from New-York regiments arrived during yesterday, and departed homeward.

abstract: BROOKLYN CITY MORTALITY. -- The total number of deaths in this city last week, was 132, of which 18 were men, 24 women, 45 boys and 45 girls. The principal diseases were: convulsions 19, cholera infantum 15, consumption 12, dropsy 9, debility 8, marasmus 5, typhoid fever 2, hooping-cough 2, typhus fever 3, measles 1, &c. Under one year of age 50; natives of the United States, 102; Ireland, 14; England, 6; Germany, 5; British America, 2; France, 2: Scotland, 1.

abstract: And the Parent Government; Arrangement with
snippet: And the Parent Government; Arrangement with
lead_paragraph: Among the late news from England which we published yesterday, was the announcement, made on the authority of the London Morning Post, that the Canada delegates have succeeded in their mission. The details of the agreement are to be laid before Parliament without delay. Meanwhile, the Morning Post alleges that the colonists, on their part, covenant to undertake the construction of the necessary fortifications west of Quebec; to enlarge and deepen the provincial canals, for military as well as commercial purposes; to maintain an efficient local militia, and to build the Intercolonial Railroad.

abstract: Building Companies called for; House Building Wanted in New-York City
snippet: Building Companies called for; House Building Wanted in New-York City
lead_paragraph: For those possessed of fortunes, or those having liberal incomes, this city is immeasurably the most desirable place on the American continent in which to live. The fact that it is the recognized metropolis of the nation; the fact that it is the largest and most populous, the richest and among the oldest of American cities, are circumstances greatly in its favor. To these advantages must be added its location, admirable in every respect, and, altogether, unequalled in its natural healthfulness, its pleasant climate, its grand surroundings, the facility of access to it from all parts of the country and from all countries of the world. To those again must be added its splendid streets, and edifices and parks, and its hundred miles of commodious and luxurious residences. To these also, its cosmopolitan and liberal spirit, its scientific and literary supremacy, its artistic treasures and opportunities, and all the innumerable appliances or gratifying the rich man's ordinary wants and ministering to his higher nature. To men of fortune or of means, possessed of taste, culture, intellect or genius, and desirous of making as much as possible out of his life and out of themselves, New-York City has a superiority which is unquestionable, and which is tacitly confessed by the continual gravitation toward it of these classes from all parts of the country.
headline: {'main': 'New-York City. Houses Wanted.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'New-York City. Houses Wanted.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: The funeral obsequies of Mrs. Wm. H. SEWARD this afternoon drew together from far and near a large concourse of sympathizing friends. The occasion and the services were exceedingly impressive and touching.
lead_paragraph: AUBURN, N.Y. Saturday, June 24.

lead_paragraph: The following article, from the Augusta (Ga.) Chronicle & Sentinel, says the Baltimore American, was authorized, if not prepared, by Mr. STEPHENS, the late rebel Vice-President, and one of the Southern Commissioners to the Fortress Monroe Conference. It gives an interesting inside view of the negotiations there, and confirms the suspicions that have been entertained of the bad faith of JEFF. DAVIS:

abstract: THE GREAT TROTTING MATCH FOR $5,000 TODAY. -- We have previously referred to the great contest at three mile heats between Dexter and Stonewall Jackson, of Hartford, which comes off at the Fashion Course, L.I., to-day. As the time approaches, the interest culminates. No match trot which has taken place for a long time has created anything like the interest which is manifested regarding the coming event -- the large sums depending on the result, and on the time that will be made, and the novelty of a three mile heat race -- will cause a large crowd to assemble on the occasion, to avoid which we advise intending visitors to make an early departure for the course.
lead_paragraph: THE GREAT TROTTING MATCH FOR $5,000 TODAY. -- We have previously referred to the great contest at three mile heats between Dexter and Stonewall Jackson, of Hartford, which comes off at the Fashion Course, L.I., to-day. abstract: A DANGEROUS NUISANCE. -- The Fourth of July will soon be here, and the boys of great and smaller growth will parade the streets with pistols and other firearms, to the great danger of quiet people and in violation of the law. At all times the discharge of firearms in the public streets is a dangerous nuisance, but particularly will it be so now when so many of the pistols and revolvers used need fixed amunition, ball included. In the hands of young and inexperienced men and boys, these weapons are dangerous beyond all reckoning, and we trust the police authorities will notify the community in advance of the coming festive occasion, that their use is a violation of law which shall meet with certain and condign punishment. There are modes sufficient for the expression of our joy and independence, without resorting to this law-breaking, life-endangering practice.
lead_paragraph: A DANGEROUS NUISANCE. -- The Fourth of July will soon be here, and the boys of great and smaller growth will parade the streets with pistols and other firearms, to the great danger of quiet people and in violation of the law. abstract: Harbor, Novel Excursion to Distribute Anti-scorbutics
snippet: Harbor, Novel Excursion to Distribute Anti-scorbutics
lead_paragraph: On Saturday an excursion party, consisting of the New-York State Agent, Col. VINCENT COLYER, and a number of ladies connected with the different Soldiers' Relief Associations of this city, embarked upon a convenient steamboat, and made a tour of the fortifications and navy vessels lying in and about the harbor. The purpose of the tour was to distribute fresh vegetables and luscious fruit to the gallant boys who were doing duty in this vicinity. It is needless to say that the trip was an enjoyable one, and hi every way a success.

abstract: The United States steamer Kanawha, from Galveston via Pensacola, June 14, arrived at this port yesterday, from blockade service. The Kanawha has been in commission nearly 47 months, and for the past 17 months engaged in blockading Galveston and, the coast of Texas as far as the Rio Grande. She has been very successful in capturing blockade-runners, having taken no less than 25.

abstract: OUR CITY VETERANS. -- It is announced that the Fortieth (Mozart), Eighty-sixth, Ninety-third and Seventy-third New-York Regiments, have received orders to report at Hart's Island for final muster and payment. The city has been shamefully remiss in its attentions to the many returning regiments daily passing through our streets, leaving to paid agents what ought to be the spontaneous ebulition of public sentiment. Now that these New-York City Veterans are coming home to us laden with honors gained upon the battle-fields of the South, we ought to show our sense of their signal services by a grand turnout of citizen soldiers and a hearty reception by the populace.
lead_paragraph: OUR CITY VETERANS. -- It is announced that the Fortieth (Mozart), Eighty-sixth, Ninety-third and Seventy-third New-York Regiments, have received orders to report at Hart's Island for final muster and payment. abstract: Suffrage; An Uncertain Remedy
snippet: Suffrage; An Uncertain Remedy
lead_paragraph: It is sheer quackery to make negro suffrage the sovereign panacea of Southern ills. Whether it would have any good effect at all -- whether, in fact, it would not do far more harm than good -- is very doubtful. The worst evil of the South, as President JOHNSON clearly pointed out to the South Carolina delegates on Saturday, has been its class rule. A few thousand men in each State have owned most of the cultivated soil, have held most of the wealth, have had the control of the legislalation and civil administration, and have kept not only black men in physical bondage,but the great mass of the white men in almost total ignorance, and in almost complete servitude mental and moral. This oligarchic power has practically shut out all the republican influences which have so mightily elevated all other parts of the country. The great problem now is how to break up that power.

abstract: There will be several changes at the theatres to-night, which we proceed to note. At Wallack's the "Iron Mask" has been withdrawn, and "Oliver Twist" takes its place. The cast includes the names of Mr. J. W. WALLACK, Mr. E. L. DAVENPORT, Miss FANNY MORANT and Miss IONE BURKE. At the Winter Garden Miss HOSMER assumes the role of Pauline in BULWER'S play of the "Lady of Lyons."
lead_paragraph: There will be several changes at the theatres to-night, which we proceed to note. At Wallack's the "Iron Mask" has been withdrawn, and "Oliver Twist" takes its place. The cast includes the names of Mr. J. W. WALLACK, Mr. E. L. DAVENPORT, Miss FANNY MORANT and Miss IONE BURKE. At the Winter Garden Miss HOSMER assumes the role of Pauline in BULWER'S play of the "Lady of Lyons." At Niblo's, Miss MAGGIE MITCHELL plays Amry in the "Little Barefoot." At the Broadway, the "Pioneer Patriot," and at Barnum's Museum, the romantic drama of "Madelaine; or, The Belle of the Faubourg."

abstract: WIPING OUT THEIR ANCIENT GRUDGES. -- England and France, unless they are conspiring to throw dust in the eyes of the world, are engaged in the grateful task of wiping out the mutual grudges of former days. This is their jubilee year by the calendar. Fifty years have elapsed since Waterloo. And they seem to be eager to celebrate the epoch of peace in the presence of the world. Nothing can be more proper than this. They had a horse-race the other day at Epsom, at which the French horse, Gladiateur, was enabled, by good English jockeyship, to carry off the honors. There was on that occasion a blending of business, sport, science, happy political augury, peace, and politeness, such as is rarely witnessed in the progress of rival nations. Now -- in a few days -- they are to have a grand mutual naval demonstration, as announced by yesterday's European mail. All the French iron-clads are to sail round the British Islands, from John O'Great's to Land's End, taking an entirely peaceful survey of the small but valuable piece of property they contain. All the British iron-clads, at the same time, are to sail round the coast of France as far as there is water communication to go by. And then there is to be a general rendezvous of the fleets at Plymouth. Nothing can be more gratifying to the outside world than this. It shows that the empire means "peace" -- near at home, if it should happen to mean "war" in Mexico.
lead_paragraph: WIPING OUT THEIR ANCIENT GRUDGES. -- England and France, unless they are conspiring to throw dust in the eyes of the world, are engaged in the grateful task of wiping out the mutual grudges of former days. All the French iron-clads are to sail round the British Islands, from John O'Great's to Land's End, taking an entirely peaceful survey of the small but valuable piece of property they contain. All the British iron-clads, at the same time, are to sail round the coast of France as far as there is water communication to go by. And then there is to be a general rendezvous of the fleets at Plymouth. Nothing can be more gratifying to the outside world than this. It shows that the empire means "peace" -- near at home, if it should happen to mean "war" in Mexico.

abstract: Brougham, Lord; Friendly Advice of
snippet: Brougham, Lord; Friendly Advice of
lead_paragraph: FRIENDS INDEED. -- It is assuredly gratifying to the United States to be befriended by a man of such immense antiquity as Lord BROUGHAM; and as he is never weary -- weak though he be -- in giving us advice, it must be pleasing to him to see how well we get along under it, even though we generally totally disregard it. But we are pained to be compelled to say that his Lordship is an illustration of the sad fact that old age is apt to be characterized by weak memory as well as by physical infirmity. By the last mail, we have a speech of his, delivered at a banquet to the Prince of WAXES, in which he gives this country a great deal of advice as to how it shall comport itself hereafter, and he precedes it by these words: "If my voice could reach across the Atlantic, it would tell our kinsmen that their best friends, those who have been their advocates through good report and through bad report, now pray and beseech them" -- to do so and so. Now, for Lord BROUGHAM, with the memory of the speeches he has delivering concerning this country during the last four years in the House of Lords, before the Social Science Congress and elsewhere, to undertake to give us advice as one of our "best friends, who has been our advocate through good report and through bad report," is decidedly lively. We thought these speeches showed that he had been a friend and advocate of the slaveholders' Confederacy, an enemy of our Union, a laudator of the Southern rebels, a maligner of the Northern loyalists, a defender of JEFF. DAVIS, an assailant of President LINCOLN, and we had thought that his sympathies, even in his old age, had been so strong as to cause him to apologize for the system of slavery which in his earlier years he had struggled so hard to overthrow. Even if our memory were poor in this case, we have the reports of his speeches in our files; and they are sadly against his present assumption. But so goes a great part of mankind, Lords as well as Commons. We have been successful; we have triumphed; we have shown that power was on our side; and now they begin to see that justice also was with us, and to claim that they too were always our friends.

abstract: Our Returns, Errors, Statistics, >amp;c.; Kana???ha, S. S., Officers of
snippet: Our Returns, Errors, Statistics, >amp;c.; Kana???ha, S. S., Officers of
lead_paragraph: The end of the current fiscal year approaches, and this is a fitting occasion for us, as a nation, to review our condition, examine the system on which our financial matters are based and by which they are regulated, to confirm its good and correct its evil. The present system of internal revenue, by which the national taxes are assessed and collected, by which the wheels of the government are kept in running order, became a part of our economy on the 1st of July, 1862. Under its provisions, collectors, assessors and assistant officers were appointed, who were unable, however, to begin actual work until the 1st September, while no collections were made and returned until October of the same year. The necessities of the nation out of which grew this system of taxation need not be enumerated here; the well-remembered exigencies of the war for the Union, the support and maintenance of our armies and navies, and the thousand and one constant and tremendous calls for money, affording amplest ground for its adoption and enforcement.

abstract: On the West Coast of Ireland
snippet: On the West Coast of Ireland
lead_paragraph: PROFITING BY EXAMPLE. -- From a report taken from a Manchester paper, and published in yesterday's issue of the TIMES, it appears that some of the unemployed "Confederate" pirates, or ruffians profiting by their example, have taken to the trade of plundering British vessels on the West coast of Ireland. One coasting vessel was bravely attacked the other week by several boats' crews of the same class of enterprisers that have been preying upon American merchantmen for the last four years. The British skipper, unable to make any resistance, quietly allowed his vessel to be plundered, and only escaped with the craft, minus his cargo, by the accident of a favoring breeze. Here is a chance for LAIRD. These new "belligerents" are likely, in time, to be in a position, financially, to order an Alabama or two.

abstract: Order on Combinations of Employers of Negroes; Labor; Combinations of Employers; Gen. Hartsuff's Letter
snippet: Order on Combinations of Employers of Negroes; Labor; Combinations of Employers; Gen. Hartsuff's Letter
lead_paragraph: Maj.-Gen. HARTSUFF, commanding the District of Nottoway, Virginia, has prohibited meetings of planters and other combinations to regulate the wages of freedmen. There have been several meeting in that part of the State, at which the planters agreed to pay only $5 per month for first-class field hands, and only $2.50 a month for second class -- the men to find their own clothing, and all time lost by sickness to be deducted from their pay. They also seem to aim at such combinations as will make those rates general throughout the State, in the evident hope that starvation will compel the black men to accept the terms.

abstract: HOBGOBLINS IN BLUE FLANNEL. -- Every fine sunny afternoon the City Hall Park is made a playground by troops of urchins from the tenement houses of the Fourth and Sixth Wards, who want space for breathing and romping. Blissfully ignorant of better places for their sports, or not having the pennies wherewith to pay car-fare, those pleasure-hunters accept the shady walks and open spaces of the Park as a rich boon, indeed. But they are not permitted to enjoy themselves in peace. Their gleeful clamor too frequently disturbs the sensibilities of the highly-respectable, cool-clad, Panama-crowned guardians of public order, who look daggers and brandish their canes to overwhelm with awe and disperse the sportive throng. Indeed, our own observation makes it plain that neither boy nor girl out of wind from running in "tag," or other harmless and not less violent pastime, can stand to gaze admiringly, when catching breath, upon the well-known Statue, or lean for a swinging rest upon the iron chains around the grass-plots, without bringing upon themselves an outpouring of authoritative wrath. Might not some of this superfluous zeal be better devoted to checking the reckless driving over the street railroads which border the Park railings on Park-row?

abstract: President's Proclamation
snippet: President's Proclamation
lead_paragraph: Whereas, it has been the desire of the General Government of the United States to restore unrestricted commercial intercourse between and in the several States as soon as the same could be safely done in view of resistance to the authority of the United States by combinations of armed insurgents; and whereas, that desire has been shown in my proclamations of the 20th of April, 1865, the 13th of June, 1865, and the 23d of June, 1865; and whereas, it now seems expedient and proper to remove the restrictions upon internal, domestic and coastwise trade and commercial intercourse between and Within the States and Territories west of the Mississippi River; Now, therefore, be it known, that I, ANDREW JOHNSON, President of the United States, do hereby declare that all restrictions upon internal, domestic and coast-wise intercourse and trade, and upon the purchase and removal of products of States and parts of States and Territories heretofore declared in insurrection lying west of the Mississippi River, (excepting only those relating to property heretofore purchased by the agents, or captured by and surrendered to the forces of the United States, and to the transportation thereto or therein on private accounts of arms, ammunition, all articles from which ammunition is made, gray uniforms and gray cloth,) are annulled, and I do hereby direct that they be forthwith removed, and also that the commerce of such States and parts of States shall be conducted under the supervision of the regularly appointed officers of the customs, who shall receive any captured or abandoned property that may be turned over to them under the law by the military or naval forces of the United States, and dispose of the some in accordance With the instructions on the subject issued by the Secretary of the Treasury.

Arms and Material of War OnlyExcepted.A Grand Opportunity for Capital and Enterprise.The Conditions of Peace Restored Over All the Land. abstract: National Academy of Design, West Room
snippet: National Academy of Design, West Room
lead_paragraph: With the consideration of the contents of these two apartments the critic's task will happily come to a close. It has been a peculiarly ungracious one this year, and the pen is laid aside with an unusual sense of thankfulness. Many of the artists, we hear, feel aggrieved at the uniform severity of the remarks applied to their several productions. They seem to think that a conspiracy prevails among journalists to undermine the prosperity of the Academy, and destroy the reputation of its members. Such an idea is, of course, ridiculous; but for that very reason it has gained many friends. Nothing is too absurd for an artist to believe when his feelings are once touched. He cannot, for the life of him, understand that a total stranger may gaze at his picture, and honestly express an opinion of its merits. That stranger, he argues, must be a friend to some one, and therefore an enemy to him.

abstract: BURSTING OF A HUGE PETROLEUM BUBBLE. We have to-day a full report of the bursting of a Petroleum swindle of the most gigantic proportions. The principal operator turns out to be a retired army officer named Col. W.D. MANN, who, by the aid of a gorgeous prospectus, an easy address, and an extensive army acquaintance, has succeeded in possessing himself of many thousand dollars of other people's money, with nothing to show for it but a few office-stools, and sundry packages of stationery. Col. MANN's victims, we regret to say, include many well-known and worthy citizens.

abstract: THE MEAT QUESTION. -- We continue to hear of increasing dissatisfaction with the conduct of the dealers in meat, and the subject in rapidly becoming the universal topic in all family circles. The tendency to Ward Anti-Meal Clubs is growing stronger day by day, and it only depends upon the public to render the movement as successful as in the case of the butter extortion. Our wealthier families can in this matter do a philanthropic work. If they will be self-denying, or rather hygienically wise enough to stop meat purchases, the efforts of the poorer classes will be greatly aided. Will they not think of this?

lead_paragraph: On yesterday, Roundsman McDONNELL arrested JERESHAH SHEMHAN on a charge of felonious assault on several parties. It would seen that the accused, while in the drinking saloon at the cornor of Baxter and Canal streets, determine to gratify an old feeling of hatred which he entertained toward THOS MANNING, the barkeeper of the establishment. He accordingly rushed upon MANNING and stabbed him in the hand with a large knife, cutting him severaly. A few moments thereafter, SHERMAN stabbed DANIEL SULLIVAN, of No. 102 Bayard-street, in the thigh infflicting a very serious wound. A third party, while attempting to wrest the weapon from the [???] was also badly cut. The desperado was committed for trial in default of $1,000 bail on each charge.

abstract: Restrictions on, Removed by President
snippet: Restrictions on, Removed by President
lead_paragraph: COMMERCE FREE AT LAST. -- The President yesterday issued a proclamation removing all restrictions upon commerce and the ordinary operations of trade and travel in the States and Territories west of the Mississippi. This completes the restoration of peace so far as general business and intercourse are concerned over every portion of our country. The only exceptions are that private persons are not allowed to deal in arms, ammunition and material from which ammunition is made, rebel uniforms and gray cloth from which they are manufactured. Of course the military establishments in the West are still kept up, and military rule will be maintained until the people reinstate their civil governments; therefore it is for their best interests that they hasten the work of rehabilitation and relieve both themselves and the General Government from the necessity of the present system of martial control, with its arbitrary commanders and large garrisons of troops who are anxious to get home, and whose heavy cost the people are quite as anxious to save.

abstract: The Damascus arrived yesterday at Porte an Basque with one day's later news from Europe. The official correspondence between the governments of Great Britain and the United States, with relation to the assassination of President LINCOLN, has been published in England. "Historicus" writes a long letter to the London Times on the treatment due the rebel leaders. He contends that the United States Government has no right to deal with them except as with prisoners of war. The Paris Moniteur states that the rumored reinforcement of MAXIMILIAN with French troops is entirely incorrect. United States Five-Twenties have advanced to 69; other American securities have also slightly advanced. The negotiations for a commercial treaty between Austria and England have fallen through.

snippet: Destitution at the South; Destitution of Inhabitants
lead_paragraph: We have before us, as we write, a package of letters which furnish a truly terrible picture of the condition of the people of Northern Georgia. These letters come from the post and district commanders at Chattanooga, Atlanta and Macon, and represent a state of affairs which is appalling, while the representations possess an authority which allow no room for doubt as to the reality of the scenes they describe.

abstract: Fashion Course, Dexter vs. Stonewall Jackson
snippet: Fashion Course, Dexter vs. Stonewall Jackson
lead_paragraph: The long-anticipated great trooting match for $5,000 between the Long Island horse Derter and Stonewall Jackson, of Hartford, at three-mile heats, came off at the Fashion Course yesterday, as we stated it positively would, "rain or shine," the articles of agreement permitting of no postponement on account of the weather. Unfortunately the weather was the most unpropritions that could possibly be imagined, for the heavy rain-showers of the morning gradually increased in violence, until in the afternoon a perfect deluge visited the track and its vicinity, rendering the former a perfect slough of despond, fetlock deep in mud and slush; hence the time made may be regarded as wonderful under the circumstances, and there is little doubt that had the track been in good condition, those who laid their money so freely on Dutchman's famous time of 7:32 1/2 being beaten, would have had a good chance of winning it.

KELLOGG, of No. 367 West Twenty-third-street, and other gentlemen of good standing, appeared before Justice DODGE, at Jefferson Market Police Court, and preferred charges against WILLIAM D. MANN and DANIEL STRATTON, Jr., of No. 240 Broadway, alleging that by false pretences they had obtained subscriptions to the amount of $45,000 for certain shares in the capital stock of the United Service Petroleum and Mining Company, of New-York, on institution which they advertised as having $500,000 capital, in 100,000 shares of $5 each, and that the accused had obtained from several gentlemen whom they had induced to subscribe for this stock large sums of money in payment for such shares, all of which, as the complainant alleged, and as other gentlemen swore, are of merely nominal value, if not nearly worthless.

abstract: Brooklyn, Annual Meeting of Alumni
snippet: Brooklyn, Annual Meeting of Alumni
lead_paragraph: The Packer Institute of Brooklyn stands in the front rank of American institutions for female education. Its present limits, all too confined, are burdened with patronage, and from its cultured ranks go annually full classes of young women prepared for the graver duties and responsibilities of life. To the paternal solicitude and practiced direction of its able and scholarly chiefs, Professor CRITTENDEN and EATON, the success and prestige of the academy is mainly due. Hundreds of girls from Brooklyn and the entire land are on its rolls, and its fame in parallel with its influence.

abstract: The Lack of Inspiration in
snippet: The Lack of Inspiration in
lead_paragraph: The complete ending of the rebellion continues to puzzle those European pubilcists, who had so long ago determined the issue of the conflict by the logic of history, and an invincible army of precedents. It is yet all but impossible for them to realize the fact that a territory of so vast extent, of such exhaustless resources, with such variety in surface and geographical character, such strength of strategic position, fertility in supplies, facilities of intercommunication, numbering so large a population, occupied by a people possessing an extraordinary military and aristocratic basis of political institutions, on which the whole framework of society rested, could be reduced to submission by any possible fortune of war. The trouble with these foreign diviners was their failure to see that we were making, instead of following history, and creating, instead of accepting precedents.

abstract: MICHAEL CORNER was tried yesterday for robbery in the first degree. The indictment charged him with taking $35 by force and violence from the person of PATRICK BARRET, at a drinking saloon in Washington-street, on the 8th day of June inst. The evidence, however, only showed that the prisonor had committed an assault on the complainant. He was convicted of this clience, and sentenced to pay a fine of $50, to stand committed until paid.

abstract: Question; the; Railroads, Condition of
snippet: Question; the; Railroads, Condition of
lead_paragraph: In all the States of the South, the most active measures are in progress for putting the railroads in running order. Every few days we hoar of the repair or opening of some new line that has been ruined during the war. The old route to Richmond by way of Aquia Creek has just been reopened, and work on the Orange and Alexandria road is well under way. The roads south of Richmond as far as Charlotte and Wilmington, in North Carolina, are in bad condition, and do not make much better time than our city street-cars, but some repairs and now stock will set things to right again. It is of high importance that the great line known as the Virginia and East Tennessee Railroad should be put in running order speedily and in the best style. Our repeated raids during the war on this road, and destruction of costly bridges, have made its repair a question of time and expense; but on such a route neither energy nor capital will be wanting. In South Carolina, the line from Charleston to the State capital has been repaired, and is kept running, but we believe the other roads in the State are still unrepaired. The Georgia system of railroads is very excellent and simple -- consisting of three great lines crossing the State from East to West, with various connections and branches. The Southernmost of these, the Atlantic and Gulf railroad, has been restored to the Board of Directors, who at once inaugurated measures for the restoration of the damaged portion of the line; and as but a small portion of it was irreparably damaged, it is announced that trains will be running at a very early period. The Georgia Central Railroad also has been restored to the control of its directors, and a large force of laborers are now engaged in repairing it. The railroad system of Alabama -- what there is of a system -- never has assumed any importance; but that part of the Memphis and Chattanooga road which crosses the State is in some sort of order. The two great lines which run through the State of Mississippi, north and south, require but a small amount of repair.
headline: {'main': 'The Southern Railroads Their Present Condition.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'The Southern Railroads Their Present Condition.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

SOUTHARE of Richmond, Mo.; also Zeta, $450, by GILBERT VAN DERWENEEM of Georgetown, D.C.; also Mystic, $9,500, by T.P. MORGAN of Washington; also Western World, by H.R. HAZELHURST of Baltimore; side-wheel Steamer Bal, $55,000.
lead_paragraph: At Washington, June 24, the following vessels were sold: Side-wheel steamer Baltimore, $16,000, purchased bb THOMAS CLYDE, Philadelphia; propeller Watch, $2,600, by ROBERT LEAR of Baltimore; also Teaser, $2,500, by JAMES BIGLER of New-York; also Resolute, $6,300, by T.J. SOUTHARE of Richmond, Mo.; also Zeta, $450, by GILBERT VAN DERWENEEM of Georgetown, D.C.; also Mystic, $9,500, by T.P. MORGAN of Washington; also Western World, by H.R. HAZELHURST of Baltimore; side-wheel Steamer Bal, $55,000. The engines of this vessel are said to be worth $75,000. Several tugs and other vessels were offered, but withdrawn, their being either no bidders, or the bids not approaching the valuation. All these vessels are said to have belonged to the Potomac Flotilla. Three weeks from the 24th there will be another sale.

abstract: FRANCE AND MEXICO -- SIGNIFICANT NEWS. -- We have news pertaining to Mexico, direct from Paris, this morning -- official news, moreover, which can hardly be regarded otherwise than as of the highest importance. The Moniteur, it appears, has been instructed by the Emperor's Government to announce that no more French troops are to be sent to the reinforcement of MAXIMILIAN. The significance of this decision is made apparent, when it is remembered that the prime object of M. ELOIN's extraordinary mission from Mexico to Paris was to present the urgent need in which the France-Mexican army stands of reinforcements. It is clear, if the present report from Paris is correct, that the Emperor of the French is about to divest himself, as soon as possible, of the responsibility of maintaining the present state of things in Mexico. And every day the reasons for his coming to this conclusion grow manifestly stronger. His further patronage of the Latin race in America would be clearly thrown away.

abstract: CITY RAILROAD CASUALTIES. On Sunday evening PETER RYAN, who was riding up town on a car attached to dummy engine No. 3 of the Second-avenue Railroad line, endeavored to jump from the rear platform when at the corner of Seventy-seventh-street. RYAN stumbled and fell, one of the wheels of the car passing over one of his feet and crushing it fearfully.
lead_paragraph: CITY RAILROAD CASUALTIES. -- On Sunday evening PETER RYAN, who was riding up town on a car attached to dummy engine No. 3 of the Second-avenue Railroad line, endeavored to jump from the rear platform when at the corner of Seventy-seventh-street. RYAN stumbled and fell, one of the wheels of the car passing over one of his feet and crushing it fearfully. The sufferer, who resides at No. 30 East Twenty-seventh-street, was immediately conveyed to Bellevue Hospital for surgical treatment.....PETER MASTERSON, Jr., a lad of 17, while attempting to jump on a Seventh-avenue car at the corner of Fifty-seventh-street, was knocked down by the horses of a car coming at full speed from the opposite direction. He fell, and sustained severe injuries. He was conveyed to his residence at the corner of Fifty-seventh-street and Seventh-avenue.

abstract: THE PRICE OF MILK. -- On July 30, of last year, the New-York milkmen decided, owing to the severe drouth, the withered leaves, the burning fields, the scarcity of berries, vegetables, &c., to raise milk to ten cents a quart. On that day gold stood at 250! Those who then met as the Washington Hotel may as well have another meeting, for it does not seem as if either rain or green stuff is now or likely to be scarce. The war is over, gentlemen, and you may as well recognize the fact; or shall we tell the public how much a quart you pay for the pure article?

abstract: Cost of Rebellion to the South Pecuniarily; Pecuniary Loss by the Rebellion; the Price of
snippet: Cost of Rebellion to the South Pecuniarily; Pecuniary Loss by the Rebellion; the Price of
lead_paragraph: It is doubtful whether the North, as a section, is much worse off to-day pecuniarily than if the rebellion had never occurred. Its industry, though checked for a time by the first outbreak, soon became more active than ever, so that probably no four years in our history has yielded, on the whole, ampler products. Our agriculture has scarcely been diminished, and has realized higher prices. Our manufactures have suffered largely in certain branches, but have gained as much in other directions; and even that portion which has met with loss has secured an incidental protection, through the high tariff created by the war, which will soon far more than compensate for any post damage. Our commerce, that is to say our carrying trade on the high seas, has indeed sustained immense injury, directly and indirectly, through the Southern blockade and the rebel privateers. But on the other hand an immense benefit has accrued, through the war, to our railroads, which have never been so full of business or so profitable as during these four years. It is true that the war has brought, in different ways, great losses to some people; but it has brought as large gains to as many others. It is true, too, that a public debt of some three thousand millions has been entailed upon the country, the greater portion of which will have to be borne by the North. But this debt is almost entirely due to the people of the North, and they will have the large interest upon it while it runs, and the benefit of the principal when it is paid. It is true that hundreds of thousands of able-bodied men have been abstracted, by the war, from industrial pursuits; but this very absence has enhanced the price of labor, which has benefited the millions of laborers left behind, and has also greatly stimulated immigration from abroad. The active operations of the war having been confined almost entirely to the South; the North has lost almost nothing by its ravages. Surveying the matter broadly, then, we may say that the North, as a section, is to-day little, if at all, out of pocket, in consequence of the war.

abstract: RIOT AT A FIREMEN's PIC-NIC -- A HOTEL PARTIALLY GUTTED -- ARREST OF SOME OF THE RIOTERS. -- Early yesterday morning the members of Engine No. 8, of the Eastern District, accompanied by their friends and invited guests, went on a pic-nic excursion to Glen Cove. During the afternoon detached parties visited the orchards and private residences in the neighborhood of their festivities and helped themselves, without leave, to cherries and whatever else came in their way. Those who remonstrated with them were generally maltreated, and the excursionists had everything their own way. The village constable was powerless before so formidable a host. Not satisfied with these petty depredations a large party made an onslaught on a hotel near the landing and partially gutted it. Not satisfied with helping themselves to the liquors and cigars of the proprietor, they ruthlessly destroyed the furniture and fixtures to some extent, and also smashed the windows and shutters of the building. After leaving Glen Cove, the party landed at foot of South Fifth-street, E.D., about 6 o'clock last evening. Shortly after landing some of them entered the liquor store of Mr. ROGERS, corner of South Fifth and First streets, and there commenced quarrelling among themselves. In a very short space of time a general melee ensued, and but for the prompt arrival on the spot of Sergeant SPENCE, with Officers TRAVIS, KRONE and MCQUADE, of the Forty-fifth Precinct, a serious riot would have ensued, there having been several hundred roughs congregated eager for a "free fight." The officers succeeded in dispersing the crowd, and arrested and locked up the following parties: Patrick Devlin, Charles Hubbs, Wm. Kennedy and John Binkes.

abstract: Shipments of Produce Increasing
snippet: Shipments of Produce Increasing
lead_paragraph: -- Very considerable purchases of cotton, flour, wheat, tobacco, tallow and other leading articles of domestic produce have been made in this market within a few days, in execution of foreign orders, or for shipment to foreign markets. These purchases have added materially to the supply of commercial bills of sterling exchange, and led to a reduction of the price of such bills to a rate which precludes the possibility of any immediate profitable shipments of specie. They thus tend directly to check the export demand for gold, and depress the premium, to the embarrassment and chagrin of the speculators for a rise, who really operate against the credit and currency of the country. They also promise increased employment to the shipping interests of the port, which greatly need such relief. Obviously, we are a thriving people.

abstract: An important order from Major-Gen. TERRY, commanding the Department of Virginia, appears in the Richmond papers. It relates to the status of the negroes, and lays down rules for the government of military officers and courts with reference to the colored population. It declares those laws heretofore existing in the State, which were predicated on the slavery of the negro, to be now obsolete, the slaves having become free; and it directs all military officers and all military courts to disregard such laws, together with the regulations growing out of them, and to treat them as null and void. In short, the negro is not to be called upon for a pass merely because he is a negro; nor, if found unemployed, be treated as a vagrant merely because of his color. Another clause of the order directs that until the civil tribunals of the State are reestablished, and while criminal justice shall continue to be administered by the military courts, these latter courts shall receive the evidence of colored persons as competent testimony in all matters, whether touching white persons or black.

abstract: Steward vs. Phenix Ins. Co., Policy Warrant
snippet: Steward vs. Phenix Ins. Co., Policy Warrant
lead_paragraph: John S. Steward vs. The Phoenix Insurance Company of Brooklyn. -- The plaintiff brought this action on a policy of insurance issued by the defendants on the 14th of May, 1860, whereby they promised and agreed to insure against loss or damage by fire to the extent fo $2,000. The property insured was a flouring-mill situated at Mackford. Marquette County, Wisconsin, and konwn as "Mackford's Mills." The building was four stories in height, built of stone, and the machinery propelled by water. On the 20th of May, 1860, six days after the insurance was effected, it took fire from some cause unexplained, and was entirely destroyed. Due notice was given to the company -- defendants in the action, who refused to pay, and thereupon plaintiff brought a suit. The complaint is in the usual form in such cases. The defendant's answer set up: 1. That by the policy and survey it appeared that plaintiff warranted that the supply of water for the mill was sufficient, with proper arrangements to supply the mill so that the machinery might be run constantly. Second, That plaintiff warranted the cash value of the property insured, including building and machinery, to be worth $10,000, when in fact it was not worth $4,000. Third, That plaintiff warranted the average value of wheat on store in the mill to lie $4,000, whereas the truth was it did not amount to half that sum. Fourth, That plaintiff warranted that the property insured was encumbered by mortgage to one J.P. Yelverton, whereas at the date of the policy there was no such encumbrance. Fifth. That plaintiff warranted that the above-named mortgagee had an insurance in the Peoples' Insurance Company, to the extent of $3,000, whereas there was, no such insurance; and 6th, that plaintiff warranted that he had no reason to believe that the properly in question was in any danger of being burned by means of incendiaries, whereas, in fact, the plaintiff well knew at the time that there existed in that community a growing hostility to the mill, and to the manner in which it was managed; that there had been many angry disputes arising from the fact that much of the water used by the mill overflowed the lands lying adjacent, and which were owned by a large number of persons.

abstract: Trade, Resumption of to Europe; Securities; Exporting to Europe; Railroad Cars, Communication between
snippet: Trade, Resumption of to Europe; Securities; Exporting to Europe; Railroad Cars, Communication between
lead_paragraph: The legitimate shipments of cotton from this country to Europe have, after four years of interruption, been resumed. Shipping has been engaged in this port alone, within a few days, for the transportation of eight thousand bales to Liverpool, and vessels are also being laden at other Northern ports. But of course the great outflow will be from the seaports of the South, into which the staple has been flowing from the interior in large volume since the removal of restrictions upon its purchase, sale and export. Ships and orders have been dispatched to Charleston, Savannah and elsewhere on the Atlantic coast, and to Mobile, New-Orleans and Galveston, on the Gulf coast, where cargoes are awaiting them. The amounts at these ports are now large, and are accumulating with unexpected rapidity.

abstract: Charles A. Allen was tried for an attempt at burglary, the indictment charging him with breaking into the premises of Miss Anna Richardson, No. 203 Church-street, with an intent to steal her property. The complainant, who was a fashionably-dressed lady of color, testified that the prisoner broke into her apartments in the night-time, and was in the act of gathering up her wearing apparel to take it off, when witness awoke and asked him what he was doing. He then dropped the things and went out. At the conclusion of complainant's testimony, the prisoner, by advice of his counsel, pleaded guilty to a petty larceny, and was sent to the Penitentiary for six months.

abstract: On Negro Suffrage and New-York Times; Suffrage; Tribune on N. Y. TIMES' Opinion of
snippet: On Negro Suffrage and New-York Times; Suffrage; Tribune on N. Y. TIMES' Opinion of
lead_paragraph: The Tribune announces that "the TIMES at last takes ground decidedly against the extension of suffrage to blacks; and it then proceeds to discourse at length on the general subject. The Tribune's sermon may be good enough, but its text is a fabrication. The TIMES has not taken ground against extending the "suffrage to blacks." On the contrary, it has taken ground, as the Tribune very well knows, in favor of extending the suffrage to blacks, whenever and wherever it might wisely and safely be extended to whites, under the same circumstances. We have repeatedly declared that the war has broken down that wall of distinction, as to legal rights and political privileges, which slavery had maintained so long; that hereafter whites and blacks would stand equals before the law; that the mere fact of a difference in color had ceased to create a difference in the rights and franchises of different men, and that henceforth the tendency of public sentiment and public action would be, to permit a black man to vote whenever, under the same conditions, the white man was permitted to do so. That is now, as it always has been, the position of the TIMES on the extension of suffrage to blacks.
headline: {'main': 'Negro Suffrage Again.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Negro Suffrage Again.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Collegiate and Polytechnic Institute, An. Com.
snippet: Collegiate and Polytechnic Institute, An. Com.
lead_paragraph: Mr. OLIVER C. PUTNAM, of No. 140 Fifth-avenue, having entered complaint against MICHAEL CORCORAN, for violating the Act of March 28, 1865, forbidding the posting of any handbill on any curbstone, &c., Justice DODGE granted a warrant, and intrusted the same to Officer HUBBERT, of the Broadway police. CORCORAN having been arrested and committed, his employer appeared to bail him from prison, but was unable to give anything but household furniture as security, and this the Justice declined to accept. He appeared not to know that any offence had been committed, and said that the bill-posters generally are not aware that they are liable to arrest for pasting any handbill, whether indecent or otherwise, on any curb-handbill, edifice, wall, rock or other place where special permission has not been given.

abstract: ALLEGED PERJURY ARISING OUT OF A LANDLORD AND TENANT CASE BEFORE JUSTICE WALSH. -- CHARLES DONOHUE, Esq., of the firm of BEBEE & DONOHUE, brought proceedings against JOHN P. WILKINSON, before Justice MICHAEL WALSH, for the recovery of the premises No. 12 Degraw-street. Mr. DONOHUE testified that on the 29th day of March, 1859, he let the promises to WILKINSON on a lease, witnessed by D.R. STEELE, of No. 32 Remsen-street -- who has a desk in the office of DONOHUE -- that there was due to him $1,000 for three years' rent. WILKINSON was put on the stand, and swore that he never signed the lease; did not know DONOHUE and was never in his office; STEELE swore that he saw WILKINSON sign the lease and identified him in Court. R.W. ANDREWS, Esq., a lawyer, also swore that he saw WILKINSON in DONOHUE's office; J.C. BLACHLEY, as agent of DONOHUE, swore that he served WILKINSON with the regular notice to pay the rent by leaving it with a person of mature age, and that he (WILKINSON) afterward acknowledged to him that he had received the notice. The justice gave the case to the jury who rendered a verdict in favor of the landlord. Whereupon plaintiff made the necessary affidavit of willful and corrupt perjury against WILKINSON who was committed to jail for examination.
lead_paragraph: ALLEGED PERJURY ARISING OUT OF A LANDLORD AND TENANT CASE BEFORE JUSTICE WALSH. -- CHARLES DONOHUE, Esq., of the firm of BEBEE & DONOHUE, brought proceedings against JOHN P. abstract: Pope, The, and Victor Emanuel's Concessions
snippet: Pope, The, and Victor Emanuel's Concessions
lead_paragraph: -- We have further, to-day, by the Cuba, bearing upon the ecclesiastical question so long at issue between the Pope and the King of Italy. Most of the vacant Sees are to be filled by their former occupants, who are not to be required to take an oath of allegiance to the King. The vacancies caused by the refusal of certain Bishops to return to their ecclesiastical duties under the Government of Italy are to be filled by others. And from this latter class, we presume, the King will be entitled to exact an oath of fidelity. If not, we can hardly see what his title as "King of Italy" practically comes to. The old Bishops, who served under the Bourbons, may possibly have some claim to be relieved from the duty of taking an oath of fealty to the Savoy dynasty. But the new incumbents cannot well claim any such exemption, unless they claim likewise to found for Italy an imperium in imperio. The King, certainly, has made concessions liberal to a degree.

abstract: We have news to-day by the Cuba respecting the alleged reinforcements for MAXIMILIAN's army, which puts altogether a different complexion upon the Moniteur's statement, referred to in yesterday's TIMES. The Moniteur, it seems, does not deny that more French troops are to be sent to Mexico, but it explains that they are to take the place of those whose term of service is about to expire, so that their will be no actual increase of the French force. We do not know that this explanation will be held to be at all satisfactory. It is one which will have to satisfy the French press and the French Chambers, But we doubt exceedingly if it is one that will bear close looking-into. This new levy for MAXIMILIAN's service follows suspiciously close upon the appearance of M. ELOIN, in Paris, with an urgent demand for more men, and more help generally, to save the new Empire from falling incontinently to pieces. M. ELOIN's request is granted, and a demand for explanations by foreign powers is anticipated by the official journal, which adroitly puts it that a certain number of the troops now in service in Mexico have completed their term, and are to be relieved. We shall see.

abstract: The  British official mind, as we learn from the London Daily News, received last night, is still manfully struggling with the question of enabling passengers in railway carriages to communicate with the guards. Nothing, however, like a solution of this perplexing problem has yet been reached; and, judging from the tone of our London cotemporary, the case shows less hopeful progress than could be wished. abstract: The Superior Court, at General Term, yesterday rendered an important decision in the case of WILKINS vs. EARLE. The latter was proprietor of Earle's Hotel, in this city, and some time ago the plaintiff, WILKINS, put up there, as a transient guest, having with him the sum of $25,000. Seeing the usual hotel notices posted in his room, in regard to depositing money and valuables in the office safe, WILKINS took it there and delivered it to the clerk. When ho called for it a a day or two after, it was gone, and he has never obtained any portion of it. He thereupon brought an action to recover the whole amount of Mr. EARLE. The case was tried before a jury, who found that plaintiff was entitled to recover $25,000. Defendant took an appeal to the General Term, and that court has now reduced the amount to $1,000, on the ground that the last-named sum was a reasonable amount for traveling expenses. The case is regarded as important, inasmuch as it defines the rights and liabilities of inn-keepers, under the statute of this State.

abstract: Women, Lack of, in Nevada and Colorado
snippet: Women, Lack of, in Nevada and Colorado
lead_paragraph: -There is a great lack of women in the new mining territories of the Far West. Nearly the entire population of Nevada and Colorado are of the male sex, and now that they have got houses and cities, and wealth of silver and gold, they are anxious beyond measure for the society and help of women. Neither wives nor servants can be had, though both have unequaled opportunities. The Rocky Mountain News, of the 14th instant, in very plaintive on the subject, and is also practical. It declares that women will find in that country the "Utopia of their dreams." If husbands are desired, they can be had at leisure; and if they wish to engage in household employment, they can quickly acquire fortune. In the populous Territory of Colorado, we are told, "there is scarce one woman where six could and would be profitably employed if they could be obtained. Wages here for common household duties are from $30 to $50 per month, including board. This makes wages, at the present rates of boarding, from eighty to one hundred dollars per month."

An answer was there after, on Feb. 27, filed by the claimants. On March 3 a note of issue was filed, and a notice of trial for the 14th was served by the libelant's proctor, but with the words interlined in the notice" that this notice is served conditionally, to wit, that the claimants file and serve their answer and pay the cost of exceptions."

abstract: County War Expenditure and Supervisors
snippet: County War Expenditure and Supervisors
lead_paragraph: At a meeting of the Board of Supervisors yesterday, a resolution was offered requesting the Comptroller to report to the board the aggregate amount of money spent by the county in carrying on the war. Supervisor PURDY warmly opposed the motion, on the ground that it was an imputation on the character of Mr. ORISON BLUNT. Supervisor ELY rejoined, saying that no reflection upon Mr. BLUNT's character was intended, and that a large proportion of the money expended by the county for war purposes did not go through Mr. BLUNT's hands at all, but was paid to the families of volunteers through the Common Council.

abstract: Wilkins vs. Earle Hotel Proprietors; Liability
snippet: Wilkins vs. Earle Hotel Proprietors; Liability
lead_paragraph: Wm.T. Wilkins vs. Wm.H. Earle. -- The defendant in this case was proprietor of Earle's Hotel, in this city, and the plaintiff was a transient guest at his house. The customary notices in regard to the deposit of money and valuables in the office safe induced the plaintiff to deposit in the safe of Earle's Hotel a package containing twenty-five thousand dollars. A few days afterward he demanded this package, but it could not be found, and, in fact, Mr. Wilkins never did recover back any portions of it. What actually became of it was not fully ascertained, but an employee of the house was suspected of having stolen the money, plaintiff then commenced this action to recover the full amount of twenty-five thousand dollars from Mr. Earle, basing his proceeding on the State law, which makes the inn-keeper liable in such cases. On the trial before the lower branch of this court two issues were submitted to the jury:

abstract: The steamship Cuba, from Liverpool on the 17th, via Queenstown on the 18th, arrived at this port yesterday, bringing two days' later intelligence than that received by the Damascus. The most important item of news is the continued advance of American securities. Five-twenties had reached 69 3/4, with every prospect of a further advance. The Moniteur states that French troops are to be sent to Mexico only in sufficient numbers to make good the deficiencies occasioned by those returning to France. The Spanish Government is busy arresting persons concerned in the late conspiracy. No appeal in their behalf has yet appeared in any of the London papers. VICTOR EMANUEL has concluded an agreement with the Pope regarding the status of bishops in the Kingdom of Italy. The Prussian Chambers have been prorogued by Herr BISMARCK, who reproached them bitterly for their demeanor toward the government.

Early yesterday morning Chief Detective YOUNG and his subordinates, MACDOUGALL, BENNETT, GOLDEN, and others, made a descent upon the Carson House, in Crosbystreet, near East Houston, and there seized a large quantity of very shabbily excerted spurious banknotes, representing upward of $10,000, in twos, threes, fives, and tens, on the New-York Exchange Bank, of this city, Bank of Kinderhook, the Bank of Fishkill, the Merchants' Bank of New-Bedford, the...
lead_paragraph: SEIZURE AT THE CARSON HOUSE. -- Early yesterday morning Chief Detective YOUNG and his subordinates, MACDOUGALL, BENNETT, GOLDEN, and others, made a descent upon the Carson House, in Crosbystreet, near East Houston, and there seized a large quantity of very shabbily excerted spurious banknotes, representing upward of $10,000, in twos, threes, fives, and tens, on the New-York Exchange Bank, of this city, Bank of Kinderhook, the Bank of Fishkill, the Merchants' Bank of New-Bedford, the Commercial Bank of Burlington, Vt., the Bank of Lowville, Sugar River Bank, of New-Hampshire, the New-York County Bank, the People's Bank of K[???]y, Mass., and the State Bank of Camden, N.J. No persons was arrested. Information concerning the existence of this counterfeit stuff was communicated to Sergt. YOUNG by Capt. RHODES, of Brooklyn, and the seizure was made within a quarter of a mile of the Fourteenth Ward Police Station.

abstract: Within a week or ten days, there has been a decided improvement in the financial position and prospects of the nation. Europe has again renewed its demand for our government goldbearing bonds, as well as for our flour, grain, provisions, cotton, tobacco and petroleum, thus giving foreign exchange a most desirable turn in our favor, and relieving us of any urgent necessity of making any further considerable shipments of specie.

abstract: There would be some reason for the high price of meat if gold were at 250 as at this time last year, or if there had been a drought parching up all the vegetation as there had been then. The whole cause of the present complaints is, that a number of speculators are trying to train the public into paying permanent exorbitant rates for meat. They think that if they can hold out against popular indignation for a while, people will get used to extortion. But this is a mistake. Prices must come down, and the sooner these speculators succumb the better. We do not intend to let the subject alone just yet. Meanwhile every family that lets the butcher severely alone acts simply with common sense. Diminished consumption was never yet known to fail in reducing the price of any article of large supply, nor will it fail in the case of meat.

Meanwhile every family that lets the butcher severely alone acts simply with common sense. Diminished consumption was never yet known to fail in reducing the price of any article of large supply, nor will it fail in the case of meat.

abstract: -- The Mayor of Jersey City having vetoed the resolution of the Common Council, appropriating $1,000 for the celebration of the Fourth of July, there is not at present any prospect of a celebration, unless the matter should be taken in hand by the citizens. The Board of Aldermen not yet having effected an organization, Mayor CLEVELAND takes the ground that  they cannot legally transact any business.
lead_paragraph: -- The Mayor of Jersey City having vetoed the resolution of the Common Council, appropriating $1,000 for the celebration of the Fourth of July, there is not at present any prospect of a celebration, unless the matter should be taken in hand by the citizens. The Board of Aldermen not yet having effected an organization, Mayor CLEVELAND takes the ground that they cannot legally transact any business.

abstract: There have for some time been supplies of three-cent pieces in the hands of brokers, but they do not seem to get into general use. The process of withdrawing the filthy scraps of paper should be hastened, or before long they will be composed solely of dirt and air. Cannot the Treasury Department see to this matter? The smallest relief would be most thankfully received.
