abstract: CITY MISSION:--On Tuesday evening, the City Mission held a meeting in the Dutch Reformed Church, Sixth-avenue, Mr. WETMORE presiding.
lead_paragraph: CITY MISSION: -- On Tuesday evening, the City Mission held a meeting in the Dutch Reformed Church, Sixth-avenue, Mr. WETMORE presiding. Missionaries to the Germans, and missionaries in the Seventh, Eighth, Eleventh, Eighteenth and Twentieth Wards, related facts showing the benefit of systematic visitation, of mission stations, of tracts, of the temperance pledge, and of practical Christian sympathy and kindness in various ways. Rev. ISAAC S. HARTLEY said we look upon these missionaries as the right-hand men of the pastors. We regard their work as simply indispensable in such a city as this. We love the City Mission for its practical efficiency, and for its Christian union; and we wish every one to contribute to its support. Some can give prayer; some can give time; some can give, money; and a few, perhaps, can give all three; but every one can do something. The tabled results were up to the usual average.

abstract: -- The only States of the Union in which slavery now has an existence are Kentucky and Delaware, and the institution is in a frightfully moribund condition in each of them. In Delaware it is an absurdity, in its character as well as in its magnitude, and the people ought to abolish what there is of it, if only for the name of the thing. In Kentucky nearly all the able-bodied blacks have done service in our army, and are therefore free; and the fact that these men have done military service makes all their wives and children free. So that what remains of negro slavery in Old Kentucky is the merest skeleton, disjointed, lifeless, hopeless, with no present value and no prospect in the future. The action of the States on the Constitutional Amendment will wipe out the institution clean and in favor of this amendment we expoo[???] that both Kentucky and Delaware will vote, though both of them have once rejected it.
lead_paragraph: -- The only States of the Union in which slavery now has an existence are Kentucky and Delaware, and the institution is in a frightfully moribund condition in each of them. In Kentucky nearly all the able-bodied blacks have done service in our army, and are therefore free; and the fact that these men have done military service makes all their wives and children free. So that what remains of negro slavery in Old Kentucky is the merest skeleton, disjointed, lifeless, hopeless, with no present value and no prospect in the future. The action of the States on the Constitutional Amendment will wipe out the institution clean and in favor of this amendment we expoo[???] that both Kentucky and Delaware will vote, though both of them have once rejected it.

abstract: The First New-York (Lincoln) Cavalry arrived yesterday morning, and proceeded to the State Agency Rooms, Eight Regiment Armory, where a splendid dinner was prepared for the command by Col. COLYER, the New-York State Agent. The regiment being expected on Tuesday night, liberal provision was made for their reception at the agency. T[???] had prepared an elegant dinner for them. [???] the tables with fruits and flowers, and Col. COLYER [???] Robertson's Band of thirty pieces waiting at the [???]tery at 5 o'clock. But this gallant regiment -- one of the pets of New-York -- did not arrive, owing to some delay in the trains. A regiment of cavalry was also in waiting to escort the command from the Battery, but that part of the programme was omitted when the regiment did finally arrive.

abstract: Delegates, and Success of their Mission
snippet: Delegates, and Success of their Mission
lead_paragraph: Two of the Canada delegates. (Messrs. GALT and BROWN,) sent to England to negotiate with the Home Government on the subject of defence and kindred questions, arrived here by the Cuba. They represent their mission as an entire success. The money necessary for the deepening and widening of their canals from Lachine to Lake Erie, for constructing the Intercolonial Railroad, as well as for building a line of fortifications on the frontier, is to be found by the Parent Government. That means, we presume, that the Province is to borrow all that it wants for these commercial and military works on the indorsement of the Imperial Exchequer -- which is equivalent to a loan from the Central Government.

abstract: ANOTHER BOGUS PETROLEUM COMPANY, -- A firm styling themselves H.S. ROE & CO. have, it appears been doing quite a large business lately by representing themselves as the "First National Petroleum Company." The company is a genuine one, and soon after it was organized ROE & CO. copied ad its advertisements and circulars, with the additional announcement that all remittances for stock must be addressed to them. It is alleged that they even issued false certificates of stock, some of which fell into the hands of the genuine company. It is supposed that ROE & CO. have pocketed some $40,000 by the operation. Mr. HALL, the District-Attorney, has procured the arrest of AUSTIN H. FULLER, a clerk to the firm of ROE & CO. ROE himself is missing.

abstract: Commencement
snippet: Commencement
lead_paragraph: THE ANNUAL COMMENCEMENT OF THE PARKER COLLEGIATE INSTITUTE. -- The twentieth annual commencement exercises of the Parker Collegiate Institute took place on Tuesday evening at the Academy in Joralemon-street. There was, as usual on those occasions, a large attendance, and great interest was manifested in the proceedings. The young lady graduates occupied the seats in front of the platform. They were dressed in white and presented a very interesting appearance. A.A. Low, Esq., presided. The order of exercises consisted of the anthem "Before Jehovah's Awful Throne;" prayer; chant, "Gloria in Excelsis;" introductory poem, by Miss ABBY MATHER; "Irving and his Friends," composed by Miss CHARLOTTE DELANO; "Only a Candle," by Miss ELLEN Ludington. "Eureka," by Miss Mary E. Steele. Chorus, "We are two Merry Minstrels." "Night Brings out the Stars," by Miss Harriet Parker. "Returned Volunteers," a poem, by Miss Mary Greene. "Spheres," by Miss Mary Bradshaw. "Cut Devotees," by Miss Mary Fullerton. Chorus, "Joy! Joy! Freedom to-day!" "Classic Ballads," Miss Pauline Hendrickson. "Silent Forces," Miss Sarah B. Cleaver. "The Moral Significance of the Ideal," Miss Susan E. Steele. "Our National Future," Miss Charlotte Johnson. Chorus, "Glory be to God on High."

abstract: Jersey City; American Drug Mills, >amp;c., $100,000
snippet: Jersey City; American Drug Mills, >amp;c., $100,000
lead_paragraph: Shortly after 10 o'clock yesterday forenoon, a fire broke out on the fourth floor of the American Drug Mills, located on the corner of Washington and Morgan streets, Jersey City. The flames spread rapidly, and in less than twenty minutes the entire building -- a five-story brick structure -- was enveloped in flames, and the firemen were unable to save the building The workmen in the upper stories barely escaped with their lives, several of them descending to the ground by means of the lightning-rod. There are also rumors that two or three persons lost their lives, but as far as can be ascertained the rumor is without foundation. The building was owned by D.S. GREGORY, Jr., & Co., whose loss will probably reach $70,000, said to be covered by insurance in New-York companies.
headline: {'main': 'Extensive Conflagration in Jersey City-- Several Manufactories Burned Down --Loss About One Hundred Thousand Dollars.', 'kicker': None, 'content_kicker': None, 'print_headline': 'Extensive Conflagration in Jersey City-- Several Manufactories Burned Down --Loss About One Hundred Thousand Dollars.', 'name': None, 'seo': None, 'sub': None}

abstract: Argyle, Duke of, and Earl Dalhousie on American Rebellion; Slavery Exists Only in Kentucky and Delaware; Dalhousie, Earl, and Duke of Argyle, on Cause of Rebellion; London Times on American War and Argyle-Dalhousie Controversy
snippet: Argyle, Duke of, and Earl Dalhousie on American Rebellion; Slavery Exists Only in Kentucky and Delaware; Dalhousie, Earl, and Duke of Argyle, on Cause of Rebellion; London Times on American War and Argyle-Dalhousie Controversy
lead_paragraph: There is an amicable controversy between these distinguished noblemen, about the CAUSE of our rebellion, the former holding that it resulted from political ambitions, while the latter attributes it to slavery. The Earl is in part -- the Duke wholly right. Without slavery there would have been no rebellion. Slavery was the fulcrum that moved the South to rebellion. It was believed and relied upon by political chiefs to delude the masses into rebellion. To this end, as the late Col. BENTON warned us, the Calhoun school of politicians had been, for thirty years, educating the people of the slave States.

abstract: Philadelphia; Bussier's Storehouse; $100,000
snippet: Philadelphia; Bussier's Storehouse; $100,000
lead_paragraph: The store house of Messrs. J.B. BUSSIER & CO., No. 108 and 110 South Delaware-avenue, Philadelphia, was destroyed by fire on Tuesday. From $5,000 to $10,000 worth of fire works, $25,000 worth of canned goods, and an immense stock of foreign fruits, the whole valued at $100,000, were destroyed. Among the incidents of the fire that attracted much attention was the daring and novel mode adopted by a sailor to get into the burning building through a third-story window. A ladder belonging to one of the companies had been placed against the house, but it was too far from the window for any one to get in. The sailor caught hold of one of the rungs of the ladder, and then swung himself until his feet reached the window. He continued this swinging motion until the sash was broken out. He then made one swing, at the same time letting go the rung of the ladder, and he lit upon his feet inside of the window.

abstract: Yesterday was a grand gala day at BARNUM's. The attractions, in addition to the billion more or less of curiosities, consisted of the debuit of two enormous whales from the coast of Labrador, the reappearance of the popular favorite C.W. CLARKE and the benefit of Mr. LEVICK. The whales are truly immense and well worth a "first-rate notice." Caged in two large boxes they have been a fortnight en route, and cost the modest sum of $7,000 la[???]d at the door of the great showman. After t[???] labor they were safely deposited in the great tank on the second floor, where surrounded by hundreds of curious ga[???]rs, including the bushy-headed Circassian, the ad[???]ean bounty from Connecticut, the polar curiosity from Nova Scotia, Mr. HERD, the manager, and sundry newspaper men. As the water was turned on we were curious to observe their movements. There being no movements, we were somewhat disappointed. After a little, the smaller  and masculine one being aroused to a sense of duty by a proctracted shower-bath of salt-water, raised his fin in token of recognition; soon thereafter he began to roll, then to blow, and finally to wriggle desperately. When the tank was well filled he aware lustily about it. He beat the briny deep with his scaly tail. He roared and spouted as if he knew the Fourth of July was coming, and he demonstrated his entire success. The female was more decorous and less demonstrative; she is also much larger and will probably remain so for a few weeks. The eclat of the whalisian demonstration was genuine and unmistakable, the reappearance of Mr. CLARKE was hearty, prolonged and uproarious, and the benefit of Mr. LEVICK, we trust was satisfactory.

abstract: -Neither the Executive of the State nor the Mayor of the City have followed the advice of the Common Council, and recommended holiday-making by proclamation on the 3d of July as well as on the 4th. If these officials intended compliance with the wishes of the Common Council in this respect, doubtless the public would have been informed of the fact before now. It is fair to presume, therefore, that Gov. FENTON and Mayor GUNTHER hold the same opinions as to the impropriety of a two-days' festival as we have expressed regarding the matter. Their silence can be construed in no other way. As the case now stands, the Common Council bid fair to "colebrate," Monday in their own fashion, and in a very exclusive manner.

abstract: I think I must tell the children and their mammas of a wonderful servant we have had for about two months past. She is not Irish, or German, or African, but that exceedingly rare bird, a genuine American servant--handy, clever and cute.
lead_paragraph: I think I must tell the children and their mammas of a wonderful servant we have had for about two months past. She is not Irish, or German, or African, but that exceedingly rare bird, a genuine American servant -- handy, clever and cute. Her virtues are manifold. In the first place, she is wonderfully quiet -- goes silently and steadily about her work -- doing all that is required of her "with neatness and dispatch." She is good-tempered -- is never "on the rampage" -- never insolent -- never unkind to children. She has no followers -- never goes off without warning: never wastes, never blunders, don't drink, and don't break the eighth commandment.

abstract: -- It is not merely the French people en masse who are opposed to the further interference of France in Mexican affairs; it is not simply the opposition members of the Legislative body, led by such men as THIERS and JULES FAVRE, who urge the withdrawal of the troops; it is not only the Prince NAPOLEON who takes ground against the Emperor's Mexican policy; it is not merely the Liberal press of Paris that exposes the folly of the expedition; but the Emperor himself is decidedly uneasy about the matter, as appears by the recent speech of his mouthpiece in the Corps Legislatif, M. ROUHER, who expressed his anxiety to find a "solution of the difficulty favorable to the interests of Mexico and honorable to France." It is felt that it would hardly be the thing to hastily withdraw the French army from Mexico just at this moment when the war in the United States is closed. It is felt that it would not only be a severe animadversion upon the Emperor's policy in having sent his troops there at all, but that it would look like a precipitate retreat before the menacing power of the American Union. It is desirable that some good excuse be found for the withdrawal, and that it be conducted in a dignified manner. M. ROUHER expressed the hope that the future would speedily furnish a proper solution of the difficulty; and there is good reason to believe that he is correct

ROUHER, who expressed his anxiety to find a "solution of the difficulty favorable to the interests of Mexico and honorable to France." It is felt that it would hardly be the thing to hastily withdraw the French army from Mexico just at this moment when the war in the United States is closed. It is felt that it would not only be a severe animadversion upon the Emperor's policy in having sent his troops there at all, but that it would look like a precipitate retreat before the menacing power of the American Union. It is desirable that some good excuse be found for the withdrawal, and that it be conducted in a dignified manner. M. abstract: Punishment and Prevention of
snippet: Punishment and Prevention of
lead_paragraph: The operations of the Court of General Sessions for the June term are worthy of some notice, illustrating, as they do, the growth of crime in this city, and the stringent discipline now required to preserve the property and lives of our citizens. Owing to the crowded state of the City Prison and the heavy criminal calendar, the presiding Judge, Recorder HOFFMAN, and Assistant District Attorney HUTCHINGS, the prosecuting officer for the term, resolved to open the court at ten in the morning, and sit each day, until every case was disposed of. The result has been that 133 cases were tried in the month of June. Of these criminals, four were acquitted; in twelve instances the prosecution was abandoned for want of evidence, and there were 116 convictions for high grades of crime. Forty-eight of the convicts were sent to the State Prison, and the remainder were sentenced to the Penitentiary and City Prison. Ninety-five were found guilty of crimes against property, and twenty-one of crimes against the person.

abstract: -- Somebody yesterday undertook to ride or drive a horse from Boston to Portland, 116 miles, between sunrise and sunset, the motive being to win a thousand dollars. The horse got within six miles of the goal considerably within the time, when he fell and immediately expired. The job is, therefore, unfinished, and the true way to complete it would be to harness the men concerned in the bet to the carcass of the horse and make them drag it back toward Boston until each and every one of the brutal bipeds shared the fate of the poor animal so wantonly murdered.

abstract: On yesterday afternoon, HERMAN HANSON, of No. 104 [???]th-street, a returned soldier, appeared before Justice SHANDLEY and preferred a complaint against Mrs. HELEN GRATGAN, of No. 74 West Houston-street, s[???]ng forth that on the 11th of March last he forwarded $440 to HELEN by ADAMS Express, with instructions to deposit the money in the bank, to his credit, and keep the bank-book until his return. On his arrival in New-York, however, he discovered that HELEN had appropriated the funds to her personal use, minus the sum of $20, which she handed him. Officer LAW, of the ESSEX Market Police-court, thereupon arrested the accused and the magistrate committed her for examination.

abstract: Empire vs. Mutual; St. George vs. Philadelphia; Fashion Course, Harry Clay vs. Ethan Allen
snippet: Empire vs. Mutual; St. George vs. Philadelphia; Fashion Course, Harry Clay vs. Ethan Allen
lead_paragraph: Last week the champion nine of the Atlantic Club was pitted against the new nine of one of the prominent New-York clubs, who have entered the lists as contestants in the championship matches this season, the strong point of the nine in question -- the Empires of New-York -- being their medium-pace pitcher MARTIN, than whom no better exists in the country. On that occasion the Atlantics found that the difficulty of punishing MARTIN's pitching was rather greater than they or their friends had anticipated. The result being that they were put out for a smaller score in the first five innings of the game, than their full nine had been in any previous match since 1860, when the Excelsior placed them hors du combat for a total of four runs only in a full game. Yesterday the Mutuals put in an appearance in a match for the first time this season, their opponents being the self same Empire nine who had so ably acquitted themselves against the champion Atlantics the week previous. Of course the desire to witness the play of the most prominent of the opponents of the champions, in their first game of the season, and also to see how far the Mutuals would succeed in batting MARTIN's pitching, led to an immense gathering of spectators at the Elysian Fields yesterday, every ferry-boat from 1 to 3 P.M. being crowded, and every car and carriage filled to its utmost capacity. A very large amount of money was invested on the result. The Mutuals, of course, being the favorities, but not at large odds.

abstract: Commencement
snippet: Commencement
lead_paragraph: The spacious auditorium of the Academy of Music was filled to overflowing by a vast audience yesterday morning, consisting almost wholly of ladies, to witness the commencement exercises of the one hundred and eleventh anniversary of Columbia College. The stage was filled by a large concourse of gentlemen, among whom we noticed Rev. Dr. Isaac Ferris, Chancellor New-York University; Peter Cooper, Esq., Dr. Rutherford, Rev. Dr. Martin, C.E. Davies, LL.D., H.M. Pierce, President Rutger's Institute; Dr. Lieber. Gen. Cullum, Superintendent West Point Academy, Col. Conklin and others. Prof. Barnard of Columbia College, presided.

abstract: Among the exceptions in the general annuity of President JOHNSON were those rebels who had practiced the horrible cruelties upon our prisoners in the South. Nothing in the history of ancient or modern war was ever published of a more appalling character than the documents, official and unofficial, relating to this subject. Nothing more terrible wan ever suffered by mortals than our soldiers were subjected to at Andersonville, Millen, Florence, Salisbury, Belle Isle and in Libby Prison. The facts are all established; the guilty parties are known; some of them are in our hinds and others within our reach. So far as we have observed, there are none of this class in the lists of those who have been pardoned by President JOHNSON. We think that justice and the memory of our martyrs, and good faith to our soldiers, and the honor of our country, and the credit of human nature, demand that some of these unparalleled culprits be brought to trial and punishment.

abstract: Jones', Thomas D., Bust of President Lincoln; Jones' Thomas D. Bust of him
snippet: Jones', Thomas D., Bust of President Lincoln; Jones' Thomas D. Bust of him
lead_paragraph: A very fine bust of the late President LINCOLN has been executed by THOS. D. JONES, formerly of this city, but more recently a resident of Cincinnati, and of Springfield, Ill. It was made during Mr. LINCOLN's lifetime, and presents with great fidelity his features and expression. It was modeled from sittings, and is pronounced by those, best qualified to judge a very excellent likeness. It was made during the six weeks immediately preceding the President's departure from home for Washington, in 1861.

abstract: Returns, Facts and Statistics
snippet: Returns, Facts and Statistics
lead_paragraph: No one fact in the working of the complicated Internal Revenue system stands more prominent than the intelligent cooperation of the masses of the people. Did the governmental revenue depend solely on the patriotism and good faith of the poorer classes of the community, there would be little need of assessors and indeed it is but fair to assume that had the wording of the original law been clear and explicit, very much of the present conflict of opinion and prospective litigation might have been avoided. During the first years of the law's operation, when intensest patriotism stirred the majority of Northern hearts, when the entire people urged a vigorous prosecution of the war, there was little need of official prompting at external pushing, but it is natural now, when the war is closed, when people look for a return to the channels of trade, when necessity demands a rigid scrutiny of every expenditure, that men should look carefully to their legal rights, being willing to pay to the government all that it is entitled to, but being equally tenacious of their own interests. Judge LEWIS, the commissioner, has been taxed with labors which few men could bear. He was embarrassed by the lack of perspicuity in the law, pestered by continual protests from the people, hampered by the conflict between the wording and the spirit of the act, and compelled to decide day in and day out questions of vast importance to the mercantile community, pending the consideration of which piles of documents from every quarter of the country accumulated on his desk. That honest men should be discouraged and rogues emboldened by such a state of affairs, is not to be wondered at. But this was in the earlier days, when system was yet to be brought out, and regularity enforced.

abstract: Even if it be true that Vice-President STEPHENS, and Gen. JOE JOHNSTON, and other prominent Southern men, have lately proclaimed their continued adhesion to the doctrines of State sovereignty and secession, we are not troubled about it.
lead_paragraph: Even if it be true that Vice-President STEPHENS, and Gen. JOE JOHNSTON, and other prominent Southern men, have lately proclaimed their continued adhesion to the doctrines of State sovereignty and secession, we are not troubled about it. Thousands of men in the South will continue to hold these doctrines as long as they live, and there will be believers in them in the next generation. War, in its action and issues, may forcibly change institutions and overthrow theories in their practical development; but it does not always eradicate from the minds of these who have been defeated by it, the theoretical convictions of a life-time -- convictions which they may have received in youth an which have been strengthened by the experiences of their maturity. Even to this day there are people in Great Britain who uphold the claims of the Stuart dynasty, and the memory of Prince CHARLEY lives in song and story. So in France, there are believers in in the divine right of the BOURBONS rule; and the Ex-King of Naples has aristocratic adherents near the throne of VICTOR EMANUEL. We know no way of altering these things. They are inherent in human nature -- some human natures. And so long as these theoretical protestants acknowledge the laws, and recognize practically the established institutions and authorities, their private fancies are of very little moment. The few eccentric believers in State sovereignty in this country will be of no more account than the eccentric adherents of the Stuarts in Great Britain.

abstract: Hibernia, Ocean Steamship of Anchor Line to Europe
snippet: Hibernia, Ocean Steamship of Anchor Line to Europe
lead_paragraph: The new steamship Hibernia, the latest addition to the Anchor Line, will sail for Glasgow. Liverpool and the Irish ports at 2 P.M. on Saturday, July 1, from Pier No. 2, North River, under the guidance of her experienced commander, Capt. JAMES CRAIG.The Hibernia makes the third vessel in the service of the company to this port, and others are now building and nearly completed. The Hibernia was launched in the month of February, 1865, from the yard of Messrs. A. STEVENS & CO., Glasgow, and is a well-built and and well-fitted specimen of iron shipbuilding and naval architecture. Alike the other vessels of this line, the Hibernia was built under the inspection of LLOYDS' surveyors, where she has received the highest classification. Strength, speed, with an excellent model, are combined in the construction of this steamship, while great care has been taken that the passengers, old and young, of either sex, should have such accommodations that neither health nor enjoyment should be sacrificed.

abstract: Suffrage; The Real State of the Case
snippet: Suffrage; The Real State of the Case
lead_paragraph: It is the habit of some of the thick-andthin advocates of negro suffrage, to ascribe all opposition to the old oppressive spirit against the race, and to make themselves out the special champions of the wronged and the defenceless. Doubtless they sincerely think this, but it is a vain fancy. As for ourselves, we are as anxious as any that full justice should be done to the liberated slaves. We abhor as heartily as any the system of which they were the victims. We admit as fully as any that this nation, which for three generations sacrificed them, body and soul, to its security and its interests, should now in turn be willing to sacrifice much for their security and their interests. We recognize as clearly as any that the Divine justice which President LINCOLN, in his last inaugural, declared was visiting the nation for its crimes toward a helpless race, will yet, sooner or later, inevitably revisit it, if it does not henceforth treat that race righteously.

snippet: Bay Ridge and Battery, New-York, New Ferry; Guavesend, L. I.; Falstaff's Barn; Incendiary; $1,600
lead_paragraph: FIRE ON LONG ISLAND. -- The barn of Mr. PETER FALSTAFF, in the town of Gravesend, was destroyed by fire on Sunday last, together with three horses, one cow, several wagons and farming utensils, in all valued at $1,600, upon which there was no insurance. The premises are owned by WM. ROBERT WATERS, whose loss is about $400, insured in the Hudson River Insurance Company. The fire, it if believed, was the work of an incendiary. Mr. FALSTAFF having lost all he had, the neighboring farmers have since collected some $600 for his relief.

lead_paragraph: Among the innumerable dangers which have threatened this country in the eyes of foreign writers, was the danger from ambitious Generals. If our officers succeeded in this war, they were not only going to clamor for other wars, but were sure to overthrow the public liberties, and proclaim themselves the masters of the nation.

abstract: THE NEW-YORK SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES is published THIS MORNING, and may be had at the counter of the publication office in wrappers ready for mailing. Price FIVE CENTS. In addition to the latest intelligence by telegraph up to the moment of going to press, there will be found in the current number detailed reports of the Trial of the assassins. Also, all official orders, reports and documents, and the latest and fullest Washington news, European news, with graphic letters from our correspondents in London and Paris, giving the tone of public feeling abroad, is made a special and permanent feature. In addition to Editorials on all the current topics of the day, the SEMI-WEEKLY TIMES has a page of carefully prepared commercial matter, giving the latest financial news and market reports; items of agricultural and domestic interest, compiled from sources many of which are otherwise inaccessible to the American reader; and marriages and deaths of the week.

abstract: the Riders of Horses to Death
snippet: the Riders of Horses to Death
lead_paragraph: The man who undertook to drive his horse from Boston to Portland is named BRACKETT. The man who rode or drove the horse was FRANK BRIGGS. Let these two names be remembered; years hence people will recollect or read that a horse was deliberately driven to death by certain Bostonians, and naturally enough they will wish to know who these men were. They were Mr. BRACKETT, (will the Boston papers give us his first name?) the owner, and FRANK BRIGGS, the rider or driver. Let all humane people remember the beautiful Boston B's -- BRACKETT and BRIGGS.

lead_paragraph: RESCUED FROM DROWNING. -- A sailor named WM. abstract: Dry Goods Exchange, Opening of; Collegiate and Polytechnic Institute Exhibition; Fordham, Commencement
snippet: Dry Goods Exchange, Opening of; Collegiate and Polytechnic Institute Exhibition; Fordham, Commencement
lead_paragraph: The exercises of the graduating class in the senior department of the Girls' Grammar School, in Twelfth-street, near Broadway, were held yesterday afternoon, in the presence of a large and deeply interested audience of ladies and gentlemen. The occasion added another to the uninterrupted series of perfect successes which have distinguished the public festivities of this excellent establishment. No pains were spared either by Miss WADLEIGH, the faithful Principal of the school, and her able assistant teachers, or by the young ladies themselves, to render the "commencement" attractive to the visitors. Entering the school-room, the eye was at once caught by the tasteful and elaborate decorations. The ceiling was almost hidden by gracefully-intersecting festoons of evergreens, pendant from side to side, and magnificent bouquets were arranged in front of the platform in stands and baskets, in numbers sufficient for a first-class horticultural exhibition. In addition to the floral brightness, there was also enough radiance and airiness of toilette on the part of the graduates, their schoolmates and the ladies present -- not to mention the sparkling eyes and happy faces -- to fairly bewilder the majority of the masculine portion of the audience, who are very apt to lose their equilibrium in the face of beauty and sweetness preserved in such a compact form. It is almost cruel to subject the sterner sex to such a bewildering ordeal. Following was the

abstract: -The leaders of the late Democratic party in the Border States seem to be pretty much all afloat; they are laboring under the disadvantage of being very dead, but not having been buried, and wanting the necessary coin to pay ferriage in old Charon's Salt River boat, they are roaming up and down the shores of Oblivion in most disconsolate mood, wondering where they shall go. One of them, Hon. ROBERT MALLORY, of Louisville, late representative in Congress, made a speech on Saturday evening last. He had a small audience of personal friends, to whom he talked for an hour in broad but very mild denunciation of the administration, all it had done and all it proposed to do. He made no specific points; did not undertake to expose any special abuse; but grumbled with and at everything. He had no plan, no better way, no platform -- no nothing; he was evidently quite adrift, without rudder or compass, without purpose or destination, and with only enough recollection of the past to remember that it is the one solitary inalienable privilege of the minority to be dissatisfied, and especially the duty of the Democratic party to abuse the other side, their men, their principles, their purposes and their acts on all occasions, and under all circumstances. The few Kentuckians who came to listen to the voice of wisdom speaking from the lips of experience, heard only the common-place growling of a politician behind the age; one who insists on shutting his eyes at midday, and declaring that it is pitch dark.

abstract: In a suit tried yesterday before Mr. Justice CLERKE, in the Supreme Court Circuit, against the New-York and Erie Railway, as common carriers, the court allowed the plaintiff to withdraw a juror on a motion to dismiss the plaintiff's complaint, for one reason among others, that there was no revenue stamps attached to one of the most important papers connected with the action. In making this disposition of the case Justice CLERKE took occasion to say, that even if defendant's counsel had not raised the objection, he, the Judge, should have felt bound to take notice judicially of the absence of the requisite stamp. It was his determination, in all proceedings before him, not to allow the United States Government to be defrauded of its lawful revenue through any fault of his. There were other points which would be fatal to the plaintiff, but this was sufficient to warrant the court in permitting the withdrawal of a juror, so that the case might be speedily presented for adjudication without prejudice to the rights and equities of the parties.

abstract: Common Council; Record of the President's Funeral
snippet: Common Council; Record of the President's Funeral
lead_paragraph: -We had the satisfaction, some time since, of commending a decision of Mr. Mayor GUNTHER on a proposal of the members of the Common Council to engage in a joint literary enterprise. The proposed undertaking was intended to illustrate in a literary and artistic way the labors of one of the Council committees in connection with the obsequies of the late President. This work, however well conceived, His Honor considered to be uncalled for, on account of the expense, and the limited number of paying subscribers, or non-paying readers that might be attracted by its publication. In that view we had the happiness of agreeing, and in these columns expression was given to the hope that the Mayor himself might be asked to edit, in his usual felicitous style, a record of the events referred to, which might form a popular edition, so to speak, of the intended heavier and more exhaustive work of the Council. These hopes have been frustrated. The Council having once entered the literary arena in a body, refuse to be driven therefrom by any such rival as the Chief Executive of the city. The work is to proceed. Twenty-five thousand copies are ordered. And the trade may expect an early supply.

abstract: New-York 4???th (Mozart) Regiment, Return, History and Officers
snippet: New-York 4???th (Mozart) Regiment, Return, History and Officers
lead_paragraph: The Fortieth (Mozart) New-York regiment arrived in this city yesterday morning, at an early hour, and almost immediately proceeded by steamer for Hart's Island, where the command will be mustered out. It is a great pity that some little time was not allowed the Fortieth to enjoy the hospitalities of the New-York State Agency, at the Eighth Regiment Arsenal, where a fine breakfast was laid out, and everything that could be desired in the way of water, towels, &c., for the men to refresh themselves. As it was, the old regiment had scarcely a glimpse of the city from which it had been absent over four years.

abstract: Brace, C. L. Letters on European Social Reforms. London--Its Organization
snippet: Brace, C. L. Letters on European Social Reforms. London--Its Organization
lead_paragraph: If one were to search about through England for the modern "chivalry" of the kingdom, one would not find it among the titled and lordly, though among these are many "true knights," but especially in that great vigorous middle class from which the best of modern England comes. In this powerful class may be found men who have consecrated themselves to a life-long crusade against the great enemies of modern society, who are fighting a heroic battle each day against ignorance and prejudice and vice and disease and death. It is these men of the true Anglo-Saxon pluck and pertinacity, never disheartened by defeat or disaster, never wearied out by the marvelous stupidity of the public they are seeking to benefit, who have covered England with the remarkable sanitary improvements and institutions of education and reform, which have so marked English progress during the last ten years. It is they who are under-draining damp and pestiferous cities, removing cess-pools -- those nests of disease -- banking up rivers, carrying off the vile sewerage, till it becomes a new source of fertility; destroying the old and picturesque houses, which are such homes of fever and crime; widening the narrow lanes, where guilt and misery have so long crouched. They struggle with the "death-rate" and the "average of crime," as the old knights of chivalry struggled with the robbers and oppressors of their time. They do incessant battle against the dragons of ignorance and vice, as their forefathers did against the dragons of the wilderness and the infidel Paynim. It is they who provide the poor with pure water; who continually press legislation on a dull and unwilling public, which shall lessen the frightful evils of overcrowding. They analyze the food of the masses, and the air which they breathe; they show the poison which lie in wait for the health of the ignorant, they battle against the nuisances of the large cities, and relieve their thronged streets by the underground railroads. They erect baths and abattoirs, and urinals, and model lodging-houses; they build the mighty sewers which carry off the drainage of towns to fertilize new fields, instead of poisoning the rivers; they erect schools and reformatories and refuges without number; they have their missions for the women, for the men, for the boys and the girls; they care for the thieves, for the beggars, the outcast women, and the little "Arabs of the street." And in smaller palaces, they can point you out the trophies of victory. In Salisbury, they show you the death-rate reduced from 27 in 1,000 before 1856 to 20 in 1,000 since that year, by a wise and efficient system of drainage; and in the close from 20 in 1,000 to 14, which is one of the lowest rates in England.

abstract: The visitor to Saratoga, this year, will find, on stepping from the cars at the depot, his first view startling as well as saddening. A mass of blackened and unsightly ruins covers the spot on which the grand old pile of the world-renowned United States Hotel stood, its spacious open portal, a few feet from where the cars stop, inviting the newly-come to enter, through shaded and picturesque avenues, and enjoy its unstinted hospitalities.
lead_paragraph: SARATOGA, Monday, June 26, 1865.

snippet: On Military Service and Social Discipline; Military Service a Social Training School
lead_paragraph: The Americans have long labored under the accusation of a certain lawlessness of character, a want of sufficient respect for authority, which showed itself in domestic life and general manners, as well as in the public relations of the citizen.

abstract: the Possibility of Under United States Government; Purposeless Speech of; Question of Martial Law Long Gone by; Question; the; Cor. TIMES
snippet: the Possibility of Under United States Government; Purposeless Speech of; Question of Martial Law Long Gone by; Question; the; Cor. TIMES
lead_paragraph: The speech Of REVERDY JOHNSON against, and that of Judge BINGHAM in defence of the jurisdiction of the military tribunal now trying the assassins of the President, were both very able; but so far as they related to the general question, whether this government possesses, during war, unrestricted war powers, they were out of time. That question belongs to the past. It has been settled. It is no more now a subject for practical discussion, either in the forum or on the stump, than the question whether the government has the right to make war in the defence of its authority against State authority. The right of the war itself, and the right to use every sovereign war power in its prosecution, are no longer theories to be bandied pro and con. They have taken the shape of fixed facts. They are consolidated, as ultimate, absolute powers, into the very polity of the republic, there to remain forever.

abstract: on Overthrowing Governments and Executing Davis
snippet: on Overthrowing Governments and Executing Davis
lead_paragraph: It does not seem at all wonderful to us when we see the aristocracy, the Tories of Europe, urging strenuously that JEFF. DAVIS has done nothing calling for punishment. But we must admit to some surprise at the tone with which the Liberals of Europe speak on the subject, and we cannot but think that they do not rightly consider the just bearings of the case.

abstract: Philadelphia vs. St. George; Empire vs. Mutual, at Hoboken; House of Refuge; Annual Visit of Judiciary
snippet: Philadelphia vs. St. George; Empire vs. Mutual, at Hoboken; House of Refuge; Annual Visit of Judiciary
lead_paragraph: The match between the above clubs which was commended on the St. George's Club ground at Hoboken on Wednesday, was resumed on Thursday at 11:15, St. George going in to the bat for their second innings. From the commencement of the innings up to the time when the call of "dinner" put a temporary stop to the proceedings, a very fine display of cricket was shown, especially by Messrs. GIBBES, BAMBRIDGE, H. WRIGHT, TERRANCE and GORDON, whose aggregate scores in the innings amounted to 127 runs, of which GIBBES scored 51 in his usual fine style; GORDON 24 by capital free battin; HARRY WRIGHT 22 ditto; TERRANCE 19, and BAMBRIDGE 11, the balance of the eleven retiring for less than average scores. The bowling was good in two or three instances, especially that of GEORGE WRIGHT, but as a general thing it was not up to the high mark shown in the match of the previous week. The Philadelphians missed the valuable services of GEORGE NEWHALL and BARCLAY in this match both in batting and bowling. The second innings of the St. George terminated with a score of 152, which with that of the first innings made their grand total 271. At 3:10 the Philadelphians went into their second innings to get 197 to win. This they failed to do, their last wicket in their second innings falling for 52 runs only, of which GEORGE WRIGHT made 24 in good cricket style and EVANS 7, the others not even getting average scores. The following is the score of the match:

abstract: Buckhardt vs. New-York and Erie Co.; Carriers' Agreements; Griffiths vs. Prince; Contract and Sale
snippet: Buckhardt vs. New-York and Erie Co.; Carriers' Agreements; Griffiths vs. Prince; Contract and Sale
lead_paragraph: Gustavus A. Buckhardt vs. The New-York & Erie Railway Company. -- This action was brought by the plaintiff, a German, who, by the way, understands very little of the English language, for the purpose of recovering the sum of about $1,119, which is the alleged value of property destroyed under the following circumstances: Sometime about the middle of November, 1864, the plaintiff undertook to convey himself and his effects from Cincinnati, Ohio, to the City of New-York, by way of the Little Miami and the New-York and Erie Railway. His effects consisted of boxes and packages, containing furniture and wearing apparel. The testimony went to show that, at Cincinnati, Ohio, the goods in question were committed to the care of the common carriers, to be by them transported to New-York. At that time there was a written or printed agreement, and entered into between the plaintiff and the railroad company, that ran its trains to connect with the Erie Railroad, in which agreement it was particularly specified that none of the proprietors of the lines would be liable for the loss or damage by fire of any goods while in transitu. This agreement or contract had no United States revenue stamp upon it, as is required by law. The property in question was safely transported to Dunkirk, the western terminus of the New-York and Erie Railway, and by the latter company it was put aboard their cars, bound to New-York the place of destination. On the route the goods in question took fire, and were destroyed at a station known as Callicoon. The defendants allege that the fire occurred without any negligence or want of care on their part. The written or printed contract, made at Cincinnati, between the plaintiff and the common carriers, was set forth in the complaint, but it did not appear that the clause therein relating to the non-liability of the defendants in case plaintiff's goods were destroyed by fire, was soon by the plaintiff, or that he knew anything about it. This stipulation, or proviso, was printed in small letters in the middle of a printed and formal paper.

snippet: O. Meade Loses $13,000; New-York, Murphy, Dr., Colored Physician, Killed by Calhoun
lead_paragraph: Mr. OGDEN MEADE, a young Memphian merchant, who appears to have roved considerably since he attained his majority, recently fell in with a gang of gamesters in the West, and was induced to hazard $13,200, which his father had loaned him to add to the capital of Messrs. FILLICKS, MEADE & Co., of Memphis, grocers. He lost, of course. Feeling anxious to recover the money and conceal his error from his parents, young MEADE followed to this city the gamesters with whom he had played, and, being unable to obtain satisfaction otherwise, he resolved to appeal to the law. He thereupon appeared before Justice DOWLING and made the following affidavit:

abstract: Brooklyn; Third District
snippet: Brooklyn; Third District
lead_paragraph: The good and bad people of this city of Gotham are accustomed to look down upon their little sister Brooklyn, to consider her of small account, and to talk rather patronizingly of the "City of Churches," as though she were but in her swaddling-clothes, and as yet engaged only in the pursuit of clergymen and their teachings. A glance at the list herewith published, of the incomes in one district exceeding $12,000, will convince any impartial judge that a people who can show such figures must be able also to demonstrate an amount of mercantile shrewdness and mental culture by no means despicable or limited. The fact is, that if Brooklyn was not so near New-York, it would hold a far higher position than that she now occupies, and she must be content to offset the few disadvantages thrust upon her by the incalculable benefits derivable from the proximity of the metropolis of the Western continent.

abstract: In July, 1860, beef ranged, at retail, from 6 cents a pound for chuck cuts to 18 cents for the choicest porter-house steak; corned from 5 cents to 12 cents. Mutton, 13 cents, for legs, down to 5 cents for shoulders. Veal was 9 to 12 cents for hind-quarters, down to 5 cents for shoulders. Pork was 12 to 13 cents; sausages, 12 cents. Your butcher will say that meat is higher now, owing to -- what? The price of gold? But, you will say, gold is only 138 cents in paper for a gold dollar, so that cannot be the reason. The bad season? No, nor that either; the weather and crops were never so fine. The army wants the meat in the field? Why, the boys have come home. Short supply of cattle? There were considerably more cattle in market this week than were wanted or sold. No, there is no reason but that avaricious speculators put up the price, and you grumble and submit to be fleeced.

abstract: Shipping Wanted South
snippet: Shipping Wanted South
lead_paragraph: We received last night our first files of papers from Texas since the restoration of the national authority in that State. The first article in the Galveston Bulletin of the 13th inst. makes complaint of the want of a sufficient quantity of shipping in that port to transport to New-Orleans and New-York the cotton now there, and which is arriving from the interior. The quantity of the staple west of the Mississippi is estimated at about a million of bales, a large portion of which will at once seek the market, in exchange principally for supplies of manufactured goods. We have already directed attention to the importance of the American shipping interest taking prompt advantage of the present opportunity to obtain control of the carrying trade of the Southern States. We shall have a brisk competition, but the advantages are on our side if we adopt a liberal policy.

abstract: -The question at issue between the butchers and the public is becoming very clear and distinct. It amounts to whether, in time of great agricultural plenty, with grass more abundant than for years, with gold at half the price it was a year ago, and with a general reduction in articles of food and wearing apparel, this city shall be forced, against all reason and common sense, to say nothing of honesty, to pay a perfectly ridiculous price for its meat. There can be no hesitation as to what the ultimate result will be, and every person who abstains from meat hastens it. There are many great hotels whose proprietors can help in the matter; their customers, at all events, will find on the various bills of fare plenty of substitutes for meat. Let those who dine at restaurants follow in the same track. Somebody is bound to be hurt if the public chooses.
